DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded sharply against the yen in Tokyo today, and share prices closed higher for the fifth consecutive trading day. The dollar closed at 131.75 yen, up 1.20 yen from Monday's close of 130.55 yen. After opening at 131.87 yen, it ranged between 131.30 yen and 132.07 yen. The dollar had plunged a total of 3.50 yen in the previous two trading days. Spot trading today amounted to $9.47 billion, down slightly from Monday's 9.55 billion dollars. A trader at a major European bank said the yen suffered partly from a rumor that the Bank of Japan might lower the official discount rate, the interest it charges for loans to commercial banks. Lower interest rates tend to make a currency less attractive to investors. Continuing tensions in the Middle East also helped push the dollar higher, he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The yen is basically weakening, especially toward the end of the year, when there is a substantial increase in demand for the dollar from travelers and trading houses,'' said Chizuko Satsukawa, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. More than a million Japanese are expected to travel overseas for the New Year holidays. Most of them buy dollars for their trips. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,956.97 points, up 172.30 points or 0.72 percent. The Nikkei average now has gained 2,094.36 points in five trading days. Volume on the first section was estimated at 530 million shares, up from 436.147 million Monday. Share prices rose Tuesday after an initial fall from profit-taking, brokers said. Investment trusts established recently by major brokerage houses were active buyers, they said. Market players feel the Nikkei average has bottomed out and is now moving up to the 25,000-point level, a level it has not hit since Oct. 31, said Toshinao Nakamura of Nomura Securities. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.95 points as of 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST) from Monday's 87.72-point close. Their yield fell to 7.070 percent from 7.120 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Man Hides with Dog in Kuwait; Another Kills Intruder with Machete
DOC.TEXT: A Florida man trapped in Kuwait by Iraqi invaders hid for 23 days with his dog in a tiny crawl space, eating only uncooked spaghetti. A New Mexico man defended his hide-out with a machete, killing an intruder. A freed Baltimore man told of watching a Kuwaiti man gunned down by a platoon of Iraqi soldiers. The family of a Missouri man who endured four months in hiding plans to burn his passport so he can't leave the United States again. Tales of captivity ranged from those who cringed inside darkened apartments in terror to a hostage held in a Kuwaiti royal palace who ate off fine china and drank from gold-rimmed crystal goblets. Tom Kreuzman of Holiday, Fla., hid with his Yorkshire terrier, Chu Chu, in an apartment air-conditioning duct about 8 feet long and 3 feet wide for more than three weeks before Kuwaiti friends moved him to a safe house. Kreuzman's homecoming joy Monday was tempered by sadness for the dog that didn't make the flight home. ``It's a tragedy,'' he said. ``She went through a lot with me over there.'' He had crated his pet and put her on the plane in Kuwait. ``At Baghdad I wanted to go down to cargo and give her some water but was told no,'' said Kreuzman, 38. ``We got to Frankfurt, the box was smashed and no dog was in sight.'' Master and dog descended from the crawl space for only about five minutes a day. Kreuzman never cooked, fearing the smell might alert occupying troops. He said the dog never barked or made a fuss that might give them away. Donald Latham, 50, of Albuquerque returned home with his stepfather, Eugene Hughes, 69, after a harrowing stay in Kuwait marked by the slaying of a burglar. ``We had a Palestinian break into our house, and I killed him with a machete,'' Latham said. He said marauding Iraqi troops had entered the apartment earlier but did not find the men. ``They stole our television, the blender, one watermelon and about half our food,'' he said. The captives returned home after Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein decided to release the many foreigners held since his forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. One man hiding in Kuwait experienced the carnage of war firsthand. ``The worst thing I personally witnessed was a Kuwaiti being shot by probably 20 Iraqi soldiers,'' said Ed Werner of Baltimore. ``The guy was crawling on the ground across the street, he fired a shot, and about 20 Iraqi soldiers just opened up on him.'' Stories of Iraqi soldiers torturing and murdering Kuwaitis were common. ``I'm a veteran of Vietnam, but there's nothing in Vietnam that scared me the way this did,'' said Robert Morris, a dentist from Milton, Mass., who returned home Monday night. ``These people that came down were barbarians.'' ``They took everything. They pillaged the country, they raped the women constantly ... they are killing the doctors,'' Morris said. Jack Rinehart of Stover, Mo., who took refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, wasn't likely to travel abroad anytime soon. ``We're definitely going to have a passport-burning party. He's not going to leave the good old U.S.A. again,'' said Rinehart's sister, Sue Iliff of Stover. Robert Vinton, 58, of Santa Fe, N.M., was held as a human shield at a petroleum refinery south of Baghdad and said conditions there were like a prison camp, including barbed wire. ``We really couldn't leave,'' Vinton said. ``Basically we were in a total prison with bars on the windows. They locked the doors at night.'' In a stark contrast to that isolated deprivation, Dave Lammel, 42, of Orinda, Calif., was held at a Kuwaiti royal family palace, using the Limoges china and crystal glassware kept there. ``I had the irony of living in these ungodly opulent conditions,'' he said. ``It was bizarre. It was like a Fellini movie.''

DOC.HEAD: CIA Reports Increase in Third World Debt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0449 to fix typo in keyword line
DOC.TEXT: Third World countries' foreign debt rose to $1.096 trillion this year, up from $1.051 trillion last year and from $786 billion in 1984, the Central Intelligence Agency reports. The figure does not include the Soviet Union, China and other countries either still under communist rule or emerging from it, such as those in eastern Europe. Those countries add at least another $210 billion, according to earlier estimates by the CIA and the World Bank. The money is owed to more affluent governments including the United States, Japan and West Germany, to their private commercial banks and to intergovernmental bodies like the World Bank. Another $29 billion owed to the International Monetary Fund is listed separately. Although the CIA reported a rise of $45 billion in the debt since last year, it showed that payments dropped to $122 billion from the $126 billion of 1989. For the debtors the payment level is more important than debt itself. Each dollar they save on payments to their creditors is a dollar they can spend on new foreign goods. They can use foreign goods either to raise their people's living standards or to invest in new equipment that will produce more goods and jobs for their rapidly rising work force. The CIA handbook includes information compiled from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris and the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland. The book consists only of tables and does not explain the rise and fall of figures. Of the 113 countries listed, the heaviest debt is reported for Brazil: $115.341 billion, up from $112.15 billion in 1989. Brazil also owes about $8 billion in back interest, but the CIA does not include such arrears in its figures. They show Brazil as paying $10.1 billion on its debt this year, compared with $11.9 billion last year and $16.1 billion the year before. The new government of President Fernando Collor de Mello is deep in negotiations with private banks, to which it owes the bulk of its debt. They are urging at least some payments on the back interest. Mexico's debt of $88.02 billion is the second largest, reduced under the plan of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Last year it was $90.789 billion. Mexico's payments also have dropped due to the new arrangement, to $10.06 billion this year from last year's $13.104 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Scholars Vote to Remove Chief Editor of Dead Sea Scrolls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that scrolls not found in present-day Israel, but in occupied West Bank, SUB 5th graf, `The Dead ... in Jerusalem.' ^By AMY WESTFELDT
DOC.TEXT: The international team of editors deciphering the Dead Sea Scrolls has voted to remove the project's chief editor, who has been criticized for the slowness of the work to publish the ancient documents, a team member said. The dismissal of John Strugnell of Harvard's Divinity School comes just a month after the scholars appointed a co-chief editor to share Strugnell's duties. The scholars voted last week to dismiss Strugnell because of health problems for which he recently was hospitalized, Frank Cross said Friday. Cross, of Harvard's Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations department, belongs to the original group of eight scholars who were given exclusive publishing rights to the scrolls in the 1950s. The group has since been expanded to between 10 and 15 scholars worldwide. The Dead Sea Scrolls, discovered in 1947 in a cave in what is now the Israeli-occupied West Bank, contain the oldest known copies of the Old Testament, other Biblical writings, ancient literature and poetry. They are kept at the Rockefeller Museum in Jerusalem. Between 35 percent and 45 percent of the documents remain unpublished, Strugnell said in a November interview. Strugnell has been ineffective as chief editor because he has not pushed researchers to work faster so the scrolls can be published in their entirety, Cross said in a telephone interview last month. ``There has been criticism, both inside the team and out,'' Cross said in November. ``It is not by chance that this move is being made.'' Cross said Friday that Strugnell has been hospitalized, but was unsure where. A Harvard spokesman Monday refused to disclose Strugnell's whereabouts, saying Strugnell had instructed him not to speak to anyone. Spokesman Peter Costa also said he didn't know if Strugnell was aware of the vote to dismiss him. ``I can't confirm or deny anything,'' Costa said. ``At the university we consider this to be private.'' He declined to elaborate. Cross said Strugnell will remain in the group researching the scrolls, but will no longer have administrative responsibilities. Three scholars in the team will replace Strugnell as general editors, and Emmanuel Tov, of Jerusalem's Hebrew University, will handle the project's administrative work, Cross said. The scholars in October chose Tov to become co-editor in chief of the group deciphering the scrolls, hoping to speed up the work.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Ends Problem-Plagued Mission With Rare Night Landing
LaserPhoto EAB1
DOC.TEXT: Columbia glided to a rare night landing a day early after a star-gazing mission plagued by computer problems, clogged plumbing and finally the threat of rain. The shuttle touched down Monday night, its signature twin sonic booms heralding its arrival over the Mojave Desert. The landing, seen by about 600 spectators, was moved up to avoid rain in today's forecast. NASA officials focused on the mission's accomplishments, despite repeated problems aiming the $150 million Astro observatory. Besides the telescope troubles, the crew had to repair a clog in the shuttle's waste collection system. ``I think we've had a resounding success on the mission,'' said William Lenoir, NASA associate administrator. It was the fourth shuttle landing at night. Columbia carried Astro, made up of three ultraviolet telescopes and a separate X-ray telescope, in its payload bay. Problems with an automatic pointing system had forced astronauts and ground crew to manipulate the ultraviolet telescopes by hand, drastically slowing the process. During the nine-day mission, the crew succeeded in pointing the ultraviolet telescopes at only 135 of 250 targets, including a comet heading out of the solar system. The mission, originally scheduled for 1986, was delayed by the Challenger explosion and later by repeated hydrogen fuel leaks. The landing came the same day the space agency received a critical review by a government panel that said NASA should end its dependence on the troubled space shuttle fleet and completely redesign a planned space station. The Advisory Committee on the Future of the U.S. Space Program also said NASA could improve by streamlining management. NASA assembled the outside review at the request of the Bush administration after a rash of embarrassments that included the grounding of the shuttle fleet because of hydrogen leaks and a mirror flaw in the Hubble Space Telescope. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze toured the Johnson Space Center in Houston space center on Monday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and spoke to the Columbia crew in remarks translated from Russian. ``What you are doing in space is very important. You are paving new roads in space, and I very much believe that you are paving those roads for the benefit and for the happiness of all of us on Earth,'' Shevardnadze said. Astronaut Jeffrey Hoffman responded with a few Russian phrases, then said in English, ``We agree with your sentiments that space travel is important for the future of all mankind.'' NASA said it was the first communication between a Soviet official and a shuttle crew in space. After the smooth landing, the seven Columbia astronauts were to stay overnight at Edwards before traveling to Houston today. More than 1,000 telescope photographs were made during the flight. The first photographs should be ready for viewing in late December or January. NASA scientists were encouraged by the final observation made by the ultraviolet telscopes, a study of Comet Levy. The comet could not be studied earlier in the flight because it was too close to the sun. ``What a thrilling way to go out,'' astronomer Paul Feldman of Johns Hopkins University said. Mission scientist Ted Gull said, ``It brought tears to my eyes.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Kuwait is Iraqi, whether in the past, present or future. We will not compromise one iota on Kuwaiti territory, its waters or the money and investment of the buried Al-Sabah dynasty.'' - Iraq information minister Latif Jassim. --- ``The worst thing I personally witnessed was a Kuwaiti being shot by probably 20 Iraqi soldiers. The guy was crawling on the ground across the street, he fired a shot, and about 20 Iraqi soldiers just opened up on him.'' - freed hostage Ed Werner of Baltimore. --- ``We trust the American government's determined stand not to permit Saddam Hussein to link the gulf crisis with the Arab-Israel conflict and the Palestinian issue.'' - Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. --- ``Should hostilities break out and go on for a while, I see a scenario where people start saying consider a draft.'' - Rep. Norman Dicks, D-Wash., a member of the House Appropriations defense subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Some Freed Hostages Have Long Journey Ahead of Them
DOC.TEXT: For four months, the priority has been freedom. Those trapped in Kuwait and Iraq have above all focused on escaping with their lives. But in the months to come, some of the 900 newly freed U.S. hostages will have to start over without the homes, jobs and, in some cases, friends they lost to Saddam Hussein's invading troops. ``It's not easy to pick up and start over like this,'' Patricia Hammer said Monday from Denver. ``I'm 42 years old and living with my mother.'' Ms. Hammer fled Kuwait five weeks after Iraq invaded Aug.2, but her ex-husband refused to let her take their two children. After eight years building a life and family away from the United States, she now feels very much alone. ``There's a lot of problems coming out,'' Ms. Hammer said. ``You're physically weak, emotionally upset. These people will be traumatized ...'' For many former hostages, the journey back to normalcy will not end when they've arrived safely in America. ``My life is still not back together ... and it won't be for a while,'' said Miles Hoffman, who was released last month after being wounded by Iraqi troops. Hoffman has been in a perpetual rush since returning to Columbus, Ga. His injured arm needed medical attention, the media needed interviews, worried friends and relatives needed reassuring and Kuwait still needs to be liberated. Hoffman and his British fiance, Nikki Murgatroyd, initially put off their wedding until all Saddam Hussein's hostages were released. ``Now she tells me she won't marry me as long as I'm married to the Free Kuwait (effort),'' said Hoffman, a financial analyst for the Kuwaiti government. ``I need time to catch up.'' Hoffman, however, figures he may have it better than some of the American hostages that were headed out of Iraq and Kuwait on Monday, less than a week after Saddam decided to free his ``foreign guests.'' ``I have a sense of purpose ... and my job,'' Hoffman said. ``You just have to put your life in order and get on with it. The thing is, some hostages are going to have a hard time doing that.'' Some people lost it all when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Bob Peek, his wife and children, like many of those who had established lives in Kuwait, have had to start over from scratch. ``It's hard to imagine ... (that) all I had was my suitcase,'' said Peek, 37, who worked for the defense ministry in Kuwait. Left behind were his family car, their entire household, souvenirs, snapshots and a lot of Arab friends. Also left behind was their bank account. ``Getting back into the swing of the States isn't bad,'' said Peek, who has moved his family to Midland, Texas, and started work for a small oil company. ``The problem is that with the economy being what it is today, it's hard to find something. ``After these people come home, after they've spent some time with family and adjusted to their freedom, they're going to hit the job market,'' he said. ``And I just wonder what they'll find.'' Since fleeing Kuwait with her three young children, Ruthie Al-Qallaf has traveled around the nation giving speeches on behalf of Washington-based Citizens for a Free Kuwait. She is doing it to keep her mind occupied, to stave off her despair at having lost everything. And she is doing it for her husband, a Kuwaiti Air Force major. Iraqi troops had shot seven members of his family by the time her husband, who is now in Saudi Arabia, escaped in October. ``I'm bitter. I'm angry. I feel sad,'' Mrs. Al-Qallaf said from Memphis, Tenn. ``(But) I've only lost my home. The Kuwaitis have lost so much more.''

DOC.HEAD: No, That's Not How Armand Hammer Got His Name
With PM-Obit-Hammer, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For years, people erroneously thought billionaire Armand Hammer was connected to the company that makes Arm & Hammer baking soda. Irked by the constant questions, Hammer finally worked out a deal in 1986 that gave his Occidental Petroleum Corp. a 5 percent stake in the baking soda company and him a seat on its board. Hammer often said he was named after Armand Duval, the hero in ``Camille,'' a play by Alexandre Dumas that was one of his father's favorites. But he conceded in his autobiography that his father, a socialist, probably also had in mind the arm-and-hammer symbol of the Socialist Labor Party.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were higher. Traders said the dollar is little changed, caught between fears of war in the Middle East and expectations of lower U.S. interest rates. The dollar, considered a safe have currency in times of trouble, would rise if war broke out in the Gulf, traders said. But lower U.S. interest rates make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors and a drop in rates would bring a fall in the U.S. currency, they said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.20 yen to a closing 131.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 131.95 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.4725 German marks, up from 1.4708 -1.2585 Swiss francs, down from 1.2610 -5.0025 French francs, up from 4.9980 -1.6585 Dutch guilders, unchanged -1,111.50 Italian lire, up from 1,109.75 -1.1585 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1566 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9455, up from $1.9450 late Monday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $374.30 per ounce at midmorning, up from $373.75 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $374.30, up from $373.75 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.91 to close at a bid $375.36. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.09 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.05.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Say Lame-duck Minnesota Governor is Pouting
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rudy Perpich was dubbed ``Governor Goofy'' heading into his final year in office. Now, after his re-election defeat, some see him as ``Governor Grumpy.'' Perpich, 62, a Democrat, said there were no hard feelings after he lost his bid for a fourth term, but since his defeat by Gov.-elect Arne Carlson he has refused to talk to most news reporters and skipped a ceremony for a state Supreme Court justice he appointed. He has also written to Carlson criticizing the new governor's leadership. ``If this was my child, I'd scold him,'' said state Senate GOP Minority Leader Duane Benson, a chief Perpich foe. Perpich was tagged ``Governor Goofy'' about a year ago when he responded to news media accounts of his lifestyle by proposing to sell the governor's mansion, dismiss his State Patrol driver and give up his luxury car. The governor lashed out at Carlson for his suggestion that Perpich solve a projected $197 million state budget shortfall and help ease a projected $1.2 billion deficit in the next two-year budget. ``You have hired only one staff person and are relying on lame-duck administrators to make your decisions,'' Perpich wrote in one of three letters to Carlson. ``That's not the type of leadership most Minnesotans were looking for during the recent election.'' Perpich missed the swearing-in ceremony for Supreme Court Chief Justice A.M. ``Sandy'' Keith on Nov. 30. His absence was striking because he had named Keith, a longtime friend, to the high court and last summer selected him to become chief justice. Keith said the governor had called him shortly after the election to complain about a Supreme Court decision Perpich said led to his defeat. The 5-2 ruling, with Keith in the majority, cleared the way five days before the election for Carlson to replace Jon Grunseth as the GOP candidate on the ballot. Sexual impropriety allegations forced Grunseth from the race. Perpich spokesman Ray Bohn said the governor missed Keith's swearing-in ceremony because he had previous commitments. Some Perpich allies said the governor is handling his defeat well. Retiring Minnesota AFL-CIO President Dan Gustafson said he's spoken with Perpich a couple of times since the election. ``He hasn't been bitter,'' Gustafson said. ``He's been a little hurt, and naturally so. This is a real tender guy and he's never been vindictive. That doesn't mean he can't get mad and angry.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Splashes Drought-Stricken West
DOC.TEXT: Rain splashed drought-stricken California today, chilly temperatures hit the Northeast and some snow mixed with scattered rainfall in the Northern Rockies. Fair skies prevailed throughout much of the nation, with forecast highs ranging from the teens in northern Maine to the 70s in southern Florida, Texas, Arizona and southeastern California. The wet weather was welcome in northern and central California, where drought conditions have persisted for several years, although rainfall was not expected to be especially heavy today. Rain also fell in Seattle and Boise, Idaho, with some scattered snow at higher elevations along Montana's eastern border with Idaho. Highs in the 30s were expected in New York and Boston. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 85 degrees at Imperial Beach, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Tamil Rebels Claim 76 Men Massacred by Soldiers and Rival Tamils
DOC.TEXT: The Tamil Tiger rebel group has accused government troops and members of a rival Tamil group of dragging 76 Tamil men out of their cars and homes and massacring them in eastern Sri Lanka. Military officials and a spokesman for the rival group denied the allegation today, but residents of a nearby town said they had heard reports of a massacre from people who fled the area. The residents, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were told some people had been shot to death while others were burned alive with blazing tires around their necks. In another development, military officials said the Tigers had ambushed a military patrol today near the northeastern port of Trincomalee, killing five ethnic Sinhalese soldiers. Some rebels were thought to have died in the 90-minute gunbattle that followed the ambush, the officials said. They gave no numbers. The Tigers, in a statement issued by their office in London late Monday night, claimed ``a terrible massacre'' was carried out Friday by Sri Lankan army troops from an army camp at Neelavenai. The Tigers accused a rival group, the Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization, of collaborating in the alleged massacre. Military officials in Colombo denied their men were responsible for any such killings. The officials said the Tigers often made such statements in an attempt to justify upcoming attacks on the army or Sinhalese civilians. Tamil guerrillas launched a violent separatist campaign against the country's Sinhalese ethnic majority and Sinhalese-controlled government in 1983. More than 14,000 people have died during the insurgency. The Tigers statement claimed 76 Tamil men were killed at Neelavenai, 9 miles south of the eastern coastal town of Batticaloa. The statement listed names and ages of 14 purported victims but gave no details of the others it alleged were killed. Senathirajah Lawrence, spokesman for the Tamil Eeelam Liberation Organization, denied his group had anything to do with a massacre. Lawrence's group was once allied with the Tigers, but says its men have given up armed struggle in favor of a political solution. ``We don't operate anywhere near the Neelavenai village,'' Lawrence said when contacted by telephone in Colombo. ``This is a canard spread by the (Tigers).'' Residents of Batticaloa, 135 miles east of Colombo, said Tamils who fled Neelavenai reported that about 70 people were killed. The residents, contacted by telephone, said they were not sure who was responsible. The Tigers broke a cease-fire with the government six months ago. After several offensives, the government controls Batticaloa and other major towns in the east. The Tigers still operate in the jungles and are in control of the northern Jaffna Peninsula. The Tigers say Sri Lanka's Tamil minority needs a separate homeland to protect it from discrimination by the Sinhalese in jobs and education. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the island nation's 16 million people.

DOC.HEAD: New Head Chosen For Battered Social Democratic Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with additional details on Engholm. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: After suffering a bruising defeat in national elections, the leadership of the opposition Social Democrats has unanimously chosen the premier of a northern state to be the party's new chairman. The nomination of Bjoern Engholm ended a week-long search for a new leader to renew the party, which has been dealt three successive electoral defeats at the hands of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats. Both chancellor candidate Oskar Lafontaine and current party chief Hans-Jochen Vogel had declined to lead the Social Democrats after the defeat in the Dec. 2 parliamentary vote. The Social Democrats are the country's second largest political force and the oldest political party in Germany. But with Lafontaine as chancellor candidate and Vogel at the head of the party, they won just 33.5 percent of the vote nationwide in the first free elections in united Germany in 58 years. The left-leaning party fared poorly, winning about 23 percent, in the five new eastern states that were carved out of East Germany following unity on Oct. 3. The cautious, 51-year-old Engholm, dubbed ``the beautiful Bjoern'' for his dapper dressing, is a study in contrast with the harsh, outspoken Lafontaine. As Kohl's push for speedy German unity accelerated this year, Lafontaine alienated voters by issuing negative statements about unity. Engholm said he found Lafontaine's style off-putting. Engholm told ZDF television his task would be to bring the Social Democrats back to the center of society. He said that he would consult with leading artists and intellectuals on the party's future course. Engholm indicated he would retain his elected office as premier of Germany's northernmost state, largely rural Schleswig-Holstein. Vogel said the party leadership had unanimously agreed on Engholm's nomination as chairman. The candidacy must be formally approved at a party congress scheduled for May. Lafontaine has remained out of view since losing the election. Engholm said he wanted to bring a new generation of Social Democratic politicians to the forefront in time for 1994 parliamentary elections. An education minister under the former West German government of Helmut Schmidt, he has already proven his own electoral resilience. In 1987, Engholm was the victim of a smear campaign while running for premier of Schleswig-Holstein. Christian Democrat Uwe Barschel won the vote but resigned 12 days later after an aide revealed he was ordered to leak claims that Engholm cheated on his taxes and was bisexual. A day before Barschel was to have appeared before an investigatory panel, he was found dead in a Geneva hotel, an apparent suicide. Engholm was elected state premier in new elections on May 1988.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Supervisors Tentatively Approve VDT Safety Rules
DOC.TEXT: The city's Board of Supervisors has given initial approval to what could become the nation's only active law regulating video display terminals in the workplace. The measure tentatively approved Monday would require employers with 15 or more employees to provide adjustable work stations, mandatory 15 minute breaks and safety education for workers. Private and government offices would have two years to comply with the VDT safety rules if the ordinance is approved a second time by the supervisors and signed by Mayor Art Agnos. ``This is the new age of safety and health legislation,'' said Supervisor Nancy Walker. She compared the VDT safety ordinance to landmark laws at the turn of the century that set work standards such as eight-hour days and compensation for overtime. ``We are once again on the cutting edge of something that others have been unable to do,'' she added. ``And we're taking heat from that.'' The only other such ordinance, in Suffolk County, N.Y., was successfully challenged by business owners who said only the state could impose such rules. The San Francisco ordinance passed 8-1. Supervisor Tom Hsieh cast the lone dissenting vote, saying it was too costly and more information on VDT problems should be gathered. The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health said VDT workers often suffer headaches, general malaise, eye strain and musculoskeletal problems caused by poor work station design that results in awkward hand, head and limb positions. Pacific Bell operator Becky Hogue, who wears wrist braces, said repetitive strain injuries cause debilitating pain. `It's been frustrating because my bosses basically don't believe I'm hurting,'' said Hogue, 30. ``Maybe this ordinance will force people to do something they should be doing anyway.'' Under the ordinance, VDT operators would get a 15-minute break every two hours. Work stations would have to have proper artificial lighting and be out of direct sunlight. Adjustable swivel chairs and document holders must be provided. Computer terminals would have to have detachable keyboards and adjustable, non-glare screens, among other safety features. Additionally, businesses would have to provide workers, at their request, with arm, wrist and foot rests that aid in proper placement of limbs and joints while working on a VDT. Jim Lazarus, vice president of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, said the business group opposes the ordinance because it would cost too much to comply ``especially during an economic downturn.'' City budget analysts estimate it would cost San Francisco about $1.6 million to retrofit VDT work stations. Private businesses would probably pay some $36 million to comply with the ordinance, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Strong Smoking-Leukemia Link
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette smoking appears to increase the risk of developing leukemia, and kicking the habit may not be enough to dodge the dreaded blood disease, a study says. Paul K. Mills, a professor at Loma Linda University and the principal author of the study, said research suggests that even former smokers are at high risk. ``It's very discouraging,'' Mills said Monday. ``We saw a strong association between prior cigarette smoking and the risk of developing leukemia.'' The study's results are being published this month in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute. Cigarette smoking also has been linked to cancers of the lung, bladder, pancreas, esophagus, throat and cervix. The study is part of the Adventist Health Study, a major epidemiological investigation of the causes of various cancers among California members of the Seventh-day Adventist Church. About 34,000 Adventists responded to the study. Although the vast majority of Adventists do not smoke by church proscription, many are adult converts to the religion who smoked cigarettes prior to their baptism into the church. The researchers found that the ex-smokers had twice the risk of developing leukemia than non-smokers. For people who regularly smoked more than 25 cigarettes a day, the risk of developing leukemia increased threefold. The Adventists who had smoked for more than 15 years had a 2{-fold increased leukemia risk. Leukemia is a bone marrow cancer in which the marrow is replaced by immature, abnormal white blood cells. The disease kills 18,000 people a year in the United States. Dr. Clark Heath Jr. of the American Cancer Society said the causes of leukemia are largely unknown. But several studies in recent years, including a large study of U.S. military veterans, have suggested smoking as a cause, he said. The Loma Linda study estimates that about 20 percent of leukemia cases were linked to smoking.

DOC.HEAD: Disarray Hobbles Government Efforts To Cope With Fuel Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 3rd, `On Monday...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with strike in southern Philippines today. Pickup 4th, `Protest leaders...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino's efforts to cope with rising oil costs have produced bizarre flip-flops on price policy, street protests and calls for her resignation from former supporters. The increases, which raised fuel prices more than 45 percent, stunned the middle class, which had been a pillar of her support. Her handling also reinforced an image of a detached president, unsure of power after nearly five years in office. On Monday, militant transport workers staged a one-day strike in Manila, Cebu and other major cities. About 6,000 people rallied in Manila against the increases, and smaller protests took place in many provincial cities. Hundreds of commuters were stranded in the southern Philippines today as transport workers continued a strike to protest the increase in fuel prices. Protest leaders included several former Aquino government appointees and veterans of the struggle that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos and propelled Mrs. Aquino to power in February 1986. Many of them demanded she resign. It all started Wednesday when the Energy Regulatory Board raised prices for all grades of petroleum, including a more than 70 percent hike for gasoline. Board Chairman Marcello Fernando said the government could no longer subsidize consumer prices due to the rise in crude oil prices that occurred after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The increases had been expected for weeks. But their magnitude stunned Filipinos already coping with 12 percent inflation. Within hours of the announcement, Mrs. Aquino went on national television to ask the board to reduce the increase for kerosene and cooking fuel, widely used by the poor. The following day, the board dutifully complied but boosted prices again for gasoline. Premium prices soared by more than 130 percent over the level of the previous week. That effectively priced gasoline beyond the budgets of many teachers, government employees and managers of small businesses. ``The decision to raise fuel prices...starts the process of pauperizing the middle class,'' wrote commentator Amando Doronila in The Manila Chronicle. ``A government installed by middle class disenchantment is in danger of losing its legitimacy...'' Government officials then launched a campaign of leaks and off-the-record briefings in an effort to persuade the public that Mrs. Aquino was unaware of the size of the increases. They blamed her executive secretary, Catalino Macaraig, for not informing the president. On Monday, the government announced that Macaraig had been replaced by the youthful, popular transport secretary, Oscar Orbos, who was said to have opposed the increases. Critics said that if Mrs. Aquino was unaware of the increases, she was derelict in her duty. If she was informed, then she deceived the public. Four of the 23 senators called for her resignation or shortening her term through rewriting the constitution. Three of the four were elected in 1987 on the administration ticket. As criticism mounted, Mrs. Aquino appeared again on television Sunday and suggested that gasoline prices be reduced to Wednesday's level. The board then canceled the second gasoline increase, fixing the price at 57 cents a liter ($2.17 per gallon) for premium and 54 cents a liter for regular. Although the government blames the increase on the Persian Gulf crisis, pressure has been mounting for more than a year to end price subsidies on fuel. In March 1989, the government promised the International Monetary Fund that it would raise fuel prices regularly to curb the deficit in the Oil Price Stabilization Fund, which subsidized consumer prices. But the government, fearful of domestic unrest if prices rose, continued subsidizing the fund, whose deficit grew to $393 million. Last month, the government promised the IMF again that it would reduce the deficit in hopes of receiving new loans. It hoped to eliminate the stabilization fund deficit in one bold move. ``They tried to correct two years of procrastination overnight,'' wrote columnist Pedro Chanco in the newspaper Malaya. ``That simply can't be done without causing massive disruptions in the lives of people.''

DOC.HEAD: Communists Heading for Victory in Serbian Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with partial official returns, Macedonian election results. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `The opposition...'
DOC.TEXT: President Slobodan Milosevic and his renamed Communists today swept toward a resounding victory in elections that placed Serbia squarely at odds with the two other leading Yugoslav republics. The opposition conceded defeat Monday in Yugoslavia's most populous republic as Milosevic took a nearly 4-to-1 lead over Vuk Draskovic, leader of the nationalist Serbian Renewal Movement. ``Serbia chose Bolshevism and darkness instead of democracy and light,'' thundered Draskovic, a shaggy-bearded, pro-capitalist novelist who described the campaign as a contest between the forces of good and evil. ``I don't want and I don't belong to that kind of Serbia,'' he said. Opposition parties accused the ruling Socialists of vote fraud, and foreign observers said they were concerned that the republic's Communist-controlled media may have unfairly influenced the outcome of Sunday's vote. In the neighboring republic of Montenegro, Yugoslavia's smallest, the Communists were also celebrating victory. By contrast, the nationalist VMRO party won a plurality over the Communists in a third and final round of voting in the poorest southern state of Macedonia. The party, which advocates Macedonia's full sovereignty, won 37 seats and their closest rivals, the reformed Communists, 30 seats in the 120-seat Macedonian parliament, according to final results made public today. The future shape of Macedonia's government is still unclear. Milosevic's victory in Serbia threatened to deepen rifts between it and the Western-minded republics of Croatia and Slovenia, which ousted Communists from power in elections this spring. The Croats and Slovenes want to transform Yugoslavia into a loose confederation from what they claim is a Serbian-dominated federation. Milosevic has slapped duties on Slovenian and Croatian goods in reprisal for their steps toward independence. If Croatia secedes, Milosevic says, he will expand Serbia's borders to protect about 500,000 ethnic Serbs living there. The state news agency Tanjug said based on a partial count, Milosevic's Socialists, formerly Communists, won about 60 percent of the 250 assembly seats in the republic. With about 25 percent of the vote counted, Milosevic had 62 percent to 17 percent for Draskovic. Milosevic's Socialists had 43 percent in the race for the parliament to 15 percent for Draskovic's party. The opposition accused the government of rigging the vote, but acknowledged on Monday that Milosevic would have won anyway. State television and newspapers in Belgrade, the national as well as Serbian capital, were unabashedly pro-Milosevic. Opposition figures were given little coverage or portrayed as traitors whose victory could lead to civil war. ``In terms of procedures at individual voting places, the elections passed fairly well,'' said Robert Hand, a monitor from the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. ``Our main concern is what happened before the elections.'' There was little voting in the republic's troubled Kosovo province, where the ethnic Albanian majority staged a boycott to protest Serbian measures that have deprived the region of self-rule. There has been no parliament, government or Albanian-language media operating in Kosovo since July 5. Milosevic's actions there drew the repudiation of leaders from the rest of the republic, as did a bill he pushed through parliament stipulating prison sentences for people slandering the president. Yugoslavia was founded as a kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes in 1918 and reformed as a Communist republic during World War II. It has traditionally been a volatile amalgam of squabbling nationalities and ethnic groups. The split between the politically center-right north and the less-developed Communist south now threatens to break the country apart. Slovenia, the most western-leaning of the Yugoslav republics, lying on the Italian border, will vote in a referendum Dec. 23 on whether to become fully independent. Yugoslavia's pro-Communist defense secretary, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, a Serb, has threatened army intervention to protect the federation's unity.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Premiers Sing Unification Song Before Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with two premiers singing a unification song, to the delight of spectators. Pickup 2nd, `The three...'
DOC.TEXT: The premiers of North and South Korea clapped and sang Korea's national anthem for unification today in an emotional ceremony preceding another round of talks on easing 40 years of confrontation. North Korean Premier Yon Hyong Muk and his South Korean counterpart, Kang Young-hoon, stood side by side in an auditorium filled with 2,000 cheering spectators and sang the song, which starts, ``Our wish is unification.'' ``The music hall turned into a chamber of unification fever,'' said one witneses. ``The delegates sang, the premiers sang, everyone sang - the whole song twice.'' Yon arrived in South Korea earlier in the day for the third round of high-level talks. Controversy flared almost immediately. In a statement, Yon's delegation said it was pessimistic about the parley and criticized Seoul for jailing three dissidents. The three were arrested Nov. 30 after they returned home from meeting North Koreans in Berlin to discuss Korean unification. The Seoul government maintains that dialogue on unification must be conducted through official channels. ``The time when discussion of unification is monopolized by certain people is over,'' said An Byong Su, a North Korean spokesman. ``We are concerned about the reality in which civilians cannot meet in their own land or travel to an alien land for meeting.'' ``Issues which do not fall within the purview of the talks should not be raised,'' countered Kim Hyung-gi, of South Korea's Unification Board. The talks, to conclude Thursday, are the third round since October and the highest-level meetings between the Koreas since the peninsula was divided in 1945 and the border tightly sealed. In neither of the two countries is the premier the highest-ranking official. Kim Il Sung is the north's authoritarian leader, Roh Tae Woo the elected president of the south. South Korean Premier Kang Young-hoon greeted North Korean Premier Yon at a Seoul hotel. Kang denied news reports that he was planning to retire after the talks finish. ``The media may be asking me to resign because I did not manage south-north dialogue properly,'' Kang told Yon. ``I think I can stay in this position only with your help.'' The premiers attended an afternoon of traditional music. Afterward, the delegates stood and sang a song which begins: ``Our wish is unification.'' The talks will deal with visitor exchanges and easing political and military tensions between the two countries. North Korea seeks a non-aggression pact but the south claims confidence-building agreements are needed first. No major agreement is expected, but the talks are seen as one more step in the lengthy process of drawing the two nations closer. North Korea is one of the world's few remaining tightly controlled Communist states, with everything revolving Kim Il Sung. South Korea, while still emerging from decades of military control, has a functioning democracy. ``Small, steady efforts and finally little gains ... will lead to quantitative change,'' said Limb Dong-won, a diplomat and spokesman for the south's delegation. ``We will positively study any North Korean proposals,'' he told a news briefing. Roh is flying to Moscow this week for a summit with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and says he will discuss improving relations on the peninsula. North Korea has bitterly criticized Roh's visit, claiming it would sabotage the dialogue between two Koreas. North Korea was a close Soviet ally before the end of the Cold War.

DOC.HEAD: As Iraqi Hostages Return Home, Other Hostages in Lebanon Remembered
DOC.TEXT: As scores of Iraqi hostages joyfully returned home, former hostage Frank Reed implored the nation not to forget the 13 Westerners still held in Lebanon. ``Terry Anderson has now gone through his sixth Thanksgiving and (is) heading for a sixth Christmas,'' Reed told 100 people gathered Monday night to honor Anderson and the other hostages. ``Tom Sutherland is heading for his sixth Christmas. What price must these men pay for being innocent people who went to do a job and had every right to be there?'' Reed, who lives in suburban Malden, spoke at the second annual ``Celebration of Hope'' sponsored by Emerson College's Society of Professional Journalists and the Free Terry Anderson Committee. The ceremony marked Anderson's 2,096th day of captivity. Anderson, 43, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, and Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, are the longest held of the hostages. Most of them are believed in the hands of Shiite factions of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. The other Americans still held include Joseph Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut; Ewward Tracy, 59, West Beirut resident; Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College; and Jesse Turner, 42, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College. As each hostage's name was read by students representing them, tears welled in Reed's eyes. His was one of the names read in his absence during the first ``Celebration of Hope'' a year ago. No hostages have been freed since the 58-year-old educator was released last April 30 after 44 months in captivity. ``People ask me how good it is to be free,'' Reed said. ``And I'm not sure that I am free. I'm reminded every single day about the people I left behind.''

DOC.HEAD: Ousted President Ordered Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they had orders to arrest ousted President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, and a dozen senior officials from his government were being sought by authorities. One was put under house arrest. A senior police official said he expected Ershad to be detained by Wednesday. Other officials said the order could be carried out today. The police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the former home minister, Mahmudul Hassan, had been put under house arrest. The police official said policemen raided a dozen other homes, looking for senior officials of Ershad's ousted government. As home minister, Mahmudul was in charge of the police and the paramilitary Bangladesh Rifles, which were held responsible for the deaths of about 100 people during the seven weeks of unrest aimed at forcing Ershad to resign. Ershad, facing unrelenting public pressure and the refusal of his army to support him any longer, handed over power last week to the Supreme Court chief justice, Shahabuddin Ahmed, as acting president. In another development, the caretaker administration moved today to drastically toughen the punishment for illegal possession of weapons, raising the maximum sentence from three years to life in prison. The order signaled that the interim government intends to act harshly against anyone trying to disrupt parliamentary elections, which are to be held within three months. Opposition parties, under pressure from radical university students who spearheaded the anti-Ershad campaign, have urged that the ousted president be tried on charges of corruption and abuse of power during his eight-year rule. The opposition has called for three days of demonstrations to back up their demand for his arrest and trial. Ershad seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982 and ruled under martial law for four years. He was widely accused of fixing two parliamentary elections, and won a presidential election in 1986 against token opposition. Shahabuddin, the acting president, has sounded out the opposition parties on the possibility of allowing Ershad to flee the country to avoid a trial. For the most part, the parties publicly opposed the idea. But Sheik Hasina, leader of one of the anti-Ershad alliances, left the door open for exile. ``We want a Bangladesh without Ershad. I don't mind if that is achieved by his arrest and trial or by throwing him out of the country,'' she told reporters today. On Monday, a mob attacked the home of Ershad's vice president, Moudad Ahmed, with crude bombs, causing some damage. Moudud was not home and no one was injured. Moudud has denied any wrongdoing and said Ershad's Jatiya party intended to contest the parliamentary elections. Shahabuddin, meanwhile, told the military not to interfere in the elections. ``The nation expects law enforcing agencies, including the armed forces, to exercise complete neutrality in helping conduct free and fair polls,'' United News of Bangladsh quoted him as telling army officers. The army traditionally plays a strong role in politics in Bangladesh. Most of the presidents Bangladesh has had since independence in 1971 were former generals or were installed by the military.

DOC.HEAD: Sarbanes Admits Borrowing Remarks of Historian
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Paul Sarbanes has admitted borrowing some remarks from Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Arthur Schlesinger while challenging the Bush administration's Persian Gulf policies. Sarbanes, D-Md., said Monday he should have credited Schlesinger, a former White House adviser to President Kennedy, last Wednesday when he disputed President Bush's conclusion that he alone had the anguish of deciding whether to send young soldiers to battle. Both Sarbanes and Schlesinger spoke on the subject at Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings last week - Schlesinger on Tuesday and Sarbanes a day later. A review of transcripts of their remarks shows Sarbanes, a committee member, borrowed Schlesinger's comments without crediting him. In his statement, Schlesinger said: ``I notice the president in his moving remarks last Friday about the anguish of sending young kids to war, said, `It's only the president that should be asked to make the decision.' I hope he will reconsider that remark. If anything is clear about the original intent of the Constitution, it is that, as Abraham Lincoln said, the Constitution was written precisely to ensure that `no one man should hold the power of bringing this oppression upon us.''' The following day, in questioning Secretary of State James Baker III before the same committee, Sarbanes said: ``The president, in fact, said, in a moving statement, when he spoke about his concern about committing American men to war, said, and I quote him, `It's only the president that should be asked to make the decision.' I would hope the president would reconsider that remark, because I think if anything is clear about the Constitution, it is that, as Abraham Lincoln said, `The constitution was written precisely to ensure that no one man should hold the power of bringing this oppression on us.''' ``I should have probably said, `As Dr. Schlesinger pointed out to our committee yesterday,''' Sarbanes said Monday. ``I'm perfectly happy to accede to the fact that what I used came from Dr. Schlesinger,'' Sarbanes said. Sarbanes said he delivered his remarks without a prepared text and drew in part from other congressional testimony that he had heard or read.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Backs Baker on Timing of Baghdad Mission
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 18th graf pvs, bgng, Shevardnadze's support... to UPDATE with report Baker asked for Soviet troops, U.S. denial.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is backing Secretary of State James A. Baker III's timetable for his mission to Baghdad, and a U.S.-Soviet agreement may be near for both powers to end weapons shipments to rival factions in Afghanistan. The two cooperative moves surfaced as Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze resume their drive for a new treaty to trim U.S. and Soviet nuclear weapons stocks. ``Bridges are being built,'' a Soviet official said Monday night after Baker and Shevardnadze discussed the unsettled issues for 3{ hours. Neither side claimed real headway on completing the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, which would require a cut of about 30 percent in long-range nuclear bombers, missiles and submarines. Baker and Shevardnadze fly to Washington tonight and will report the results of their talks to President Bush on Wednesday. Once the treaty is completed, Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are expected to set the date for a treaty-signing at a summit meeting in Moscow. On three other fronts there was marked progress toward closer ties. Baker offered sympathetic consideration Monday to any Soviet request for emergency food and medical supplies. Shevardnadze, his country staggering on the edge of economic disintegration, said ``we would appreciate it.'' Also, the Soviet foreign minister appeared to credit reports that his government would suspend weapons shipments to the pro-Moscow regime in Afghanistan while the Bush administration ceases arming a coalition of rebels. That could end the decade-old war in the Southwest Asian country. ``We'll reach agreement on Afghanistan tomorrow,'' Shevardnadze told reporters. On Iraq, the Soviet foreign minister backed Baker's stand on going to Baghdad for talks with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Baker has rejected an Iraqi proposal that he go to Baghdad on Jan. 12, only three days before the United Nations Security Council's deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or face a forcible eviction. Baker said Sunday he ``won't be a party to playing games that back us up to that deadline.'' He proposed going to Baghdad to see Saddam either Dec. 20-22 or on Jan. 3. At Baker's meeting Monday with Shevardnadze, a senior Soviet official said, ``the foreign minister reiterated his support, his understanding of that schedule.'' The Soviets - who sent Yevgeny Primakov, their top expert on the Persian Gulf, to Baghdad on two futile missions - do not plan to send an emissary there ``for the time being,'' the Soviet official said. Shevardnadze's support, and deferral of any new Soviet overtures to Saddam, strengthens the united stand taken by the two superpowers against Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Washington Post today quoted Soviet sources as saying Baker asked Shevardnadze to commit a token Soviet military force to the gulf, but that Shevardnadze refused. A U.S. official disputed the account, saying that while Baker and Shevardnadze had discussed sending such a force in past meetings, the subject had not come up in their talks here. Baker's trip to Iraq could be the last opportunity for Iraq to yield to international demands for a pullout before facing an attack. Meanwhile, a U.S. official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Iraqi government had not responded to Baker's rejection of the Jan. 12 proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says Congressional Silence on Gulf Shows Support for Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with Quayle quotes; Picks up 4th graf pvs, Congress ha not.
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said today that congressional inaction on the Persian Gulf crisis sends a message of support for President Bush's policy against Iraq. But he accused some Democrats of playing politics with the situation. ``They passed resolutions before they left and they've done nothing to change those resolutions, so therefore our interpretation is support,'' Quayle told reporters at the Republican Governors Conference. He said the White House would like Congress, now in recess, to adopt a favorable resolution, but that's not likely. He did not call for a special session, saying that is for congressional leaders to decide. Lacking a new endorsement measure, he said, silence equals support. The resolutions he cited were adopted by the House and Senate in October, endorsing administration policy at that time. That preceded Bush's decision to double the American force deployed against Iraq and open the possibility of offensive action to drive Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. Quayle said congressional hearings on the crisis permitted Democrats ``the luxury of criticism without the burden of accountability.'' He would not identify Democrats he said had attempted to use the crisis ``for partisan political advantage.'' ``I'm not getting into names at all,'' he said today when asked whether he was criticizing Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, the panel that held the initial hearings hearings he criticized. ``Congress has not even sworn in its new members, yet already it's playing politics,'' he told Republican governors on Monday. The GOP governors conference was winding up today with an appraisal of the Nov. 6 elections and a look at the next campaign by pollsters and party leaders. The vice president told the governors he is confident Republicans will be united behind Bush in 1992. ``When the president unveils our agenda, I am certain it will rally our troops and unify our growing, yet at times contentious, Republican Party,'' Quayle said in a reference to in-house GOP debate over the best way to shape and deliver future government programs. ``Once the president decides, it will not be Republicans vs. Republicans, but Republicans vs. Democrats,'' Quayle said. ``The election cycle of 1992 is already upon us. The battle for this decade's political agenda has certainly begun.'' Quayle complained that the first three witnesses before the Senate Armed Services Committee early this month all were critical of Bush policy. Nunn, chairman of that committee, is a fixture on the list of potential Democratic challengers for the White House. Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., who sought the nomination in 1988 and says he is considering it again, is a committee member. They have been among the critics of Bush's decision to double the U.S. force arrayed against Iraq, opening the possibility of offensive action to drive Saddam Hussein out of occupied Kuwait. Democratic congressional leaders decided on hearings instead of calling Congress back into session to consider legislation on U.S. policy. Bush had said that was alright with him. He also has said he would welcome congressional backing for his course. Quayle told the governors the prospect of recalling Congress posed a dilemma because ``there is no perceived consensus.'' ``I cannot predict with any certainty what they will do when they get back in January,'' he said. Retired military and government officials at the Armed Services Committee hearings and at companion hearings of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended a go-slow course in the gulf crisis, one in which the U.S.-led alliance against Saddam Hussein would wait for economic sanctions to take their full toll on Iraq. But Quayle said waiting 12 to 18 months would be unacceptable. ``Patience at any price would be a failed policy,'' he said, amounting to appeasement of Saddam. Quayle said the Iraqi president is trying to use Congress and American public opinion in ``a political war'' to deprive the administration of its option to use force. It won't work, he said, because ``despite the efforts of some in Congress, the fact of the matter is that the American people support the president.'' Quayle added that in the end, ``when America's vital interests are on the line, the majority of Congress can rise above partisan politics.'' But he argued that is not happening now. ``A Congress solidly united behind the president would strengthen the chances for peace,'' Quayle said. ``Unfortunately, by portraying themselves as the party of peace, and the administration as the party of war, some congressional Democrats - but by no means all congressional Democrats - seem to have placed partisanship above statesmanship,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Seeks to Head Off General Strike
DOC.TEXT: President Ion Iliescu, attempting to stave off a nationwide strike that could bring down the government, opened crisis talks today with government and union leaders. The unions threatened a nationwide work stoppage if Premier Petre Roman did not step down by this evening. The labor groups say Roman's economic reforms have lowered Romanians' living standard, already among the worst in Europe. The government has said it will not resign and that a strike could bring grave consequences. Romanians are increasingly dissatisfied with the government of the National Salvation Front one year after they ousted the Communist dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu in a bloody revolution. The Front, which took over after Ceausescu's ouster last December, overwhelmingly won May elections with pledges for gradual economic reform. But price liberalization introduced Nov. 1 doubled or tripled the prices of many consumer goods and some food products. Anti-government protest fueled by disillusionment as the anniversary of the revolution approaches forced the government to rescind plans last week for more food price increases Jan. 1. But the unions refused to withdraw the strike threat. Students at Bucharest's Polytechnic University and in the western city of Timisoara declared a strike today, state radio reported. They were pressing past demands for the resignation of Iliescu, often accused by the opposition of being a neo-Communist. The nationwide Fratia labor federation, which claims about 800,000 members in various industries, is demanding that recent price increases be rescinded, salaries raised and proposed legislation restricting the right to strike withdrawn. It has threatened to call a nationwide general strike if the demands are not met, or unless the government resigns by this evening. The talks between the unions and the government began at mid-morning at Iliescu's offices in the capital's Cotroceni Palace. State radio said the government was represented by Roman, Reform Minister Adrian Severin, and Social Services Minister Ion Aurel Stoica. The union delegation was headed by Fratia leader Miron Mitrea, who said Monday he expected a general strike to win support from other large independent unions. A drivers union claiming 100,000 members struck Monday. Government spokesman Bogdan Baltazar said this the government would not resign. ``The government was elected in free democratic elections ... and is supported by the people,'' Baltazar told a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Santa's Elves Answer Letters in Nanoseconds
DOC.TEXT: In these days of megabytes and disk drives, writing a letter to Santa Claus just won't do. So Santa has upgraded to a computer and now receives and answers wish lists by electronic mail with some assistance from a few computer-literate elves. Santa went from a jolly old elf to a computer wizard with the help of Joyce Perkins, creator of the On-Line Santa Project. Ms. Perkins teaches business computer applications at the El Paso Technical Center, part of the public school system. A few weeks back, she set up Santa's mailbag on a computer bulletin board. A bulletin board is a service computer users dial up to share information and programs and contact each other. Ms. Perkins also enlisted her students as Santa's elves to reply to all the letters that come in by modem, a device that lets computers communicate via phone lines. Santa's electronic mailbox is overloading with wish lists from children engaging in Yuletide log-ons. ``We've had a ball,'' said Ms. Perkins. ``It's taken off and gone crazy.'' Every day, the elves divide the messages, making sure Santa's mail is answered quickly. They sign their messages with names such as Frost-byte, Skippy Chips, Clickey Mouse and Nanosecond Nic. ``It's fun being able to chat with little kids,'' said Angel Locklear, a senior at Austin High. ``They're learning, and we're helping build up their dreams.'' Among the requests for new bikes, talking dolls and electric trains, came one appeal for 16,000 Nintendo cassettes. ``Aren't we being a little greedy,'' one of the elves messaged back.

DOC.HEAD: Defeated Challenger Plans to Return to Canada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with prosecutors saying Tyminiski to be questioned today and may be allowed to leave Wednesday. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Polish authorities said today that Stanislaw Tyminski, the defeated presidential contender, will probably be allowed to go home to Canada if he guarantees he will return to face a slander investigation. Meanwhile, the man who defeated him, President-elect Lech Walesa, went to Poland's holiest Catholic shrine in Czestochowa today to pay homage to the Black Madonna icon at the Jasna Gora monastery. Later, Walesa was returning to Warsaw to mull over his choice for prime minister. Walesa won a landslide victory over Tyminski in Sunday's presidential runoff election and is to be sworn in for a five-year term later this month. Tyminski, an emigre businessman, says he needs to go home to Canada to gather evidence to defend himself against the slander charges. The Justice Ministry said Tyminski was to be questioned today and might be allowed to leave Wednesday if he makes a sufficient guarantee he will return for legal proceedings. Tyminski and his Peruvian-born wife planed to leave for Toronto on Wednesday morning. He said he only wanted to leave the country for three days, and that he was prepared to put up $100,000 to guarantee his return. A prosecutor in Nowy Sacz in southern Poland began a slander investigation after Tyminski accused Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of treason during a Nov. 17 campaign rally. The prosecutor's office in Warsaw said on Monday that Tyminski had to stay in the country and answer a Dec. 17 summons in Nowy Sacz. Tyminski said Mazowiecki, who lost in the first round of the presidential election on Nov. 25, had betrayed the nation by creating chaos through economic reform after taking office in August 1989. There has been speculation that Tyminski, hounded by Poland's highly partisan press, could return for good to Canada, where he lived many of the past 21 years after leaving Poland to seek his fortune. He has said he wants to remain active in Polish politics. ``My duty and responsibility is to stay here because I received very strong suport,'' Tyminski said at a news conference today. But he said he was unsure whether he would found an opposition political party. Tyminski, a 42-year-old computer company owner who also brought cable TV to the Peruvian jungle, portrayed his saga as a rags-to-riches story and tapped into the Polish mythology of the rich uncle in America. But his first-round election success was derailed before Sunday's runoff by questions about his connections with former Communist operatives and the vagueness of his promises for quick economic recovery. Tyminski, who also has Canadian and Peruvian citizenship, had lied with his children near Toronto until this fall, when he returned to Poland. In making his request to leave Poland, Tyminski said he wanted to see his children for the first time in more than two months. He also said he needed to prepare his defense using videotapes of the Nov. 17 campaign rally that were taken to Canada. He said the tapes will prove he did not slander Mazowiecki.

DOC.HEAD: Hezbollah Says Israel Strafes Bases; Israel Denies Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Israel saying no helicopters in action today. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem guerrillas said two Israeli helicopter gunships rocketed and strafed several of their bases in southern Lebanon today, but Israel denied the report. An Israeli army spokeswoman said no Israeli helicopters were in action over Lebanon today. She spoke on condition of anonymity under army regulations. Police said there was no immediate word on casualties from the reported 15-minute raid on Deidaba Hills, a stronghold of Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah said in a communique issued in Rashaya that several of its military bases in Deidaba, three miles north of Israel's self-designated security zone, were attacked by Israeli Cobra gunships. The communique did not give any other details. The air raid would be Israel's 19th in Lebanon this year. By police count, 20 people were killed and 130 wounded in the previous strikes.

DOC.HEAD: Assassin of Civil Rights Activist Denied Parole
DOC.TEXT: The man serving a life term in a state prison for assassinating civil rights activist Malcolm X in 1965 has been denied parole. The decision by the state Board of Parole means 49-year-old Thomas Hagan, also known as Talmadge X. Hayer, must serve another two years before becoming eligible for another hearing, said Edward Elwin, executive director of the Parole Board. Hagan, who is imprisoned at Edgecomb Correctional Facility in Manhattan, has been a model prisoner and is one of only 30 inmates who have qualified for an extended furlough program, said Kelly Priess, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Corrections. However, the three-member parole panel, after a hearing in November, cited ``the seriousness of the crime'' in rejecting Hagan's request for early release, Elwin said Monday. Priess said Hagan has participated in the prison furlough program since May 1989 and he is allowed to return home and work in the community about four days a week. There was no indication in his prison records that Hagan has had any disciplinary problems and he has shown ``acceptable behavior,'' Priess said. Malcolm X became a leading figure in the civil rights movement in the 1960s. He also stirred controversy for his refusal to reject violence in gaining freedom for ``people of African descent here in the Western Hemisphere.'' He was gunned down in February 1965 while speaking to supporters at a rally in New York City. Hagan, who was shot in the leg by one of Malcolm's bodyguards, has said the assassination was to avenge blasphemies that he contended Malcolm X had made against Muslim leader Elijah Muhammad. Hagan has said he did not know who ordered the killing. Two other men convicted of helping in the assassination, Muhammed Abdul Aziz and Kahlil Islam, have been released on parole in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Ammunition, Literature on Bomb-Making Found in Kahane Suspect's House
DOC.TEXT: Police searching the home of the man accused of killing Israeli extremist Rabbi Meir Kahane found stockpiled ammunition and literature on bomb-making, according to court papers. A motion filed Monday by the Manhattan district attorney's office said El Sayyid Nosair had a case of 1,440 rounds of 7.62mm ammunition, suitable for many types of military rifles, stored in his house in Cliffside Park, N.J. Police also found several rounds of .22-caliber and .38-caliber ammunition and literature on ``subjects such as bomb-making, hand grenades, security and listening devices,'' the motion said. Police found an article from The Jewish Press about Kahane's most recent trip to the United States and an advertisement for the lecture where the American-born founder of the militant Jewish Defense League was killed, the motion said. The prosecution argued in the motion that the ammunition and literature showed Nosair ``deliberately planned the murder.'' Nosair, 35, was shot in the neck Nov. 5 by a U.S. Postal Service policeman who happened to be outside the hotel where Kahane had been speaking when he was killed. Nosair was scheduled to be examined by a private doctor today after his lawyer said he was not well enough to be moved from a hospital to a jail. Nosair, a native of Egypt, has been charged with murder in the death of Kahane, who advocated the expulsion of Arabs from Israel. He also is charged with two counts of attempted murder in the wounding of a passerby and of the postal officer. Nosair, who is being held in lieu of $300,000 bail, was scheduled for a bail hearing Monday, but Justice Alvin Schlesinger postponed it until Dec. 18 because his attorney, Michael Warren, was 35 minutes late.

DOC.HEAD: New Fighting in Township Claims at Least 35 Lives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE death toll to 35. Pickup 5th pvs, ``Inkatha came...''
DOC.TEXT: At least 35 people were killed today as rival black factions battled with guns, knives and axes, setting fire to shacks and chasing terrified people through the streets. Dozens of homes were burned and hundreds of residents fled as rival groups battled for several hours during the morning in Tokoza black township and in a surrounding industrial area. Hacked and mutilated bodies lay outside houses that had been burned and pillaged. The fighting pitted mostly Xhosas loyal to the African National Congress against Zulus of the Inkatha Freedom Party in what increasingly appeared to be a tribal confrontation. The Xhosas live in a squatter camp, while the Zulus live in adjoining hostels. At least 53 people have died in factional fighting in Tokoza since the latest fighting began on the weekend. ``Inkatha came. They were burning the shacks. They are trying to drive us out,'' said a terrified Xhosa man wearing only trousers and holding a club. Xhosa squatters armed with clubs, spears and knives gathered for safety at one end of the township, while hundreds of armed Zulus in white headbands were waiting in a migrant workers's hostel at the other end of Tokoza. ``We want revenge ... We want to fight,'' some Zulus chanted. Police in armored vehicles roared through the dusty township on the eastern outskirts of Johannesburg. Police patrols hovered on the edges of the township, but rarely ventured into the narrow lanes leading to its densely packed shacks. Xhosa and Zulu residents accused each other of starting the violence. Both sides accused the police of collaborating with their opponents. A number of Zulu women armed with clubs and knives, their faces painted white, were helping guard the Zulu hostels. They claimed the police had fired on them. ``The police don't help us,'' said one angry woman. ``The Xhosas started the fighting. They better leave this place. This is for Zulus only.'' Enraged Xhosas at the other end of town yelled insults at the police, saying they were ``Inkatha.'' Police spokesman Capt. Eugene Opperman denied police were involved in the fighting. ``We side with no one,'' he said. Opperman said the fighting apparently started today when Xhosas attacked a Zulu hostel and the Zulus mounted a revenge attack. Police were fired on by men in a vehicle and fired back, killing one man and wounding two others, Opperman said. No police were hurt. More than 1,000 people have been killed in the factional riots in the Johannesburg area since August. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose apartheid, but both want to lead a non-apartheid South Africa. Inkatha favors a conservative policy, including free enterprise, while the ANC leans more to leftist economic policies. President F.W. de Klerk, who has promised to end apartheid, is expected to begin talks next year on ending white-minority rule.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Sends Condolences To Armand Hammer's Family
With PM-Obit-Hammer, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev expressing condolences, additional background. ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today sent condolences to the family of Armand Hammer, citing the late industrialist for his prominent role in Soviet-American relations. ``Mr. Hammer was associated with one of the most remarkable pages of our relationship'' with the United States, the message said. ``He met with Lenin and was very close in many ways to the Soviet Union, and to Russia.'' Gorbachev's message was read by his spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko. Hammer died in Los Angeles on Monday after a brief illness. He was 92.
