Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said Hammer will be remembered in the Soviet Union for his tireless efforts to maintain good relations with the Kremlin, even during the Cold War. ``Armand Hammer was not only an observer, a witness to the decades in the history of Soviet-American relations, but also a man who actively participated in the building of those relations,'' Gremitskikh said. ``His constructive activity was especially appreciable and fruitful in the periods of coolness in the relations between the U.S.S.R. and the United States,'' Gremitskikh said. ``He always raised his voice, and in addressing leaders of both superpowers, spoke out in favor of overcoming difficulties and for fruitful cooperation in all spheres.'' Hammer's involvement in the Soviet Union began in 1921 as a young doctor just out of medical school who came to the country to help in famine relief. He met with Vladimir Lenin and sought his help in re-establishing trade between the Communist regime and the West. He worked out a deal to trade surplus U.S. grain for Soviet products. At one point, Hammer was sole representative for 38 U.S. companies in the Soviet Union, and also owned and operated an asbestos mine and founded the first pencil factory in the nation. During one visit to the Soviet Union, he said: ``I'll never forget what Lenin told me during one of our meetings. He said, `Dr. Hammer, we don't need doctors. We need business people who can do things.' That was the end of my promising medical career.'' Hammer maintained his ties to the Soviet Union from the Lenin years to the era of perestroika initiated by Gorbachev. He met with every Soviet leader since Lenin. ``He always raised his voice, and in addressing leaders of both superpowers, spoke out in favor of overcoming difficulties and for fruitful cooperation in all spheres,'' Gremitskikh said. One of his largest developments in Moscow is the huge Mezhdunarodnaya Hotel and SovIncenter exhibition complex. Built on the banks of the Moscow River, it is known in the city as the Hammer center.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules State Sodomy Law Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: An 1879 law against homosexual sodomy is unconstitutional, a state judge has ruled. ``It's great, really exciting. This is a very important day for us,'' said Nell Hahn, attorney for the Texas Human Rights Foundation, which helped file the suit challenging the law. District Judge Paul Davis announced the ruling after a hearing Monday, and said a written opinion explaining the decision would be issued Jan. 2. A spokesman for the state attorney general's office said no decision has been made on an appeal. Gay men and women from Austin, Houston and Dallas challenged the law that makes it a Class C misdemeanor, punishable by a $200 fine, for consenting adults of the same sex to have ``deviant sexual intercourse.'' The plaintiffs asserted that the law violates Texas constitutional guarantees of privacy, equal protection and due process, as well as the state Equal Rights Amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Two Big Soviet Republics Dispute Elements of Gorbachev Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Russian lawmaker, Kazak president rejecting Gorbachev proposal on economy. No pickup. Changes byline
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of the Russian Federation and the president of the Kazakh republic today rejected Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's proposal to retain central control over the economy. Gorbachev has proposed a new Union Treaty to keep the 15 Soviet republics together and to maintain central government control over key natural resources and major industries. But the Russian republic's Congress of People's Deputies and Nursultan Nazarbayev, president of Kazakhstan, the third-largest Soviet republic, each said they would sign the proposed treaty only if it gives them control over their own economies. ``We stand for the treaty,'' Nazarbayev said. ``But attempts from the top to organize the treaty will not succeed.'' Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation - the largest Soviet republic - has taken the same stand, and repeated it on Monday as the Russian parliament voted to appoint a commission to negotiate the Union Treaty, the state news agency Tass reported. The legislatures of the second-largest Soviet republic, the Ukraine, and all but one of the remaining republics have declared economic and political sovereignty. The 15th, Kirgizia, was reportedly debating the issue this week. Nazarbayev said at a news conference he thought at least 11 Soviet republics would sign the treaty. The three Baltic republics and Moldavia, he said, were boycotting the negotiations. ``The economic integration of the republics will not allow us to get out of this crisis separately. We must do it together,'' Nazarbayev said. He said the balance of ownership must change. Now, central authorities own 93 percent of businesses in Kazakhstan and turn over less than 1 percent of the profits. Nazarbayev said that under his republic's sovereignty declaration passed Oct. 25, his Central Asian republic would take control of those businesses, including substantial coal reserves in the eastern part of the republic and a huge oil and natural gas field now being explored in Western Kazakhstan. Moreover, Kazakhstan plans to sign a contract with a U.S. consortium in January to exploit an oil field, and Kazakhstan plans to reap its share of the profits from that deal rather than send them to the central government, he said. The vote by the Russian Federation Congress of People's Deputies marked a small victory for Gorbachev, because it commits Russia to be ``a full-fledged subject of the renewed U.S.S.R. on the basis of a new Union Treaty.'' But it also gives Yeltsin strong leverage in negotiations with Gorbachev by asserting the right of each republic for self-determination and gives the central government responsibility only for defense, state security and foreign policy. The draft proposed by Gorbachev would retain broader powers for the central government, including control over transportation and energy supplies. The Russian parliament decided to appoint a commission of lawmakers to work with representatives of the central government and other republics to work on the draft Union Treaty. No date has been set for its completion.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Party Member Apologizes for Racist Remark
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note offensive language in graf 4, ``After Taylor...''
DOC.TEXT: A Conservative Party member apologized today to a black parliamentary candidate for racist remarks that had been condemned by local and national party leaders. William Galbraith issued his apology on the day the Cheltenham Conservative Party Association was scheduled to vote on expelling him. Galbraith's remarks had been condemned by Prime Minister John Major and other Tory leaders. Cheltenham police were investigating complaints that Galbraith's remarks about John Taylor, who hopes to be the first black Conservative in the House of Commons, were an incitement to racial hatred. After Taylor had been selected as the local candidate for the next national election, Galbraith was quoted in a national newspaper as calling Taylor ``a bloody nigger.'' Galbraith repeated the slur in broadcast interviews. Galbraith also said he was unhappy that Taylor was not a resident of Cheltenham, an almost totally white, heavily middle-class town, although it is common in British politics for parliamentary candidates to be outsiders. Major declared in the House of Commons that the remarks had no place within the Conservative Party, and Galbraith has been banned from the local Conservative Club and from two of his favorite pubs. On Tuesday, Galbraith issued a statement supporting Taylor. ``Mr. Galbraith acknowledges that Mr. Taylor's color and ethnic origins are utterly irrelevant in the circumstances,'' Galbraith said in the statement released by his lawyers. Taylor said he was pleased with the apology. ``I have never made race and color an electoral issue,'' he said. ``I have always remained at arms length from all this - all I wanted to do was to get on with the pleasant task of getting to know the people of Cheltenham. All this has been a diversion.'' Taylor, 38, was selected two weeks ago as the Conservative candidate for Cheltenham, a picturesque town 120 miles northwest of London. He has run previously as a Conservative candidate in Solihull, his home town in central England. Typically, aspiring politicians have to run one or more hopeless campaigns before being selected in a district where they have a chance of winning. Taylor, the son of a West Indian cricket player, is a barrister - a lawyer qualified to argue cases in court - and a member of the local council Solihull. There are only four blacks in the 650-seat House of Commons, all members of the Labor Party. About 5 percent of Britain's population is classified as ``non-white,'' a broad label that includes West Indians, Pakistanis, Indians Chinese and persons of mixed race.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Apologizes For Mistaken-Identity Shooting
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army today apologized for killing a Protestant bakery worker it thought was a member of the security forces. David Shiels, 30, was shot to death on Dec. 3 as he stepped outside his mobile home in Maghera, 30 miles northwest of Belfast, to feed his dog. His brother works as a police officer. The IRA issued a statement today which said the gunmen were ``acting on erroneous information'' and it ``profoundly apologized.'' The dead man's brother, George Shiels, rejected the apology. ``I treat that with utter contempt. Do they consider themselves officers and gentlemen that they dare offer such apologies to us?'' Shiels said. In other developments today, British news reports said the IRA was conducting a campaign to intimidate Protestant and Catholic shop owners who serve police officers and soldiers. Garage, cafe, and fast-food shop owners have placed advertisements in Northern Ireland newspapers indicating their intention to stop serving the forces after their lives were threatened, press reports said. The IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland, under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets October Trial Date in $200 Million Silverado Civil Suit
DOC.TEXT: An October 1991 trial date has been set for a $200 million civil lawsuit against Neil Bush and other key figures in the collapse of Silverado Banking Savings and Loan. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. filed the lawsuit against the president's son and 12 other former Silverado directors, attorneys and executives in September. The suit claims the officials were ``grossly negligent'' in their management of Silverado, which collapsed in 1988. The bailout of the thrift is expected to cost taxpayers about $1 billion. The suit claims the defendants authorized excessive compensation to management and approved a series of loans and other transactions that drove the $2.3 billion thrift into insolvency. U.S. District Judge Sherman Finesilver scheduled the trial to begin Oct. 7, 1991, according to court documents made public Monday. Defense attorneys said there is still a chance that the case will be settled out of court or dismissed. Bush, who served as a outside director at Silverado from 1985 to 1988, has filed a motion to dismiss the case against him on the grounds that federal banking regulators approved all the transactions he voted on as director. Most of his co-defendants also are seeking to have charges against them dropped. Bush also is fighting a separate action brought by the federal Office of Thrift Supervision accusing him of operating as a Silverado director with conflicts of interest.

DOC.HEAD: Two Pilots Missing in USS Lexington Collision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The Navy ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with identity of second pilot. Picks up 6th graf pvs., `A duty ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers searched the Gulf of Mexico today for the pilots of two Navy jets that collided during takeoff and landing practice from the carrier USS Lexington. The two TA-4 Skyhawks collided Monday during routine training maneuvers 86 miles northwest of Key West, Navy officials said. Both pilots were missing. ``One aircraft was verified to have gone into the water, threfore destroyed,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Ray Kempisty, a Navy spokesman for the Chief of Naval Education and Training in Pensacola. ``The other is missing and presumed destroyed.'' The Lexington, the Navy's oldest aircraft carrier, is homeported in Pensacola. The Navy said the pilots were Philip J. Palmatier Jr., commanding officer of a training squadron, and Ensign Troy A. Moore, a flight student. Both pilots were stationed at Naval Air Station Chase Field in Beeville, Texas. A duty officer at Pensacola said the pilots' flight suits have glow strips and carry strobe lights, flares and a radio beacon. The weather in the area at the time of the crash was mostly clear, with light winds. Ships and aircraft took part in the search. The TA-4s are built by McDonnell Douglas Corp., and are capable of carrying 10,000 pounds of munitions and traveling at a top speed of 675 mph, according to Jane's ``All the World's Aircraft.'' The Lexington is scheduled to be decommissioned next November after 47 years of service. In 1989, A T-2 Buckeye trainer crashed into the ship's control island and cartwheeled across the flight deck in a fireball, killing five people. The student pilot at the controls was attempting his first landing on a carrier. Navy investigators were unable to pinpoint a cause for that crash.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Soviet Agent Detained in Salzburg
DOC.TEXT: A suspected Soviet agent was detained in Salzburg today after receiving documents about U.S. weapons systems from an informant who escaped into a crowd of Christmas shoppers, officials said. The arrested man hada Soviet diplomatic passport and claimed to be accredited at the embassy in Vienna, senior intelligence official Karl Koenig said in a telephone interview from Salzburg. Police detained the unidentified 39-year-old man on a Salzburg street after he was given a thick envelope by another man, Koenig said. The contact man escaped in the late morning Christmas bustle and traffic, he said. Koenig said police acted on confidential information. The detained man is allegedly an officer of the Soviet military intelligence GRU, but police refused to identify him while they try to determine his name and the validity of his diplomatic passport. Koenig said police were unable to reach anyone at Vienna's Soviet Embassy. A spokesman at the embassy who did not identify himself told The Associated Press he knew nothing of the incident and could therefore not comment. Koenig said the material in the envelope included materials about U.S. weapons categories, technical know-how, and the U.S. space agency NASA. He said the material was all in English and was being sent to the prosecutor's office. If the man is a diplomat accredited in Austria, he would have to be released because of diplomatic immunity.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Six Sheriff's Deputies of Stealing Drug Dealer Cash
DOC.TEXT: Six members of an elite narcotics squad were convicted of stealing thousands of dollars in drug money in a scandal that rocked the Los Angeles County sheriff's department. A seventh deputy was convicted of money laundering Monday in the case, which led to the disbanding of whole sheriff's units and imperiled dozens of criminal cases. Federal prosecutors portrayed the deputies as corrupt lawmen who skimmed money taken in drug raids to buy boats, homes, cars and vacations. The jury convicted the deputies on 24 criminal charges. ``We trust these people and now they're doing things they shouldn't be doing, things that they arrest people for doing,'' juror Dawn Hurtt said. The defendants were members of an anti-drug unit that was responsible for some of the department's largest cocaine and drug money seizures. The deputies had up to 23 years of experience with the sheriff's department. ``The verdicts handed down today are not an occasion to celebrate, they are not a victory,'' Sheriff Sherman Block said in a statement. ``They are the just conclusion to the unlawful actions of a few who sought to hide their crimes behind a badge of honor.'' The U.S. District Court jury also convicted six of the deputies for conspiracy and theft. Five were found guilty of lying on their tax returns. The jury deadlocked on 26 other counts, which Judge Edward Rafeedie dismissed. Three deputies were acquitted of charges related to the theft of $527,000. The deputies remained free on bail. ``I'm sure this jury did the best job they could,'' said defendant James R. Bauder. ``But we're disappointed.'' The scandal broke in February when federal prosecutors filed a 27-count indictment accusing the deputies of stealing $1.4 million in drug cash. However, the jury only found the deputies guilty of taking $48,000 in a 1989 incident videotaped during an FBI sting operation. The scandal led to an investigation of the nation's largest sheriff's department. Block disbanded four narcotics teams and set a five-year limit on the time a deputy can spend working in the narcotics bureau. Dozens of narcotics officers were transferred and more than 30 criminal cases were dismissed, became subject to plea bargains, or came under review. A federal grand jury continues to investigate the department and some narcotics officers in the Los Angeles Police Department. Prosecutors accused the deputies of seizing cash during raids and obtaining statements from alleged traffickers disowning the cash. The deputies then allegedly stole some of the money and distributed it among themselves. Prosecutors pointed to evidence of thousands of dollars stashed in shoe boxes at deputies' homes and alleged shopping sprees that showed the men were living well beyond their $40,000 to $60,000 salaries. The deputies said they got the extra cash through baby-sitting, gambling or inheritance. Two other narcotics deputies are scheduled to stand trial next year in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW YORK
Pickets March as Tribune Board Discusses Future of Daily News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Chicago pickets; picks up 3rd graf pvs `On Monday ...' Board meeting is private. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: About 100 pickets marched outside Chicago's landmark Tribune Tower this morning in support of striking New York Daily News unions as the Tribune Co.'s directors prepared to discuss the tabloid's future. ``Settle or sell,'' chanted the pickets, who were led by three representatives from the Daily News branch of The Newspaper Guild, the newsroom workers' union. The publishing company's board of directors was to discuss the strike, now in its 47th day, during its regular meeting today. Among its options are selling the New York tabloid, closing it down or waiting out the strike. ``The Tribune organization has been trying to set up a situation where they could legally destroy the unions - force a strike, so they could legally shut down the paper,'' Don Singleton, a Daily News reporter and bargaining team member, told the crowd. ``We hope we can convince the Tribune not to shut the place down. Stop wasting the millions of dollars they have been spending to bust the unions.'' Don Turner of the Chicago Federation of Labor said the company ``tries to kill unions. But we know in the end the workers are going to be victorious, as they always are.'' Three Chicago Tribune unions that walked out in 1985 had also accused the company of bargaining in bad faith. The pickets were from various Chicago labor groups. The demonstration was peaceful. On Monday, the News and its unions said they will go to Washington this week and meet separately with the director of a federal mediation service. The Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella of the striking unions, is to meet with Bernard DeLury, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, on Wednesday morning. DeLury will meet separately with management. Gov. Mario Cuomo, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Cardinal John O'Connor addressed an estimated 6,500 people at a pro-union rally Monday in front of the News offices. Cuomo, in his first show of support for the strikers, said a federal law allowing the use of replacement workers is ``not wise'' and ``not fair.'' ``We need to resolve this matter at the Daily News to show the world it can be done,'' Cuomo said. Jackson told the crowd that ``strike breakers are also family breakers'' and that the use of replacement workers is ``immoral, it is illeal, it is wrong.'' In a letter to O'Connor released Monday, News publisher James Hoge said: ``I have been troubled by press reports of your questioning the morality of the Daily News exercising its lawful rights to employ replacement workers. We would not have done so unless the very survival of the business was not threatened after the strike began.'' The News has printed daily since the strike began Oct. 25. But its distribution has been curtailed by violence against delivery drivers, threats against newsstand vendors and a union-led boycott, which also crippled advertising sales. The strike has cut the News' circulation from 1.09 million to 552,000 as of last week. The News says that by the end of this year its losses over the past decade will have mounted to about $200 million and that it must have major concessions to operate profitably.

DOC.HEAD: Balloon Crashes; Four Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-5 bgn, `The three ...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE that 3 men on board balloon were licensed pilots and ADD police description of crash, Picks up 6th graf pvs, `John Remy ...'; SUBS 9th graf pvs, `The balloon ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE that Ingwersen was among those killed. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Authorities were ...'
DOC.TEXT: A hot air balloon struck a broadcast tower near the city's downtown today and crashed, killing four people. The balloon crashed in a wooded area behind the studios of television station WBNS. Three men, all licensed hot air balloon pilots, and a woman riding in the gondola were killed, police said. Radio station WTVN-AM reported that the balloon took off from Mohawk Middle School, but no students from the school were on board. The balloon drifted northwest and passed over the downtown before it crashed about two miles west of downtown. Lt. Randy Thatcher of the State Highway Patrol said the balloon went into a steep climb to clear the broadcast tower. ``It snagged on the top of the antenna and fell,'' Thatcher said. ``Half the descent was fairly slow until all the air was out of the envelope. Then it fell straight down very fast.'' John Remy, a reporter for WTVN, said he was on his way to work when he saw the balloon hit the tower, which is 1,069 feet tall. He said the balloon appeared to fall about 900 feet. ``I was sort of watching this balloon, and I said to myself it looks awful close to the tower, but that's just my line of sight,'' he said. ``But then it hit it, popped and just burst into shreds. ``It went straight down. ... It was a terrible thing to see.'' The balloon was owned by a restaurant, Bogey Inn. Karl Demmler, owner of the restaurant, was en route to the site. Eric Ingwersen, who runs a hot air balloon school and was acting president of the Central Ohio Balloon Club, usually operated the balloon, and was one of the pilots killed in the crash. Authorities were alerted to the crash at 8:22 a.m. The Federal Aviation Administration sent an investigator to the site. The green-and-yellow fabric of the balloon was draped over the edge of a small stand of trees adjacent to the tower, about 50 feet from a stanchion that holds five of the cable guy wires that steady the tower. What appeared to be a piece of the balloon fabric fluttered from the broadcast tower.

DOC.HEAD: Armand Hammer Named After Dumas Character
With AM-Obit-Hammer, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Industrialist Armand Hammer often said he was named after Armand Duval, the hero in Alexandre Dumas' play ``Camille.'' But he conceded later that his father, a socialist, also had in mind the arm-and-hammer symbol of the Socialist Labor Party. For years, people erroneously thought Hammer was connected to the company that makes Arm & Hammer baking soda. Irked by the continuing questions, Hammer finally worked out a deal in 1986 that gave his Occidental Petroleum Corp. a 5 percent stake in the baking soda company and him a seat on its board.

DOC.HEAD: Pileup Kills Seven on Fogbound Interstate 75
DOC.TEXT: At least seven people were reported killed and 50 injured in a 50-vehicle pileup this morning on a fogbound Interstate 75. Wrecked cars, some of them burning, littered a five-mile stretch of the Knoxville-to-Chattanooga interstate hours after the 9:30 a.m. accident. Some troopers responding to the massive pileup were overcome by fumes, but hazardous materials teams at the scene said any danger from a burning truck carrying dicumyl peroxide had dissipated. Joe Wilson of the Bradley County Emergency Management Agency said seven people were confirmed dead and at least 50 injured. Wrecks occurred in both the southbound and northbound lanes of the interstate and hampered efforts to remove the injured. Some suffered burns and several were in critical condition at hospitals in nearby Athens and Cleveland. ``We have staffed our emergency room and have put our disaster plan into play,'' said Linda Dunlap, assistant nursing administrator at Cleveland's Bradley Memorial Hospital. Sue Allison of the Tennessee Department of Safety in Nashville said a propane tanker was involved but not damaged in the accident, the worst of which was concentrated on a bridge over the Hiwassee River near the Bowater paper mill. One southbound lane was reopened 1{ hours after the accident. Four fire trucks, several ambulances and helicopters from Knoxville and Chattanooga hospitals were called to the scene, said Steve Weber, a Cleveland Police Department dispatcher. Cecil Whaley, director of the Tennessee Emergency Management Agency, blamed the accident on the thick fog. ``Boy, it's a mess. It's a California-type accident where a thick fog bank formed and people started running into it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Planned To Commemorate Jews Murdered By Nazis
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Lech Walesa will be a patron of a new museum planned to commemorate Jews murdered in Nazi concentration camps on Polish soil, according to reports Tuesday. The Polish news agency PAP also reported that Walesa was invited to visit Israel by President Chaim Herzog. The museum would be on the site of the former Warsaw Ghetto, where Jews were first isolated and then deported to death camps during the German occupation, the news agency said. The initiative is being undertaken by Walesa's advisory Citizens Committee, it said. A foundation will be established to raise money and establish the museum in a former hospital next to Umschlagplatz, where the Nazis loaded Jews onto trains for transport to death camps. Among the concentration camps established in occupied Poland were Treblinka, Auschwitz, Birkenau and Maidanek. The Warsaw ghetto was razed by the Nazis after a last desperate uprising in 1943. During the presidential campaign that ended with Walesa's landslide victory Sunday, the Solidarity chief was accused by political opponents of tolerating anti-Semitism among some supporters. Walesa denied the charge and condemned the resurgence of anti-Semitism in post-Communist Poland.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Endorses Unchanged Use Of Contraceptive Pills
DOC.TEXT: A decade-long study of possible links between oral contraceptive use and cancer found the evidence too inconclusive to warrant changes in prescribing the pill, the World Health Organization said Tuesday. An expert panel said that family planning programs based on the pill do not need to be changed. The agency reported on studies in eight developing and three industrialized countries that explored whether using the pill increases the risk of cancer. Experts from 11 countries met privately at WHO headquarters in Geneva to review the studies and other evidence, according to a statement issued by the agency. Their findings included: -Most studies suggest no general link between the pill and cervical or breast cancer. More research is needed because some studies have found connections between long-term oral contraceptive use and the risk of either cancer among some groups of women. But the link could also be due to better disease detection or special characteristics of women using the pill. -Oral contraceptives increase the risk of benign liver tumors, but this is a very rare complication. -The pill can reduce the risk of ovarian cancer, cancer of the inner-lining of the uterus and benign breast diseases. The general conclusion was that ``evidence about the association between oral contraceptives and various types of tumors does not indicate there is any need for a change in policy in prescribing the contraceptive pill,'' said Dr. Olof Meirik, an official in WHO's human reproduction program. More than 60 million women are believed to use the pill worldwide, nearly two-thirds of them in developing countries, WHO said.

DOC.HEAD: Panda Twins Doing Well, Zoo Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese zoo's first artificially conceived panda twins passed their three-month birthday in good health, making panda history, an official report said Tuesday. The Xinhua News Agency quoted Zhang Anju, vice president of the China Zoo Society, as saying that the twins, one male and one female, are ``sure to survive'' at this point. Most giant pandas born in captivity die in their first weks, and scientists are not sure why. Zhang said the problem was especially acute with pandas conceived through artificial insemination, as the twins were. It also is rare for both twin pandas to survive because mother pandas frequently take care of one and neglect the other. Zhang said the female cub's weight had increased from 5.3 ounces when it was born Aug. 24 to more than 13 pounds as of Monday. The male's weight increased from 5 ounces to 13 pounds. They were born at the Chengdu Zoo in southwestern China, which has an active program of inseminating captive pandas. The procedure is controversial among scientists. Many foreign wildlife experts argue that it would be better to reproduce conditions in the wild to encourage mating and natural pregnancies. Xinhua said only 24 of the 1,155 pandas born worldwide as a result of artificial insemination have survived. The twin's mother, Qingqing, was herself the product of artificial insemination. China has the world's only wild panda population, but its numbers have plummeted in recent decades to between 1,100 and 1,500 due to poaching and human encroachment on its habitat. About 100 pandas live in Chinese zoos.

DOC.HEAD: Oliva to Succeed Brademas as NYU President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: L. Jay Oliva, a scholar in Russian history and chancellor of New York University, was named Tuesday to succeed John Brademas as president of NYU. Oliva, 57, will assume the presidency of the nation's largest private university in January 1992. Brademas, a former 11-term Indiana congressman who served as NYU's president since 1981, will become president emeritus in 1992. He had said last summer he would step down as president when he turned 65. Oliva's appointment by NYU's board of trustees came as no surprise. A trustee committee decided to forgo a national search when it became clear Oliva had overwhelming support from all constituencies. Oliva will be the first faculty member to lead the 44,000-student university in its 159-year history, said Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of NYU's board of trustees. ``In Dr. Oliva, we have not only a great teacher and outstanding scholar, but someone who understands the way a university functions on every level,'' Tisch said. Oliva has a reputation as an easygoing, approachable administrator who lives in a student dormitory with his wife, Mary Ellen. In an interview Tuesday, Oliva said he planned to remain in that dorm room as president and to continue teaching. ``I've been waiting all my life to say, this is the age of the teacher,'' he said. Asked if Russian history held any lessons for someone about to assume a college presidency, Oliva singled out Czar Peter the Great, the subject of one of Oliva's books. ``Peter the Great felt it was totally unproductive to be daunted by big problems. Peter never brooked the idea that a big challenge was impossible,'' he said. Brademas greatly increased NYU's stature, aided by his formidable fund-raising abilities. Since 1981, NYU raised more than $800 million, dorm space was greatly expanded, and the university moved to the front ranks nationally in fields including business, fine arts, and accounting. The cost has risen with the reputation. Tuition, fees, room and board for entering students this fall were $21,400, among the nation's highest. Oliva said one of his priorities will be to make it easier for students to cross departmental lines in their studies - to encourage law students to take courses in the business school or the school of public administration, for example. ``We've got our buildings. Now what I want to see is a community of scholars,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Shamir Meet Today to Discuss Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs, bgng, Israeli officials... to UPDATE with comments from U.S. official; picks up 6th graf pvs, bgng, The administration...
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today he and President Bush have smoothed relations between their two countries strained by the U.S. partnership with Arab leaders against Iraq. The president issued a ``warm welcome'' to Shamir at the outset of their Oval Office talks this morning, but he rebuffed questions from reporters about the Middle East situation. ``We have been delighted to express our full support for the leadership of the president, for the policy of the United States in this recent crisis of the gulf,'' Shamir told reporters after spending nearly two hours with Bush at the White House. ``And the president also expresses his support for our behavior, for our policy'' in the crisis, Shamir added. Israeli officials said before the meeting that Shamir would tell Bush that Israel does not intend to launch any pre-emptive strikes against Iraq. Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly said that Shamir didn't talk about ``potential Israeli actions'' but that Bush thanked him for keeping a low profile in the crisis. ``There was a strong expression of identity of views on seeing Iraqi aggression rebuffed,'' Kelly told reporters. But he also said ``there was no attempt to duck the tough issues'' of Jewish settlements in the occupied territories and Israel's use of force against Palestinian protests in those areas. Kelly did not elaborate. The administration has been concerned in recent days by suggestions from senior Israeli officials that if the United States doesn't dismantle Iraq's military machine, Israel might. ``We have reached general understanding, more or less, on all the moves in the gulf and on Israel's position,'' Shamir told reporters. The meeting ``will enhance the special relationship between the United States and Israel,'' Shamir said. Israel has been torn between its promise to the United States to lay low in the Persian Gulf crisis, and fears that the administration is moving toward a diplomatic solution that will leave intact Iraq's stores of chemical and biological weapons. Administration officials have been discussing arms control measures that might be used to prevent Iraq from menacing its neighbors once the current crisis is resolved. ``Israel looks to the United States to provide the leadership and resolve that will rid the Middle East of such dangers in the future,'' Shamir said in a statement issued in New York on Monday. But, he added, ``Saddam Hussein of Iraq knows that Israel will not remain passive if he tries to harm us.'' Saddam has threatened Israel with chemical weapons, and Israel's air force has been on high alert since his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush and Shamir also discussed the shape of the Middle East after the crisis with Iraq is resolved. Shamir said they agreed that substantive peace moves would have to await resolution of the gulf crisis. Israelis are worried that some U.S. allies in the gulf crisis, especially Syria and Saudi Arabia, will demand payment for their support in the form of U.S. pressure on Israel to relinquish lands it captured from the Arabs in the 1967 Mideast war. But Shamir said he had been assured by Bush this would not happen. ``I trust the president,'' he said, that ``there won't be any deal at the expense of Israel.'' ``We trust the American government's determined stand not to permit Saddam Hussein to link the gulf crisis with the Arab-Israel conflict and the Palestinian issue,'' Shamir said in his New York remarks. The administration, while rejecting attempts by Iraq and its allies to link the two issues in a United Nations Security Council resolution under debate in New York, is keen on reviving stalled Mideast peace moves. Dennis Ross, a senior aide to Secretary of State James A. Baker III, will head for Israel next week to discuss how to move toward talks on Arab-Israeli peace. U.S. attempts until now have focused on getting Israelis to sit down with Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, but the Palestinians' fervent support for Iraq in the gulf crisis has changed that equation. The Israeli government, which has balked at the U.S. attempts, hopes to seize the opportunity to press for a changed peace formula. Israeli officials said Shamir was stressing that the shape of future Mideast talks will depend on the outcome of the confrontation with Iraq: if the U.S. side emerges victorious, members of the coalition like Syria and Saudi Arabia might be willing to talk peace with Israel. But a perception that Iraq has gained the upper hand would scuttle all hopes for peace by strengthening the Arab hardliners, Israeli officials say. Israel also is seeking additional U.S. help in absorbing the flood of Jews - 1,000 to 2,000 a day - immigrating from the Soviet Union. Shamir said Israel's population of 4.5 million could grow by 1 million in the next three to five years, and the cost could reach $40 billion. Israeli officials said Shamir wasn't making a specific aid request, but that Israel is looking for the type of guarantees the administration provided this year to finance the construction of $400 million in new homes. Shamir said Bush had promised that Israel's request would be debated.

DOC.HEAD: State Treasurer's Office Announces Expedited Payments
DOC.TEXT: The state treasurer's office announced today that it would expedite payments to Philadelphia to help it past a fiscal crisis that threatens a payless payday for city workers Dec. 28. An aide to State Treasurer Catherine Baker Knoll said the announcement was released prematurely by mistake, but that the payments would be made. The treasurer had planned to review two more documents before an announcement, executive deputy treasurer Seymore Heyison said from Harrisburg. He would not elaborate on the nature of the mistake or the additional documents. In a letter to Mayor W. Wilson Goode, Mrs. Knoll said, ``At this difficult time for the city, you can be assured that I remain deeply concerned about the city's financial difficulties.'' A week ago, Mrs. Knoll said she would not invest in a proposed sale of short-term notes to help the city remain solvent until major tax payments come due in February and March. The treasurer's refusal to join the note sale was a blow to the Goode administration, which also is asking the city pension fund, state teachers pension fund, local banks and private investors to buy about $300 million in notes this month. ``The mayor believes this is an important ingredient to the short-term note sale,'' Goode's press secretary, Karen Warrington, said. ``It provides ability to have the state pay directly to a third party. And it increases the security for any short-term monies that we would want to borrow.'' Heyison said he did not know how much money the city would receive, or how soon, as a result of the directive. ``It all depends on what request they send over from various agencies,'' he said. Philadelphia's requests would be handled with the same review measures as they would normally, he added. ``We're not doing anything differently than we normally do for voucher transmittals other than expediting the processing,'' he said. City workers and pensioners widely oppose risking part of their $1.5 billion in pension funds to help Philadelphia meet its short-term obligations, said Charles Johnson, a municipal printer who serves on the city Board of Pensions and Retirement. The board meets Thursday and Friday, but a vote may be delayed. No formal proposal had been made by the city as of Monday, and the board has hired Washington attorney Ian Lanoff to advise them on whatever proposal is made. The city's credit rating has dropped to junk-bond levels during its fiscal crisis this year, making its notes too risky for the pension board's normal investment guidelines. But Goode recently signed a law that allows the board to invest until July 1 in any Philadelphia obligation, regardless of quality. Sluggish tax revenues and arbitration-awarded pay increases have added to past budget imbalances to create a projected $229.5 million deficit for the fiscal year that started July 1. A $375 million note issue flopped in September, leading to a cash crisis. Until major tax payments come due in February and March, the city risks having to survive on daily receipts of less than one-fourth its average $9 million daily bills.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Grants Ivana Trump a Divorce
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with reaction and background. Unfaith is cq in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: A judge granted a divorce this morning to Donald and Ivana Trump, citing the millionaire developer's ``cruel and inhuman treatment'' of his wife. Mrs. Trump, supported by her lawyer Michael Kennedy, fled the Manhattan courthouse in tears after the divorce was approved. State Supreme Court Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob granted the divorce in response to a petition by Mrs. Trump. The judge said her decree was ``based on Mr. Trump's cruel and inhuman treatment such as made it unfaith or improper to continue to be married.'' Trump had a much publicized affair with would-be actress Marla Maples in the past year. ``There is going to be no further comment other than she has her divorce,'' said a woman in Kennedy's law office. Trump issued a two-sentence statement saying: ``I wish Ivana the best. I have no doubt that she will do very well in the years to come.'' The judge said all other issues such as maintenance, child support, equitable distribution and the validity of any pre- and post-marital agreement will be decided at trial, unless they are otherwise resolved. No date was set for such a trial. Trump has said his wife signed a marital agreement giving her $25 million and their Connecticut mansion. Mrs. Trump has challenged the agreement. The couple has three children.

DOC.HEAD: South Carolina Governor to Lead GOP Group
DOC.TEXT: South Carolina Gov. Carroll A. Campbell was elected chairman of the Republican Governors Association on Tuesday, and Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin became vice chairman. As the governors wound up their annual conference, Campbell and Thompson said all agreed the Republican administration should try to prevent Congress from imposing mandated programs that require state spending. ``The mandates that are coming out are breaking the states,'' Thompson said. Campbell said federal requirements for spending on Medicaid and other programs are diverting funds that should go to education and other state needs. ``Our message to the president is: `Please stop it - use your veto,''' Thompson said. Campbell said the governors would hold their 1991 conference in Utah at the invitation of Gov. Norman Bangerter. He said a specific site hasn't been selected.

DOC.HEAD: Fifty Whales Beached on Cape Cod
DOC.TEXT: More than 50 pilot whales were found beached today on Squaw Island near the Kennedy family compound on Cape Cod and volunteers rushed to try to rescue them. ``They are still alive at this moment,'' said James Ellis, spokesman for the Center for Coastal Studies in Provincetown. Fifty-four whales, measuring up to 20 feet in length, were spotted around midmorning near the island, and a single whale was found on the Cape's bay side, Ellis said. Ian McMillan, associate director of the Cape Cod Aquarium, said rescuers would try to determine which whales are in the best shape to be returned to the water. The tide had already gone out, leaving some of the whales in shallow pools. It was the first mass beaching in the area since 70 pilot whales beached themselves at several spots four years ago. Most of those whales died, but three young whales beached on the Cape three years ago were rescued and returned to the sea. Experts disagree on the cause of the beachings. Theories include that the pod, or school, of whales follows a sick leader ashore, or that the marine mammals are disoriented by magnetic variations along geological faults. The rescue effort, being coordinated by the New England Aquarium, included the Centers for Coastal Studies, the International Wildlife Coalition and the International Fund for Animal Welfare, said Kathy Shorr, a spokesman for the Center for Coastal Studies.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: An aide to California Sen. Alan Cranston today denied she pressured or asked federal regulators to reverse their decision tightening controls on Charles H. Keating Jr.'s troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan. Testifying at the Senate Ethics Committee's Keating Five hearings, Carolyn Jordan said she talked by telephone with two staff regulators in May 1988 but did not make a request to go easy on Lincoln. Jordan, Cranston's staff assistant on the Senate Banking Committee, underwent friendly questioning by Cranston's defense attorney, William Taylor. ``Did you put any kind of pressure on (the regulators) in any way to change their ways and ease pressure,'' Taylor asked. ``I did not say anything ... No I did not,'' Jordan said. Jordan spent all morning on the witness stand, and her sometimes spotty memory provoked a sharp complaint by the ranking Republican on the ethics panel, Sen. Warren Rudman of New Hampshire. ``I'd like to get more specific,'' Rudman said, interrupting the questioning. ``The witness obviously has very good recollection about some things and very poor recollection about others. I think we've got to guard against just getting totally meaningless answers,'' he said. Jordan was questioned about her contacts with thrift examiners on behalf of Keating around the time of a key regulatory decision in May 1988. The panel heard testimony last week that she called the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to complain about a May 5, 1988, plan to impose new regulatory controls on Lincoln. She acknowledged making the call and mentioning her contacts with Keating's lobbyist, Jim Grogan. Two weeks later the board eased its regulatory grip on Lincoln. The result of the board's change was that eventual takeover of Lincoln was delayed and the cost of the taxpayers' bailout of insured deposits was increased, according to federal regulator William K. Black. Earlier, she testified she found nothing unusual about Cranston's meeting with regulators on behalf of Keating. She said she did not know until months later about the April 2, 1987, meeting that four of the senators, including Cranston, held with then top thrift regulator Edwin J. Gray, on behalf of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan. But she contended, ``I didn't think it was unusual.'' She testified that she was aware of a second meeting a week later that all five of the senators under investigation held with San Francisco-based regulators. She said she asked if she should plan to attend and Cranston said the senators did not want aides present. ``It didn't really strike me as unusual when he said it was about Lincoln,'' she said. ``Just in the back of my mind I assumed they were going to talk about some of the background information about the examination'' regulators were conducting at Lincoln. Those meetings have emerged as crucial in the ethics panel's investigation of allegations the five senators improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating. Jordan acknowledged visiting Keating's American Continental Corp. parent company in Phoenix in late 1986, where she gave a speach to management and toured its facilities. Her trip was paid for by a California-based thrift industry association, she said, and Keating's company paid for her lodging. That visit was just a few months before Cranston attended the meetings on behalf of Lincoln. The ethics panel is investigating allegations the five senators improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating, who contributed $1.3 million to the lawmakers and their causes. In addition to Cranston, those under investigation are Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Donald Riegle, D-Mich. Keating has been charged in California with fraud stemming from the sale of junk bonds, largely to elderly investors who became victims of the Lincoln collapse.

DOC.HEAD: US Intelligence Detects Further Iraqi Troop Buildup in Kuwait Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs, Pentagon announcing more Iraqi, US troops in gulf, plans to seek more allied help; picks up 6th graf pvs, The Pentagon.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has placed 20,000 more troops in and around Kuwait in the past week, expanding the Iraqi armed force in the area to more than half a million soldiers, the Pentagon announced today. The United States buildup also is continuing. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said today that an additional 10,000 U.S. troops have arrived in the Persian Gulf area since last week, increasing the total U.S. force there to 260,000. Williams also said that more than 220,000 ground, sea and air forces of other allied nations are arrayed against Iraq. These include forces from Britain, France, Egypt, Syria and several gulf nations, including Saudi Arabia. Last week, the Pentagon said Iraq had sent 480,000 troops to Kuwait and southern Iraq. That represented an increase of 30,000 from the week before. Williams described the latest additions to the Iraqi force as ``a rounding out of existing brigades'' committed to the occupation of Kuwait, rather than the arrival there of newly activated brigades. He said U.S. intelligence sources had not detected any increase in the 4,000 Iraqi tanks in the area. Bush administration officials have cited the continuing buildup of Iraqi forces in Kuwait and southern Iraq as a sign that President Saddam Hussein does not intend to comply with UN resolutions demanding his withdrawal from Kuwait. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in a speech Monday that Saddam Hussein ``has given us absolutely no indication whatsoever of any intention'' of withdrawing from Kuwait and allowing the restoration of the exiled Kuwaiti monarchy. Williams also disclosed today that the administration planned to ask allied nations such as Germany, Japan and Korea for additional financial contributions to help defray the cost of Operation Desert Shield. He said he could not say when the requests would be made, nor by which member of the administration. The Pentagon, meanwhile, is continuing to add air and ground forces to Operation Desert Shield. The Air Force is sending more F-15 Eagle fighter jets to the Persian Gulf to expand U.S. offensive capabilities against Iraq, and the Army is ordering more National Guard and Reserve soldiers to active duty. The Pentagon announced on Monday that elements of the 36th Tactical Fighter Wing at Bitburg, Germany will deploy to the Middle East starting Dec. 28. Officials declined to say how many of the 72 planes based at Bitburg are being sent. The Air Force in recent days has disclosed deployments of a variety of additional aircraft to the gulf, including F-117A ``stealth'' fighter-bombers, F-111 medium-range bombers, A-10 tank killers and OA-10 observation planes. The additional aircraft are part of a broad-based reinforcement of U.S. deployments in and around Saudi Arabia, including more than 100,000 extra ground forces, more than 30,000 extra Marines and three additional aircraft carrier battle groups. Tens of thousands of reservists are being called up to support the reinforcement. The F-15s from Bitburg will give the United States greater air-to-air combat capability in the event of war with Iraq. The aircraft are armed with Sidewinder and Sparrow missiles and a 20mm Gatling gun. An undisclosed number of F-15s were dispatched to the Gulf in August from the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing at Langley Air Force Base, Va., and from the 4th Tactical Fighter Wing at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, N.C. In its announcement, the Army said it ordered to active duty 1,457 members of National Guard and Reserve units in 20 states to provide a variety of support services, including cargo transport, medical service and civil affairs. The Army activations brought to 121,940 the number of reservists called to active duty in all four services. Of that total, 90,186 are from the Army National Guard or Reserve.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats: Last Major Exodus of Westerners Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to leave with charter flights leaving for London, Frankfurt and Bangkok. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: In the last major evacuation of hostages, three more chartered flights left Iraq, carrying hundreds of foreign captives freed by President Saddam Hussein. Only a few were Americans. Two British chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 707s brought 240 foreigners, mostly Britons, from Kuwait to the Iraqi capital. A third American charter returned to the Iraqi capitial with only one Irishman and two Canadians aboard. There were no Americans on any of the flights from Kuwait. ``We must have gotten them all,'' said one American consular official, referring to earlier evacuation flights from the emirate and speaking on condition of anonymity. About 160 Japanese, including 14 diplomats from the Japanese Embassy in Kuwait, left Baghdad today on a flight for Bangkok, Thailand. Diplomats said just 14 Americans were on the charter flights that left Baghdad today. Seven were among the 310 people, mostly Britons, on the flight that left for London. Seven more were among the 16 passengers on the American-chartered Iraqi Airways 707 to Frankfurt. The others included an Irishman, two Canadians and six Britons. The White House said today that Thursday's evacuation flight of Americans from Iraq and Kuwait is ``likely to be the last'' and would probably also carry home the remaining staff of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``We would anticipate that once all Americans who want out have been able to get out that we would remove the entire staff of the embassy,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and members of his staff had long defied Iraq's orders following its Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait that they abandon the compound. They and the British have had to cope with deprivation after Iraqi troops cut off electricity and water. President Bush has said he would close the Kuwait embassy once all Americans have been evacuated. Not all of the estimated 600 U.S. citizens left in Iraq and Kuwait were expected to leave. Diplomats said about 400 were expected to remain in Iraq, mainly people with dual U.S.-Iraqi citizenship or American spouses of Iraqi citizens. British Embassy officials said about 150 Britons in Iraq and Kuwait intended to stay for various reasons. Saddam on Thursday announced he was letting all Westerners go, and the first flights of people subsequently freed began Sunday. More than 150 freed Americans arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington on Monday, and more than 500 former hostages flew into London. There were other flights to Italy and Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Lived in Squalor Dies with Big Cash in Coffee Cans
DOC.TEXT: A 72-year-old man who lived in a flophouse and shaved his head to save money died with $11,000 hidden in coffee cans and $22,000 in a bank. Charlie Haines rented a grimy $80-a-month downtown apartment, where he was found dead Sunday, apparently of natural causes. His only obvious possessions were a small color television, a collection of hats and a footlocker filled with papers and pictures. ``He probably had the first dime he ever made and he was always worried'' somebody was going to get it, neighbor Ray Church said Monday. A police officer and a deputy coroner found $11,241 in cash in coffee cans, boxes and clothing, authorities said. Haines also had $22,141 in a bank account that hadn't been touched in months. He received a veteran's pension of $563 a month, authorities said. ``He probably lived on $30 a month, did his own cooking and even shaved his own head'' to avoid having to pay for haircuts, Church said. The money was turned over to Spokane County Treasurer Skip Chilberg by Coroner Graham McConnell, who said he found no will and there was no known next of kin in Spokane. Under state law, the money will be held for six years and then forfeited to the state unless an heir is located, Chilberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Exhume Body Suspected of Being Missing Candy Heiress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT by deleting reference to cemetery in forest preserve and CLARIFY that body was buried in different suburb from where it had been found; picks up 3rd graf ``They were ...''
DOC.TEXT: Investigators removed a body from a pauper's cemetery in a southern suburb today and plan to examine it to determine if it is that of candy heiress Helen Brach, who disappeared 13 years ago. Federal, state and county authorities were on the scene in Willow Springs, but officials refused to comment immediately. They were looking for the body of a woman found dead in woods in south suburban Calumet City in 1978, according to reports in the Chicago Tribune. It was not immediately clear whether authorities had exhumed the correct body. ``We developed additional information, which we felt significant enough to warrant a re-examination of the body,'' Jerry Singer, a spokesman for the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said Monday. He declined to describe the new information. Mrs. Brach, heiress to the Brach Candy Co. fortune, disappeared at age 65 in 1977 in Rochester, Minn. Her net worth then was estimated at $17 million. Her estate is now valued at more than $50 million. After she was declared dead in 1984, most of her money went to the Helen Brach Foundation, a charitable trust. Authorities want to conduct genetic testing on the body, although Cook County Medical Examiner Robert J. Stein concluded in 1978 that the body was not Mrs. Brach's. The unidentified body was then buried in a pauper's cemetery. The Tribune, citing unidentified sources, said the dead woman was missing her hands and part of her face, including her teeth. That made it impossible to compare Mrs. Brach's dental records with those of the body. Although Singer declined to describe the new evidence, the Tribune reported the renewed interest in the case stemmed from a federal investigation in Chicago into horse traders suspected of defrauding wealthy people. The newspaper said a former boyfriend of Mrs. Brach's figures in the probe. One theory suggests that Mrs. Brach was slain after she repeatedly complained to authorities that she had been defrauded in the purchase of horses, the newspaper said. Mrs. Brach was the widow of Frank V. Brach, former head of the Brach Candy Co. He died in 1970.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves New Contraceptive Implant
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts graf 5, Susan Dauley, and subs pvs graf 11, The company, with company comment.
DOC.TEXT: A new contraceptive touted by family planning experts as the most effective, reversible method of birth control will soon be available to American women. The Food and Drug Administration approved Norplant on Monday, clearing the way for Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories to begin training health practitioners how to insert the implant that can prevent pregnancy for up to five years. ``It's going to be interesting to watch what kind of reaction Norplant gets among the public and physicians,'' said Jeannie Rosoff, president of the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a research and policy group that focuses on reproductive health issues. ``There are going to be some women for whom this is a godsend. The numbers we don't know yet,'' she said. ``But any new addition that is safe is desirable.'' Susan Dauley, who underwent a test implant six years ago, told a news conference in New York today she decided to do it again. ``It just took a few minutes,'' Mrs. Dauley said. ``You hardly feel anything.'' Family planning experts say Norplant is the first major new contraceptive available to American women in three decades, since the birth control pill was approved in 1960 and a new generation of intrauterine devices, or IUDs, became available around that same time. Norplant was approved in Finland in 1983 and has been approved in 15 countries since then. Half a million women in those countries have used it, according to The Population Council, which developed the device. Norplant consists of six thin, flexible capsules, each about an inch and a third long. They are inserted in a fan-like arrangement under the skin of a woman's inner arm above the elbow. The minor surgical procedure is done in 10 to 15 minutes with local anesthesia in a doctor's office or a clinic. The capsules contain a hormone that is released slowly over five years. The implants can be removed any time and fertility is quickly restored. Norplant is 99 percent effective for women weighing less than 150 pounds. It may be less effective in heavier women, according to the council. It will be marketed by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories of Philadelphia and company officials expect the drug to be available commercially in February. Dr. Marc W. Deitch, medical director at Wyeth-Ayerst, said the company won't discuss the cost of Norplant until it goes on the market, probably in February. But he said it will cost less than five years' worth of birth control pills. ``That's the controlling factor,'' said Dr. Amy Pollack, associate medical director for the Planned Parenthood Federation. C. Wayne Bardin, vice president and director of medical research for The Population Council, said last week he had been told the price would be in the range of $200 to $300, not including the cost of implanting the device. One group for whom Norplant is likely to be popular is women who have had all the children they want but aren't sure they want to be sterilized. Sterilization is the leading method of birth control for married couples in the United States. In 1988, in nearly 40 percent of married couples in which the woman was between 15 and 44, sterilization was used, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. ``Many make that decision (to be sterilized) for lack of another choice,'' Pollack said. Some, however, may not like Norplant's side effect. The major one is menstrual irregularities, including prolonged periods and spotting between periods. About 15 percent of the women who have the implant have it removed because of bleeding, according to the council's studies. Other side effects include occasional headaches, mood changes, nausea and acne, the FDA said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Weighs Direct Aid, Trade Concessions for Soviets
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The White House could unveil an economic assistance package for the Soviet Union as early as Wednesday when President Bush meets with Soviet Foreign Secretary Eduard A. Shevardnadze, administration officials said today. Meanwhile, a U.S. study indicates there is no widespread hunger in the Soviet Union and adequate food supplies exist - if authorities can just get it distributed. Administration officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that an aid proposal that could include emergency food shipments was on Bush's desk awaiting his final approval. It is likely that Bush will want to announce the steps on Wednesday when the Soviet official is here, the sources said. It was not immediately clear what the package would entail, but Bush has been considering lifting trade restrictions in place since 1974 as well as a separate proposal to grant Moscow $2 billion in loan guarantees to buy U.S. food. Furthermore, the package was expected to include emergency medical supplies and possibly direct food shipments - particularly in light of Shevardnadze's request in Houston on Monday for food. An aid package for Moscow ``is being discussed,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Fitzwater noted that Baker and Shevardnadze planned to hold a joint news conference later today and ``I don't want to prejudge any announcements.'' However, other officials said that, while the package might be alluded to at the Baker-Shevardnadze news conference, specific details most likely would not be laid out until Wednesday. The administration said Monday it is considering several ways to help the beleaguered Soviets get through the winter, including direct humanitarian aid as well as waiving longstanding trade restrictions to loosen up credit. Shevardnadze bluntly appealed for U.S. aid before a meeting Monday with Baker. ``We would appreciate, if possible, some food supplies,'' he said in reply to a question from a reporter. ``That is the most acute problem.'' Baker pledged a sympathetic response. ``As far as humanitarian assistance, medical assistance, food and that sort of thing, I know the president will be forthcoming with respect to trying to help,'' the secretary said. Fitzwater said Monday that Bush is considering waiving trade restrictions imposed by the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, which was designed to punish the Soviets for refusing to permit free emigration of Jews. Bush had pledged to hold up granting the Soviets most-favored-nation trade status until the Soviet legislature passes new emigration legislation. But the measure has been tied up for months, partly due to concern among some Soviets that it would lead to a ``brain drain,'' a mass exodus of the troubled country's best-trained people. Nonetheless, Jews are being permitted to leave in record numbers. Fitzwater said the administration was motivated by the Soviets' cooperation in the Persian Gulf crisis and by ``a very serious need in terms of their economy and in terms of their ability to get food supplies'' distributed to Moscow and other major cities. Meanwhile, a top State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a U.S. study of the Soviet consumer goods shortage confirms there is no widespread hunger in the country and that adequate food is available if authorities can get it distributed. ``The medical supply problem is deeper,'' the official said, ``and we're looking at working with private groups to help relieve that situation.'' AmeriCares, a private relief agency, recently announced it was dispatching 40 tons of medical supplies to the Soviet Union. Japan also has promised medical assistance. Although Germany and several other Western European countries are organizing food aid programs, the U.S. government still sees no immediate need for such relief, the official said. Several European countries, following the lead of the Germans, are shipping food to the Soviets despite transportation logjams that have left many tons of supplies sitting on rail sidings with no place to unload. Several leaders have said the aid program is necessary to shore up Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, whose popularity and authority have been battered by the deepening crisis. U.S. observers say the Europeans appear to be motivated at least partly by the fear that severe shortages, coupled with the Soviets' easing of travel restrictions, could cause a mass exodus of people fleeing the Soviet Union for the more prosperous countries of Western Europe. Gorbachev has pledged to crack down on black marketeering and boost food imports to ease the food crisis. He installed a longtime KGB officer and an army general at the top of the Interior Ministry to tighten domestic control in the face of deteriorating order and growing squabbles with the country's 15 republics. And he announced formation of vigilante committees to crack down on theft and diversion of food supplies from established channels.

DOC.HEAD: More Hostages Leaving But Peace Signs Fade
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with three hostage planes leaving Iraq, U.S. and Iraq send more forces. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of foreigners, including about a dozen Americans, left Iraq today as the exodus of hostages drew to a close. But tensions remained high in the Persian Gulf as Iraq and the United States both bolstered their forces. Earlier today, two Iraqi Airways Boeing 707s chartered by Britain brought 240 foreigners, mostly Britons, from Kuwait to the Iraqi capital. A third American charter returned to the Iraqi capitial with only one Irishman and two Canadians aboard. There were no Americans on any of the flights from Kuwait. ``We must have gotten them all,'' said one American consular official, referring to earlier evacuation flights from the emirate and speaking on condition of anonymity. About 160 Japanese, including 14 diplomats from the Japanese Embassy in Kuwait, left Baghdad today on a flight for Bangkok, Thailand. Diplomats said just 14 Americans were on the charter flights that left Baghdad today. Seven were among the 310 people, mostly Britons, on the flight that left for London. Seven more were among the 16 passengers on the American-chartered Iraqi Airways 707 to Frankfurt, Germany. The others included an Irishman, two Canadians and six Britons. The White House said today that Thursday's evacuation flight of Americans from Iraq and Kuwait is ``likely to be the last'' and would probably also carry home the remaining staff of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``We would anticipate that once all Americans who want out have been able to get out that we would remove the entire staff of the embassy,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. In another development today, the Pentagon announced that Iraq has placed 20,000 more troops in and around Kuwait in the past week, expanding the Iraqi armed force in the area to more than half a million soldiers. The United States buildup also is continuing. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said today that an additional 10,000 U.S. troops have arrived in the Persian Gulf area since last week, increasing the total U.S. force there to 260,000. Williams also said that more than 220,000 ground, sea and air forces of other allied nations are arrayed against Iraq. These include forces from Britain, France, Egypt, Syria and several gulf nations, including Saudi Arabia. On Monday, President Bush lashed out at Saddam in a speech clearly aimed at limiting the Iraqi president's publicity gains from releasing foreign hostages. ``What has happened to Kuwait is more than an invasion,'' Bush said. ``It is a systematic assault on the soul of a nation.'' For months after his troops seized Kuwait, Saddam prevented many foreigners from leaving Iraq and Kuwait - sometimes freeing Westerners only after receiving prominent emissaries from abroad. Last week, he said all those who wanted to leave could do so. Iraqi Information Minister Latif Jassim, meanwhile, denied news reports that Baghdad might withdraw from Kuwait if it can keep the southern tip of the Rumailah oil field, which extends for two miles into Kuwait. Before Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, Saddam accused Kuwait of overexploiting the field. ``Kuwait is Iraqi, whether in the past, present or future and we will not compromise one iota on Kuwaiti territory,'' Jassim said. In his condemnation of Iraqi atrocities, Bush drew on the reports of some of the hundreds of foreigners who have left Iraq and Kuwait. They included hostages held as ``human shields'' at strategic sites and men who hid out in Kuwait after the invasion. More than 150 Americans arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington on Monday, and more than 500 other former hostages flew into London. Other flights carried foreigners to Italy and Jordan. The experiences related by the hostages ranged from terrifying to unpleasant to tedious. ``For the most part, it was boring,'' said Gale Rogers, a consular officer at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. With fresh water and electricity cut off by the Iraqis, the Americans were without air conditioning in the summer. The air was ``hot with flies'' in the summer and ``cold with flies'' in the winter, Rogers said. For Tom Kreuzman, 38, of Holiday, Fla., the four-month period included 23 days hiding in a crawl space and eating dry spaghetti. His Scottish terrier, Chu Chu, accompanied Kreuzman through the ordeal but was lost at Baghdad airport on Sunday, he said. ``It's a tragedy,'' said the former U.S. Air Force serviceman, who worked for the Kuwaiti Defense Ministry as a technician on their Hawk missile system. ``She made it that far. She went through a lot with me over there.'' While Iraq says the hostage release does not mean it will leave Kuwait, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said compromise could be reached on the dates for upcoming talks with the United States. Aziz was quoted by The New York Times today as saying Saddam was reconsidering his demand that Secretary of State James A. Baker III visit on Jan. 12. U.S. officials have said Jan. 12 would be too late because it falls three days before the deadline established by the U.N. Security Council for Iraq to quit Kuwait or face the likelihood of being attacked. President Bush proposed the talks on Nov. 30, a day after the U.N. resolution was approved, and Aziz is to travel to Washington this month for talks with Bush. Bush plans to have at least 400,000 troops in the Persian Gulf region by mid-January. The multinational force arrayed against Iraq also includes about 100,000 troops from other nations.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Investigators Say EPA Lax on Cleanup Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators accused auditors at the Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday of not aggressively pursuing potential fraud by private contractors involved in millions of dollars in environmental cleanup programs. But the EPA's inspector general, John Martin, told a House subcommittee he stands by his office's work and said its investigations have led to 250 indictments since 1984 as well as the recovery of $16 million in fines through administrative actions. Investigators for both the House Energy and Commerce Committee and for the General Accounting Office testified that hundreds of EPA contracts have not been audited because of backlogs. And in some cases, they said, questions of possible fraud have not been pursued adequately. Three subcommittee investigators acknowledged, however, that their year-long investigation uncovered no actual proof of fraud or evidence of deliberate wrongdoing by EPA auditors. ``This subcommittee is concerned that the public is not getting its money's worth in environmental protection from these large contract expenditures,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee. The panel's subcommittee on oversight and investigation has been examining complaints about the work of the EPA's inspector general's office for more than a year. A subcommittee report said the findings indicate that the IG's office ``has failed to effectively pursue waste, fraud and abuse'' that may be occurring by the agency's major private contractors. The EPA has contracts with private firms valued at more than $8.6 billion, many of them involving toxic waste cleanup under the Superfund program. The GAO report said that most of EPA's contracts dating back four years have yet to be audited because of a backlog both within the EPA and at the Defense Contract Audit Agency, which handles may of the contract reviews for the agency. The Defense audit agency has 273 outstanding requests for contract audits from the EPA as of the end of last month, with 40 percent of them made more than two years ago, said the GAO investigators. Of the more than $1 billion in contracts between the EPA and six major private contractors between 1983 and 1990, only a small number have ever been audited, said GAO investigator Richard Hembra. Martin, who has been the EPA's inspector general since late 1983, said the congressional investigators ``have not found fraud. ... They have not found anything wrong that we did not find already. ... They found it in our files.'' He strongly defended the agency's office of investigations, saying they ``have no objective other than putting the bad guys in jail.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Ordered To Arrest Ousted President
DOC.TEXT: Police said Tuesday they were ordered to arrest Hussain Muhammad Ershad, the president who was ousted last week in a popular uprising against what opponents called his corrupt government. Police put former Home Minister Mahmudul Hassan, a close aide of Ershad, under house arrest and sought other former Cabinet ministers and top officials in Ershad's government, said a senior police officer. Most of Ershad's close associates went into hiding for fear of mob violence. At least 12 homes were raided by police searching for them, the officer said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Another ranking officer said he expected Ershad to be arrested early Wednesday. It was not clear whether he would be jailed or kept under guard at his exclusive home in the Cantonment, a restricted military area of Dhaka. Ershad, who has been in seclusion, would not accept telephone calls from reporters Tuesday. The former general, who seized power in a 1982 coup, could face charges of subverting the constitution in connection with alleged vote rigging in two parliamentary elections and a presidential election. He may also be accused of unlawful business deals, according to opposition politicians who have pressed for his arrest. As home minister, Mahmudul was in charge of the police and the paramilitary forces that tried to suppress seven weeks of often violent demonstrations seeking Ershad's resignation. A member of Ershad's inner circle, Mahmudul was on the crisis team that advised Ershad to decree a state of emergency on Nov. 27. The measure failed to quell the street protests, and Ershad quit when the army also deserted him. Diplomatic sources estimated 60 people were killed in Dhaka and another 40 in other trouble spots around the country. Most were shot by Mahmudul's security forces. Five policemen armed with rifles Tuesday stood inside the gate of Mahmudul's enclosed home in the luxurious Gulshan district in the capital. Other policemen were on patrol on the street. The caretaker government headed by Supreme Court chief justice Shahabuddin Ahmed has been under intense pressure from political parties and university students to try Ershad on charges of corruption and abusing power during his eight-year rule. But a trial could involve tricky legal questions about presidential immunity and rake up emotions at a time when the country should prepare for its first free election in a decade.
