The interim government is committed to holding a vote within three months. Shahabuddin privately discussed sending Ershad into exile. But the idea met a cool reception from most political parties, which demanded a trial. Sheik Hasina, leader of the powerful Awami League, left the possibility open. ``We want a Bangladesh without Ershad,'' she said Tuesday. ``I don't mind if that is achieved by his arrest and trial or by throwing him out of the country.'' The interim administration has removed civic leaders, heads of public companies and at least three top army officers who were appointed by Ershad or considered close to him.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Composer Completes Mozart's Unfinished Requiem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Saigusa's composition...' to show that Mozart died before completing the work; pickup 4th graf, `One of...'
DOC.TEXT: An Austrian group has chosen a Japanese composer's arrangement of a requiem left unfinished by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart to mark the 200th anniversary of the composer's death, it was announced Tuesday. The International Stiftung Mozarteum, an organization devoted to Mozart research, chose Shigeaki Saigusa's ``Symphonic Concerto for Violin, Viola, Cello and Orchestra.'' It is to be performed Dec. 5, 1991, the anniversary date. Saigusa's composition is a completed version of Mozart's unfinished ``Requiem Mass.'' Mozart was commissioned to write the work in the summer of 1791 but died before completing it. One of his students, Franz Xavier Sussmayr, completed a version of the work after Mozart died later that year. But, said Saigusa, ``Sussmayr's version was written in a style too `romantic' to suit Mozart's composition. ... The Stiftung Mozarteum asked me to write my own version.'' ``I tried to return to his state of mind,'' said Saigusa, one of Japan's foremost composers of classical music. He said his composition will be recorded in May and released next August.

DOC.HEAD: Snake Expelled From School
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT that Swaziland refers to neighboring country, not black homeland within South Africa. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A 12-foot-long python kept armed soldiers at bay after it slithered into a classroom in a primary school in neighboring Swaziland, the South African Press Association reported Tuesday. The news agency said the soldiers were called to the school Monday to remove an ``intruder'' but backed away in shock when they saw the snake. The soldiers, teachers and students watched from a distance as four local men stuffed the python into a sack and took it away. The snake apparently entered the classroom during lessons and was coiled in a corner, gazing at the blackboard, when a student noticed it. Swaziland is a small country surrounded on three sides by South Africa and also bordering Mozambique.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0754, AM-Gulf Costs, transmitted Dec. 10 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Dec. 10 that troops serving in the Persian Gulf are entitled to $110 per week extra in hazardous duty pay. Those payments in fact are $110 per month.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Chief Says Foreign Powers Trying to Destabilize Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the KGB security police said in a nationally televised speech today that foreign powers are backing radicals in the Soviet Union, and he vowed to restore ``law and order.'' ``Forces are striving to achieve power,'' KGB Chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov said in an address that appeared to be the sharpest warning yet that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was planning a major crackdown. ```Democracy' and `glasnost' will just remain beautiful words unless there is law and order in society,'' said Kryuchkov, outlining part of Gorbachev's campaign to curtail corruption and economic crimes. Gorbachev has ordered the KGB and other state security agencies to stem the flow of food and consumer goods from the centralized state distribution system. Authorities claim that the goods are showing up on the black market and that ``speculation'' is responsible for food shortages in the country. Despite the declared end to the Cold War, Kryuchkov seemed to revert to th rhetoric of an earlier era in warning that foreign governments were encouraging radical elements in Soviet society. ``The growing of some ultra-radical movements is not at all accidental but deliberate. Some of them have material and financial support from abroad,'' he said, without saying which foreign countries he was referring to.

DOC.HEAD: Famed British Museum Reading Room Is Saved For Readers
DOC.TEXT: The British Museum's celebrated domed reading room, where Marx, Lenin and Gandhi pondered ways to change the world, will remain the hushed preserve of readers and thinkers, the museum said Tuesday. The announcement ended half a century of argument over the fate of the reading room, beloved by generations of scholars for its cerebral but cozy atmosphere. The reading room's 18 million books will be moved to the new British Library in the next three years, museum director Sir David Wilson announced. But the circular chamber, with its cathedral-style windows and concentric rings of reference-book shelves, will remain a reading room. The room, built in 1857, will even be redecorated in its original 19th-cetury style. ``I hope this will settle the argument,'' Wilson said. The reading room's fate had been uncertain since just after World War II, when the museum proposed to knock down 7{ acres of surrounding historic Bloomsbury for a new library and modern reading room. The plan was quashed by the government in 1967 after objections from residents and conservationists. In 1978, when the government approved building the new British Library, scheduled for completion in the mid-1990s, there was fresh uproar about the potential loss of the reading room. Devotees feared it would become just another display area in the museum, or even face eventual demolition. Academics and writers set up a committee to keep the room as a library and prevent a ``considerable loss of amenity and historic connection.'' Karl Marx and Lenin used the reading room. Lenin's application for a ``reader's ticket'' - needed to use the room - is on display, signed under his alias, Jacob Richter. The reading room was also a haunt of Indian independence leader Mohandas K. Gandhi, playwright George Bernard Shaw, historian Thomas Carlyle and novelist Thomas Hardy. Poet Algernon Swinburne once fainted in the reading room on being ``overcome by the close atmosphere,'' an official recorded. Wilson made his announcement about the reading room's future in unveiling an $155 million plan for using the new space the museum will acquire when the books are moved to the new national library, half a mile away. The redecoration of the room will also include a glass entrance for the public to see in, he said. After the reading room's collection of books is moved, Wilson said some of the 100,000 volumes belonging to the museum's ethnography department would be housed there. He also said books on ``one or two other subjects which are in demand'' would be available in the reading room. And it will be open for study of any of the 8 million objects in the British Museum, he said. The room is shaped like a bicycle wheel, with a circular inquiry desk at the hub. Lines of reading desks radiate outward like spokes, with 300 places for readers. The circular interior wall, under huge windows, has three tiers of books with galleries running around them. Out of sight behind the walls are the 12 million books available to readers. Another 6 million books in the reading room's collection are housed in 16 separate locations in London. All 18 million volumes will be united in the new library, being built at a cost of $953 million.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wins Council Seat By Choosing Right Kiss
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Shipley won a seat on the Amity City Council with a kiss. Shipley, Roberta Lawson, and James Hampton each received four write-in votes in the November election for a council seat that no one campaigned for in this community of 1,000 about 45 miles southwest of Portland. The three-way tie was broken with a kiss in accordance with a state law requiring the council member to be selected by lot. Shipley, 23, drew the winning chocolate Kiss from a sack Monday night. The drawing was delayed for a few minutes while Recorder Karin Johnson searched for the sack she'd brought with two green-wrapped candies and one red. It turned out that one of the council members had eaten the red one. It all worked out, though. Hampton withdrew from the race, leaving two candies and two candidates. Johnson marked one candy with an X, and Shipley drew it. Lawson also won. Later in the meeting, the council appointed her to fill another vacant council seat.

DOC.HEAD: Eight More Americans Evacuated from Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 6 grafs new with more Americans evacuated from Iraq; picks up 4th graf pvs, Meanwhile, those.
DOC.TEXT: Eight Americans boarded a U.S. chartered aircraft today in Iraq, leaving just three remaining to be evacuated so far as is known, State Department officials said. The officials said they believe all other Americans who wanted to leave Iraq and Kuwait have done so. But another flight is scheduled for Thursday to pick up any who may not have made their presence known to U.S. officials. That flight is ``likely to be the last,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``We would anticipate that once all Americans who want out have been able to get out that we would remove the entire staff of the embassy,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Other officials, asking not to be identified, said the three Americans yet to be evacuated all were used as ``human shields'' and have not yet been allowed to leave because of visa problems. No Americans boarded the Boeing 707 in Kuwait today and eight got on in Baghdad, the officials said. The flight then departed for Frankfurt. Meanwhile, those who came back to the United States on Monday said they were relieved to be free after more than four frightening, boring and unpleasant months as captives. ``It feels absolutely great,'' Jack Rinehart, 37, of Stover, Mo., said several hours after he and more than 150 Americans landed at nearby Andrews Air Force Base, Md., on a chartered Pan Am jumbo jet. ``It's great to be back,'' said Dwight Durmon of Fayetteville, Tenn., as he clutched the hand of his wife, Cathy. At the White House today, Fitzwater noted that the second plane load of Americans had left Iraq about noon. He said that those Americans would be flown back to the United States on Wednesday by military charter. The final evacuation flight, now scheduled for Thursday, ``is likely to be the last and it is also likely to be the one to evacuate U.S. Embassy personnel from Kuwait,'' Fitzwater said. While he adhered to a U.S. policy of not revealing the number inside the besieged embassy in Kuwait City, Fitzwater said: ``suffice it to say, it's a small group.'' He said that the United States technically would consider the embassy ``an active and open embassy available for work whenever we should want to do that.'' But, ``from a practical matter, we won't have anyone there to raise the flag,'' he added. ``While the president is very happy to see the individual hostages being released, he has watched some of it on television ... the president shares what I'm sure is everyone's concern and disgust with some of the stories that are being told of harassment and deprivation during their captivity,'' Fitzwater said. ``We watch this process with a certain amount of caution in the sense that it's not completed yet. And we won't be happy until everyone is out,'' he added. The first group of former hostages - some of whom had been held as ``human shields'' at strategic sites in Iraq - left Baghdad on Sunday. They spent the night in Frankfurt, Germany, before coming to the United States. Last week, the Iraqi parliament voted to allow the 8,000 American, European and Japanese hostages to go free. Monday's flight carried 156 people, including four Canadians. Fitzwater refused to say how many Americans remained in Iraq and Kuwait. Ivan Selin, the State Department's undersecretary for management, greeted the evacuees. They then were whisked away - out of sight of hordes of reporters - for private reunions with their families. The ex-hostages spent the night in the capital, and some said they expected to be debriefed by U.S. officials. Rinehart, an electrical engineer who was on a sales trip to Kuwait when Iraqi troops invaded the country Aug. 2, was holed up at the embassy compound for his entire stay. ``I was the camp plumber,'' said Rinehart, explaining how the embassy staff and the private citizens inside kept themselves occupied during the siege. Some people cooked, cleaned and guarded the complex. Rinehart said he helped dig a 14-foot water well. ``For the most part, it was boring,'' said Gale Rogers, a consular officer at the Kuwait embassy. Life at the embassy also was uncomfortable. Without fresh water and electricity, the Americans were without air conditioning in the summer. The air was ``hot with flies'' in the summer and ``cold with flies'' in the winter, Rogers said. The Americans ate mainly rice and tuna fish with different sauces, a diet that caused Rinehart to lose 25 pounds, he said. Rogers, of Arlington, Va., said the Americans were afraid at times, particularly right after the invasion. ``The threat is there all the time if you can't go home and you can't leave,'' he said. But private citizens hiding in Kuwait were even more frightened because they were subject to arrest and could be picked up in house-to-house searches. ``Many are afraid to sleep at night,'' Rogers said. Durmon said that in Iraq, people are afraid of the secret police. ``The secret police there are surveilling you,'' he said. Durmon said he was in Kuwait but later was moved to Iraq. He declined to say what his job was. Those who left Kuwait on Sunday said the country is in chaos with roads destroyed, street lights knocked out and wrecked cars everywhere. ``Everything is broken,'' Rogers said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Station May Await Turn of Century
DOC.TEXT: The new chairman of the House science committee said Tuesday that America's space station will be pushed into the next century if the broad changes sought by the administration's space advisory panel are implemented. Rep. George Brown, D-Calif., called Monday's recommendations of the Advisory Committee on the Future of the U.S. Space Program ``a reasoned, balanced report.'' Both Brown and his Senate counterpart, Al Gore, D-Tenn., plan hearings in January on the study commissioned by NASA and the White House. The report recommended that reliance on the space shuttle be reduced and that plans for Space Station Freedom be scaled down both in scope and mission. It said, too, that NASA should concentrate on science, not engineering spectaculars. NASA already had switched orbital delivery of some cargoes from the space shuttle to unmanned, single-use rockets, and most of the future shuttle missions are dedicated to science. The sixth and last flight of 1990 landed in California early Tuesday after nine days of astronomical observations with four telescopes. It was the 13th mission since flight resumed in 1988. NASA has scheduled seven flights in 1991. Brown, elected by the House Democratic Caucus last week as chairman of the Committee on Science, Space and Technology, said that while the space future report is a good approach, ``I lament that we are still in stage of going through reports, re-evaluations, and redirections when the space program deserves stability and adequate resources.'' In passing the NASA budget for 1991, Congress also demanded that the space station be made smaller and less costly - a move also recommended by the space future panel. NASA is in the midst of a 90-day period of drawing up new designs. ``Another restructuring of the space station is going to make it impossible to maintain the present schedule,'' Brown said. ``It probably means we won't even get started on building the station until the latter years of the '90s and there will be no occupancy until the 21st Century.'' The first shuttle flight to put hardware for the station into orbit had been scheduled for 1995 and the station was to have been permanently manned well before the year 2000. ``This further complicates relationships with our partners in the station, the Japanese, Europeans and Canadians, who need to be fully involved and have to modify their own participation as a result of any changes we make,'' Brown said. The next shuttle mission - to deploy unclassified payloads for the Air Force and the Strategic Defense Organization - is planned for late February or early March, a welcome hiatus to crews that had to handle three flights in as many months. ``After these three, I think Christmas is going to be a real nice break,'' said flight director Bob Castle. ``We'll come back from Christmas and be ready to go.'' The planned 1991 missions include an April trip in which the Gamma Ray Observatory is to be carried into orbit, and in May, a space life sciences laboratory is to ride aboard Columbia. Discovery is to fly in July with another in a series of tracking and data relay satellites, which gather information from other satellites and space shuttles and send it to the ground. Atlantis is to fly in August with several Defense Department payloads on a mission lasting 10 days. Discovery is scheduled again in November with the Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite; and the final launch is that of Atlantis in December, carrying a manned scientific laboratory in its cargo bay. The space future committee was headed by Norman R. Augustine, a veteran aerospace executive who is chairman and CEO of the Martin Marietta Company. Commenting on the report, NASA administrator Richard Truly pointed out that despite leaks that grounded the shuttle and flaws in the Hubble Space Telescope, NASA has averaged one launch in every two months since shuttles returned to flight in 1988. He said it will not be difficult to adopt many of the recommendations in the report. ``Frankly, I believe we are exactly in line with the Augustine report and with Congress,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Leaders Urge National Endowment to Accept Risks
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts has a special responsibility to protect freedom of artistic expression and should support promising new works that might prove risky or unpopular, a nonpartisan forum affiliated with Columbia University said Tuesday. The report by The American Assembly also said the arts community was ill-equipped to deal with the recent controversy over alleged federal support for obscene and blasphemous works that once threatened the NEA's existence. The public affairs forum's report summarized a four-day conference of more than 70 business, government, foundation and arts leaders last month at Arden House in Harriman, N.Y. A copy was made available in Washington. The assembly was directed by Stephen Benedict, former director of Columbia University's graduate program in arts administration, and Steven Lavine, president of the California Institute of the Arts at Valencia. Participants included NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer; John Brademas, president of New York University, and Andrew Heiskell, chairman of the New York Public Library and former chairman of Time Inc. Since the recent battle in Congress over imposing anti-obscenity restrictions on federal arts grants, the forum said, the NEA ``has a specially compelling responsibility to protect freedom of expression, not only for the artists it supports but for every artist.'' The assembly leaders added that ``government policies and private actions that threaten to curb artistic `speech' or to constrict in any way the marketplace of ideas for the arts have no place in American society and must be vigorously opposed.'' The report noted that the NEA controversy was triggered by its grants for exhibitions of sexually explicit photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe and works by artist Andres Serrano that were accused of being anti-religious. ``Government arts programs should support new work of promise that may prove risky or unpopular,'' the forum said. ``Some art has always been controversial and will continue to be, especially as cultures and art forms become more diverse and the boundaries of art continue to expand.'' The assembly leaders said government grants must be administered on the principle that ``no artist's work may be compromised, suppressed or unrecognized because of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual preference, or political or religious beliefs.'' The forum said the arts community must overcome its differences and develop new ways to build the case for public support of the arts. It recommended a coalition with corporate executives willing to serve as arts advocates with all levels of government. ``Arts advocacy can only succeed if all participants in the process refrain from asserting their interests at the expense of others,'' the forum said. In October, Congress repealed strict anti-obscenity curbs on the NEA and voted instead to penalize grant recipients whose federally subsidized works are ruled obscene by the courts. Legislation extending the NEA's statutory authority for three years, with a first-year budget of $174 million, also required the NEA chairman to ensure that grant awards take into account ``general standards of decency.'' Members of the National Council on the Arts, the presidentially appointed advisory body to the NEA, will confer informally this weekend to discuss how the new ``decency'' guideline will affect the endowment's grant-making decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Serbia's Communist Victory Creates New Crisis for Yugoslavia
LaserGraphic
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The Communist victory in Serbia's first free vote since 1938 creates a new crisis for Yugoslavia's unity. The nation's fate hinges on whether the republic's hard-line president chooses dialogue or conflict with his political adversaries in Croatia and Slovenia. The two northern republics' moves for more independence, or even secession, have angered Slobodan Milosevic, who defeated center-right candidates in Serbia's presidential elections Sunday. He is a leader of Serbia's Communists, who renamed themselves the Socialist Party. The Socialists also were leading in Serbia's parliamentary ballot. Milosevic's victory seems certain to widen the political gap between north and south, speeding the drive for independence in the Western-minded republics. It is also likely to keep ethnic Albanians living in the once semi-autonomous Kosovo province under direct Serbian rule. ``We now consider Serbia a sort of foreign partner for negotiation,'' said Slaven Letica, a chief adviser to Croatia's center-right president, Franjo Tudjman. ``We are willing to discuss to try and resolve the Yugoslav crisis and we now consider Milosevic a democratically elected president, but we don't know if he will negotiate with us,'' Letica said. Tudjman's nationalist-oriented Croatian Democratic Union ousted Communists in spring elections in Croatia. He has allied against Milosevic with Slovenia, where center-right government parties also defeated Communists at the polls. The northerners' parliaments have flouted federal laws and proposed transforming Yugoslavia into a loose conferedation with a common market. Serbia favors keeping power centralized in Belgrade, the federal and Serbian capital. Before year's end, Croatia is to adopt a new constitution that would pave the way for independence. Slovenia holds a plebiscite Dec. 23 on whether to stay in the federation. The vote is seen as a last bargaining card to force Serbia to negotiate on decentralization. A survey published in Slovenia's leading daily, Delo, following Serbia's Sunday election indicated that 90 percent of Slovenians plan to vote in the referendum. Only 1 percent said they opposed independence. ``People here invested a lot of hope in those elections, hoping things would change,'' Zoran Thaler, Slovenia's deputy foreign minister, said of the Serbian balloting. ``Now we see it won't be different.'' Yugoslavia was formed from the wreckage of the Hapsburg and Ottoman empires in 1918 as the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes. It held its last free elections in 1938. The nation was reassembled during World War II as a communist republic. Only single-party elections were held after 1943. Like the rest of the Balkans, Yugoslavia is plagued by ancient, unresolved ethnic conflicts, exacerbated by historic and economic divisions. Milosevic has ruled Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, with a firm hand since late 1987. Before Sunday's election, he refused to publicly acknowledge the possibility of the federation's break-up or discuss the issue with Slovenia and Croatia. It's unclear whether he will talk now with Tudjman or Slovenia's president, Milan Kucan. ``We don't know if Milosevic after the elections will be the same Milosevic as before the elections,'' said one central European diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. Western diplomats say Serbia might agree to Slovenian secession to deprive Croatia of a political ally. It would be possible for tiny alpine Slovenia, whose 2 million people are ethnically homogeneous, to make a clean break without raising the country's ethnic tensions to a boiling point. But Croatia, home to 500,000 ethnic Serbs, could not. A secession attempt could push the southern Slavs into civil war. Milosevic has said any attempts by Croatia to pull out of the federation would force Serbia to redraw its borders to protect its minorities. The central republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina, whose patchwork population of Serbs, Croats and Moslems make it a miniature Yugoslavia, likely would split along national lines in an armed conflict. ``Yugoslavia has always seemed able to pull itself back from the brink of self-destruction, but maybe not this time,'' said a Western diplomat. The federal army, whose officer corps is dominated by Serbs and their traditional allies from Montenegro, has indicated it could intervene in Slovenia to preserve federal unity. Slovenia's government controls only a small local militia and plans to appeal for Western diplomatic assistance if that happens. But anything other than symbolic help is unlikely. ``If (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev sent troops into the Baltics, the West wouldn't lift a finger, so why should they help us?'' said a Slovenian government official who also spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian President Sees Winter Showdown With Moscow
With AM-US-Soviet Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president said Tuesday that Moscow will try to bring his rebellious republic to its knees this winter by cutting off all supplies of food and raw materials. President Vytautas Landsbergis told a news conference that Soviet officials have informed his government that food, fodder, energy and material shipments to Lithuania will end on Jan. 1, ostensibly because of shortages in the Soviet Union. ``All forces and all measures are going to be used to destabilize the situation in Lithuania and force it to remain part of the Soviet Union. They hope General Winter will be on their side,''Landsbergis said. He said citizens in his Baltic state have begun storing reserves for expected shortages and ``I am convinced this winter is going to be a decisive one in our struggle.'' Landsbergis met Monday with President Bush and was meeting Vice President Dan Quayle on Tuesday to appeal for U.S. support in Lithuania's drive to cast off Soviet rule and become an independent state. Bush restated U.S. policy urging self-determination for the Baltic states and a peaceful settlement to their differences with Moscow. Landsbergis said he was confident Bush would not sacrifice Lithuania to keep Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in power. Asked if Washington might overlook the Soviet use of force against Lithuania in its eagerness to hold together the anti-Iraq coalition, he said, ``especially after my meeting with President Bush, I have absolutely no basis to think that way.'' But Landsbergis also criticized the West in general for failing to see Soviet pressure against Lithuania as an act of aggression. He said the West gave in to the Soviets in not allowing the three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia to send representatives to a 35-nation European conference in Paris two weeks ago. He compared the situation in Lithuania, which was invaded and annexed by Stalin in 1940, with that of occupied Kuwait. ``No one believes Saddam Hussein when he says Kuwait is eternally going to be part of Iraq,'' he said. Last March the Lithuanian parliament voted to declare independence from Moscow, which followed by imposing an economic embargo on Lithuania that lasted about three months. The latest dispute erupted in November when the three Baltic states rejected a Soviet plan that would give Moscow control over budgetary, financial and tax matters and require that almost all foreign currency earnings be turned over to the central government. Landsbergis said the dispute is behind the latest boycott threat. ``There is no question that people will suffer'' if another blockade is enforced, he said, adding he hoped ``assistance from the West will not be limited to the sending of medicine.'' Landsbergis also expressed concern about Gorbachev's appointment earlier this month of former KGB general Boris Pugo to the interior minister's post. He said Pugo, considered a hardliner, represents ``a group of people for whom the survival of the empire is much more important than social and economic reforms.'' Landsbergis said he planned to meet Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov in Moscow Thursday. He said he would discuss the threatened economic blockade, but that his primary purpose would be to lay the groundwork for stalled negotiations with Moscow on the republic's eventual independence.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Shevardnadze to Meet with Shamir
With US-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will meet in Washington with Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, a move that could enhance relations between the two countries, U.S. officials said here today. Shevardnadze is winding up two days of meetings here with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. One of the main topics is the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The Soviets have held out the prospect of resuming normal relations with Israel after a 23-year break. They have exchanged diplomats but formal ties remain broken since the 1967 Mideast war. The session will give Shevardnadze a chance to try to persuade Shamir to agree, at least in principle, to a Mideast peace conference. The prime minister objects, arguing that the Soviets might line up with the Arabs and try to impose unacceptable terms on Israel. Shevardnadze and Baker, changing plans, decided to head back to Washington Tuesday night instead of Wednesday morning. One reason, said the U.S. officials who demanded anonymity, was to give Shevardnadze more time to get to see Shamir, who visited President Bush today. Baker will meet with Shamir Thursday. The Bush administration has stood alongside Israel in trying to forestall a drive by Arab and neutral governments to hold a peace conference in which the Palestinians' complaints against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza could be considered. Baker has said a conference would be useful only ``at an appropriate time'' and ``properly structured.'' He said those circumstances were not right at this point. Also, Baker wants to avoid linking the Israeli-Palestinian dispute with the U.S.-led drive to force Iraq to leave Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actors Bruce Willis and Demi Moore are expecting a second child next year. Willis and Miss Moore, who married in 1987, already have a daughter, 2-year-old Rumer, and are thrilled at the prospect of another child, publicist Paul Bloch said Tuesday. ``Both parents are very, very happy and very excited about it,'' said Bloch. They were one of the most successful husband-wife acting teams in Hollywood this year with a pair of box office hits - Willis in ``Die Harder'' and Miss Moore in ``Ghost.'' Willis' next movie, ``The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' will be released next week. --- INDIANAPOLIS (AP) - David Letterman often torments his ``Late Night'' guests, but his attitude is completely different toward sick and handicapped children in his hometown. Letterman quietly gave money to Roncalli High School last month for construction of a wheelchair ramp. His attorney, Ron Elberger of Indianapolis, asked that the amount not be disclosed. ``My understanding is that it came straight out of his pocket,'' said Roncalli Principal Joseph Hollowell. ``His attorney dropped by and left a check.'' Individual donations and fund drives raised $45,000 to buy a wheelchair lift for the multi-level high school. Letterman attended a different school. Letterman also sponsors a summer camp for children with cerebral palsy. ``Mr. Letterman sometimes calls the children, or writes them a letter. And they're personally written letters, too,'' said Kirby Gamber of United Cerebral Palsy of Central Indiana. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Singer Brenda Lee sang 10 seconds of her ``Rockin' Around the Christmas Tree'' during a surprise birthday call Tuesday to her from Mayor Bill Boner, who was serving as host of a live radio show. Lee, who turned 46, was called at home by Boner, host this week of a two-hour morning talk show on WLAC-AM. At his request, she briefly sang the beginning of ``Rockin' Around the Christmas Tree.'' Boner told her he would not ask her age. ``What a gentleman you are,'' she said. --- DUE WEST, S.C. (AP) - Country singer K.T. Oslin's latest song appears to be all about a local resident named Cornell Crawford, but Crawford isn't talking. Crawford he does admit that he ``could be the one'' referred to in Ms. Oslin's song ``I Ain't Never Gonna Love Nobody But Cornell Crawford.'' Ms. Oslin said she based the lyrics on words from neatly written graffiti she found on a restroom wall 15 years ago during a concert tour stop at Erskine College in this town of 1,200 in western South Carolina. After Ms. Oslin told her story on Arsenio Hall's talk show, retired Erskine history professor Lowery Ware launched a search and found Due West resident Cornell Crawford, now in his mid-40s and happily married with a family. Crawford said he had never heard of the note on the wall or the song until he read a story in his newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Servicemen In Desert Shield Celebrate Hanukkah Discreetly
DOC.TEXT: Jewish servicemen in the U.S.-led multinational force celebrated the first night of Hanukkah on Tuesday shielded from the media to avoid offending Saudi Arabia. Religion has been a delicate issue for U.S. military forces in Saudi Arabia, where all religions except Islam are banned. Chaplains have been renamed morale officers and all religious services have been conducted in private. ``Hannukah will be celebrated in Operation Desert Shield,'' said Army Col. William Mulvey, head of the U.S. military's Joint Information Bureau. ``Hanukkah services are well organized and we anticipate they will be well attended by U.S. military personnel. Of course, in the kingdom of Saudi Arabia, worship services are being held in a discreet manner,'' he said. In addition to Saudi sensitivities, there is concern the Iraqis could use any pictures of Hanukkah celebrations as propaganda against Arab nations contributing to the mutinational force deployed in Saudi Arabia. One Jewish soldier at the U.S. Navy's Fleet No. 5 Hospital got assurances last week that candles would be provided for Hanukkah. Each night of the eight-day celebration, another candle is lighted on the menorah. Hanukkah commemorates the rededication of the Temple of Jerusalem by the Macabees after their victory over the Syrians.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani: Multinational Forces Must Withdraw
DOC.TEXT: The Iranian president reiterated Tuesday that U.S.-led forces must withdraw from Saudi Arabia and said the Persian Gulf crisis should be solved by the gulf states. Tehran radio said Hashemi Rafsanjani's comments came in his first round o talks with visiting Sudanese leader Lt. Gen. Omar el-Bashir. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Rafsanjani as calling for an ``unconditional withdrawal'' of foreign forces in the region. ``This crisis must be resolved by the Persian Gulf states, and foreign forces must leave the area as soon as possible,'' the radio quoted him as saying. Iran has condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But it also has opposed deployment of the multinational force in Saudi Arabia. ``Establishing security in the Persian Gulf and attempting to find a fundamental solution in order to prevent a devastating war ... is one of the main duties of the regional and Moslem states,'' Rafsanjani was quoted as telling Bashir. Bashir arrived in Tehran on Monday for a four-day official visit.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Stumbles Into Program: `Chevy Chase Has Arrived'
DOC.TEXT: Preparations had been carefully made for President Bush to launch the Transportation Department's new advertising campaign against drunken driving. A lectern had been moved to center stage in the auditorium of the Old Executive Office building. An aide produced the presidential seal and carefully placed it. The lights were raised. The Secret Service arrived. Then a door opened and the president entered. And walked into a large advertising poster on a raised stand. Arms flailing, he nearly knocked it to the floor. Bush recovered and walked to the lectern. ``Chevy Chase has arrived,'' he announced, as the audience laughed. That was a reference to the comedian who specialized in extravagant pratfalls in comic imitation of former President Gerald R. Ford's alleged clumsiness.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Widens 13.9 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The nation's foreign trade deficit, hurt by higher oil prices and increased military spending from the Persian Gulf crisis, widened a sharp 13.9 percent in the July-September quarter, the government said Tuesday. The Commerce Department said the $25.6 billion third quarter deficit was up from a second quarter deficit of $22.5 billion. It was the largest quarterly imbalance since a $26.7 billion gap in the final three months of 1989. The new report covered the current account, which is considered the most important yardstick of the country's international performance because it measures not only trade in merchandise but also trade in services and investment flows between countries. The higher deficit in the July-September quarter was viewed as especially ominous because an improving trade balance had been the only bright spot in a lackluster economy this year. A rising trade deficit would make the recession many economists believe has already started even steeper by removing the strength that export growth has provided to the manufacturing sector over the past several years. ``A lot of people are looking to exports as the key to moderating the severity of the recession and helping to pull the country out of the downturn,'' said Howard Lewis, a trade expert at the National Association of Manufacturers. Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, predicted the trade deficit for this year would hover around $100 billion and would remain stuck at that level in 1991 as well. Before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices soaring, some analysts had forecast that the trade deficit for this year could drop as low as $90 billion, which would have been the smallest imbalance since 1983. For the third quarter, the primary weakness came from a 29 percent jump in the merchandise trade deficit, which rose to $29.75 billion as imports hit an all-time high. More than half of the increase in imports reflected higher petroleum prices. Another factor contributing to the increase in the third quarter deficit was a rise in direct spending for U.S. military operations overseas, which climbed to $4.31 billion, a 17 percent increase reflecting the troop buildup in the Middle East. That increase lowered the overall services balance to $5.8 billion in the third quarter. In one bright spot in the report, the balance on investment earnings shifted into a surplus of $2.46 billion, reflecting improved earnings by Americans on their overseas investments. That had been in deficit by $1 billion in the second quarter. The other component of the current account, unilateral transfer payments, primarily foreign aid payments and government pension payments to Americans living overseas, increased the deficit by $4.11 billion in the third quarter. The current account trade deficit is closely watched because it translates directly into the amount of money America must borrow from overseas to cover the shortfall between what the United States exports in goods and services and what it imports. A decade ago, America was the largest creditor nation. It ran surpluses in its current account as the earnings from its overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade. But as Americans handed over billions of dollars to foreigners to pay for imported merchandise, the investment cushion eroded and disappeared altogether in 1985 when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. That means foreigners now own more in U.S. assets than Americans own overseas. At the end of 1989, the country's net debtor position was put at $663.7 billion and economists believe that figure will grow by another $100 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: Projected Cotton Crop Rises
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 cotton crop is expected to be almost 15.4 million bales, up 3 percent from prospects a month ago, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. ``Harvest proceeded with little interruption during November,'' the department's Agricultural Statistics Board reported. ``Yields and grades in the High Plains were good to excellent, and Louisiana's production is a record high level.'' The latest forecast, based on Dec. 1 indications, is up 26 percent from last year's cotton output of less than 12.2 million bales. Upland cotton accounted for 15.01 million bales of the Dec. 1 estimate, and American-Pima, or extra-long staple, 395,900 bales, the report said. The indicted 1990 production of upland cotton as of Dec. 1, included: Alabama, 400,000 bales and 383,000 last year. Arizona, 800,000 and 649,000. Arkansas, 1,100,000 and 851,000. California, 2,800,000 and 2,661,000. Florida, 46,100 and 29,000 (carried over from previous forecast.) Georgia, 380,000 and 342,000. Louisiana, 1,200,000 and 868,000. Mississippi, 1,850,000 and 1,555,000. Missouri, 305,000 and 269,000. New Mexico, 80,000 and 80,000. North Carolina, 260,000 and 141,000. Oklahoma, 350,000 and 173,000. South Carolina, 145,000 and 154,000. Tennessee, 490,000 and 476,000. Texas, 4,800,000 and 2,870,000.

DOC.HEAD: Barriers Remain in Asia, Latin America for U.S. Banks
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department said Tuesday that despite progress in Canada and Europe in easing barriers to U.S. financial institutions, serious obstacles remain in Japan and some other Asian and Latin American countries. ``Progress in reducing barriers abroad is occurring at a varied pace, but generally not as rapidly as the Treasury would like,'' Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in a report to Congress on foreign treatment of U.S. financial institutions. The 506-page National Treatment Study describes how U.S. firms are permitted to operate overseas, particularly whether they are able to operate on equal grounds with their domestic competitors. ``Significant progress has been made in Canada and most European countries and within the European Community,'' Treasury Undersecretary David C. Mulford told reporters at a briefing. But he said that ``while there's been some progress in Japan, it has been disappointingly slow and incomplete as of this time and fundamental problems still remain. ``In other Asian countries such as Korea and Taiwan, progress has been inadequate and serious barriers to U.S. financial firms exist,'' he continued. ``We are concerned about denials of national treatment in Latin America.'' The study describes national treatment as ``equality of competitive opportunity.' It notes the United States long has been a strong advocate of the principal and the``free international movement of goods, services and capital.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Jan. 14 Trial for Marlon Brando's Son
DOC.TEXT: The murder trial of Marlon Brando's son was scheduled for January, although a defense lawyer said key prosecution witness is confined under a suicide watch in a Tahiti hospital. Christian Brando made a brief court appearance Tuesday and answered, ``Yes,'' when Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas asked if he agreed to have his murder trial postponed to Jan. 14. The trial was first set for Nov. 5. A hearing is expected later this month to determine whether another judge will request for French assistance in returning Christian Brando's 20-year-old sister from the Polynesian territory to testify in his trial. Defense attorney Robert Shapiro told reporters Tuesday that Cheyenne Brando, who was with her brother in the hours before he shot her Tahitian lover, has been placed in isolation. The trial date was set after Miss Brando's mother was named as her guardian. ``She is being confined in an isolated unit because another suicide is contemplated,'' Shapiro said. ``She's a danger to herself. ... This is a person I couldn't anticipate would be a competent witness in this or any other proceeding.'' Prosecutors, however, said they have learned that Miss Brando was declared ``incapacitated,'' rather than incompetent by the Tahitian court that appointed her guardian. They indicated this signals a temporary condition rather than a permanent one. Miss Brando's family has said she took a drug overdose and recovered, but two weeks later hanged herself, only to be saved by her mother before she died. Christian Brando, 32, told police he accidentally shot Dag Drollet, 26, during a struggle May 16 at the actor's mansion. Miss Brando fled to Tahiti a month after Drollet's death and gave birth to his child. She has refused to return to California to testify. Authorities in Tahiti also have barred her exit, charging her as an accomplice in Drollet's slaying. Miss Brando's version of events has never been clear. She has given at least five depositions in the United States and Tahiti, but Shapiro says they have contained conflicting accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Says Arce Gomez Organized Bolivia For Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: A former Bolivian interior minister organized his country as a for-profit cocaine haven, federal prosecutors said Tuesday as they opened their drug trafficking case against Luis Arce Gomez. Attorneys for Arce Gomez countered that he was ``hard on drugs'' and had made powerful enemies for his anti-corruption efforts. Arce Gomez, a colonel in the Bolivian army in the early 1980s and minister of the interior in what was then the country's military government, was indicted on drug-trafficking charges in 1983. Prosecutor Michael P. Sullivan told the jurors that Arce Gomez and others in Bolivia and the United States conspired in 1980 to import and distribute cocaine into the United States, with Bolivian government figures being paid for protecting trafficking. Sullivan said testimony would come from Arce Gomez co-defendant and former lieutenant Herland Echeverria Barrancos, 39, who pleaded guilty Monday in a plea bargain to one count of conspiracy to import drugs. Echeverria's job was to arrange protection and collect money from traffickers, prosecutors said. Defense attorney Stephen Finta described Arce Gomez, 52, as a very popular leader dedicated to his country. But Arce Gomez made enemies when he became interior minister because he fought corruption after his ``predecessors regarded the ministry as their own private piggybank,'' Finta said. Arce Gomez was also tough on drug traffickers, Finta said, and advocated the death penalty for them. Arce Gomez was extradited to the United States last December on the 1983 drug-trafficking indictment. But the case was quickly overshadowed by the invasion of Panama and the arrest of former Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega. Arce Gomez is also charged with human rights violations in Bolivia, allegedly organizing death squads with the help of Klaus Barbie, the Nazi ``Butcher of Lyon'' later extradited to France as a war criminal. The first prosecution witness called was Alex Pacheco, a confessed drug dealer who allegedly plotted with Arce Gomez and others to bring about the 1980 military coup that overthrew Bolivia's civilian government. Pacheco said his job was to arrange for protection payments from cocaine traffickers. In the indictment, Arce Gomez, Echeverria and 17 others were accused of accepting as much as $75,000 every two weeks to look the other way as drug traffickers moved in and out of Bolivia, a prime source of coca. They also allegedly seized cocaine from uncooperative traffickers, and once took $1.5 million for releasing confiscated cocaine held in Bolivian government vaults, investigators say. Arce Gomez was forced out of the military government in 1981 under U.S. pressure, and fled to Argentina. He left that country after its military government fell, and was arrested on a ranch at Santa Cruz, Bolivia. Bolivian authorities immediately flew him to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Balloon Crash
LaserPhoto CO6
DOC.TEXT: A hot air balloon floated over downtown office buildings up to 42 stories tall but then struck a 1,069-foot broadcast tower, ripped and crashed Tuesday, killing all four people aboard. The bodies of three men and a woman, all experienced pilots, were found in the balloon's crumpled gondola about 200 yards from the WBNS television tower, said Highway Patrol Lt. Randy Thatcher. People who saw the balloon said they had feared it wasn't high enough to clear the tower. ``I'd been watching it from work when it came over town, and it looked like it was losing (altitude),'' said firefighter David Roe, who saw the accident from the fire department's medical training center about a mile away. ``It started climbing at a steep angle and looked like it would be OK, so I turned around to go back to my job. Then the secretary screamed, `Oh my God! It hit the tower!' and I saw it was going down,'' Roe said. John Remy, a reporter for radio station WTVN-AM, said he was on his way to work when he saw the balloon hit the tower. ``I was sort of watching this balloon, and I said to myself, `It looks awful close to the tower,' but that's just my line of sight,'' he said. ``But then it hit it, popped and just burst into shreds.'' The balloon took off shortly after 8 a.m. from a field near Mohawk Middle School, just southeast of downtown. It went northwest over downtown buildings up to 42 floors high. It crashed about 20 minutes after takeoff less than three miles from the school. WBNS officials said the accident did not disrupt broadcasting. The station switched to an auxiliary tower while a steeplejack removed a piece of green balloon fabric that fluttered from the top of the tower. The victims were members of the 75-member Central Ohio Balloon Club, said club member Robert Nezey of Columbus. ``I can't tell you what happened in that balloon. Nobody can. I do know that these were very experienced, good people in there,'' Nezey said. Killed were Doug Shirey, 27, of Circleville; and Scott Meeker, 26; Kathy Nemis, 20, and Eric Ingwersen, 31, all of Columbus. Authorities did not know who was at the controls at the time of the crash. Doyne Shirey said his brother was fascinated with flying. ``If he had the opportunity, he flew - every chance he got - in a balloon, helicopter, it didn't matter,'' Shirey said. The balloon was owned by the Bogey Inn, a restaurant in Delaware County north of Columbus.

DOC.HEAD: After Winning Landmark Case, Abused Woman Still Fears For Her Safety
DOC.TEXT: A Connecticut woman whose assault by her husband generated a landmark damage award said Tuesday that ``he's going to find me'' when he is released from prison, perhaps as early as next year. ``I fear most of all that by being in prison this long, it's only made him more of an animal and more angry,'' Tracey Motuzick of Torrington, Conn., told the Senate Judiciary Committee while testifying on behalf of legislation designed to stiffen protections against domestic violence. ``Because of what I've experienced with him, I know he's going to find me,'' said Motuzick. Motuzick, formerly Tracey Thurman, won a $2.6 million judgment with her then-infant son after claiming in 1985 that Torrington police violated her rights by failing to protect her from her estranged husband, Charles. She was left partially paralyzed after he stabbed her 13 times on June 10, 1983, and kicked her in the head. The damage award was reduced to $1.97 million in negotiations after the police officers appealed, said her attorney, Burton Weinstein. Thurman's attorney said during a parental rights dispute a few years ago that the defendant had no intention of harming his former wife after his release. The case was the subject of a 1989 television movie called ``A Cry for Help: The Tracey Thurman Story.'' The original verdict was heralded as a landmark for battered women by the National Organization for Women, and was considered by attorneys to be the first time a federal court allowed a wife to sue police for damages in a domestic dispute. Charles Thurman was sentenced to 15 years in prison for the assault. But, with time off for good behavior, his release date is listed as December 1991 by state corrections officials. He may also face at least several months more for a 1981 probation violation, officials said. Weinstein said in telephone interview Tuesday that ``I'm going to do my best to build the tightest fence possible, and appropriate security measures will be taken. We will take every precaution.'' Motuzick testified on behalf of a bill drafted by Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., which would make it a federal crime to cross state lines to continue spousal abuse; provide new funding for battered women shelters; and make ``stay-away'' orders enforceable in states other than the one where the order originated. Her voice quavered when Motuzick told the panel, ``My son and I will always be affected by what happened to us. But this was preventable if the police had taken my calls seriously.'' Motuzick sat at a witness table next to Charlotte Fedders, whose spousal abuse case was also the subject of a television movie, as well a book. Herhhusband, John, is the former enforcement chief of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Fedders said she endured 17 years of black eyes, bruises and a broken ear drum. ``Domestic violence occurs in all economic, cultural, racial and religious groups,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Dip 1.6 Cents A Gallon
DOC.TEXT: The average national pump price of regular unleaded gasoline dropped 1.6 cents a gallon to $1.371 for the week ending Tuesday, the American Automobile Association reported. AAA said the decline was the first since Nov. 20, when the price fell 2.6 cents. The price Tuesday remained 29.6 cents above the level of Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and sent oil prices higher, the AAA said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Boosts Campaign Against Drunken Driving
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying drunken driving has created a national crisis of deaths and injuries, helped launch a public-service advertising campaign on Tuesday to promote the message: ``Friends don't let friends drive drunk.'' Bush told an audience of business, advertising and safety officials gathered in the Old Executive Office Building that getting drunken and drugged drivers off the streets and highways is one of the key goals of his administration. ``It is time for the American people to remember that drinking and driving are a deadly combination,'' the president said. The advertising campaign, developed by the Department of Transportation and The Advertising Council, Inc., includes video spots of coffins, grave stones, grieving relatives and friends and features a repeated theme that friends should get involved when friends have had too much to drink. ``Take the keys. Call a cab. Take a stand. Friends don't let friends drive drunk,'' is the repeated message. ``I can't think of a better gift to a friend this holiday season,'' said Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. Jerry Ralph Curry, head of the Transportation Department's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said 22,425 people were killed and 345,000 injured in alcohol-involved crashes last year. ``Every 23 minutes there is an alcohol related traffic fatality in the United States,'' Skinner said. ``This campaign encourages all of us to take personal responsibility for stopping these needless deaths.'' The campaign, produced for the ad council by the agency of Wells, Rich, Greene, includes three television announcements, six radio spots and print and outdoor advertising. The announcement of the ad campaign was a part of the annual observance of the Transportation Department's Drunk and Drugged Driving Week which is held in advance of the holiday season. This year it is being observed Dec. 9-15.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
Quadriplegic Dependent on Ventilator Begins One-Year Experiment at Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: VanderEls in 11th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Jenny Langley already has received the only Christmas present she wants this year. On Monday, Ms. Langley moved out of a hospital and into her own home. Left paralyzed and dependent on a ventilator from two accidents, Ms. Langley, 27, has begun a one-year experiment to test whether a ventilator-dependent quadriplegic can live outside an institution successfully and economically. ``I'm so happy to be here. It's going to be a great Christmas,'' said Ms. Langley. With a $65,000 grant from the Shepherd Spinal Center in Atlanta, Ms. Langley wants to show state officials they could save money by providing quadriplegics with independent care at home rather than paying to keep them in nursing homes or hospitals. The Georgia Department of Medical Assistance for the first time next year will seek funds to allow quadriplegics to live at home rather than in an institution. Six states - Oregon, Maine, Illinois, California, Minnesota and Rhode Island - offer funding for disabled people who choose to live at home, Shepherd officials said. Deputy Commissioner Russell Toal said the medical assistance department is asking for $584,000 for fiscal year 1992 to begin an independent care program for 24 quadriplegics for six months. ``It's something that's been needed for a long time,'' Toal said. ``I think we need to give them the opportunity to live on their own.'' A 1976 diving accident left Ms. Langley paralyzed from the waist down at age 14. Ten years later, an auto accident paralyzed her from the neck down and made her dependent on a ventilator. Ms. Langley's parents went broke trying to care for her. Their Yatesville home was sold on the auction block in July to satisfy an unpaid bank loan. Ms. Langley was admitted to Shepherd this summer with respiratory problems, and she was planning to live in a $675-a-day South Carolina nursing home when she recovered. ``We're really excited about this situation for Jenny. It's so much better than the other placements we've had to do,'' said Shepherd resource director Leigh VanderEls. Ms. Langley has a $125-a-day budget with which she'll pay for rent, utilities, food and part-time attendants. Sheryl Langley, Jenny's 33-year-old sister, and her two daughters will live with Jenny in the three-bedroom, $750-a-month brick house about 30 minutes south of Atlanta. ``I don't know what I would do if I had to live in a nursing home,'' Jenny Langley said. ``People who have their minds don't deserve to just be put away. They have a right to live.'' Quadriplegic Larry McAfee, a 34-year-old Atlanta resident who waged a highly publicized court fight last year to win the right to shut off his life-sustaining respirator, said he is inspired by Ms. Langley's move. ``Tell her I said good luck. It's fantastic,'' said McAfee, who remains on a respirator and plans to move in January from an Atlanta hospital into an Augusta personal-care home with two or three other quadriplegics. McAfee has lived in several hospitals or nursing homes since a 1985 motorcycle accident left him paralyzed from the neck down. ``Anytime you can get away from an institutional setting, it's more stimulating. It allows you the freedom to live,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Amazon Town Gears Up for Chico Mendes' Murder Trial
LaserPhoto XAP2
DOC.TEXT: From politicians in chartered planes to peasants on horseback, thousands have converged on this village deep in the Amazon for a murder trial that some say could shape the future of the world's largest rain forest. Two cattle ranchers accused of killing union leader and renowned Amazon defender Chico Mendes are expected to go on trial beginning Wednesday, nearly two years after Mendes was gunned down. But already, the village of pastel-colored wood cabins about 2,650 miles miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro is buzzing with speculation and a sense of fear over the final judgment. Local residents, many of whom survive by harvesting rubber and nuts from the forest, see the trial as symbolizing the battle between the poor seeking collective use of the rain forest against landowners, and ranchers who want to cut it down. Private and government development efforts in the Amazon region have intensified since 1980, and estimates on deforestation range from from about 5 percent to 12 percent. The rain forest, about twice the size of Alaska, is the only habitat for many of the world's plant and animal species. ``This is a historic trial, not only in Brazil but in the world,'' said chief prosecution lawyer Marcio Thomaz Bastos. ``In Brazil, it is a test case of reckless lawlessness. And for the whole world, it is an indicator of whether or not man will allow the Amazon to be destroyed.'' Mendes, a 44-year-old rubber tapper who led a movement to stop destruction of the rain forest, was killed by a shotgun blast on Dec. 22, 1988, as he stepped out of the back door of his humble wood house in Xapuri. Rancher Darly Alves da Silva and his 23-year-old son, Darci, are charged with planning and executing the crime. They were being held in the Acre state prison in Rio Branco, the capital of this far western Amazon state. The two were to be flown to Xapuri by helicopter under heavy guard. About 2,000 peasants from all over the region are descending on this town in canoes, mule-drawn carts, on horseback and on foot. People are setting up tents, hammocks and mattresses in the spare rooms or porches of relatives or friends. Rubber tappers traveled up the Acre River more than 50 miles to attend the trial. ``If Darly and Darci are found not guilty, only God will be able to save our town in the rain forest,'' said Raimundo da Silva Maia, a 51-year-old tapper. Hundreds of politicians, including some government officials and many representatives of leftist Workers Party of which Mendes was a member, began to arrive late Tuesday aboard chartered planes and buses from Rio Branco, 110 miles away. More than 100 state troopers were flown in to prevent violence between ranchers, residents and rubber tappers. Roadblocks of heavily armed police were set up along the muddy, rutted road that connects Xapuri to Rio Branco. Judge Adair Longhini said at least a dozen heavily armed troopers would surround the small wooden courthouse near the main square. But many residents doubted the security measures would be enough to guarantee a violence-free trial. ``We're worried the trial will trigger violence, not stop it,'' said Ilzamar Mendes, the widow of Chico Mendes. ``Darly has had messages sent to us saying he would take his revenge whether he was released or not,'' she said. In the meantime, the town is bustling to accommodate the crush of visitors. Brand-new public telephones are sprouting on street corners. Sidewalk curbs, park benches and trees trunks are getting fresh coats of green and white paint. Banners are strung over the brick streets reading ``Justice for All'' and ``Save the Amazon.'' ``We are waiting to see if justice will finally be served, '' said Amini de Carvalho Santana 26, a drugstore clerk. ``The forest and the people who live in it will be destroyed without justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Vail Makes Snow With Treated Sewage Water
DOC.TEXT: It's safe enough to ski on but authorities say it's not a good idea to eat any of the snow from Vail's snowmaking operations, which use water that is partly from treated sewage. Water intakes for snowmaking in the Rocky Mountains resort 70 miles west of Denver are less than 100 yards downstream from a sewage plant's outflow into Gore Creek. When the creek runs low, regulators let Vail's snowmaking crews take only the same amount of water from the creek that the sewage plant is pumping in. As a result, state officials say, one-third to two-thirds of Vail's manmade snow is water from the sewage plant. ``Would I eat that snow? Knowing what I know? Probably not,'' said Jay Skinner, a Colorado Division of Wildlife official who monitors resort snowmaking and its effect on streams. ``I know it should be treated OK, but I wouldn't drink what's coming out the effluent pipe, either.'' ``If it was a problem, you'd think someone in government would have told us,'' said Joe Macy, Vail's ski mountain planner. ``But the state accepted this agreement,'' The Vail sewage plant actually is one of the state's cleanest because it uses tertiary treatment, the most stringent method, health officials said. But last winter, it still released up to 368 parts per million of fecal coliform bacteria and up to 1.1 ppm of ammonia, far in excess of drinking water standards.

DOC.HEAD: Tyminski Gets Permission to Leave Poland, Jaruzelski Bids Adieu
DOC.TEXT: Defeated presidential challenger Stanislaw Tyminski got permission Tuesday to leave Poland, President-elect Lech Walesa paid homage at the country's holiest shrine and incumbent President Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski bade the nation farewell. Tyminski, 42, had been ordered to remain in Poland pending investigation of slander charges against him, but he told reporters Tuesday night he had obtained permission to return temporarily to his children and home in Canada after posting a $100,000 bond. Tyminski said he would depart Wednesday morning, but he pledged to return to Poland by Jan. 5. ``I would like to see my children,'' Tyminski said. ``And I would like to rest after the campaign.'' Jaruzelski, in a farewell speech broadcast on nationwide television Tuesday night, apologized for ``each harm, pain and injustice'' during his nine years in power - apparently referring to his 1981 decision to impose martial law to quash Solidarity and the years of repression that followed. ``The word of `sorry' may sound all too casual,'' Jaruzelski said. ``But I cannot find another one.'' He said, however, that he was guided by ``the good of the country (and) by a will to spare Poland a tragedy and its people excessive suffering.'' Jaruzelski as head of the Communist Party was Poland's leader from October 1981 until July 1989, when he was elected president - an office whose powers he used only passively. His term will end when Walesa is sworn in, expected Dec. 21. The announcement that Tyminski could leave followed a three-hour, 25-minute meeting in Warsaw with two prosecutors from the southern province of Nowy Sacz. Tyminski said he had not retracted his allegation against the government of ``treason'' and of betraying the citizens by creating economic chaos. ``I do not regret what I said,'' Tyminski said Tuesday, ``and I am ready to bear all the consequences.'' He added, ``I cannot change what I said.'' Prosecutors on Monday ordered the emigre businessman be barred from leaving the country pending a Dec. 17 hearing. Polish law provides for jail terms of six months to eight years for those who ``demean the top state authorities,'' prosecutors have said. Tyminski said he and his Peruvian-born wife planned to leave Wednesday morning for the Toronto home where they lived until this fall, when Tyminski returned to his native Poland and decided to run for president. Tyminski said he would go for three days, to see his children and to prepare his defense using videotapes of the Nov. 17 speech that are in Canada. Meanwhile Walesa, the election victor, made an emotional pilgrimage to the 14th-century Jasna Gora monastery in Czestochowa, 135 miles southwest of Warsaw. ``Queen of Poland, in this historic moment I stand before you at the very sources of my faith,'' Walesa said before the Black Madonna, the jewel- encrusted icon whose image the Solidarity chief always wears on his lapel. ``Assuming ... the office of president of the fair republic of Poland, conscious of my responsibilities to God, the nation, history and my conscience,'' he pledged to protect the ``dignity ... sovereignty and security'' of Poland and ``devote myself entirely to the nation.'' His homage recalled the sanctuary provided by churches nationwide to Solidarity activism when the union was banned by the Communists. In Rome, Polish-born Pope John Paul II sent his congratulations to Walesa, and pleaded for unity during Poland's difficult post-Communist transition. At Solidarity's Gdansk headquarters, the union's national commission considered the procedure to name a new chairman. An special nationwide congress was proposed for as early as mid-January. After a campaign that strained Poland's new democracy and registered discontent with its difficult course toward economic reform, Walesa received 74.25 percent of the vote Sunday to 25.75 percent for his dark-horse challenger in the presidential runoff election. Walesa, who has already started consulting with advisers on naming a new prime minister, is to be sworn in for a five-year term by Parliament. Tyminski said on Tuesday that he would not contest the results, despite allegations Sunday night that supporters had been intimidated and ``some people had their dogs poisoned.'' Tyminski, who has Canadian, Peruvian and Polish citizenships, said he was unsure whether he will found a political party. The leader of the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada and owner of computer businesses, Tyminski portrayed himself as a rags-to-riches story. But his first-round success was derailed before Sunday's runoff by questions about his connections with former Communist operatives and his vagueness of his promises for quick economic recovery.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to DELETE Bjt designator
Hartz Mountain to Pay Fine in Repellent Case
DOC.TEXT: Hartz Mountain Corp. will pay $45,000 to settle charges that it failed to report pet illnesses and deaths from a top-selling flea and tick repellent, the Environmental Protection Agency said Tuesday. The pet product giant agreed to pay half the original $90,000 in penalties, but admitted no liability, according to a statement. EPA said the fines stemmed from a 1987 investigation into complaints from veterinarians and consumers about Blockade sprays for dogs and cats. Agency spokesman Al Heier said the animals were absorbing the pesticides into their skins and suffered tremors, vomiting and convulsions. Young kittens and old cats were the most susceptible, but often recovered if they were bathed, he said. The Illinois-based National Animal Poison Information Network told EPA that by the end of 1987 - the year the product went on the market - it had reports of 496 incidents, including 75 deaths, Heier said. Harrison, N.J.-based Hartz Mountain placed warnings on its labels in 1987, then voluntarily removed the product in 1988 to conduct more extensive testing, Heier said. Blockade was reintroduced in 1989. EPA did not bring its formal 18-count complaint until Jan. 31. Hartz spokesman William Pearlberg said the company was ``most surprised'' at the complaint, believing it had reported all required information in a timely manner. Registered pesticide producers must pass on health complaints to EPA within a ``reasonable'' period. EPA defined that as a month in the Blockade case, EPA attorney Scott Garrison said. ``We did not consider it to be reporting when we had to send inspectors out to get it,'' Garrison said. Heier said Blockade flea and tick repellents contain a combination of the pesticides DEET and fenvalerate. ``There is some danger in the product,'' Heier said. ``However, from our information, it shows the risks of using Blockade is no greater than using any other pet product.'' According to Heier, the revised label directs consumers not to use Blockade on cats less than a year old, on pregnant cats or on puppies younger than 3 months. Hartz Mountain maintains the formula is effective in preventing insect-borne diseases.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Says U.S. Troops Threatened to Kill Libyan POWs
DOC.TEXT: Libya on Tuesday accused the United States of ``international piracy'' for airlifting hundreds of Libyan prisoners of war out of Chad. U.S. troops evacuated about 600 Libyan POWs held by the former Chadian government on Friday and Saturday as victorious rebels consolidated their control of Chad. The United States has said the evacuation was part of a humnitarian gesture with international backing. In another development, Libya said Tuesday it has asked Iraq to hand over some American hostages to be held in exchange for the former Libyan prisoners of war taken from Chad. The report came from Libya's official JANA news agency, monitored in Rome. But Iraq's information minister has said Iraq will not hand over any Americans. U.S. and other foreign hostages were freed under a blanket decree by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and have been leaving the Iraqi capital on evacuation flights. In the evacuation of the POWs, Libya said U.S. troops threatened to kill any Libyan who refused to go. The Libyans were flown to Nigeria, that country's foreign minister confirmed on Tuesday. Other former POWs returned to Libya, which helped arm the rebels. Libya has accused the United States of training the POWs to destabilize Col. Moammar Gadhafi's Libyan government, and called for an emergency meeting of the Security Council to discuss the matter. Yemen currently holds the presidency of the council. Yemeni Ambassador Abdalla Saleh al-Ashtal said the council may meet on the request Wednesday. Libyan Foreign Minister Ibrahim Bashari said the Libyans were put on a U.S. Air Force plane ``against their will and against their wishes, under the protection of the French forces stationed at N'Djamena,'' Chad's capital. In his letter to Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, which was released Tuesday, Bashari said the prisoners ``were forcibly removed, having been threatened, subject to the use of weapons by United States agents and with the cooperation of the French forces, that whoever refused to leave would be killed and his body thrown onto the road.'' ``This act of international piracy by the United States constitutes a violation of the sovereignty of an independent state,'' Bashari said. His letter gave no indication of how he learned the alleged details of the evacuation. The U.S. Mission to the United Nations has had no comment on the Libyan accusations. The French Mission had no immediate comment. Chadian forces captured the Libyan fighters in clashes in 1983 and 1987. Chad and Libya have battled on and off in a border dispute for more than 20 years. The International Committee of the Red Cross complained Monday in Geneva that it was not allowed to supervise the airlift and said it wanted to interview the prisoners to make sure they left voluntarily. ``The ICRC has not been able to carry out protection work on their behalf as it would have wished,'' it said in a statement. The Red Cross said it was never allowed to visit Libyan prisoners captured during the long conflict between Chad and Libya, despite repeated requests to Chad's former government led by President Hissene Habre. Idriss Deby's rebel forces toppled Habre this month. Deby is now interim president. Nigeria's foreign minister, Gen. Ike Nwachukwo, told reporters Tuesday that the Red Cross had asked his country to take in the Libyans on humanitarian grounds, ``so we did.'' He said they were currently outside Lagos, the capital, and were being readied for transfer to another country, which he would not identify.

DOC.HEAD: Undergoes Physical Therapy for Paralysis
DOC.TEXT: Actor Burt Lancaster, partially paralyzed by a stroke two weeks ago, remained hospitalized Tuesday in an intensive care unit where therapists worked to help him regain his motor skills. The 77-year-old star was visiting a friend when he collapsed Nov. 30 and was taken by ambulance to Los Alamitos Medical Center in serious condition. Doctors said the stroke left his right side partially paralyzed. ``He's still in intensive care and he's undergoing extensive physical therapy and speech therapy. His spirits are high,'' said his agent Ben Benjamin. Doctors had no idea how long Lancaster would be hospitalized, and nursing supervisor Wendy Beck would only say Lancaster was stable. Lancaster, who starred in more than 70 motion pictures, won an Academy Award in 1960 for his portrayal of an evangelist in ``Elmer Gantry.'' Benjamin said Lancaster's wife has been with the actor constantly, taking a hospital room nearby.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Westinghouse to Seek Permission to Restart Savannah River Reactor
DOC.TEXT: The operator of the Savannah River nuclear arms plant has not decided when to ask federal permission to restart a reactor, despite a published report the request will be made this summer, a company spokesman said. ``Specific recommendations are far from being finalized,'' said Jack N. Herrmann, public relations spokesman for the Westinghouse Savannah River Co. The Augusta Chronicle reported Tuesday that Westinghouse said in a 250-page report to be submitted to the Department of Energy that it plans to request permission to begin full-power operation for the K-reactor between June 30 and July 9. The newspaper did not report when Westinghouse wants to start the reactor, but said testing could begin as early as June 3. Savannah River Site's three aging reactors are the nation's sole source of tritium, a key element in the production of nuclear weapons. Tritium, a radioactive gas used to boost the explosive power of nuclear weapons, decays about 5.5 percent annually, and must be replenished periodically in warheads. The K-Reactor was shut down in the summer of 1988 amid charges of unsafe practices. In May, Energy Secretary James Watkins told a Senate subcommittee that the K-Reactor would begin operations in late December or early January and that all three reactors would be up and running by the end of 1991. But Deputy Energy Secretary Henson Moore said last month the agency didn't know when the reactors would restart. Improved U.S. relations with the Soviet Union had reduced the need to try to meet the December restart schedule, Moore said.

DOC.HEAD: For Communists and Capitalists, Hammer Left Mark on Soviet Union
With AM-Obit-Hammer, Bjt
