DOC.TEXT: Armand Hammer's nearly 70 years of contact with the Soviet Union left an indelible mark on this country, from memorabilia enshrined in Vladimir Lenin's apartment to a modern capitalist trade center in Moscow. Hammer, 92, who died Monday in Los Angeles, received official adulation in the Soviet Union while bringing him some scorn in his native United States for dealing with the nation's former Cold War enemy. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent a message of condolence to the Hammer's family and said he ``was associated with one of the most remarkable pages'' in U.S.-Soviet relations. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said the charismatic entrepreneur will be remembered for his tireless efforts to maintain good relations with the Kremlin. ``It is a big loss,'' said Dr. Matt Shatz, a producer at Armand Hammer Productions, a Moscow film-making company Hammer founded 12 years ago. ``He put all his strength into this company,'' Shatz said. Hammer made many trips to the Soviet Union, the first in 1921 as a 23-year-old doctor just out of Columbia University medical school. Hammer, the son of a Russian-born father, arrived as the Soviet Union suffered famine exacerbated by World War I. He met Lenin, the Soviet founder, and was enlisted to help re-establish trade between the Communist government and the West. Hammer's first deal was U.S. grain for Soviet products. Hammer stayed in the country until 1930, becoming an executive of the Amalgamated American Co., which the state news agency Tass said was founded with Lenin's personal approval, Tass said. During a later visit to the Soviet Union, he said: ``I'll never forget what Lenin told me during one of our meetings. He said, `Dr. Hammer, we don't need doctors. We need business people who can do things.' That was the end of my promising medical career.'' Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp., became a representative of 38 foreign companies in the Soviet Union. He owned and operated an asbestos mine and founded the first pencil factory in the U.S.S.R. Visitors to Lenin's meticulously preserved apartment in the Kremlin can see four of the pencils standing in a holder on Lenin's desk. Guides also point proudly to a black leather chair where Hammer sat during his meetings with the revolutionary leader, and to a small stature of monkey sitting contemplatively on Charles Darwin's book ``Origin of the Species.'' Hammer had given the sculpture to Lenin as a gift. Hammer met with dictator Josef Stalin, but the two could not work together and Hammer ended up selling his enterprises to the Soviet government. After Stalin's death, Hammer resumed his efforts that melded business and politics. ``He will live in history, as well as in people's memories, as an entrepreneur who made cooperation by his country with the Soviet Union possible in the years when nobody dared to even think about it,'' read an unsigned obituary in the government newspaper Izvestia. In 1978, then-Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev awarded Hammer the Order of Friendship Between Peoples in honor of his 80th birthday and help in establishing better U.S.-Soviet relations. At the same time, Hammer was wrapping up a deal to split the cost of a huge new international trade center in Moscow. The center, built for the 1980 Moscow Olympic Games, houses the huge Mezhdunarodnaya Hotel and SovIncenter exhibition complex. It is known as the Hammer Center and is one of the city's most modern office complexes. After the Chernobyl nuclear power plant explosion in 1986, Hammer personally helped bring a bone marrow specialist, Dr. Robert Gale, to the Soviet Union along with costly medicine and equipment for operations. Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, Hammer cultivated his passion for art and presided over the opening of several exhibits and galleries. He handed over historical relics, including letters by Lenin, to the Soviets.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Stockpiles Still at Record Highs
DOC.TEXT: Global wheat stockpiles continue at record high levels, putting a damper on U.S. exports and market prices, an Agriculture Department report showed Tuesday. Overall, 1990-91 wheat production forecasts increased from a month ago, with gains in Canada, China and Mexico more than offsetting reduced prospects in Brazil, the European Community and South Africa. The projected average U.S. market price was reduced 5 cents a bushel from November, to a range of $2.50 to $2.70 for the marketing year that began June 1. In the previous two years, the farm price of wheat was $3.72 per bushel. According to the new supply-and-demand report, exports are still expected to be 1.075 billion bushels in 1990-91, down from 1.233 billion last year. The U.S. wheat stockpile carried over next June 1 into the new harvest and marketing year was projected at 937 million bushels, down slightly from the November outlook but still much larger than the 536 million bushels carried forward last June 1. Looking at corn and other coarse grains, the report showed global production in 1990-91 and the year-ending stockpile to be up slightly from last month. ``Although prolonged dry conditions have cut corn planting in South Africa ... gains in the EC, Canada and Turkey are more than offsetting,'' the report said. ``The smaller crop likely will eliminate corn exports by South Africa during their 1990-91 marketing year.'' As with wheat, farmers harvested a bumper corn crop this year. However, unlike wheat, total corn use is expected to exceed output, meaning some reduction in the stockpile during the 1990-91 marketing year that began on Sept. 1. Consequently, corn prices at the farm are projected to average $2.20 to $2.50 per bushel this season, compared with $2.36 in 1989-90. The corn stockpile next Sept. 1 was projected at 1.236 billion bushels, down from 1.344 billion estimated this Sept. 1. World oilseed production, including U.S. soybeans, also is forecast at a record level in 1990-91, up 2 percent from last year. The U.S. soybean carryover next Sept. 1 was projected at 265 million bushels, up 10 million from the November forecast. The soybean inventory this Sept. 1 was 239 million bushels. Farm prices of soybeans were projected to average $5.25 to $6.25 per bushel in 1990-91, down 10 cents on both ends of the range from November. Last season, soybeans averaged $5.70 per bushel nationally at the farm.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 500 Americans Will Stay in Iraq and Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: More than 500 Americans, a majority of them children, will remain in Kuwait and Iraq after this week's evacuation flights, although the number who are doing so voluntarily is unclear, the State Department said Tuesday. Spokesman Richard Boucher said some families with one or more Americans are staying because they have roots in Iraq or Kuwait. In other cases, the non-American head of household has been unable to obtain permission from Iraqi authorities to leave. Just how many there are in each category could not be determined. The evacuation of Americans appeared all but over Tuesday, as only eight boarded a government-chartered Boeing 707 in Baghdad, a department official said. When the same plane had left Kuwait en route to Baghdad, there were no Americans aboard. With the exception of three Americans who have had visa problems, Boucher said, all Americans who wish to leave Iraq and Kuwait apparently have left, so far as is known. On the chance that some Americans appear who have not yet made their presence known to U.S. officials, an additional charter flight is planned for Thursday. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that flight is likely to be the last. There are five U.S. diplomats working at the embassy in Kuwait and all will be brought home soon, but it has not yet been decided whether they will be aboard the Thursday flight. The three other Americans who have been left behind had been among those used by Iraqi authorities as human shields to deter a potential U.S. military strike, Boucher said. He said that as many as 510 Americans will remain in Kuwait and Iraq permanently. That is more than half the number who were in the two countries when President Saddam Hussein announced last week that all foreign hostages were free to go home. ``As of today, we believe that as many as 310 Americans have chosen to stay in Kuwait,'' Boucher said. ``This includes 60 women, 215 children, and 35 males with dual Kuwaiti-American citizenship. As many as 200 more Americans have chosen to stay in Iraq. Of these 40 are women, 79 are children and 80 are men with dual Iraqi-American citizenship. ``Obviously, the decision to leave is a deeply personal one, but we have made every effort to offer our best advice as well as the means to depart,'' he said. The embassy has made an effort to ensure that there was not ``the slightest possibility that any American was unwillingly left behind,'' Boucher said. He said U.S. officials have received information about 30 persons said to be Americans living in Kuwait but have had no luck in locating them. ``It is not known whether these individuals are still in Kuwait, whether they have ever been in Kuwait, whether they are American citizens, or even whether many of them exist,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Factional Fighting in South African Black Township Kills 37
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One graf SUBS for 6th graf, `Buthelezi, citing ...' to UPDATE with Buthelezi says Mandela declined invitation to tour Tokoza together. Picks up 7th graf, `Xhosas loyal ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JOH2,3
DOC.TEXT: Factional rivalries erupted in warfare Tuesday in Tokoza, where Zulus and Xhosas slashed and shot 37 people to death and burned scores of homes before black officials held peace talks. In the afternoon, when the violence had died down, women piled household belongings on their heads and fled in the rain to seek shelter in a nearby township. Armed men stayed behind, guarding their shacks in the impoverished township and the workers' hostels that have become a flashpoint of factional unrest. Representatives of the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party, whose supporters are at the center of the clashes, met later and said they would appeal to their followers to stop fighting. Past appeals from leaders of the rival groups have made little difference. The death toll in Johannesburg townships has exceeded 1,000 since August, and ANC leader Nelson Mandela and Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi have yet to sit down to talk. Buthelezi, citing a tight schedule and late notice, rejected an invitation to tour Tokoza on Wednesday with Mandela and other black leaders. He said he instead would visit Tokoza separately with national Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok and said Mandela declined an invitation to join them. Xhosas loyal to the ANC and Zulus who back Inkatha battled for hours with guns, knives and axes and chased terrified people through the alleys of the Phola Park squatter camp within Tokoza, east of Johannesburg. Hacked and mutilated bodies lay outside shacks that were reduced to smoldering piles. Fighting also raged in a nearby workers' hostel, where Zulus live, and in a surrounding industrial area. ``We want revenge ... we want to fight,'' some Zulus chanted as they congregated at the hostel later. Both sides blamed each other for the violence and accused government security forces of helping their opponents. Police in armored vehicles roamed the township but rarely ventured into the narrow lanes of shacks making up Phola Park. Helicopters hovered above, and the government said police and army reinforcements would be deployed in Tokoza. In the late afternoon, Zulus wearing white headbands and carrying iron bars stared out from the broken windows of their hostel or stood guard outside. One woman carried a large saw. Others held rocks in addition to their bars. Down the road in the squatter camp, a few Xhosas were on guard outside their shacks, draped in blankets in the heavy rain. Police spokesman Capt. Eugene Opperman said reports indicated fighting flared before dawn when Xhosas attacked the Zulu hostel and the Zulus mounted a revenge attack. He denied police took sides in the fighting. He said officers were fired on several times but were not injured. Hostels have been a frequent target of township unrest because they generally house Zulus who come from the Zulu homeland to take jobs at mines or in other industry. At least 53 people have died in factional battles in Tokoza since the latest fighting began over the weekend. Inkatha and the ANC are South Africa's largest black political movements. While both oppose apartheid, they disagree strongly on how best to fight it and on their vision of a future South Africa. Inkatha favors a conservative policy, including free enterprise, while the ANC leans more to leftist economic policies. Inkatha has opposed sanctions, which the ANC supports, and Inkatha condemned the ANC's armed struggle against the white-led government. ANC National Executive Committee member Penuell Maduna, and Inkatha Youth League chairman Themba Khoza represented their groups at the peace meeting Tuesday. They said in a joint statement that they would try to persuade their members to be more tolerant of other political groups. Buthelezi, the Inkatha leader, released a statement later deploring the violence but also alleging there was a deliberate effort to keep him from taking part in the high-profile township tour Wednesday with Mandela and other black leaders. Buthelezi said he received his invitation from the South African Council of Churches only Monday. ``I am very troubled that I am given this kind of overnight warning of very important matters,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Congress Sounds Warning About Gulf Involvement
DOC.TEXT: Parliament in the Russian republic on Tuesday told national leaders not the let the country get caught in a military confrontation in the Persian Gulf, the state news agency Tass reported. President Mikhail Gorbachev must not let the Soviets be drawn ``into a military conflict in the gulf that could lead to very grave consequences for global peace and stability,'' the Russian Congress of People's Deputies said in a resolution. The parliament of the vast republic, the country's largest, recently has claimed the right to make some foreign policy, but it has no legal power to enforce the resolution over the Kremlin. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in recent weeks have shed their cautious tone regarding Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and indicated support for military action unless Saddam Hussein's forces don't withdraw. The Soviet Union has some ships in waters off Iraq, but has not deployed any other forces to join the U.S.-led multilateral force against the Iraqis, a onetime ally of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia in Good Condition But Plumbing, Lint Woes Need Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Columbia, the oldest space shuttle, came back from its 10th mission in good condition but with no quick answers to its lint and plumbing woes, a NASA official said Tuesday. Columbia dropped out of orbit a day early to beat rainy weather forecast for the Mojave Desert landing site and touched down at 9:54 p.m. Monday, ending its astronomy mission after nine days. On Tuesday, there was no sign of the rain. The origin of lint that fouled cooling systems for two computers needed investigation, but it likely was inside the devices before launch and not from the shuttle interior, said Columbia flow director Bascom Murrah. ``The orbiter cooling system looked clean,'' he said. ``These panels were given to us by the payload community. So if there was debris in there, we think ... that that probably came with the panel when it was given to us to install in the orbiter.'' Shuttle cleaning procedures were reviewed and everything was ``up to snuff,'' Murrah said. The lint was suspected to have caused failure of two computer terminals for controlling the $150 million Astro observatory, a group of ultraviolet and X-ray telescopes in Columbia's payload bay. Much of the aiming of the telescopes had to be done by the crew's astronaut astronomers using a joystick and keyboard. Only 135 of 250 planned targets were observed, although that still amounted to a wealth of data about stars, galaxies, quasars, supernovas and a comet. Ultraviolet and X-ray radiation from such objects is blocked by the Earth's atmosphere. No brake problems were observed when Columbia landed and the thermal tiles that protect it from the heat of re-entry into the atmosphere were in good to excellent condition, Murrah said. Damage to tiles from impacts with debris either during launch, re-entry or landing was minimal, he said. Television pictures of Columbia on the runway showed blotches on its underside, but Murrah said the shuttle was just showing its age. Columbia ``is an old bird and we've got a lot of pockmarks on it that we've repaired. But a lot of that you were seeing was old repairs and not damage from this flight,'' he said. There was no immediate answer to the question of why the shuttle's system for collecting and dumping liquid waste into space had clogged. The clog caused a collection tank to fill up and threatened to force an early end to the mission. The astronauts, however, became plumbers and were able to drain the tank into urine collection bags. The system will be examined after the shuttle is flown back to Kennedy Space Center in Florida. ``We had had a problem previously with clogging in that system and we changed out a line and a dump valve and evidently there's more debris upstream of those components. But that orifice is very, very small and it doesn't take much to clog it,'' Murrah said. The opening is tiny to compress the stream into a spray so it will fan out and not freeze solid on the outside of the craft. One of the science instruments in the cargo hold, the Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope, stored its pictures on film. The film will be removed Friday and sent to Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., for processing. The pictures will be ready later this month or in January. Murrah said Columbia should be mounted aboard NASA's Boeing 747 ferry plane in time to begin its return trip Sunday. The flight to Florida will take two days.

DOC.HEAD: Cicconi Leaving White House; Baltimore Dean Arriving
DOC.TEXT: Presidential assistant James A. Cicconi, a member of President Bush's senior staff, said Tuesday he will step down from his post at the end of the year to return to his law practice. Cicconi serves as staff secretary. All presidential documents and speech texts flow through his office. Cicconi said he wanted a break from the long White House hours so he could spend more time with his three small children. He will return to the firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer and Field where he was a partner before he joined Bush's 1988 presidential campaign. On another personnel matter, Bush announced Tuesday that he will name Donald Henderson, dean of the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, as associate director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy.

DOC.HEAD: Pfizer Warns Patients About Heart Valves
DOC.TEXT: Pfizer Inc. will conduct an unprecedented search to warn about 23,000 patients about rare but often fatal fractures of an implanted heart valve, officials said Tuesday. The Food and Drug Administration said it had accepted Pfizer's plan to locate patients who have the Bjork-Shiley 60-degree convexo-concave heart valve. Valve fractures have occurred in about seven of every 10,000 patients per year, the FDA said. The valve was implanted in about 82,000 people worldwide between 1979 and November 1986, when it was removed from the market. About 23,000 of the patients who are still alive are in the United States and Canada. About 295 fractures of the valve were reported to the FDA, with 178 deaths resulting. When a valve fractures, a patient's life can be saved if the valve is replaced quickly. ``That's why it is important for C-C valve patients to ask their doctors how to recognize early signs of valve fracture and what to do should it occur,'' FDA Deputy Commissioner James Benson said. Public Citizen Health Research Group, a Ralph Nader-founded advocacy group, has been pressing the FDA and Pfizer for years to notify patients about the danger. The FDA's procedure has been for companies recalling medical devices to contact physicians, who then would speak to their patients. But that policy is being reviewed, said FDA spokeswoman Susan Cruzan. Also, the agency is developing a plan to work with foreign governments to notify patients overseas, she said. About 59,000 patients with the valve live outside North America. The company last week sent letters to about 19,000 heart specialists telling them of the program and asking them to contact patients who have the Shiley valve. About 450 hospitals are also being contacted. On Thursday, the company will announce plans for a patient registry that will include a toll-free telephone number for patients to identify themselves. The program will be run by Medic Alert, a nonprofit foundation, which will send letters to patients through their doctors, or directly if their doctor can't be located, said Pfizer spokesman Rick Honey. Those patients will be sent information about their valve implant, as well as an identification card and a bracelet or neck chain identifying them as having a C-C heart valve. Medic Alert has set up a telephone number where patients can get further information. The number is 1-800-245-1492.

DOC.HEAD: Death Machine Builder Vows Retaliation on Nazi Hunters
DOC.TEXT: A man who makes execution devices used around the country appeared in court trial Tuesday on charges of practicing engineering without a license. Outside the courtroom, Fred Leuchter Jr. was also on trial for his views that the systematic extermination of Jews by gas chamber during World War II did not occur. ``You liar, you liar, I watched my family go to the gas chamber,'' yelled Anton Segure, a 63-year-old Holocaust survivor who came from Albany, N.Y., to protest Leuchter's view. ``I was there. Forty-five years ago my whole family was gassed.'' Leuchter's case on charges he is not a licensed engineer was continued until Jan. 22 with no argument. He complained that the charges, which include a maximum three months in jail and $500 fine, have thwarted his lucrative business as an expert witness about execution technology in capital punishment trials and consultant on execution machines. Leuchter acknowledges he is not a state-certified engineer, but asserts it is not required for his consulting work. He has designed and built capital punishment equipment, primarily electric chairs, for prisons in a number states of where the death penalty is legal. The state filed the charges against Leuchter at the urging of several of the groups protesting his beliefs. And Jewish activists seized the occasion of the hearing to protest Leuchter's revisionist theories, and they flew in Nazi hunter Beate Klarsfeld from Paris to join them in this suburb north of Boston. ``He is a very dangerous man. He denies the death of 6 million people,'' said Klarsfeld, who helped convict former Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie. ``We are determined not to let him go on with this denial.'' Leuchter refused to acknowledge protesters, who also crashed a news conference he held a few hours after the pre-trial hearing Tuesday. But when asked several times what he thought of eyewitness accounts of the mass murders of Jews in concentration camps in the 1940s, he said: ``There are no eyewitnesses. There are none.'' Leuchter asserts in published reports and interviews that gas chambers at at least three death camps were not technically equipped to kill thousands of prisoners. Meyer Hack rolled up his coat sleeve to reveal the 73,684 tattooed on his arm in the camp at Birkenau, and said he wished Leuchter had been with him in 1942 and 1943 when he escaped the chamber by faking his own death. ``I talk with my heart,'' the 73-year-old Hack said trembling and clutching the woman next to him. ``The brute will never know.'' But Leuchter, who boasts he is the only true expert on execution technology in the United States, said the issue is free speech. ``Because certain groups and individuals did not like my report, these groups or individuals have formed an international cabal to destroy the report,'' he said. A Texas lawyer who has addressed the Aryan Nations Congress has volunteered to take Leuchter's case for free. The attorney, Kirk Lyons, said they are considering a civil defamation suit. Leuchter claims he is a scientist who has disproved the existence of an event long accepted as part of history. ``I'm sure Columbus, Galileo and Copernicus caused emotional harm to those who promoted the flat-earth theory, but that did not stop the earth from being a sphere,'' he said. Leonard Zakim, executive director of the New England Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said it would be giving Leuchter too much credit to engage in an intellectual debate over the authenticity of the Holocaust. ``It's as ridiculous as saying World War II never happened,'' Zakim said. ``Wouldn't it be great if what he said was true?''

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Aide Contradicts Regulator at Ethics Hearing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf to UPDATE testimony; INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, bgng: Last week xxx to UPDATE with hearing adjourning for day; ADDS 11 grafs to include detail of testimony.
DOC.TEXT: Contradicting a regulator's testimony, Sen. Alan Cranston's banking aide denied on Tuesday that she pressured U.S. officials to weaken their hard-nosed enforcement of Charles H. Keating Jr.'s savings and loan. Carolyn D. Jordan told the Senate Ethics Committee that if she had tried to pressure regulators to go easy on Keating's thrift, ``they would have clearly understood. I did not say that.'' A senior career regulator testified last week that pressure from Ms. Jordan caused thrift officials to weaken their enforcement of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan. The official, William K. Black, said her action was a factor in delaying government seizure of the Irvine, Calif., S&L and inflating the taxpayer bailout cost. Ms. Jordan repeatedly testified she could not recall specifics of meetings she attended with Keating or his executives. At one point an annoyed committee Vice Chairman Warren Rudman, R-N.H. remarked, ``The witness has very good recall of some things and very poor recall about some others.'' Ms. Jordan, counsel to the Senate Banking Committee, said she called two officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board after the regulators proposed close supervision of Keating's savings and loan on May 5, 1988. She testified that Cranston, D-Calif., one of five senators under investigation by the Ethics Committee, did not ask her to make the call. Ms. Jordan said the impetus came from Keating executive James Grogan, who called her immediately after the bank board met to complain about its action. Ms. Jordan said she found it unusual that the board would take tough enforcement action when Lincoln officials were disputing regulators' findings that the thrift was failing. Lincoln was seized April 14, 1989, and the cost to taxpayers is expected to exceed $2 billion. Last week, Black told the committee that pressure by Ms. Jordan caused the board to modify its enforcement program several weeks later and that the changes permitted Lincoln to continue making risky direct investments and to expand its junk bond business. Also, the regulator contended Ms. Jordan's call helped delay government seizure. The hearing adjourned for the day after Ms. Jordan completed her testimony. An executive session is scheduled for Wednesday so the committee can privately question Grogan. The committee, now in its 16th day of hearings, is investigating the relationship of Cranston and four other senators to Keating: John McCain, R-Ariz.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. Keating and associates raised $1.3 million for the campaigns and causes of the five, all of whom intervened with regulators on behalf of Lincoln. The committee is trying to decide whether their assistance was related to the contributions. A number of committee documents show that in contacts with Keating or his executives, Cranston and his chief fund-raiser, Joy Jacobson, often linked the subjects of contributions and Lincoln's battle with the bank board. Cranston received $850,000 from Keating for three voter registration projects the senator strongly supported. Former bank board chairman M. Danny Wall has testified that Cranston made an unusual number of calls to him on behalf of Lincoln, but Wall said he did not believe the calls were improper. Ms. Jordan was questioned about a memo she wrote to Cranston on May 6, 1988, in which she discussed Grogan's account of the bank board's tough enforcement stance the previous day. She said the board wanted a ``supervisory agreement'' that would trigger public reports on Lincoln's condition. ``It can affect the value of Lincoln stock and will depress prices and affect liquidity,'' Ms. Jordan wrote in the memo to the senator. She then wrote Cranston: ``I told them you were very concerned that the board would choose the supervisory approach after all that had come out about the behavior of Ed Gray's people at the FHLBB of San Francisco, and additionally when Lincoln had over 6 percent net worth and was not losing any money.'' Edwin J. Gray is the former chairman of the bank board. Both Cranston and Keating argued with him over regulators' tough supervision of Lincoln. Ms. Jordan also testified that she, not Cranston, was responsible for the insertion in the Congressional Record in 1987 of a Cranston statement that was helpful to Keating. She said Cranston never approved the statement, an assertion that produced skepticism from Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., a committee member. Helms said, ``Now what is the story? Did he approve that going in the record?'' Jordan responded, ``No, he did not.'' Helms: ``So just staff members put it in without his knowledge?'' Jordan: ``That is correct. Cranston's statement in the record said he opposed expanding authority of the bank board to limit risky investments - and was glad sponsors withdrew such a proposal from pending legislation. The statement was cited by Keating in his lawsuit challenging a rule already approved by the board, which limited risky investments. A week after the statement was placed in the record, Cranston, DeConcini, McCain and Glenn attended a crucial meeting with Gray. Gray testified that at the meeting, DeConcini cited Keating's legal challenge and asked that the risky investment rule be waived for Lincoln until the court case was resolved. DeConcini has denied such negotiation took place.

DOC.HEAD: Light Precipitation In The West
DOC.TEXT: Light rain was scattered over parts of the West on Tuesday, and the central Plains warmed while temperatures in New England dropped. Scattered light showers developed behind a cold front curving through the Southwest and extended over parts of California and Nevada during the morning. Snow fell at some higher elevations of California and Nevada, with up to 4 inches of snow falling in the northern Sierra Nevada during the night. Light showers associated with the same cold front also extended over parts of Idaho and Montana and eastward into North Dakota. Freezing rain fell over northwestern North Dakota during the afternoon. Strong southerly wind helped temperatures warm into the 50s during the afternoon as far north as the central Plains region and the middle Mississippi Valley. Temperatures were mostly in the 60s in the southern Plains and the lower Mississippi Valley. But afternoon temperatures were only in the 20s across much of New York state and northern New England. Overnight temperatures dipped into the teens in the northern Plains and the northern Atlantic Coast. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was zero at Gunnison, Colo. In Alaska, heavy snow fell over Kodiak Island, with a total of 11 inches of snow during the 24 hours up to 3 a.m. AST Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Total Food Aid Hits 1,272 Tons, But Estonia Says No Thanks
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has received 1,272 metric tons of food aid from abroad since the start of a campaign to stave off shortages that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said threaten his reforms. ``We welcome the hand offered to us and will not push it away,'' presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko said at a briefing Tuesday, according to the state news agency Tass. More shipments were expected Wednesday and they would be distributed to Byelorussia, the Ukraine and parts of Russia, Ignatenko said. The shortages have grown more acute in recent months, exacerbated by distribution problems, black market pilfering and panic buying, officials have said. An Associated Press survey of major cities across the country indicated shortages were worst in urban areas. The Baltic republic of Estonia, however, apparently was having few problems. Estonian Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar told Soviet officials Tuesday by telegram that his republic does not need food aid from the West, the independent Interfax news agency reported. But it would accept medicine for children and the elderly, he said. Estonia, like the other Baltic republics Latvia and Lithuania, traditionally have been well-off compared to other republics because of their own food resources and proximity to sympathetic Scandinavian countries.

DOC.HEAD: Senegal Gives Asylum to Ousted President of Chad
With AM-Chad
DOC.TEXT: The ousted president of Chad, Hissene Habre, flew into Dakar on Tuesday from his temporary refuge in Cameroon, and Senegal's Cabinet said it was granting his request for political asylum. A government source said Habre, 48, agreed not to engage in political activity while in Senegal. Habre aides said last week he hoped to find final refuge in the United States. Reporters watched Habre and his entourage arrive in a small plane. The party was immediately whisked away by car. Official sources said they were taken to a government-owned guest villa. A Cameroonian presidential guard who watched the entourage leave Yaounde said a Chadian military plane accompanied it carrying Habre's baggage, cash and two Mercedes Benz automobiles. Habre fled into Cameroon from Chad's capital, N'Djamena, on Dec. 1 as a rebel army led by Habre's former military adviser, Idriss Deby, advanced after a series of victories. Deby was installed Dec. 3 as Chad's interim president.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Shamir Upbeat on US-Israel Relationship in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 17th graf ``Israel got'' etc. with comment from Shamir aide about Israeli position on gulf.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir put a positive face Tuesday on relations strained by new U.S. ties to Israel's Arab foes. Bush promised to keep Israel's ``qualitative edge'' in weaponry, an American official said. The two leaders, in a ``friendly and good exchange of views'' on the Persian Gulf crisis and other subjects, also discussed prospects for increased U.S. aid to ease Israel's immigration burden, said Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly. But Bush voiced U.S. concerns about treatment of Palestinians living in the Israeli occupied territory, Kelly said, though the president did not bring up the touchy matter of the slaying of 17 Palestinians by Israeli police during an October riot at a Jerusalem holy site. Nor did Bush press Shamir to cooperate with a planned United Nations investigation of that incident, because their discussion ``evolved that way,'' without that subject coming up, Kelly said. Shamir told reporters he felt assured by Bush that the United States would not accept a deal with Iraq that would threaten Israel, especially in light of Israel's increasing edginess over new U.S. alliances in the region. ``I trust the president, what he said. He has said it several times, and he said it to me now again, that there will not be any deal at the expense of Israel,'' Shamir said after spending nearly two hours with Bush and his aides. Having promised the United States it will lie low in the Persian Gulf crisis, Israeli leaders have indicated fear that the administration would accept a diplomatic solution that would leave intact Iraq's stores of chemical and biological weapons. Israel also is worried about Bush's plans to sell Saudi Arabia some $20 billion in sophisticated arms and has asked for an increase in U.S. military aid to offset the unprecedented sale. ``The prime minister was assured by the president that we will maintain a qualitative edge in armaments for Israel, but at the same time we want to help out with the legitimate self-defense needs of our Arab friends in the region,'' Kelly told reporters after the meeting. On immigration, Shamir told Bush that Israel ``would be looking for additional help'' to cope with influx of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union and Ethiopia. Shamir did not ask for a specific amount, and Bush was generally supportive, Kelly said. But he said the administration was waiting to see the impact of its current loan program, under which the United States has guaranteed $400 million in loans for new immigrant housing on condition that the homes not be built in the occupied territories. After the meeting, both Shamir and Kelly stressed the nations' common opposition to Iraqi aggression in the gulf area. ``We have been delighted to express our full support for the leadership of the president, for the policy of the United States in this recent crisis of the gulf,'' Shamir said. ``And the president also expresses his support for our behavior, for our policy'' in the crisis, Shamir added. Israeli officials had said Shamir would assure Bush Israel would not launch any pre-emptive strikes against Iraq. But when asked about that, Kelly said Shamir didn't talk about ``potential Israeli actions.'' He said Bush thanked him for keeping a low profile in the crisis. ``Israel got praised several times for its position,'' said Shamir's adviser Avi Pazner. ``There is no willingness on our part to change that position,'' he told reporters. As delicate diplomatic aspects of the gulf crisis proceed, senior Israeli officials have suggested that Israel might go after Iraq's military machine if the United States does not. ``There was a strong expression of identity of views on seeing Iraqi aggression rebuffed,'' Kelly told reporters. Shamir said that he and Bush reached a ``general understanding, more or less, on all the moves in the gulf and on Israel's position.'' A meeting between Shamir and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze was being arranged for Wednesday in Washington, Israeli sources said. Shevardnadze was traveling to Washington to meet with Bush following two days of talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Houston. Israel's cool relationship with the Soviet Union has begun to thaw somewhat under the policies of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Kelly said that it was understood by the administration that the peace process involving Israel and the Palestinians was more or less on hold until the gulf crisis is resolved. Israel is worried that some Arab nations backing Bush in the gulf crisis will demand U.S. pressure on Israel to relinquish the occupied lands. The administration, while rejecting attempts by Iraq and its allies to link the two issues in a U.N. Security Council resolution, hopes to revive stalled Mideast peace moves. Previous U.S. efforts focused on getting Israelis to sit down with Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, but the Palestinians' fervent support for Iraq in the gulf crisis has made that even less likely.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2, 3 to add surname; SUBS 5th graf to drop reference to surname being withheld
DOC.HEAD: From Young Lemonade Entrepeneur, $20 For Gulf Troops
With AM-US-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon knew that Arab oil money would help pay for the Persian Gulf operation, but it probably didn't consider tapping the lemonade market. David Petito did. The 8-year-old resident of the capital mailed $20 in lemonade sales receipts - 20 one-dollar bills - to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Delivered with the cash in a wooden box was a note to the Pentagon chief that said: ``Dear Secretary Cheney: Please use this money to help buy water to help for the troops in the desert and the men on the boats at the gulf.'' Cheney's spokesman, Pete Williams, told reporters Tuesday that David raised the money at a lemonade stand in Washington at the corner of Nebraska and Connecticut avenues. The money will become part of a special federal account set up by Congress to keep track of private and foreign contributions for Operation Desert Shield. ``It will be added to the account and used as necessary,'' Williams said with a grin.

DOC.HEAD: Americans, Other Freed Hostages Arrive in Frankfurt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jetliner ferrying seven Americans and other former hostages to freedom arrived in Frankfurt late Tuesday from Baghdad. On board the Boeing 707, along with the Americans, were two Canadians, two Britons, an Irishman, an Italian, and an Australian, said Craig Springer, U.S. Consulate spokesman in Frankfurt. Before departure, diplomats said six Britons were on board and did not mention an Australian or Italian. There was no immediate explanation for the discrepancy. U.S. officials had originally planned to charter a Boeing 747 jumbo jet to Frankfurt and it was to have two State Department doctors aboard to deal with people coming out of hiding in Kuwait who have experienced a lot of stress. Just one of the doctors was on the flight, said Springer. Springer said the former hostages would stay in a hotel outside Frankfurt overnight and fly to their final destinations the following day on regular commercial flights. The Boeing 707 was one of three chartered jetliners delivering former hostages out of Iraq on Tuesday. Two others left for Bangkok and London. Diplomats said 14 Americans were on the charter flights from Baghdad. Seven were among the 310 people, most of them Britons, on the flight that left for London. Seven more were on the flight to Frankfurt. A Japanese-chartered Iraqi Airways 707 left Baghdad for Bangkok with 159 people aboard, including 14 Japanese diplomats from Kuwait and the rest mostly former Japanese hostages. The White House said Tuesday that a scheduled Thursday evacuation flight of Americans is ``likely to be the last'' and will probably also carry home the remaining staff of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last week announced the blanket release of all Westerners, and the first specially chartered freedom flights began Sunday. Earlier Tuesday, diplomats said about 600 U.S. citizens remain in Iraq and Kuwait. They also said about 400 were expected to remain in Iraq, mostly people with dual U.S.-Iraqi citizenship or American spouses of Iraqi citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Army Demands Tougher Sentences for Stone-Throwers
DOC.TEXT: The army said Tuesday it will press for tougher sentences for convicted Arab stone-throwers, who have received jail terms ranging from six months to 10 years in the past. Officials said the move was part of a new campaign to quell the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising. On Monday, the army began posting snipers at key intersections in the occupied lands with orders to shoot Arabs pelting Israeli vehicles. At least four Palestinians have been wounded in ambushes in the occupied West Bank, the army said. In Bethlehem, meanwhile, troops began erecting barbed wire barriers across some roads leading into the city on Tuesday, but the area around the site believed to be Christ's birthplace remained open to visitors. On Sunday, a soldier was killed and two others wounded by a roadside bomb blast. The town's 40,000 Palestinian residents remained under a curfew. A few tourists visited the Church of the Nativity and Christ's birthplace. Normally, Bethlehem is crowded with Christian pilgrims during the Christmas season. Army prosecutors will ask for harsher sentences for stone throwers in the military courts in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, an army official said. But he would not specify what sentences would be requested. ``The policy is to deal with rock throwing in a much firmer way,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Israel army radio suggested the army hoped to halt rock throwing at Jewish settlers, who have complained of an increase in stonings in the past year. The maximum sentence for stone-throwing is 20 years, the same as for manslaughter, but it has never been imposed. Until now, sentences have ranged from about six months for first offenders who didn't cause damage to a year for those who caused some damage. Sentences of 10 years have been made for those who injured someone. Palestinian lawyer Jonathan Kuttab, who has defended hundreds of clients against stone-throwing charges, said military court judges usually follow the requests of prosecutors. Kuttab claimed there are different standards of justice between the military and civilian courts, where Jewish settlers are tried. He cited the case of settler leader Moshe Levinger who served three months in prison after shooting to death a Palestinian shoe salesman. Levinger was convicted of firing into stores after soldiers ignored his complaint that his car was stoned. ``Because Israel makes the claim that it does have all the trappings of justice, it must be noted that this is not the case,'' Kuttab said. ``The military courts are part of the mechanism of control and punishment.'' The army official rejected Kuttab's charges of unfair treatment of Palestinians, but acknowledged that sentences in military trials were imposed for deterrence as well as punishment. Army officials have said stone throwing made up about 90 percent of the violent incidents during the uprising. They estimate 100,000 cases of stone throwing since December 1987. During the uprising, Israeli soldiers and civilians have killed 777 Palestinians, while 54 Israelis have been slain by Palestinians. At least 316 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators.

DOC.HEAD: Scottish Piper Proudly Plays as Former Hostages Head Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one bracketed graf after 9th graf `The flight...' to UPDATE with plane's arrival in Frankfurt, specifying nationalities of those aboard. Picks up 10th graf, `President Saddam...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Scottish piper played proudly Tuesday as he and hundreds of other foreigners boarded flights for home after four months as hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. Callum Strachan - dressed in the traditional kilt, tam and kneesocks of his native Scotland - saluted other hostages by playing the bagpipes as they cleared Iraqi passport control for flights home. Three chartered jetliners carrying nearly 500 foreigners - including 243 who flew to Baghdad on Tuesday from Kuwait - left the Iraqi capital for London, Frankfurt and Bangkok. Diplomats said just 14 Americans were on the charter flights from Baghdad. Most of those leaving were Britons. One of the Britons, Ken Emsden, 61, said that four months after the Iraqi invasion, there was still gunfire every night in Kuwait. He said he saw the bodies of four civilians in the street outside his hideout Tuesday morning. ``The people who deserve the greatest admiration are the Kuwaitis who sheltered us despite the fact that they could be executed on the spot if they were found helping us,'' Emsden said. ``We're just happy it's finally over,'' said Sid Hatcher, 35, of Knoxville, Tenn., who was held at an industrial site in Iraq. The flight to Frankfurt carried just 14 former hostages, while the plane bound for London had 310 aboard. The Japanese-chartered plane headed for Bangkok carried 159 people, including 14 Japanese diplomats from Kuwait. (In Frankfurt, Germany, U.S. Consulate spokesman Craig Springer said seven Americans, two Canadians, two Britons, an Irishman, an Italian and an Australian comprised the former hostages on the U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 707 that landed there late Tuesday from Baghdad. The seven other Americans were on the London flight, diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity.) President Saddam Hussein announced on Thursday that Iraq would allow all foreigners to leave. He had barred many foreigners from departing, and some were detained at strategic sites to ward off a possible attack. An undisclosed number of Americans chose to stay. ``We will continue to provide all services we possibly can to all Americans left in Iraq and Kuwait,'' a senior U.S. diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the final evacuation flight for Americans, now scheduled for Thursday, ``is likely to be the last and it is also likely to be the one to evacuate U.S. Embassy personnel from Kuwait.'' The U.S. Embassy personnel in Kuwait have defied Iraqi orders to evacuate, as have British diplomats. But on Tuesday, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd indicated the two remaining British diplomats might soon leave the occupied emirate. He said in London that once all British hostages have left, ``we will work out with these two brave men how long they should stay.''

DOC.HEAD: First Hanukkah in Israel for Many Soviet Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: Many of the 150,000 Soviet Jewish emigres used the beginning of Hanukkah on Tuesday to celebrate their new lives while learning the centuries-old traditions of their faith. While the Soviet Jews knew of the eight-day festival of lights, many of the immigrants are secular Jews and know little of Jewish history. ``Either they are totally confused or talk nonsense because they have been cut off from Judaism for generations,'' said Alexander Ilyin, 27, an immigrant who gives religious instructions to newcomers. Other Soviets who immigrated earlier - as well as government ministries and organizations - have arranged special seminars and trips to help new immigrants understand the meaning of Hanukkah. ``I never knew what Hanukkah or even Judaism was in the Soviet Union,'' said Binyamin Kletzel, 58, an artist who arrived five days ago from Kuibyshev on the Volga River. ``The only thing being a Jew meant to me was that we got beat up.'' Hanna Yeruslusky, who immigrated from Kuibyshev three years ago, helped Kletzel look for an apartment before the holiday began at sundown. She said she hoped the joy of Hanukkah would make the immigrants forget their troubles adjusting to a new country. The many immigrants have strained Israel's housing and job markets, as well as the government budget. More than 1,000 Jews have been arriving in Israel daily as a result of the Soviet Union easing its emigration policies. Hanukkah marks the victory of the Jews over the Greco-Syrian kingdom in 165 B.C. The kingdom had tried to impose its culture on the Jews and desecrated the holy temple in Jerusalem with statues of Greek gods. Jews rose in revolt and drove the Syrians out of the country. According to legend, when the Jews entered Jerusalem and tried to rekindle the Temple's eternal flame, they found only enough oil for one day. But the oil miraculously lasted eight days. To commemorate the miracle, Jews light candles at sunset for eight consecutive days. The candles are placed in a candelabra called a menorah. The festival is celebrated by religious and secular Jews as a holiday that not only marks the ancient Jewish victory but also reminds Israelis of their desire to perpetuate national Jewish identity.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Drug Traffickers Free German Journalist
DOC.TEXT: German journalist Hero Buss, who was abducted by drug traffickers along with six other journalists on Aug. 30, was freed Tuesday. Juan Gomez Martinez, publisher of the daily El Colombiano, said the erman was left near the newspaper headquarters. The publisher has been acting as a spokesman for the families of the kidnapped journalists. Buss, a freelance journalist, has lived several years in Colombia. He called his Colombian wife, who lives in the northern port of Cartagena, and was quoted as telling her, ``I am here finishing my stroll.'' Buss had spent 102 days in the custody of the Medellin cartel. The Extraditables, the armed branch of the cartel, released a statement announcing Buss' release as ``recognition of the fight for the defense of human rights in Colombia and various Latin American countries.'' The statement announced the decision to go along with proposed legislation that would allow drug traffickers to be tried in Colombia and ``procedural guarantees'' of safety. President Cesar Gaviria took office Aug. 7, 1990, vowing to remain tough against drug trafficking, but hinting that he might stop extraditions to the United States and other unspecified moves to stop the bloody drug war that has killed hundreds of people the past year. Gaviria's predecessor, Virgilio Barco, launched a major offensive against the traffickers when Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, the front-running presidential candidate, was assassinated in August 1989 by gunmen employed by Colombia's drug traffickers. In the following 12 months, Barco's administration allowed 22 drug suspects to be extradited to the United States, killed Medellin cartel leader Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine magnates. The traffickers are afraid of extradition to the United States, where they are unable to indimidate judges. Many traffickers have been freed by Colombian judges under threat of violence or due to bribery. Buss was the second journalist freed by the traffickers. On Nov. 26, Juan Vitta, editor of the weekly Hoy por Hoy was released. Remaining in the hands of the traffickers are Diana Turbay, publisher of Hoy por Hoy and daughter of former President Julio Cesar Turbay Ayala; Francisco Santos Calderoon, editor of the Bogota daily El Tiempo; Azucena Lievano, editor of the a TV news program and his two cameramen. Also held by the Extraditables is Maruja Pachoon, director of the government's Film Promotion Board and her sister-in-law Beatriz Villmizar. Buss said that he did not see the other kidnap victims, but said he had been told that the others were fine and would be released starting Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Crash Scene Resembles War Zone
With AM-Interstate Pileup, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gutted trucks and cars were sprawled over a two-mile stretch of the highway in southeastern Tennessee where 15 people died and more than 50 were injured in a fiery chain reaction accident Tuesday morning. Hours after the smash-up, fireman were still spraying water on the twisted, burned-out wreckage from the 75-vehicle pileup. Rescue workers stepped over spilled cargo from trucks as well as scattered luggage and clothing thrown from cars. And the survivors marveled at their own good fortune amid the carnage that surrounded them. Mary Youness, 55, of Cleveland, and her family were next to a propane tanker truck when the accident began. They heard crashes all around in the fog, she said, but their car managed to slide onto the shoulder unscathed. ``We feel terribly lucky. This truck was on the other side of us, and a car was smashed between this truck and another truck,'' Mrs. Youness said. ``And the truck driver said that if the car had not been between them - a girl was killed in the car that was between - if the other truck had hit him, this explosion of propane would have wiped everything out,'' she said. Officials feared the death toll, the worst since the state began keeping records 20 years ago, still could mount as rescue workers searched the remains of some of the vehicles. But there were also tales of heroism. Bill Johnson, 45, was headed south on Interstate 75 about 9:30 a.m. when his citizens band radio started crackling that there was trouble ahead on the fog-shrouded highway. ``Everybody was hollering on the CB's, `Set it down,''' Johnson said. ``I stopped because I could see the tail lights of the truck ahead. But when I stopped, another one hit me in the back.'' Johnson said he got out of his pickup and rushed to check on the two people in the vehicle behind him, a four-wheel drive truck. The driver was shaken up, he said. ``I said, `Are you all right?' and he said, `Buddy, I don't know.' I said, `Will you please just get out of your truck?' He said, `I don't know,' I said, `Please, get out of your truck,''' Johnson said. Both people got out and Johnson and the driver walked around back of the four-wheel drive vehicle. Seconds later, a rental truck rushed out of the fog and crashed into the rear of the second vehicle, turning it into an unrecognizable heap of metal. ``That's how quick it hit,'' Johnson said, shaking his head. ``We got right by that before he hit .... this is the worst thing I've ever seen.'' The people, who left with rescue workers before Johnson got their names, were frightened but unhurt. ``They didn't get a scratch,'' Johnson said.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher of New York Daily News Says No Sale
LaserPhotos CX4, CX7
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of the New York Daily News on Tuesday claimed progress in regaining circulation lost in a nearly 7-week-old strike and said the tabloid isn't ready to cut losses and sell. Publisher James Hoge met with the board of directors of the Tribune Co., which owns the Daily News, to discuss the strike as about 100 pro-union pickets marched outside the landmark Tribune Tower. The strike is costly ``but not as expensive as trying to run the paper with all the excess costs and contract abuses that we had ... in the old contract,'' Hoge told a news conference. A spokesman for nine striking unions said the Daily News can't hope to survive without a settlement or sale of the newspaper. ``Our rule is that we are plowing ahead as long as we can show that we are making significant progress,'' Hoge said of putting out the newspaper under strike conditions. ``It is the opinion of everyone involved in this process that we are making significant progress and we are going forward.'' The newspaper has published every day since the strike began Oct. 25, but circulation dropped from 1.09 million. Hoge said net paid circulation was up this week to 580,000 copies from 552,000 a week ago. Hoge attributed the increase to a network of news dealers and hawkers that now total nearly half the pre-strike number of 12,000 outlets. Hoge said he was confident that advertisers who bailed out of the Daily News would return to the newspaper as circulation increases. The striking unions representing 2,100 workers claim unfair labor practices. The Daily News has hired replacement workers to put out the newspaper. On Wednesday, negotiations switch for the first time to Washington before the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. The two sides were to meet separately with a mediator. Theodore Kheel, a legal adviser to the striking unions and their frequent spokesman, called the decision to keep publishing ``a form of sheer masochism.'' ``The News has no hope of survival whatsoever in the absence of a settlement or sale,'' Kheel said. ``The sooner the board realizes that, the better everyone, including the Tribune Co., will be.'' George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella of striking unions, said Tribune Co. President Charles Brumback was ``hell-bent on a course of financial bankruptcy.'' McDonald urged Tribune Co. stockholders to call for Brumback's immediate resignation. About 100 people, most of them from Chicago union locals, picketed the Tribune Tower, led by several striking Daily News workers. The demonstration was peaceful. Gov. Mario Cuomo, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Cardinal John O'Connor addressed an estimated 6,500 people at a pro-union rally Monday in front of the Daily News offices. The Tribune Co. also publishes the Chicago Tribune.

DOC.HEAD: At the Movies: ``Mermaids''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Film opens Friday, Dec. 14.
DOC.TEXT: In a season of self-consciously serious films, ``Mermaids'' is a refreshing breather, a bittersweet reminiscence of one family's chaotic coming-of-age in the 1960s. The holiday treat in ``Mermaids'' is the addition of another memorable portrait by Cher in the gallery of women she's portrayed on screen. The entertainer, who once had trouble being accepted as a serious actress, has matured into a powerful movie presence with a gift for showing the soft center of tough women without getting gooey about it. In ``Mermaids,'' Cher is Mrs. Flax, a woman on the run from her own personal demons who takes her two young daughters along for the ride. She wears tight dresses, tends to bed the wrong men and when it all falls apart, as it does every few months, she packs up her girls and hits the road, choosing a new town by poking her finger at a map. For teen-age daughter Charlotte, who narrates this story, these moves are a recurring nightmare. Although not Catholic, she retreats into fantasies about being a nun. Charlotte, portrayed by the ubiquitous Winona Ryder (who seems to be in every movie requiring a teen-ager this season), fashions a shrine in her room and sees all events as signs from God. Her young half-sister, Kate (Christina Ricci), is obsessed with competitive swimming and seems unfazed by the upheavals as long as there's a swimming pool in their new town. We meet the fatherless Flax family as mother is breaking up with another beau and moving on. This time they settle in a picturesque New England village where the local shoe salesman (Bob Hoskins) takes a fancy to Mrs. Flax. Charlotte meanwhile becomes smitten with the young, handsome caretaker at the nearby convent, challenging her vow to become a nun. Relationships develop and careen toward an unexpected crisis which seems too clearly a filmmaker's technique for bringing the movie to a conclusion. Suspension of disbelief is essential here. Director Richard Benjamin deftly uses the splendid New England scenery and the '60s backdrop to draw Mrs. Flax's world. The songs of the era are sprinkled throughout, and a segment recalling the John F. Kennedy assassination is poignantly evocative of a calamity seen through the eyes of a teen-ager. ``It seemed there were no adults alive anymore,'' Charlotte muses as she walks the empty, leaf-strewn streets in that autumn of 1963. Winona Ryder's earnestness is appealing, and Hoskins, exuding warmth and normalcy, is the perfect foil for Cher's brassy Mrs. Flax. Some will be reminded of Cher's tough but caring mother in ``Mask.'' But Mrs. Flax is her own woman. Cher knows her well and insists that we like her. How can we resist? ``Mermaids'' is rated PG-13 with a non-explicit sex scene and discussions of sex but no objectionable language. ---= Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General audiences. All ages admitted. PG - Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 - Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R - Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. NC-17 - No one under 17 admitted.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: ``The people who deserve the greatest admiration are the Kuwaitis who sheltered us despite the fact that they could be executed on the spot if they were found helping us.'' - Ken Emsden, 61, a freed British hostage. --- ``We have reached general understanding, more or less, on all the moves in the gulf and on Israel's position.'' - Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir after meeting with President Bush. --- ``As of today, we believe that as many as 310 Americans have chosen to stay in Kuwait... As many as 200 more Americans have chosen to stay in Iraq... Obviously, the decision to leave is a deeply personal one, but we have made every effort to offer our best advice as well as the means to depart.'' - State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. --- ``I listened to President Bush and senators and congressmen stand up on television and say America will not tolerate the holding of its citizens. And my brother has been chained to a wall in a dirty basement cell in Beirut - this will be his sixth Christmas.'' - Peggy Say, sister of Terry Anderson, one of the 16 Western hostages held by radical Moslem groups in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager Guilty of Attempted Murder in Central Park Jogger Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs at bottom to UPDATE with comment from juror. Antron is cq in 21st graf.
DOC.TEXT: A 16-year-old on Tuesday became the first defendant convicted of attempted murder in the gang rape of the Central Park Jogger. A second youth was acquitted of the same charge and convicted of lesser charges. Spectators erupted in anger and shock when the verdicts were returned against Kevin Richardson and Kharey Wise after 12 days of jury deliberation. Richardson's mother, Grace Cuffey, fainted and the courtroom was cleared while she was treated with oxygen at her seat. ``You're going to pay for this. Jesus is going to get you. You made this ... up,'' Wise told prosecutor Elizabeth Lederer as he was led from the courtroom in handcuffs. Richardson, 16, was convicted of attempted murder, rape, sodomy, robbery, assault and riot. Wise, 18, loudly cursed Lederer after he was acquitted of 10 of 13 counts against him, including attempted murder, rape and sodomy. He was convicted of first-degree assault, sexual abuse and riot. Three other teen-agers were convicted in August of rape and assault in the case. Richardson and Wise were jailed without bail pending a Jan. 9 sentencing. Richardson, charged as a minor, faces a maximum prison term of five to 10 years. Wise, charged as an adult, could receive nearly nine to 26 years in prison if the judge orders him to serve the terms concurrently. Wise admitted in a videotapd statement that the April 19, 1989, attack on a woman investment broker ``was my first rape, and it will be my last.'' Wise's lawyer, Colin Moore, argued that police coerced the statement from his client. Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said he was pleased the jury had rejected that allegation. ``A jury has rejected spurious claims that the police manufactured evidence and used coercive tactics to obtain confessions,'' Morgenthau said. The woman was not widely identified because she was a sexual assault victim. Her case generated enormous public interest and debate. Critics of the national media attention attributed it to her status as a white investment banker in a city where minority crime victims get less attention. Others cited her dramatic fight for life, her recovery and return to work, and her quiet bravery. The verdicts came in the second trial stemming from the attack on the woman, now 30, along a jogging path in Central Park. She still suffers vision, balance and olfactory problems. Wise and Richardson wept and hugged each other when the verdicts were read. ``I am obviously shattered, very, very disappointed,'' said Richardson's attorney, Howard Diller. ``I'm really dismayed the jury found him guilty on every single count. It's shocking.'' Moore said ``a fair and just verdict would have been an acquittal on all counts.'' Both attorneys said they would appeal. Supporters of the defendants yelled at the judge and the prosecutors. The woman, found about four hours after the attack, lost three-fourths of her blood. Her skull was broken, her left cheekbone was crushed and she had bruises all over her body. Antron McCray, Yusef Salaam, and Raymond Santana, all 16, were cnnvicted Aug. 18 of rape, assault and other charges in the case. All were sentenced in September to five to 10 years in prison. Steven Lopez, 16, will be the last to face charges during a trial scheduled for early next year. The second trial began much as the first had, with Lederer saying the defendants' own words would convict them. Defense lawyers charged videotaped statements were coerced by racist police looking for black and Hispanic suspects. The statements were the prosecution's chief evidence. Wise described how the victim screamed, kicked and struggled violently until she was struck unconscious with a rock. Lederer asked Wise whether he thought they had left the woman dead. ``That's the way I looked at it,'' he said. Wise later said police hit and tricked him into fabricating the confession. His attorney charged police and prosecutors with using ``Hitlerian tactics.'' Diller compared the ``hue and cry'' in the case to that of the arrest and conviction of Bruno Hauptmann in the 1932 kidnap-murder of aviator Charles Lindbergh's infant son. Lederer insisted the case was ``not about race. It's about violence. It's about right and wrong.'' Juror Victoria Bryers said Wise was convicted of first-degree assault because the jury felt he showed depraved indifference to the jogger's plight. ``He was at the scene and left her to die,'' said Bryers, the mother of three children.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Charge Firm with Cheating Workers Out of Insurance Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities unsealed a 42-count indictment Tuesday charging six men with operating a $21 million investment and insurance scam that left more than 1,300 families with no health insurance coverage. The grand jury indictment resulted from a two-year investigation by the FBI, the Internal Revenue Service and inspectors from the U.S. Postal Service and the Department of Labor. ``What is especially frightening is that we all can be victimized by this type of criminal enterprise because each of us has a very fundamental need for a health insurance policy that will assure us and our families that we can afford the health care we may need,'' said Julian De La Rosa, inspector general with the Labor Department. He spoke at a news conference at the federal courthouse in Charlotte. ``There are more than 1,350 victims that have been identified in this one investigation,'' De La Rosa said. ``But the tragedy is not confined to these 1,350 unfortunate people.'' The indictment describes allegations of fraud by the now-defunct Cap Staffing of Charlotte, a firm which leased employees to more than 120 firms. The company was to use fees paid by the firms to provide health insurance and other benefits to the workers. But the indictment said the company's managers used the funds for themselves. The companies that used Cap Staffing are in North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Virginia, Kentucky, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Illinois, the indictment said. The issue of such health insurance scams was the subject of a hearing last spring in the U.S. Senate, and De La Rosa said his office is investigating about three dzen similar schemes. ``The victims number in the tens of thousands with unpaid medical claims totaling in the tens of millions of dollars,'' he said. Six men were arrested Tuesday: Robert W. Long, Victor S. Blackwell and Jerry M. Wolicki, of Charlotte; David R. Harris, of Greenville, S.C.; Michael A. Krebser, of Stuart, Fla.; and Michael H. Spieles, of Palm City, Fla. In an accompanying civil action, officials also seized seven homes, 26 vehicles and business and personal bank accounts from the men. The property was worth $3 million, officials said. Long and Blackwell made short court appearances Tuesday morning, where they were released on bond, said U.S. Attorney Tom Ashcraft. Ashcraft said the seized assets would be used to help the victims of the scam, but ``it would be a mistake to think there is a big pot of gold out there.'' De La Rosa said the biggest tragedy was that many of the victims were left uninsurable. ``This has had a catastrophic effect on many of these people who have been refused expensive and medically necessary care because they lack health insurance and they may never be able to obtain it for any pre-existing conditions,'' De La Rosa said. The charges listed in the indictment include mail fraud, money laundering, embezzlement and conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Hershey Deploys First Round of Heat-Resistant Chocolate
LaserPhoto HX2
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia finally have chocolate bars that melt in their mouths, not in the sand. At the request of the Army, Hershey Foods Corp. sent 144,000 ``Hershey's Desert Bars'' that won't melt in 100 degree-plus heat. The first round of heat-resistant chocolate sent to the Persian Gulf was a test of the product, said Hershey spokeswoman Bonnie Glass. If the chocolate bars taste good and are tough enough for desert warfare, Hershey will send thousands more, she said. ``Chocolate has long been an American favorite and we are happy that we can supply the soldiers in Saudi Arabia with a familiar taste from home,'' said Richard A. Zimmerman, Hershey's chairman and chief executive officer. Ms. Glass said Hershey has cooperated with the Army since 1937 in providing specially made chocolate bars. In June 1937, Hershey sent 90,000 candy bars to military personnel. ``There have been heat-resistant bars in the past, but one of the specifications given out by the Army is that it tastes good, like commercially available chocolate,'' she said. ``Another specification is that it is made with real milk chocolate,'' Ms. Glass said. Ms. Glass would not answer any other questions on the bar's contents or how it is made. The troops haven't sent word yet on the Desert Bar, but an Army spokesman said the chocolate candy is good. ``It's quite a tasty bar. A familiar chocolate candy bar and it's in a familiar form,'' said Harvey Keene, spokesman for U.S. Army Nattick Research, Development and Engineering Center in Nattick, Mass. The development of candy for military use isn't unprecedented. M&M's, a product of Mars Inc., first were made for military personnel during World War II. What made M&M's so useful to the military is as simple to explain as the product slogan: ``Melts in your mouth, not in your hands.''

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Communists Agree to Allow Political Parties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-22, `The students ...,' with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Alia meeting with students, minor editing. Picks up penultimate graf pvs, `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communist Party in Albania, the last country practicing Stalinism in Europe, on Tuesday decided to allow the formation of other political parties, the state news agency ATA said. The surprise announcement in the country of 3.1 million residents was made in a communique released after a meeting of the party's policy-setting Central Committee in the capital of Tirana. ``The plenum was of the opinion that the creation of independent political organizations according to the law in force is to the good of the further democratization of the life of the country and pluralism,'' the ATA report said. The Balkan nation, which opened its borders slightly this year after decades of isolationism under the late Enver Hoxha, would be the last country in Europe to introduce a multiparty system. Albania broke relations with the Soviet Union in 1961 over Hoxha's Stalinist and pro-Chinese policies. Sixteen years later, Albania severed ties with the Chinese. Albania has scheduled elections for Feb. 10. They are seen as a test of the government's willingness to live up to pledges of gradual reform and of the people's ability to exercise a measure of political freedom after decades of authoritarian rule. But it was not immediately clear if there will be enough time for new political parties to form and compete in the elections. The Central Committee meeting was held following student unrest that started this weekend and continued Tuesday with a protest of between 2,000 and 3,000 students. ATA said the Central Committee also fired five full members and two candidate members of the Politburo and called on Premier Adil Carcani to make ``the necessary changes'' in his government. Yugoslav and other observers believed the Politburo reshuffle and the call for the creation of independent parties amounted to a defeat of the hardliners led by Nexhmie Hoxha, 69, widow of Hoxha, who died five years ago. It scheduled an party congress for June 1991 and a national party meeting on Dec. 26 ``to define the electoral platform of the party and endorse the list of its candidates for deputies to the People's Assembly.'' Earlier Tuesday, students demanded Communist authorities provide more heat and light for their dormitories. President Ramiz Alia has conceded Albania's economy was ``on the brink of a state of emergency.'' A severe drought has curbed power supplies. Most of Albania's power comes from hydroelectric plants. The students gathered outside their rooms in Tirana and stayed away from classes on Tirana University's campus on the edge of the city, diplomats in Tirana said. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said police were out in force, apparently to keep the students away from the public. No violence or arrests were reported. On Sunday, several students were hurt and detained in clashes with club-wielding police, diplomats said. ATA, monitored in Vienna, took the unusual step of reporting unrest on Sunday and Monday. Alia met with student representatives late Tuesday and urged them to return to classes or else ``incidents which nobody desires could occur.'' According to radio Tirana monitored in London, Alia told the students that top national leaders had followed the protests ``and from the beginning had expressed themselves in favor of dialogue.'' The students told Alia their idea of creating an independent political organization of students and young intellectuals, and Alia said they could submit their demand for registration to the ministry of justice. The government acted relatively swiftly to defuse a political crisis in July, when thousands of Albanians streamed into foreign embassies in Tirana, taking refuge until being allowed to emigrate. Since then, the Communist leadership, which has tinkered with economic and political reform following Eastern Europe's 1989 revolutions, has come under further pressure with the defection of Ismail Kadare, the country's greatest writer. He fled in October, saying his hopes that Alia could become Albania's Mikhail Gorbachev had been dashed.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze To Hold Unprecedented Meeting With Angolan Rebel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 10th graf: ``In Lisbon,'' two Angolan sides not to meet in Washington; SUBS 15th graf: ``During the,'' with death toll
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's top diplomat will meet here on Wednesday with the leader of the Angolan rebel group which has been fighting the Soviet-backed government for more than 15 years. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told a news conference in Houston, where he was winding up discussions with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, that he has agreed to meet with Jonas Savimbi, whose UNITA rebels have been fighting the leftist government in Luanda since shortly after it seized power. It is the first meeting between Shevardnadze and Savimbi. At the same time, the State Department announced that Angolan Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro van Dunem will meet separately with Baker on Wednesday. Baker met with Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos last March in Namibia.
