The United States and the Soviet Union have been supporting rival factions in Angola's civil war but lately have been encouraging the two sides to reach a negotiated settlement. ``We are trying to do what we can to help bring the parties closer together so the next round of negotiations set for January in Lisbon will be successful,'' a State Department official said. ``This is a major development that demonstrates continued Soviet-American efforts to cooperate on these issues,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official said the Savimbi-Shevardnadze meeting was ``95 per cent nailed'' down before Baker opened talks with the Soviet diplomat on Monday in Houston. Savimbi spent part of the day in Washington conferring with State Department officials. In Lisbon, an Angolan government spokesman said the foreign minister or other Angolan officials would not see Savimbi in Washington. A joint statement of Baker and Shevardnadze issued late in the day Tuesday said the meetings will discuss such issues as a cease-fire, free participation of UNITA and other parties in Angola's political process and the convening of free elections with monitoring by neutral observers. Also on the agenda will be the termination of deliveries of all lethal material to Angola after agreement on a cease-fire. According to official U.S. estimates, the Soviet Union has continued to send hundreds of millions of dollars worth of weapons into Angola. Last fall, Congress approved legislation that would halt the $60 million a year aid to the Angolan rebels if the Angolan government agrees to a free election and the Soviets halt arms deliveries to government forces. Angola was a Portuguese colony until 1974, when the withdrawal of the colonial government set off a scramble for power won by a Marxist group. During the following years of the Cold War, Angola was a divisive issue for the superpowers, and according to Angolan government figures, 350,000 people lost their lives in the fighting. Cuba first sent troops to support Angola's Marxist government in 1975, and not long thereafter Congress forbade U.S. support for government opponents. During the Reagan administration, Congress lifted the prohibition and covert U.S. aid to UNITA began in 1986. In December 1988, President Fidel Castro agreed to a phased withdrawal of his forces, a process that is scheduled to end next July. The agreement was brokered by the United States and received strong encouragement from the Soviets. But progress toward a settlement in Angola has been halting. A cease-fire agreed to last year broke down quickly and government forces launched an offsensive a year ago against UNITA. On the plus side, the Angola's ruling party agreed this past weekend to open the way to a multi-party system, which has long been a key Savimbi demand.

DOC.HEAD: Last Escapee in Helicopter Prison Breakout Captured
DOC.TEXT: The last convict sought by police after a daring helicopter prison breakout in southern France has been captured in Algeria, police announced Tuesday. Hamid Mazouz, 37, an Algerian serving a life sentence in France for a string of armed robberies, was taken into custody by Algerian authorities at the end of November, Bordeaux police said. Mazouz and three French convicts escaped from the high-security Lannemezan prison near the Spanish border Nov. 5 in a private helicopter hijacked by a friend. They ordered the captive pilot to fly across the border, where they abandoned him and the helicopter and attempted to go into hiding. The three French convicts - all killers serving life terms - were recaptured after gunbattles with police in Zaragoza and Huesca. But Mazouz escaped and remained at large despite efforts by Spanish police to track him down. Bordeaux police said Monday that Mazouz was arrested while trying to enter Algeria, where he is wanted on charges of voluntary homicide. The details of his arrest were not immediately available. It was unclear whether Algerian authorities would extradite him to France or try him on the homicide charges.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds More Foreigners Leave Iraq and Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf pvs, `The flight ...,' to UPDATE with plane landing in London. Picks up 16th graf pvs, `A Japanese ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHR1,2; WX12,19; TP2; BAG1
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 500 more foreigners flew out of Iraq and occupied Kuwait on Tuesday, ending four months' captivity following the Iraqi invasion of the oil-rich emirate. One freed British hostage said he saw bodies on the street outside his Kuwait hideout Tuesday morning. Three chartered flights brought 243 foreigners from Kuwait to Baghdad to join hundreds of other hostages on three chartered jetliners that left Iraq for Bangkok, London and Frankfurt. Callum Strachan, dressed in a traditional kilt from his native Scotland, saluted the other hostages by playing his bagpipes as the foreigners cleared Iraqi passport control. ``The people who deserve the greatest admiration are the Kuwaitis who sheltered us despite the fact that they could be executed on the spot if they were found helping us,'' said 61-year-old Briton Ken Emsden. He said there still was gunfire every night in Kuwait and that he saw the bodies of four civilians in the street Tuesday morning. ``We're just happy it's finally over,'' said Sid Hatcher, 35, of Knoxville, Tenn., who was held at an industrial site in Iraq. Diplomats said just 14 Americans were on the flights from Baghdad - seven headed to Frankfurt and seven to London. There were no Americans on the flight from Kuwait to Baghdad. ``We must have gotten them all,'' said one American consular official, referring to earlier evacuation flights from the Persian Gulf emirate. He spoke on condition of anonymity. In Washington, the Bush administration said a planned evacuation flight Thursday is ``likely to be the last'' for Americans and will probably also carry home the remaining staff of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``We would anticipate that once all Americans who want out have been able to get out that we would remove the entire staff of the embassy,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. In Frankfurt, Germany, U.S. Consulate spokesman Craig Springer said seven Americans, two Canadians, two Britons, an Irishman, an Italian and an Australian were on the U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 707 that landed there late Tuesday from Baghdad. Before departure, diplomats said six Britons were aboard and did not mention an Australian or Italian. The discrepancy was not explained immediately. Springer said the former hostages would stay overnight and fly to their final destinations Wednesday on regular commercial flights. The flight to London carried about 310 people, nearly all of them Britons but including seven Americans. They arrived late Tuesday at Gatwick airport outside London. A Japanese-chartered jetliner left Baghdad for Bangkok with 159 people aboard, including 14 Japanese diplomats from Kuwait. Nearly all the others were former Japanese hostages. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said in Washington that more than 500 Americans, most of them children, are remaining in Kuwait and Iraq - some because of roots there; in other cases, because the non-American head of household could not get Iraqi permission to leave. Boucher said that except for three Americans with visa problems, all Americans wanting to leave apparently have left, so far as is known. After his troops seized Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein barred many foreigners from leaving and detained some foreigners at strategic sites to ward off a possible attack. Last week, Saddam said all foreigners who wanted to leave could do so. The United Nations has authorized the use of force to liberate Kuwait unless Iraq withdraws by Jan. 15. By that date, the U.S.-led multinational force assembled in the gulf and Saudi Arabia after the invasion will include more than 500,000 troops - about the same size as the Iraqi force in and around Kuwait. In other developments Tuesday: -Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said he and President Bush have smoothed relations between their two countries. ``We have reached general understanding, more or less, on all the moves in the gulf and on Israel's position,'' Shamir told reporters after meeting with Bush in Washington. He did not provide details. -Libya's official news agency, JANA, said Libya has asked Iraq to hand over some American hostages to Libya. The agency said Libya wants to exchange the Americans for former Libyan prisoners of war who were taken from Chad. The report did not give any numbers. -France said it will send nearly 4,000 more soldiers to Saudi Arabia by Jan. 15, boosting its deployment there to about 10,000. -The first of 170 Czechoslovak chemical decontamination experts left for Saudi Arabia. Czechoslovakia's CTK news agency said all the volunteers will be in the gulf region by week's end. -The Commerce Department reported that higher prices for imported oil and spending for overseas military operations helped boost the deficit in the broadest measure of foreign trade to $25.59 billion in the third quarter, up 13.9 percent.

DOC.HEAD: War Spawns Child Starvation, Child ooldiers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One graf SUBS for 23rd graf, Monrovia was ... CORRECTING former population to about 425,000. Picks up 24th graf, The war .. .
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Four-year-old Falah Saah, too weak from starvation to cry out, could only murmur listlessly as he lay in his mother's lap. ``I want drink, drink, drink,'' he said softly, nearly drowned out by the moans from other sick children in the ward at Island Hospital, one of only two hospitals still operating in Monrovia, the capital of war-wrecked Liberia. His mother, Maita Solui, said he is one of only three of her seven children to survive the West African country's yearlong civil war. Hundreds of children have died of starvation, and doctors say that unless a huge food aid program is launched, thousands more will succumb. Other youngsters, brutalized by seeing mothers raped and fathers, brothers and sisters killed, became child soldiers in the rebel armies. Falah's eldest brother joined up, and was killed. The physical and mental condition of the surviving children has raised fears about the future generation of this West African nation. Relief workers say the degree of starvation has been so great that many children who live will suffer brain damage. The child soldiers suffer in other ways. At the rebel base in Caldwell, outside the capital, a young boy played with a remote-control toy car. Draped over his shoulder was a machine gun - a real one. ``I'm a man, I have killed like a man,'' boasted another little boy. He looked 6 or 7 years old, with a gun nearly as tall as he was, but refused to give his age. For orphans who have watched their parents killed by Liberian troops, the rebel camp offered a substitute family, food - and an opportunity for revenge. ``They are still little children, but how are we going to convince them of that when it's all over?'' said Myrtle Gibson, a real estate agent who turned to relief work. ``How are we going to make them real people again? ``After this war, we're going to have a lot more wars to fight.'' Hunger is the most immediate problem. Starving Monrovians ate the city's pet dogs and cats months ago. They ate zoo animals, including chimpanzees. Then they turned to the vegetation, eating weeds and slashing down palm trees to eat the filling but non-nutritious fiber under the bark. A little food is on sale - bunches of green leaves and weeds, some stolen tinned goods, a few oranges, looted rice. But few can afford it. The Belgian branch of the international aid group Doctors Without Borders started supplementary feeding now reaching 3,000 children with help from newly arrived United Nations workers. U.N. representative Michael Heyn said the relief workers hoped to soon feed 25,000 children. But he said 90,000 children in Monrovia alone need a special diet to recover. ``The world community has focused mainly on the political and military aspects of the crisis, but does not realize yet that the Liberian people are literally starving and dying, particularly the children,'' he said. Island Hospital has become a center for orphans of the war, children who have lost their parents in panicked rushes away from the fighting. Then there are the wounded, like a little girl whose leg had to be amputated, a boy who lost an eye. Ellen James, a nurse at the hospital, goes out on the streets with other health workers to bring in starving children, but they can only help a few. ``We pick up 10, maybe 12; meanwhile they are dying in their hundreds,'' she said. ``It is difficult to find a child who is not suffering from severe malnutrition,'' said Dr. Richard Ndamse, one of six volunteers working at the hospital for a token payment of six cups of rice a month. The hospital has no running water and little electricity. A generator was turned on only for emergency operations because of a fuel shortage. Monrovia has been without running water, electricity and regular food supplies for six months. The victims in the war have been mostly civilians. It is not known how many have died - certainly more than the 10,000 killed in the fighting that began last Dec. 23. Monrovia was once a city of about 425,000 people, about one-quarter of whom remain. According to the United Nations, more than 750,000 Liberians have fled to neighboring countries. The war began a rebellion against the corrupt and oppressive government of the late President Samuel Doe and turned into a tribal conflict with three warring armies. They agreed to a cease-fire on Nov. 28, but an interim government and other provisions still remain to be negotiated.

DOC.HEAD: Georgians Outlaw Separatists, Kirgizia Elects New Speaker
DOC.TEXT: The Georgian legislature Tuesday abolished the autonomy of a separatist minority in the southern republic, news reports said. The vote could set up a new confrontation in the region. Also Tuesday, the Kirgiz legislature elected a new speaker during a session expected to take up a sovereignty declaration. The Central Asian republic is the only one of 15 republics that has not declared some form of autonomy or sovereignty. The law by the recently elected Georgian Supreme Soviet legislature would end 68 years of autonomy for Ossetia, a small enclave in the northern part of the republic that has demanded greater self-rule. Ossetia is one of 20 autonomous areas in the Soviet Union which have limited jurisdiction over their affairs. A handful have declared themselves full republics. Like other ethnic groups, they fear rising nationalism by republic leaders. Ossetians last week elected their own legislature, but ethnic Georgians living in the region boycotted the vote, according to the independent news agency Interfax. The state news agency Tass quoted ``observers'' as saying Soviet Interior Ministry troops would be necessary if the Georgian parliament imposes a curfew and a state of emergency in Ossentia. Soviet troops have been deployed in Georgia and other republics following ethnic tension, although some hard-liners have demanded more soldiers to stop all secessionist drives. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev replaced his moderate interior minister, Vadim Bakatin, last week with former Latvian KGB chief Boris Pugo. Hard-liners welcomed the appointment and predicted a crackdown to stop fragmentation of the union. Tuesday in Kirgizia, the legislature elected Medetkan Shermikulov, 51, as speaker of their chamber, Tass said. He will replace Absamat Masaliev, who resigned Monday to concentrate on his duties as Kirgiz Communist Party chief. The Kirgiz legislature also planned to consider resolutions on republic sovereignty and its stance on Gorbachev's proposed national Union Treaty. Tass did not say whether the legislature took the measures.

DOC.HEAD: Canada Unveils $3 Billion `Green Plan' to Safeguard Environment
DOC.TEXT: The government unveiled its $3 billion ``green plan'' on Tuesday, promising to create five new national parks by 1996 and to set aside 12 percent of Canadian territory to safeguard wildlife and ecosystems. Environment Minister Robert de Cotret's plan includes more than 100 measures to protect Canada's land, water, soil, forests and wildlife over the next five years. ``Three billion dollars is a lot of money,'' de Cotret said at a news conference. ``That's three thousand million dollars. It's all fresh, new money. The only thing recycled in the green plan is the paper it's written on.'' However, opposition spokesmen and environmentalists criticized the plan, calling it vague and lacking emphasis on enforcement of pollution regulations. ``This document will do nothing to help the Canadian ecosystem,'' said Dan McDermott, a spokesman for Greenpeace. ``It is neither green nor a plan.'' The plan includes a commitment to put aside one-eighth of Canadian territory as ``protected space'' for wildlife and ecosystems - almost double the existing 6.9 percent. However, that goal will require the cooperation of the provinces, and some have already indicated they don't support it, said Lee Clark, parliamentary secretary to de Cotret. The green plan promises the virtual elimination of toxic pollution and reduction of emissions that cause ground-level ozone, the major ingredient in urban smog. It sets aside $100 million for an environmental initiative in the Arctic, but offers few details on the strategy. The plan also sets a goal of cutting Canada's garbage production in half by 2000. It promises new legislation on the safety of drinking water, protection of wild animals and plants, promotion of energy efficiency, and dumping of waste in the oceans. The plan promises to establish at least five new national parks within six years.

DOC.HEAD: Candlelight Ceremonies Honor Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with ceremonies going ahead, quotes, color. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Evansville and ...'
DOC.TEXT: Candles, towboat lights and truck horns briefly united residents of dozens of Midwest cities along the Ohio and Mississippi rivers Tuesday night in a tribute to soldiers in Operation Desert Shield. Residents in at least 47 cities in six states, most of them small towns along the Ohio River, took part in the candlelight ceremonies at 6:45 p.m., said organizer Marvin Peter of Evansville. ``My son is over there and the only way I can help him is to show people I am patriotic and support him doing his duty, whatever it is,'' said Lee Wright, who held a candle in a gathering of more than 1,000 people at Evansville's riverfront. Some of the ceremonies were sponsored by chambers of commerce and others were organized by support groups for soldiers' families. The tribute lasted about a half an hour. Vietnam veteran Russell Abrams was one of several hundred people who heard the National Anthem and watched as candles were lit in Owensboro, Ky. Abrams said he wished a similar ceremony had replaced the protests during his three years at war. ``It would have done my heart a lot of good to know this was going on at home instead of what was,'' he said. In Louisville, Ky., about more than 200 people sang ``America the Beautiful'' and other patriotic songs. About 150 people in Cincinnati sang ``Let Their Be Peace on Earth,'' and a passing barge blew its horn and flashed a light skyward. Residents of cities in Pennsylvania, Illinois, Virginia and Tennessee also took part, Peter said. ``Trucks on the interstate passed the word by CB radio to honk their horns for five minutes at 6:45, and churches rang their bells ,'' Peter said. ``Some of the cities were pretty far inland, like Jackson, Tenn., and some places in central Indiana.'' Evansville and two other Ohio River cities, Henderson and Owensboro in Kentucky, were the first to plan the event. After that, the idea spread up and down the river and along the Mississippi River, Peter said. ``It's just mushroomed like crazy,'' he said. ``You look at the whole thing, and that's thousands and thousands of people.'' The event was meant to signal support for the soldiers and their families, but made no statement about the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf prompted by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Peter said. ``You hear lots about the little groups of anti-war demonstrators,'' he said. ``But this is mid-America very quietly doing their thing.'' Almost 90 towboats operated by American Commercial Barge Line Co. were instructed to shine their lights into the air at 6:45 p.m. and blow their whistles, Vice President Chris Brinkop said from the company's Jeffersonville, Ind., headquarters. Most of the boats were on the Ohio River, he said, with some on the Mississippi River as well. ``I can't say that I remember anything like this happening before,'' Brinkop said. He said the towboat crews were sympathetic with the plight of soldiers and their families who are separated by Operation Desert Shield. ``We have crews out at Christmas, and we know that's a terrible hard time to be away from home,'' he said. Peter said the ceremony began with United We Stand, a support group he formed in August for Evansville familes of soldiers serving in Operation Desert Shield. Peter's son, 21-year-old Pfc. Eric Peter, is stationed in Saudi Arabia with the Army's 82nd Airborne Division out of Fort Bragg, N.C. ``What you have here I think is a major show of support for the troops and the families,'' Peter said. ``Everyone hopes for peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Westerners Flee Chaotic Somalia
DOC.TEXT: Western embassies and aid organizations are urging their nationals to leave Somalia, where banditry, rebellions and an accelerating breakdown of law and order put life at risk. Roughly 50 or more Westerners left the capital, Mogadishu, since last weekend following directives from the U.S., British and German embassies and the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. The foreigners left a city beset by a steep increase in poverty and street crime, violence from security forces, an advancing rebel army and a collapsing economy. Observers say President Mohammed Siad Barre faces the greatest threat to his 21-year rule. ``It's a terrible situation,'' said a Western diplomat who monitors Somalia for his mission. ``It has all the classic signs of a regime on its last legs.'' He spoke on condition of anonymity. Since June, six or more unexplained bombings hit diplomatic missions and government offices and at least three foreigners died in robberies, holdups and car thefts. In July, security forces fired on a soccer stadium crowd who jeered the president, killing at least 60 people, diplomats say. In July, the Red Beret presidential guard seized at least 36 four-wheel drive vehicles at gunpoint from Western organizations. The fanatically loyal Red Beret battalion, drawn from Siad Barre's Marehan subclan, guards him around the clock. He had a bunker built at Mogadishu's international airport, which doubles as an air force base. Diplomats say he has been known to spend time there. It affords a quick escape route by air. On Sunday, Germany ordered the nearly two dozen Germans to leave Somalia, except for a skeleton staff at the embassy. It said it did not know how many Germans might still be in the Horn of Africa country for aid groups or private businesses.. The Americans and British last weekend also advised all non-essential personnel and dependents to leave, and urged tourists not to visit. A Foreign Office spokesman in London said about 100 Britons remain in Mogadishu. The State Department advisory urged the more than 100 private American citizens in Somalia - a nation of more than 6 million people - to leave as soon as possible. Those who stayed should keep in touch with the embassy and use caution. ``Communal violence is occurring in ... Mogadishu and violent crime and vehicle thefts are increasingly common. A state of civil war exists in much of the countryside,'' the warning said. Siad Barre, who seized power in a bloodless 1969 coup, has fought a series of clan-based rebel groups in recent years. Rebels of the recently formed United Somali Congress, which springs from the large, central Hawiye clan, are reportedly within 30 miles of the capital. Further north, Siad Barre is challenged by the Somali National Movement, which draws its strength from the Isaaq clan and has been fighting to overthrow him since 1982. In the south, renegade Col. Omar Jess leads a force whose core is a battalion he induced to desert with him last year. The Somalia Patriotic Movement also operates in the south. As the war intensified, many fled the countryside for the capital, where the population tripled since last one year. The Western diplomat blamed some capital city banditry on Somalis who moved to Mogadishu from the nation's desert regions. ``They come to Mogadishu heavily armed and from a culture of free-lance banditry,'' he said. ``They have no wherewithal. They're nomads not used to living in cities. ``They are forced to shoot people to get something to eat.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced to Community Service over Fatal Jump
DOC.TEXT: A worker in charge of a bungee jump that ended in death was sentenced Wednesday to 200 hours of community service after being convicted of manslaughter. High Court Justice Thomas Thorp said jailing 19-year-old Jason John Collett would achieve nothing. Collett was in charge of an amusement park bungee jump on Feb. 10 when Thomas Wayne Hemi, 19, died of multiple injuries after hitting the ground. Participants in the thrill-seeking support jump from a bridge or other high place with an elasticized bungee cord attached to their ankles that is designed to stop their fall just above the surface. Hemi's cord had not been properly secured to the tower from which he plunged. The judge said Hemi was Collett's friend and the memory of what happened would stay with him throughout his life. Collett had clearly been ``unacceptably lackadaisical'' on the bungee tower, Thorp said. The jury had, however, added a strong plea for mercy with its verdict.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Bud Goes Independent
DOC.TEXT: The original Budweiser brewery will pay $6.5 million to leave government control next year and link with its U.S. counterpart, a news agency said Tuesday. Budvar, the small brewery in the southern Bohemian town of Ceske Budejovice, known as Budweis in German, has brewed its namesake beer since the 19th century. Adolphus Busch, a Bavarian native, acquired the rights to sell the beer in North America early this century. St. Louis-based Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc., the world's largest beer producer, tried to set up a joint venture with Budvar in 1988, but Communist authorities nixed the deal at the time. Efforts for ties between the companies were renewed following last year's democratic revolution. Government authorities sought compensation from Budvar in exchange for independence and the right to use the famous trademark. Budvar workers went on strike Monday in an effort to speed up the talks. Antonin Kratochvile, general manager of the state-controlled brewery chain Jihoceske Pivovary, said Monday that Budvar had agreed to pay the group $6.5 million for independence. ``After long negotiations which lasted almost a year the conflict was finally resolved,'' the official CTK news agency reported. CTK said the brewery would be independent in January. ``The Budvar beer is being brewed again for local distribution and export as well,'' CTK added. Details of a possible U.S-Czech joint venture have not been disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Stop's Truck Sign Comes Down - Kind Of
DOC.TEXT: The truck stops here, says Vincent Gramuglia, at least until he can figure out his next move. Gramuglia's controversial tractor-trailer truck sign was pulled Monday from its 50-foot perch alongside the New York State Thruway and became lodged against the same storage tank it was ordered removed from by a judge. ``We've got a unique problem,'' Gramuglia said. ``The truck is stuck.'' Gramuglia's 55-foot rig sat atop an empty oil storage tank and served as a huge billboard to advertise the ``three truck stops, four motels and seven restaurants'' available off the highway in Fultonville, about 40 miles west of Albany. After a yearlong battle with Thruway Authority officials, who said the sign was a distraction to motorists, Gramuglia agreed in state Supreme Court last week to take the sign down. On Monday, with about 75 people and three television news crews on hand, he tried to do just that. Gramuglia, owner of the Countryside Fuel Stop, said he used torches to cut where the truck was welded to a huge steel I-beam. He placed rollers under the I-beam, greased the whole operation with Italian olive oil and used a tow truck's winch to pull the truck off. When the 12-ton truck fell, its back end wedged itself 4 to 6 feet into the ground, with the cab leaning on the storage tank, Gramuglia said. Further attempts to winch the truck off resulted in two broken steel cables, he said. ``They can't say we didn't comply with the Supreme Court ruling,'' said Gramuglia, who admitted he was having a good laugh over the problem. ``We'll take it off eventually, but we'll leave it like that for a few days.'' ``It's more of distraction now than it was when it was sitting on top of the tank,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration to Ask Allies for More Money for Gulf Operation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf: ``In an,'' Sununu puts Iraq wtihdrawal odds at 50-50
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Hostages Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration plans to ask U.S. allies to chip in more money to offset the enormous cost of sending and sustaining more than 400,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon said Tuesday. The Pentagon also announced that Iraq now has more than half a million troops in and around Kuwait - 50,000 more than U.S. intelligence estimates of a week ago and five times the size of the army that invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Monday said a continuing Iraqi buildup indicated that President Saddam Hussein has no intention of giving up Kuwait, despite the optimism generated by Saddam's release of American and other hostages. In an interview Tuesay night on CNN's ``Larry King Live'' program, White House chief of staff John Sununu was asked if Hussein would pull out of Kuwait. ``I think right now it's 50-50, and it's hard to give a better answer than that,'' Sununu replied. As a second planeload of Americans left Iraq on Tuesday bound for Frankfurt, Germany, and then the United States, the White House said an evacuation flight scheduled for Thursday probably will be the last to leave Iraq and probably will carry the remaining staff of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``We would anticipate that once all Americans who want out have been able to get out that we would remove the entire staff of the embassy,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said that for diplomatic and political purposes, Bush would like to leave the American flag flying above the embassy to signify that it is an active U.S. outpost. ``From a practical matter, we won't have anyone there to raise the flag. So, that'll just play itself out,'' Fitzwater said. The evacuation of U.S. civilians coincided with a further buildup of U.S. troops in the area. Pete Williams, a Pentagon spokesman, said American air, sea and ground forces in the gulf area have risen by 10,000 since last week, to 260,000. The latest arrivals apparently are the lead elements of a huge U.S. reinforcement that President Bush ordered Nov. 8 to strengthen the U.S. offensive capability. By late January about 430,000 U.S. Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps personnel are expected to be in the area - the largest U.S. expeditionary force since the Vietnam war. Williams also announced that ground, sea and air forces dispatched to the gulf area from Britain, France and 24 other allied nations now total more than 220,000. He said he could not disclose how many forces were sent by each country. Bush's decision to expand Operation Desert Shield deployments beyond the 240,000 originally planned in August threw a monkey wrench into the Pentagon's efforts to estimate future costs. And it added urgency to determining how much more money and materials allied nations may be willing to contribute. Williams said allies have offered $6.5 billion in assistance through Dec. 31. ``We will probably seek additional support from other nations to continue their share of the responsibility for Desert Shield,'' Williams said, adding that the Pentagon has not yet determined how much the operation will cost next year. The Pentagon's original estimate of $15 billion for the budget year that began Oct. 1 is no longer valid, Williams said, because it was made before Bush ordered the U.S. reinforcements. Pentagon and congressional sources said Monday the 1991 cost of the operation could be about $30 billion, but they stressed that estimates are uncertain because of fluctuations in fuel prices and other changing circumstances. The biggest unknown is whether the U.S. forces will go to war. Williams didn't say which allies would be asked to increase their contributions, or when. The leading contributors to the U.S. military operation since it began Aug. 7 are Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Japan, Germany and the United Arab Emirates, Williams said. Williams said Kuwait has provided the most aid so far, $2.5 billion in cash. Saudi Arabia has provided services and materials, such as transportation, food and fuel, valued at $987 million through Oct. 31, Williams said. He said the Saudis, unlike other allies, have made an ``open-ended offer'' of assistance for the duration of the standoff with Iraq. Japan has provided $376 million in cash and $50 million in materials or services, and Germany has given $272 million in cash and $65 million in support, Williams said. Neither of those countries has sent military forces to the gulf. Williams said Congress, in passing a supplemental appropriation of $1.9 billion for Desert Shield expenses for August and September, established a Defense Cooperation Account into which all allied financial aid is being deposited. The balance in the account as of Nov. 30 was $3.9 billion, Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Millionaire Promises to Give No More to Auburn University
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Goodwin saying Tuesday his decision not related to Curran case. Picks up 4th graf, `Auburn University ...'
DOC.TEXT: A millionaire who underwrote Auburn University's hiring of a controversial Catholic theologian says he will give no more to the school that denied tenure to the Rev. Charles Curran. ``I understand they're taking it out on him because he's a Catholic. Some of my best friends are Catholic,'' J.W. Goodwin, owner of a Birmingham engineering firm, said Monday in a story Tuesday in The Montgomery Advertiser. Goodwin backed away from the comment Tuesday, saying he didn't know if Curran was denied tenure because of his religion. Goodwin told The Associated Press on Tuesday he wrote his alma mater out of his will because of ``a personal matter'' but would not elaborate. ``It didn't have anything to do with that preacher,'' Goodwin said. Auburn University President James Martin has refused to make public the reason he gave Curran a one-year contract, rather than the security of a tenured position, when Curran was named Goodwin-Philpott Eminent Scholar in Religion, beginning with the 1990 fall term. Goodwin, 86, who donated $600,000 to set up the chair at Auburn, said it did not bother him that Curran has been censured by the Vatican for arguing that in some circumstances homosexual acts and abortion might not be sinful. Martin met privately Friday with the 13-member, faculty-controlled Promotions and Tenure Committee, but his reason for denying Curran tenure remained secret. While the committee that had overwhelmingly recommended last May that Curran be given tenure issued a statement in support of Martin's action, some faculty leaders said the problem had been aggravated. ``I am fully anticipating some rather strong reaction from the faculty if they cannot fathom the meaning of all this,'' said Auburn faculty senate President Gary Mullen. The university senate is expected to address the issue Jan. 8. Ronald Henry, an Auburn vice president who is chairman of the tenure committee, said he would never disclose Martin's ``non-academic'' reasons for denying tenure. Curran replied, ``If they admit it's a non-academic judgment, they have admitted it's a violation of academic freedom.'' Goodwin said Martin and former Auburn President Harry Philpott told him that Curran was ``the man they thought would be good for the job, and I said, `If it's all right with you, it's all right with me.''' Some faculty members had speculated earlier that Martin was under pressure from Catholic quarters not to give Curran a long-term post. But Goodwin said he was convinced Martin was persuaded by an unnamed member of the board of trustees not to make Curran's hiring permanent because the trustee objected to the fact that Curran was Catholic. Curran was added to a two-member religion department that already has a tenured Catholic professor. Goodwin's $600,000 donation was part of some $8 million he has contributed to his alma mater over the years. Goodwin, a 1929 engineering graduate, first let his displeasure be known in a letter to Martin, informing him that he had stopped bids on a new veterinary building he was bankrolling ``until this Curran thing is cleared up.'' Auburn's College of Veterinary Medicine was planning to use a large contribution from Goodwin to build a $750,000 laboratory for the artificial breeding of horses. ``I'd be glad to reconsider,'' said Goodwin, ``but they're going to have to get some people off that board of trustees. I'm not going to let them play hanky-panky with the money I worked like hell for.''

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Guerrillas Attack Oil Facility
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Cuban guerrillas forced company helicopter pilots to help them bomb installations of a subcontractor for the American company Mobil Oil Corp. in a northern jungle region, a leftist senator said Tuesday. Sen. Edmundo Murugarra said about 150 members of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement hit drilling operations Monday in the Upper Huallaga River Valley. He said the rebels forced the pilots to fly over the site while the guerrillas dynamited the installations from the air. The minister of energy and mines, Fernando Sanchez Albavera, said Tuesday the attack caused $3 million in damage. He said it was ``important to stress Mobil's decision to continue to work in Peru'' despite the raid. Mobil and U.S. Embassy officials refused to comment on the attack. The Upper Huallaga is a coca-rich jungle area 200 miles northeast of Lima. It also contains most of Peru's oil reserves. The valley produces more than 60 percent of the world's supply of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. Hundreds of guerrillas from both of Peru's main rebel groups operate in the area, providing protection for drug traffickers in exchange for arms and cash. Tupac Amaru, a smaller and less dangerous rebel organization than the Maoist-oriented Shining Path movement, started attacks in 1984. Guerrillas thought to belong to Shining Path on Tuesday tried to assassinate a district attorney in Cuzco, 350 miles southeast of Lima, police said. Cuzco, the ancient Inca capital and gateway to the Inca citadel Machu Picchu, is one of Peru's principal tourist attractions. The city has been relatively free of guerrilla attacks, except for a car bomb three months ago. Shining Path rebels on Monday bombed state electricity company offices in the northern mountain city of Huaraz, police said Tuesday. Huaraz, 175 miles north of Lima, is a popular area for backpackers and mountain climbers. Guerrilla violence has increased in the area since the Shining Path killed a British backpacker outside Huaraz in May 1989. More than 21,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Dead, 51 Injured in Multiple Car Pileup on Interstate 75
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `One northbound ...' to include dropped first name and reference to Beazley. Picks up 15th graf, `Efforts earlier ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KV1
DOC.TEXT: Two chain reaction crashes in dense fog on a highway in southeastern Tennessee killed 15 people Tuesday, injured more than 50 and left the roadway looking like a war zone. A morning fog covered Interstate 75 over the Hiwassee River, about 40 miles north of Chattanooga, when the 75-vehicle pileup began about 9:30 a.m., said Cecil Whaley, director of the Tennessee Emergency Management Agency. People involved in the accident, which covered more than a mile of the interstate, described hearing booms in the fog as dozens of tractor-trailers collided with each other and with cars. Traveling salesman Ralph Fisher of Cleveland, Tenn., was headed north when he hit the fog patch. He said he noticed traffic slowing down so he pulled to the roadside. ``After that I started hearing bangs and booms from everywhere. Immediately after that there was a truck on fire from across the road. We stared hearing them banging and booming from over there. Then all of a sudden you started hearing them from everywhere,'' said Fisher, 43. Whaley confirmed 15 dead, but said the number could rise as crews searched the burned shells of vehicles. In some cases, only nameplates distinguished the wreckage of a car smashed into the side of a truck. ``This is one of the worst accidents that anyone can remember happening in Tennessee in terms of the number of vehicles and fatalities involved,'' said Whaley, who followed rescue efforts from his Nashville office. Names of the victims would not be immediately released because some of the bodies were burned beyond recognition, Whaley said. Authorities believe an initial accident occurred in the southbound lane, and cars jumping the median or people rubbernecking to see the southbound crash may have caused the second pileup in the northbound lane. From there, authorities say it was a ghastly chain reaction. Russell Newman, eastern district regional director of the Tennessee Emergency Medical Agency, says no one is really sure what happened. ``It's just a conjecture as to what caused it, but it was just one of those damn chain reaction collisions that happen in this kind of situation - very heavy fog and probably too much speed,'' Newman said. In Washington, the National Transportation Safety Board said it was dispatching a six-person team of experts in highway and hazardous material investigations. One northbound lane of the interstate was reopened to traffic Tuesday afternoon. TEMA official Gary Beazley said he didn't know when the other lanes would be reopened. Efforts earlier in the day to remove the injured to hospitals in Athens and Cleveland were hampered because of wreckage. Helicopters from Knoxville and Chattanooga helped with the evacuation. Joe Wilson, spokesman for the Bradley County Emergency Management Agency, said the worst of the accident was centered at a bridge over the Hiwassee River, where the worst of the accident was centered. Bradley Memorial treated 24 people and Athens Community Hospital received 20 people. People were treated for lacerations, multiple trauma, burns, fractures, contusions and smoke inhalation. At least six seriously injured people were airlifted to Chattanooga's Erlanger Hospital and one was transported to the University of Tennessee Medical Center in Knoxville, Whaley said. He said about 20 of the 51 injured had been released from hospitals. Some troopers were overcome by fumes shortly after the accident, but officials said the danger had dissipated by midday. A propane tanker involved in the wreck was not damaged, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Black Leader Says Race Relations at Stake In Fiesta Bowl
DOC.TEXT: Race relations will suffer if the University of Alabama plays in the Fiesta Bowl in Arizona, where voters rejected a holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr., a black leader said Tuesday. State Rep. Alvin Holmes, Alabama NAACP president Lillian Jackson and several other black leaders met with University President Roger Sayers to discuss their concerns over the planned trip to the Jan. 1 college football bowl in Tempe, Ariz. The fact that Alabama, one of the state's major institutions, is planning to participate in the event is particularly significant, Holmes said. ``Here in the state of Alabama was where Dr. Martin Luther King was thrust into international leadership,'' he said. ``It was here in the state of Alabama where Martin Luther King received his greatest resistance to the civil rights movement and it was here in the state of Alabama where (former Gov.) George Wallace stood in the schoolhouse door. ``Of all universities in the nation, the University of Alabama should be the last one to play in a state where they refuse to honor Dr. King,'' Holmes said. Holmes said he wants the team to pull out of the game against Louisville. The black leaders presented a list of demands to Sayers, which included hiring a black university vice president and establishing a scholarship for black students. Sayers said the university will consider the proposals and come up with a package next week. King's daughter, Yolanda King, canceled an acting performance in a musical play in Arizona on Sunday because she felt her presence there might be misconstrued. Sayers had been scheduled to meet with Southern Christian Leadership Conference officials, but the meeting was canceled. Instead, SCLC President Joseph Lowery met with Gov. Guy Hunt in Montgomery on Tuesday evening. Hunt's press secretary, Terry Abbott, said the governor told Lowery he ``respectfully disagreed'' with his stance and that Hunt ``knows well that university officials are very sensitive to the issues.'' ``I understand his position and I hope he understands mine,'' said Lowery. John Nettles, president of the Alabama SCLC, said Lowery's meeting with Sayers would be rescheduled.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Demands Military Exercise Halt at Talks with South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with comments from first day of talks. CHANGES byline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: North Korea said Wednesday that peace on the divided Korean peninsula must be achieved without interference from outsiders and it indirectly attacked Seoul's alliances with both Washington and Moscow. ``We only wonder when this dependence on outside forces and flunky-like way of thinking, impairing national dignity and interests, will disappear,'' Premier Yon Hyong Muk of North Korea said. He spoke at the opening of the third round of talks between himself and South Korean Premier Kang Young-hoon. ``If we depend upon foreign forces, we cannot but be subjected to their interference, cannot but be worried about their attitude,'' Yon said. ``You are entreating foreign countries for intervention and interference in an endeavor to force your will.'' The talks are meant to ease political and military tensions on the peninsula. South Korean President Roh Tae-woo flies to Moscow Thursday for a summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Moscow, a longtime ally of the Communist North, established diplomatic relations with Seoul two months ago. Roh's trip has been bitterly critized by the North as an attempt to sabotage the talks. The opening day session lasted about two hours and both sides offered proposals which were little changed in substance from past talks. No major agreement is expected, but the talks are seen as one more step in the lengthy process of drawing the two nations closer. The talks, to conclude Thursday, are the third round since September and the highest-level meetings between the Koreas since the peninsula was divided in 1945 and the border tightly sealed. Yon demanded immediate withdrawal of 43,000 U.S. troops based in South Korea, withdrawal of U.S. nuclear weapons he claims are stored in the South and a halt to the annual U.S.-South Korean military maneuver called Team Spirit. He asked direct talks between North Korea and Washington on replacing the 1953 armistice agreement which ended the 1950-53 Korean War with a peace treaty. South Korea refused to sign the armistice. South Korea urged the North to sign a basic agreement aimed at easing 45 years of confrontation and to accept two ideological systems pending unification. South Korea warned the North to cease what it said was its slandering of Roh and to end contacts with South Korean dissidents. ``Your side has continued to slander and revile our side even though you have agreed to talk peace and reconciliation,'' said Kang. ``Your side is inciting and encouraging certain dissidents in the South to conduct illegal activities.'' North Korea has demanded the release of dissidents jailed for unauthorized contact with the North, a matter the Seoul government calls meddling in domestic affairs. On Tuesday, hours after the North Korean premier crossed the heavily fortified border, police in the southern city of Kwangju stormed two universities to try to block students from screening banned North Korean movies. The national Yonhap News Agency said about 1,000 students hurling rocks and firebombs drove 1,000 riot police out of Chonnam University. Students barricaded the school's main gate with tires and desks, it said. At Kwangju's Chosun University, police firing tear gas stormed the school but were driven back by 500 students, Yonhap said. Police arrested four students, it said. There was no report on injuries. In a prelude to the talks, the premiers sang Korea's national anthem for unification in an emotional ceremony on Tuesday. The two stood side by side in an auditorium filled with 2,000 cheering spectators and sang the song, which starts, ``Our wish is unification.''

DOC.HEAD: City Attempts to Close 2 Live Crew Rapper Luther Campbell's Nightclub
DOC.TEXT: City officials sought Tuesday to close a nightclub owned by rap singer Luther Campbell of 2 Live Crew after one man was killed and another wounded in a weekend gunfight there. City Attorney Alex Vilarello filed papers Tuesday in Dade Circuit Court seeking an injunction closing the Strawberry Too club. He said a hearing on the request was not expected before Friday. Campbell, who has owned the club for two years, was acquitted of obscenity charges in Florida's Broward County in October that stemmed from a concert featuring songs from his group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' Also acquitted were 2 Live Crew members Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross and Chris ``Fresh Kid Ice'' Wongwon The Hialeah City Council, meeting in emergency session Monday, ordered Vilarello to seek the injunction after Saturday morning's gunfight terrorized an estimated 200 patrons of the club. Police said the shooting was the latest violent outburst at the club where two people were wounded in another gunfight in the parking lot last July. ``Forty to 60 percent of available manpower is being expended at this location continuously,'' said Police Chief Rolando Bolanos. Police say they have been summoned to the club 128 times this year, including five times for shootings. Campbell said police were to blame for not controlling crowds outside the club. ``I think the city of Hialeah is full of it, personally, because every club in the city of Miami, Miami Beach, all over the county, has police outside of the club,'' Campbell said. Police said Saturday's incident began about 4 a.m. when Campbell's bodyguard, Robert Mulkey, poked Timothy Taylor, 22, in the head and told him he couldn't enter the club, which was being used for a private party. Taylor allegedly hit Mulkey over the head with a portable telephone and fled. Police said Mulkey then hit Taylor over the head with his gun, grazing him when the weapon discharged. The single gunshot prompted an outburst of more than 50 shots, and Morris Richard Anderson III, a bystander, was killed. Anderson, 22, was shot in the back. Authorities said it wasn't immediately clear how many people were involved in the gunfight.

A new contraceptive touted by family planning experts as the most effective, reversible method of birth control will soon be available to American women. The Food and Drug Administration approved Norplant on Monday, clearing the way for Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories to begin training health practitioners how to insert the implant that can prevent pregnancy for up to five years. ``It's going to be interesting to watch what kind of reaction Norplant gets among the public and physicians,'' said Jeannie Rosoff, president of the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a research and policy group that focuses on reproductive health issues. ``There are going to be some women for whom this is a godsend. The numbers we don't know yet,'' she said. ``But any new addition that is safe is desirable.'' ---= CHICAGO (AP) - Federal investigators said they have new reason to believe a body found in a forest 12 years ago is that of missing candy heiress Helen Brach, an official said. ``We developed additional information, which we felt significant enough to warrant a re-examination of the body,'' Jerry Singer, a spokesman for the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said Monday. He declined to describe the new information. A court order was granted to exhume the body, which is buried in a pauper's grave. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - A group of joyful Americans are home for the holidays today, relieved to be free after more than four frightening, boring and unpleasant months as captives in Iraq and Kuwait. ``It feels absolutely great,'' Jack Rinehart, 37, of Stover, Mo., said several hours after he and more than 150 Americans landed at nearby Andrews Air Force Base, Md., on a chartered Pan Am jumbo jet Monday. ``It's great to be back,'' said Dwight Durmon of Fayetteville, Tenn., as he clutched the hand of his wife, Cathy. The former hostages - some of whom had been held as ``human shields'' at strategic sites in Iraq - left Baghdad on Sunday. ---= EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif. (AP) - Columbia glided to a rare night landing a day early after a star-gazing mission plagued by computer problems, clogged plumbing and finally the threat of rain. The shuttle touched down Monday night, its signature twin sonic booms heralding its arrival over the Mojave Desert. The landing, seen by about 600 spectators, was moved up to avoid rain in today'sforecast. NASA officials focused on the mission's accomplishments, despite repeated problems aiming the $150 million Astro observatory. Besides the telescope troubles, the crew had to repair a clog in the shuttle's waste collection system. ``I think we've had a resounding success on the mission,'' said William Lenoir, NASA associate administrator. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Armand Hammer, the communist's son who became an American captain of industry as well-connected in the Kremlin as he was on Wall Street, has died at age 92. Hammer died at his home Monday night after a brief illness, said Frank Ashley, a spokesman for Hammer's Occidental Petroleum Corp. Hammer, a self-made millionaire by the time he graduated from Columbia University medical school at age 23, was also a philanthropist, art collector and crusader for world peace. ``He was absolutely indomitable,'' said his attorney, Arthur Groman. ``He never lost his courage or tenacity. In the last months, he was uncomplaining and optimistic.'' ---= MOSCOW (AP) - The highly publicized Soviet food shortage is most acute in big Russian cities and seems milder in the countryside, smaller cities and in non-Russian republics, a survey indicates. ``The situation is better here than in Russia,'' said Povilas Klimas, deputy mayor of Vilnius, capital of the Baltic republic of Lithuania, which declared independence in March. ``We're ready to go ahead on our own.'' Officials from the 12 cities surveyed by The Associated Press said there was more food in farmers' markets than in state stores, although prices were higher. They blamed shortages on panic-buying and the collapse of the centralized distribution system, which is not getting the harvest into cities. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has appealed to the West for food to prevent winter unrest that he says may jeopardize his reforms. Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze carried the plea Monday to Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ---= LONDON (AP) - British aid agencies say millions of people in the four corners of Africa face starvation as early as January, and some compare the situation to the Ethiopian famine that shocked the world five years ago. John Magrath, a spokesman for the Oxfam charity, said Monday he had received a telex from a worker just back from the Ethiopian province of Eritrea: ``Terrible drought,'' it said. ``Animals dying. People already on the move.'' Oxfam has joined with six other agencies to form the British Disaster Emergency Committee, which is launching an appeal in the new year for funds to assist Ethiopia, the Sudan, Mozambique, Angola and Liberia. ---= SPRINGFIELD, Va. (AP) - Incredulous motorists who pull into U.T. Brown's filling station might wonder if they hadn't taken the wrong turn and wandered into an amusement park. The landscaping around Cardinal Plaza Shell's gasoline pumps includes a Japanese rock garden with stone dragons and pagodas, a five-foot fiberglass Ninja Turtle and a miniature putting green surrounded by sand traps. To help his customers fill 'er up with the Christmas spirit, Brown has scattered his gardens with nine welded-wire reindeer and a sleigh, all blinking with hundreds of tiny white lights. And, of course, a red-nosed Rudolph stands watch over his herd from a perch above the garage. There's a 25-foot illuminated Christmas tree on the roof of the gas pump bays, 500 red and white lamps bordering the immaculate lawn, and a giant candy cane decorating the tire racks.

DOC.HEAD: Norway Hopes to be Smoke-Free in 10 Years
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Norway, which already has the world's most expensive cigarettes, is trying to stop smoking everywhere indoors and wipe out the habit in a decade. Even a smoker's home may not be his castle for long. Schools and day-care centers tell children about the dangers of passive smoking and encourage them to tell their parents to quit or smoke outside. Norwegians with tobacco habits are responding by rolling their own cigarettes, using butts over again, taking snuff and smoking on balconies. Tore Sanner, a professor at the Oslo Cancer Institute and head of the smoke-free campaign, granted that the number of smokers has remained constant for 10 years despite increasingly aggressive measures. About 1.2 million Norwegians smoke, or 37 percent of the population, but fewer young people are starting. Tobacco consumption has dropped only marginally, to 6,700 metric tons a year from 6,800 in 1980. Sanner, in no mood to give up, declared: ``You saw what happened to the Berlin Wall. Nobody thought it would fall.'' Tobacco advertising has been prohibited since 1975. Smoking is forbidden in all public transportation, in terminals, museums and other indoor public places. A 2-year-old law bans smoking in any office where there is more than one person. Because 85 percent of the price is taxes and fees, a pack of 20 cigarettes costs 31 kroner, or $5.40. The government proposes to raise the price by another 10 percent next year. Some Norwegians are as stubborn about smoking as Sanner is about getting them to quit. On a snowy day in downtown Oslo, Bjoerne Ulvaes, 28, took a last deep drag before his streetcar arrived. He put the cigarette out and slid it back into the pack, his fingers shaking with cold, before getting aboard. ``You do cut down,'' Ulvaes said, but added he did not intend to quit. Many people doubt they will see a smoke-free society in Norway. Taxes of 250 percent and numerous restrictions did not stop people from drinking alcohol, but did lead to widespread bootlegging and home distilling. Customers at the Manhattan Pub laughed, shook their heads at the idea and continued smoking. A saleswoman in a tobacco store said trying to end smoking in 10 years was ``ridiculous and out of touch with reality.'' Nonetheless, new restrictions are planned. In two years, restaurants will be required to keep one-third of their space smoke-free. Plans are being made to raise the age limit for buying tobacco from 16 to 18. High-tar brands probably will be banned and cigarette prices will continue going up. Sanner said his campaign alliance, which includes the Norwegian Sports Association, is lobbying to have the price raised 20 percent each year. Anne-Marie Mueller of the government's National Council on Tobacco Unhealth said new regulations are needed to stem the increase in hand-rolling and the use of snuff. Scandinavians squeeze snuff into a small ball and put it between the gum and inner side of the lip. More people use it as smoking becomes more expensive and restricted. Ms. Mueller said her council wants prices of all tobacco products raised because ``price is our most important weapon.'' Smokers have begun organizing against what they call the ``ban mentality.'' ``It is a matter of freedom of choice,'' said Thor Petter Krosby, a non-smoker who heads the 2-year-old smokers' organization Smokepeace. ``There is an air of fanaticism'' about anti-smoking activists, he said in remarks about proposals to ban smoking entirely at Oslo University, indoors or out. Krosby said Smokepeace does not encourage people to smoke, but that most of its 300 members are smokers. Anti-smokers are trying to soften their image with the help of NRK, the state-controlled television network. It carries no product commercials, but does broadcast anti-smoking advertisements. Some recent ads have a touch of humor. In one, Dracula sinks his teeth into the throat of a young chain smoker, then staggers away coughing, smoke pouring from his mouth.

DOC.HEAD: Books and Authors: Two-Sided Stories: The Novels of David Lodge
DOC.TEXT: David Lodge is on his first American publicity tour and the English author seems a little dazed. Blame some of it on jet lag, the rest on culture shock. When his first novel came out in 1962, writers didn't give interviews. In fact, Lodge waited years before he even had a public reading. But he'll have to adjust. This mild-mannered author is now, somewhat, a celebrity. His claim to fame is such gently mischievous novels as ``Changing Places,'' ``Small World'' and ``Nice Work,'' which has just been issued in paperback. These stories always have two sides - men vs. women, religion vs. secularism, America vs. England. And Lodge is the referee, laying down the rules and calmly watching from the sidelines as characters collide and opinions crumble. ``The very first novel I published, `The Picturegoers,' is about an agnostic boy and a Catholic girl, and as a result of their relationship she becomes agnostic and he becomes religious,'' Lodge said, relaxing in an armchair in his Manhattan hotel room. ``Because I don't have very strong political or idealistic ideas to put forth myself, I find it easy to put forth novels of contrasting views. I also find it humorous, working on a level where everybody understands the rules and obeys them.'' Lodge, born in 1935, grew up in southeast London. His childhood was often grim and, as he writes in the introduction to ``Out of the Shelter,'' an autobiographical novel, his irreverent sense of humor was shaped by air raids and postwar austerity. In ``Nice Work,'' the author toys with the stuffy Victor Wilcox and the overeducated Robyn Penrose, throwing them together in an uneasy merger of the smokestack and the ivory tower. Wilcox is the manager of an engineering firm, his quest for identity reaching no further than his resume. Penrose, who teaches classes on 19th century industrial novels, would rather read about factories than actually visit them. Lodge takes these imaginary creatures and sets them in a cage called Rummidge, an English city that occupies, for fictional purposes, ``the space where Birmingham is to be found on maps of the so-called real world.'' The year is 1986, the government has proclaimed it ``Industry Year,'' and a university panel has developed an Industry Year Shadow Scheme: a faculty member is to ``shadow'' a senior management employee in local manufacturing. Robyn gets the assignment. Her subject, naturally, is Victor. Here's a boy-meets-girl story set against the background of a city's crumbling economy. Victor, pompous and materialistic, finds himself falling in love with this attractive, independent woman. Robyn is horrified by her initial exposure to the lue-collar world, but slowly realizes machines and assembly lines are no less important than analyses of Jane Austen. An encounter is inevitible and Lodge, keeping the sex safe, writes with the detached amusement of a nosy neighbor whose ear is pressed against the wall: ``Robyn's mood is blythe. She feels mildly wanton, but not wicked. She sees herself as not seducing Vic but as putting him out of his misery. ... Perhaps she feels a certain sense of triumph at her conquest: the captain of industry at the feet of the feminist literary critic - a pleasing tableau. ``For Vic the event is indefinitely more momentous, his mood infinitely more perturbed. The prospect of going to bed with Robyn Penrose is the secret dream of weeks come true. ... He regards himself with wonderment led by the hand by this handsome young woman toward her bedroom, as if his soul is stumbling along out of step behind his body.'' ``The scene where they actually go to bed together, I must have written about 10 times; it took a lot of thinking,'' explained Lodge, who in 1987 retired as a professor at the University of Birmingham. Robyn is far more serious, even questioning the very idea of novels, which she attacks as capitalist tools. ``The message of the novel is clear,'' she states. ``The alienation of work under industrial capitalism can be overcome by an infusion of loving kindness and imaginative play ... '' That's going too far for Lodge. Feminism is up for grabs, so are religion and politics, but the author doesn't mind sounding a little dogmatic about writing, the only time he's willing to solemnly bow his head and offers thanks to a power greater than his own. ``We learn how to negotiate our lives through novels,'' Lodge said. ``We learn about experiences beyond our own. A novel is not the only form that does that, but I still think it's the most versatile of all forms. You don't need much money, all you need as a writer is a pad and a pen. ``When you get to my stage of life, you don't ask yourself why you write. It's sort of what you've become; you're a novelist. It's like being a professional golfer.''

DOC.HEAD: `Arctic Wars' and `Playing God with Nature': About Hard Choices
DOC.TEXT: Many people find it easy to support the idea of wildlife conservation and the environment, until it gets uncomfortable, until choices and distinctions become difficult to make. That's the tacit message of ``Arctic Wars,'' a one-hour PBS special tonight on Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which already is staked out as ``the environmental battleground of the 1990s.'' It's also the message of ``Africa: Playing God with Nature?,'' a National Geographic Explorer special on TBS Sunday that shows three African nations' different approaches to wildlife conservation. Take the tundra: At the northeast boundary of Alaska, beside the Yukon Territory, is the 19 million-acre Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a wilderness area created by Congress in 1980. Under the congressional act's Section 1002, the refuge's 1.5 million-acre coastal plain is exempted from the wilderness designation. Why? The oil industry figures the so-called ``ten-oh-two'' lands sit on more than 2{ billion barrels of oil. The 1002 lands are core calving grounds for the porcupine caribou, and prime habitat for the wolf and grizzly bear. Unfortunately, porcupine caribou aren't cute, grizzlies are scary, and wolves have suffered from bad press. It's also the homeland of native Indians and Eskimos who rely on the caribou for their subsistence. And yet, there are Alaskans who also need jobs in an economy that derives 85 percent of its revenues from the oil industry. What will become of the lands? The oil companies insist the adjoining oil fields at Prudhoe Bay are in decline, that they'll need the oil and that they can get it out and return the wilderness to ``useful tundra.'' Useful tundra? ``The official position of the Bush administration concerning ANWR and other areas is that we'll go forward with exploration and drilling if we can do it in an environmentally sound manner,'' says Assisant Interior Secretary David O'Neil. ``Arctic Wars'' makes it all too clear that the 1002 lands probably would be open to oil exploration and development today if it weren't for the Exxon Valdez oil spill of 1989. As one oil executive argues, ``If you perceive that the aesthetics of a drilling rig destroy wilderness, then we've reduced the argument to one of aesthetics, which is a very difficult argument.'' What ``Arctic Wars'' doesn't make clear is that oil development, or even extensive recreational use, threatens species plants, animals, insects and microscopic life we know nothing about. Once gone, it is gone for good. The other side of conservation is in Africa, where Kenya, Zimbabwe and South Africa have taken three fundamentally different tacks in managing wildlife. The problem is most critical in Kenya, where the world's highest birth rate and endemic poverty have decimated wildlife and habitat. Where humans compete with animals for food and space, animals always lose. Disastrous policies by Kenya's government in the '70s literally destroyed one game preserve by overpopulating it with elephants, and created enormous ill will among its people by denying them access to game during famine. Kenya's war on poachers and a worldwide ban on ivory have helped save the dwindling elephant herd. Tourism is Kenya's largest source of hard currency, and that also may help the elephant. This is small consolation to a Kenyan farmer trying to eke out a living on lands adjoining unfenced game preserves. To him, the elephant that eats and tramples his crops is a 2{-ton cockroach. Zimbabwe takes a sensible, if unsentimental, approach, in demanding that wildlife ``pay its own way,'' with licensed trophy and meat harvesting. Local people are ``given'' their wildlife as manageable assets. Then there's South Africa's intensively managed Kruger Nation Park - a fenced area the size of Massachusetts, where as many as 400 elephants - usually old males - are killed each year to keep the population in balance. ``Arctic Wars'' and ``Playing God with Nature?'' don't answer questions, they pose them. It's our planet. What shall we do with it? --- Elsewhere in television ... PUBLIC TV AUDIENCE STILL GROWING: Public television increased its audience by 9 percent in November, its second straight month of audience growth in the fall season, the Public Broadcasting Service says. November's prime-time rating was an average 2.4, up from 2.2 during November 1989. October's 2.3 rating was up 10 percent over the same period last year, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. figures, PBS said. A rating point equals 931,000 TV households, so PBS averaged nearly 2.5 million households tuned in. That's minuscule compared with commercial TV ratings, but sheer bliss to PBS executives and their audience. PBS also reports its member-support pledges are running 6 percent over last December's pledge period.

DOC.HEAD: Sydney Pollack and Robert Redford Team for ``Havana''
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: If anyone can get Robert Redford back on the screen, it's Sydney Pollack, and the talented pair combine again for a drama against the backdrop of the 1958 Cuban revolution, ``Havana.'' The film marks the seventh collaboration for the unlikely pair: the outgoing Jewish Hoosier, and the secretive, golden-haired California blond. Their previous movies: ``This Property Is Condemned,'' ``Three Days of the Condor,'' ``Jeremiah Johnson,'' ``The Way We Were,'' ``The Electric Horseman,'' ``Out of Africa,'' the latter winning Pollack the 1985 Academy Award for director. Pollack and Redford met in 1961 when both were unknown actors working in Denis Sander's anti-war film, ``War Hunt.'' Pollack had aimed for an acting career ever since leaving Lafayette, Ind., at the age of 17 and enrolling at Sandford Meisner's Neighborhood Playhouse in New York. He appeared in several Broadway plays, including ``Stalag 17,'' playing the role that won William Holden an Oscar in the film version. After two years of Army service, he returned to New York, then joined John Frankenheimer as dialogue coach on the film ``The Young Savages.'' That led to TV directing, then his first feature, ``The Slender Thread,'' starring Sidney Poitier and Anne Bancroft in 1965. His other films have included ``They Shoot Horses, Don't They?'' ``Absence of Malice'' and ``Tootsie.'' Pollack, 56, recently talked about his relationship with Redford and other matters in an interview with The Associated Press. Here are the highlights: Q. It's been five years since ``Out of Africa.'' Why such a gap between films? A. I had often threatened to set up a production company, so I went off and did it. I had always heard people say it takes so long to get pictures done. I found out. It took me three years to set up the company (Mirage). We did `Presumed Innocent,' `Major League,' `The Fabulous Baker Boys' and `White Palace.' I didn't start looking for my own project for at least a couple of years. Then I dug up `Havana,' which I had started working on in 1976. I didn't take the time to hunt around. I just remembered liking it ... and putting it away. Q. What was so intriguing about that period in Havana? A. Mostly it was romanticism ... the most sensual place in the world in the '50s, as corrupt as any place in the world. There was this wonderful - in terms of filmmaking - week of Christmas 1958 when the guns were in the hills and the gambling was at a fever pitch. The vividness of the colors and the sensuality was like catnip for a filmmaker. Q. Did you visit Havana yourself? A. Many times. But they (the U.S. government) just wouldn't let me shoot there. As long as you're invited and you don't spend money, you can go there. You're just not allowed to spend money because that's called ``trading with the enemy.'' Since Cuba is our enemy, they wouldn't let me spend millions of stockholders' money down there. (Havana was re-created in the Dominican Republic at an extra cost of $12 million to $14 million.) Q. How did you persuade Redford to abandon his causes and skiing and make another movie? A. Well, I bought a lot of good groceries, because he likes to eat. He knows I cook pretty well, and I just waved the smells and got him in. No, I think he welcomed the challenge of stretching a bit. It's a sleazier, lower-class character than he usually plays. This guy's a little more vulnerable. He's the person who does the pursuing instead of the one who lays back and is the object of pursuit. He's roughed up a little bit, with a tattoo, he's got some mileage on him now. All of that certainly was good for me, and I think it was for him, too. Q. What about Lena Olin, his co-star? A. Lena was one of the most impressive of the newer actresses I had seen. I needed somebody I thought could knock the pins out from under Redford and make him drive after her through a war even though she was rebuffing him. Also she had some substance beyond sexuality, which is not uncommon among pretty women. Q. After seven pictures with Redford, can you work in shorthand? A. It's pretty minimal, what's required now. Sometimes I don't even say anything. If a take of his close-up is cut and I say ``One more,'' I don't need to say more. He just knows to try something different. After seven pictures and 25 years, it is a shorthand. That doesn't mean that we don't get into fights and arguments and beefs and I don't sometimes have to push him like hell. There are always areas that we disagree on, but he's very good about trying things, whether he agrees or not. Q. How would you answer people who say ``Havana'' is a pro-Castro movie? A. It's not pro-Castro. It's anti-Batista (the previous dictator). If that means that de facto it's pro-Castro, then I have to live with that. ... It's a movie that's saying quite clearly that there was a degree of corruption in 1958 by the Batista government that every American acknowledged, including the American government.
