DOC.TEXT: Advertising spending this year is growing at the slowest pace since the mid-1970s and could slow even further in 1991, a prominent industry forecaster said. Robert Coen, of the ad agency McCann-Erickson, said Monday he expects U.S. ad spending will rise 4.9 percent to $130.1 billion this year and 4.6 percent to $136 billion in 1991. He blamed the slowdown on the economic downturn and worries created by the Persian Gulf standoff. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The government is preparing to lend up to $7 billion to entice buyers to hard-to-sell property it inherited from failed savings and loans - a move critics denounced as a way to postpone resolving the mess. ``They're just going to sink into the same quicksand that the S&L operators couldn't pull themselves out of,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., who heads a House task force overseeing the bailout. ``I just think they would be better off to face up to the problem now. The Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board more than doubled the lending limit from the previous $3 billion in the move that was revealed Monday. --- VIENNA, Austria (AP) - OPEC ministers have arrived here for strategy talks that are likely to leave intact a boost in oil production approved in August after Iraq invaded Kuwait. But, during their annual winter meeting, ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will no doubt fret privately about the recent unexpected softening of world crude prices. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration is reviewing scores of ideas for reducing America's dependence on foreign oil, including a 50-cent-a-gallon gas tax and easing environmental barriers for building energy plants. Although in the works for nearly two years, Energy Department officials say the crafting of a national policy gained momentum and urgency after the Persian Gulf crisis cast a spotlight on U.S. reliance on oil imports. Environmentalists are already attacking the plan, which goes to President Bush later this month. --- ATLANTA (AP) - GTE Corp. and Contel Corp. shareholders were voting on a merger creating the nation's second-largest mobile-cellular telephone company, at a time when the industry is enjoying continued growth. The $6.2 billion merger, that was to be voted on Tuesday at separate shareholders' meetings in New York and Stamford, Conn., is expected to be approved. But because of remaining regulatory hurdles, company officials are predicting the merger will not be completed until the second quarter of 1991. The combined company would be second in size to McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's top cellular phone operation. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Security Pacific Corp. said it would set aside $850 million for bad loans, foreclosed real estate and restructuring costs, a move that will result in a fourth-quarter loss of up to $360 million. The Los Angeles concern, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company, said Monday its profit for the 1990 fiscal year will decline to about $160 million, compared with $741 million in 1989. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A group of asbestos victims filed a petition to send Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. into involuntary bankruptcy, possibly derailing a settlement plan in the worker health crisis. The petition was filed Monday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati, where Eagle-Picher is based. The motion, by three asbestos victims, was filed while a hearing was being conducted before U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Brooklyn federal court on the controversial settlement plan. --- EAGAN, Minn. (AP) - Northwest Airlines will invest in struggling Hawaiian Airlines in exchange for some of the Honolulu-based carrier's lucrative South Pacific routes, the air carriers announced. Northwest would own 25 percent of Hawaiian Airlines after paying the airline and its parent, HAL Inc., $20 million, including $7 million as a secured loan, according to a statement released Monday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - If you've always wanted to ride a train across the country, but didn't have the time to take it all the way back, United Airlines and Amtrak may have just the deal you've been waiting for. They unveiled a train-plane ticketing agreement Monday that will offer passengers a cheaper fare when they fly one way and ride the rails the other way. The setup would also allow travelers to fly into certain major gateway cities, then take trains around the region before returning to the gateway city to fly home. ---

Stock prices showed little change Monday, drifting uncertainly after the stock market's pullback late last week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 20.30 points Thursday and Friday, recovered 6.68 to 2,596.78. The dollar advanced in New York after falling overseas. Bond prices rose. Gold prices moved higher. Silver futures edged lower. Oil futures rose. Livestock and meat futures advanced. Grains and soybeans were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Electricity Privatization ``An Outstanding Success''
DOC.TEXT: A $10.1 billion privatization of Britain's electricity industry was a huge success, the government said, with Britons seeking more than 10 times the number of shares being offered. Demand from the public was so strong, in fact, that it triggered a ``clawback'' mechanism that scaled back the amount of shares reserved for both foreign investors and domestic institutional investors, said Kleinwort Benson Ltd., the government's financial advisor. Kleinwort said Monday the offer was 10.7 times oversubscribed by the general public. Under the offering, the government sold a total 2.16 billion shares in the 12 electricity distributing companies of England and Wales. The shares sold for 240 pence, or $4.68 each, for a total 5.18 billion pounds ($10.1 billion). The government plans to sell its two electricity generating companies and the Scottish electricity industry next year. The sell-off is Britain's biggest and most complex privatization yet. The Conservative government has sold $64 billion worth of state-owned companies over the past decade to promote capitalism and encourage wider ownership of the companies. The privatizations include telephone, gas, and water utilities, as well as British Airways PLC, British Aerospace PLC and the automaker Jaguar PLC, which has since been bought by Ford Motor Co. Critics had questioned the government's timing of its latest sale, noting that many investors have shied away from the stock market since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. They also cite the worldwide economic slowdown. The government had planned to cancel the sale if a war broke out in the Persian Gulf. But Kleinwort said it received 12.75 million applications from individual investors, the highest response ever for a government privatization. Energy Secretary John Wakeham said only about 25 percent of the applicants will receive all the shares they requested, and many investors will receive only the minimum 100 shares because of the huge demand. He said some shares will go to about 97 percent of the applicants who are electricity customers, while two-thirds of all applicants will receive some shares. Officials noted the ``clawback'' provision will boost the percentage of shares available to the public to 54.6 percent from 34.4 percent. British institutional investors will now get 30.4 percent of shares and foreign investors will receive 15 percent. Shares will begin trading Tuesday afternoon. Analysts are predicting prices will jump 40 percent to 50 percent when trading begins. The London Stock Exchange plans to remain open an extra 90 minutes Tuesday to accommodate anticipated heavy dealing. ``There might very well be a scramble tomorrow afternoon for the shares'' among institutions that saw their allocations scaled back, said Sean Darby, an analyst at the investment firm Yamaichi International (Europe) Ltd. ``The government has made sure that everybody has got something, but basically they kept it down to the lowest rung,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Germany's Largest Auto Producer Planning Massive Investment In Skoda
DOC.TEXT: Volkswagen plans to invest up to $6.3 billion in the Czechoslovak car company Skoda, the German carmaker said after winning a bid to take over the company. Franstisek Vlasak, deputy premier of the Czech republic, told a news conference in Prague on Monday that cooperation between the two car companies will begin in January. A joint stock venture will be formed, with Volkswagen pumping in some $300 million at the start, Vlasak said. Ortwin Witzel, a Volkswagen spokesman, said Skoda's 21,000 employees were assured of no layoffs in the deal, which is to begin with a 35 percent investment in Skoda next year that will reach 70 percent by 1995. On Sunday, Czechoslovakia announced that Volkswagen had outbid Renault of France and Sweden's Volvo for Skoda. The company is considered one of the best auto manufacturers in Eastern Europe. It has a long manufacturing tradition, using its own designs, and its cars have a reputation for reliability. Volkswagen said Skoda will become another of VW's subsidiaries, joining Audi and Volkswagen in Germany and SEAT in Spain. In the first stage beginning next year, Volkswagen said the venture will produce 200,000 Favorit-model Skodas. By 1997, that number is to increase to 400,000 cars a year. Skoda currently produces about 250,000 cars a year. Volkswagen said it foresees a market of up to 3 million vehicles in the central European region by the year 2000. Volkswagen said it will modernize Skoda's main manufacturing facility in Mlada Boleslav and eventually build a new engine factory and assembly plant. Volkswagen said the motor plant is to be completed by 1995 and produce about 500,000 engines for the Czechoslovak auto industry as well as for other Volkswagen units. An international distribution network will also be developed to sell Skoda cars outside Europe, the company said. A contract must still be signed between the two companies and a new leadership named. Miroslav Gregr, Czech minister of engineering, said Monday in Prague that it may be possible to sign the basic provisions of the contract by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Forecaster Expects Sluggish Ad Spending Growth Through 1991
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Advertising spending is expected to grow next year at the slowest pace in more than two decades but should pick up along with the economy in 1992, a prominent industry forecaster says. Some analysts say the forecast may be too optimistic, while other executives expressed reservations about whether the economy will improve as expected in the second half of 1991. Robert Coen, an executive at the ad agency McCann-Erickson, said Monday he expects U.S. ad spending will rise 4.9 percent to $130.1 billion this year, the smallest increase since 4.8 percent in 1975. Next year, he said, spending should grow 4.6 percent to $136 billion, the smallest increase since a 0.7 percent increase in 1970. Coen blamed the slowdown on the economic downturn and worries created by the Persian Gulf standoff. Newspapers are being especially hard hit. Coen, whose semiannual forecasts of ad spending trends for the investment firm PaineWebber Inc. are the most closely watched in the industry, has scaled back his estimate of ad spending growth for 1990 twice in the past year. Last December, he said domestic ad spending would grow 6.2 percent in 1990. He trimmed that projection to 5.3 percent last June. Coen said he is hopeful that improvements in the economy in the latter half of 1991 and the prospect of the Olympic Games ``could start another resurgence in ad spending'' in 1992. He told the 18th annual PaineWebber media conference that national ad spending will rise 6.7 percent to $73.6 billion this year while local ad spending will increase a meager 2.8 percent to $56.5 billion. National ad spending is doing better than his December 1989 forecast of a 6.3 percent increase, but local ad spending has come in well below his earlier estimate of 6.2 percent growth. He said newspapers, for instance, saw local ad spending grow at a slim 1 percent pace this year as spending by retailers slumped due to their heavy debt loads, the poor business environment and deteriorating consumer confidence. In addition, he said the deepening decline in classified ad spending resulting from rising unemployment and a sluggish housing market ``made it a disastrous year'' for local ad spending in newspapers. He expects only 2 percent growth in local ad spending in newspapers next year, but added that a revival in the economy could lead to a ``fast turnaround.'' National advertising, on the other hand, was stronger than expected this year partly because of increased competition for market share in categories such as coffee, credit cards and mutual funds, Coen said. For 1991, Coen said he expects national ad spending will rise 5.7 percent and local ad spending will increase 3.1 percent. ``Until unemployment rates fall and the real estate and housing sectors turn around, we must continue to be pessimistic about local ad growth next year,'' Coen said. Gordon Medenica, vice president for corporate planning at the ew York Times Co., said operating profits in the newspaper industry fell about 3 percent in 1990 and could fall another 2 to 4 percentage points next year. He said he was also ``a little worried about this consensus forecast'' that the economy will improve in the second half. Jack Butcher, circulation director at The Tampa (Fla.) Tribune, said he expects the average cover price of newspapers will rise to 35 cents daily and $1 on Sundays in 1991 from their current levels of 30 cents and 75 cents. But he said he expects the industry will still be able to show circulation growth of 0.5 percent to 1 percent because improvements such as more localized reporting, better printing quality and color have been made. Some analysts said Coen may be too optimistic about national ad spending next year. His forecast, for example, calls for a 6.1 percent rise in national broadcast advertising compared with 7.8 percent in 1990. But David F. Poltrack, a top researcher at the CBS Broadcast Group, said he expects ad spending on the Big Three television networks will rise only 2 percent this year and 2 percent in 1991. He said revenue at CBS, ABC and NBC was about 5 percent ahead of last year for the first nine months of 1990 but that ``the bottom fell out of the market'' in the fourth quarter, which ``will be down significantly from 1989.'' Ad spending growth outside the United States continues to outpace domestic ad spending increases, Coen said. He said ad spending overseas rose 12.6 percent to $145.5 billion in 1990, and is expected to increase 7.5 percent to $156.4 billion in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Class Action in Key Worker Health Case
DOC.TEXT: In a major step toward resolving the nation's biggest product liability issue, a federal judge has consolidated tens of thousands of lawsuits against a company filed by victims of asbestos-related diseases. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein late Monday certified a class action for 65,000 worker health claims against Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. and froze all litigation against the Cincinnati-based industrial products maker. But victims' lawyers said Weinstein had flouted legal procedure, appointed partisan attorneys to negotiate with the company who supported his desires and sought to force a settlement they said was unfair. ``The judge's attitude is there is no Constitution among friends,'' said Ron Motley, a Charleston, S.C., attorney for several thousands asbestos victims. ``He was not acting as judge. He was acting as king,'' said Fred Baron, a Dallas plaintiffs lawyer. ``Fortunately in this country the laws are not determined by kings.'' Lawyers said they would appeal Weinstein's order, which also appeared to violate an automatic halt on legal proceedings in the case imposed when a motion was filed Monday in Cincinnati to place Eagle-Picher in involuntary bankruptcy. If it succeeds, Weinstein's plan could become a model for dozens of companies struggling under the burden of asbestos liability and help clear state and federal courts nationwide of 90,000 asbestos cases. Litigation has mounted since the early 1970s, when medical evidence grew that asbestos was responsible for lung cancer and other respiratory diseases in Americans who worked in shipbuilding, boilermaking and other trades where the mineral was used as a fire retardant and insulator. The biggest case involves the Manville trust fund, which faces 130,000 claims. The fund has run out of cash and is being reorganized under Weinstein's orders. The trust was created out of the 1988 bankruptcy reorganization of Manville Corp., once the nation's largest asbestos user. Weinstein, who crafted a class-action solution to illnesses caused by the Vietnam War defoliant Agent Orange, wants to consolidate asbestos cases to eliminate long and costly trials that have delayed payments to victims and squandered money on legal costs. ``Judge Weinstein is out to break the logjam of national asbestos litigation by certifying the class, which will be the beginning of the end of asbestos litigation,'' said Kenneth Feinberg, a Weinstein-appointed mediator in the Eagle-Picher case. Eagle-Picher, which favors the class action, has said it faces bankruptcy unless it solves its asbestos problems. It is liable for injuries caused by cement insulation products containing asbestos it made from 1931 to 1971. The company has spent $540 million in the last five years on its asbestos obligations and faces an estimated $600 million in future claims. It has sold assets to pay claims, but is running out of divisions to pawn as well as insurance. The first case against the company was made in 1966 and about 20,000 new claims are being filed annually. Under the settlement plan, Eagle-Picher would place an estimated $625 million into a trust fund over 20 years. The trust also would receive 25 percent of Eagle-Picher stock and 50 percent if the company failed to meet its annual payments after five years. Payments would not begin until November 1993. Plaintiffs lawyers said the plan provides too little money and that victims would do better if Eagle-Picher filed for bankruptcy. The main stumbling block appeared to be a demand that the trust control Eagle-Picher stock, which the company refused. Only one of three lawyers appointed by Weinstein to represent current Eagle-Picher victims has approved the plan, and he doesn't have any asbestos clients. More than 90 attorneys with 40,000 asbestos clients signed a petition opposing the proposal. ``There is a massive lack of confidence in the settlement,'' Grant Hering, a New York plaintiffs lawyer, told the judge. ``For people who are victims, who have suffered what they have suffered, it is a gimmick they can't comprehend.'' Weinstein interrupted hearings on the plan in Brooklyn federal court to certify the class action. He froze all litigation involving Eagle-Picher pending a final settlement, except for payment of $45 million in already negotiated claims. The judge issued the order despite an automatic stay from the involuntary bankruptcy petition filing, which he called ``fraudulent on its face.'' The motion was filed at the behest of plaintiffs lawyers by three victims who said Eagle-Picher had not met settlement agreements. In a statement, Eagle-Picher called the bankruptcy petition ``totally without merit.'' It said it did not believe the three victims had legal standing to file the petition. Weinstein appointed a former federal judge to study whether claimants would receive more money in a bankruptcy reorganization or the settlement. He said hearings on the plan's fairness would be held in New York, Cincinnati and Detroit. Eagle-Picher stock fell 75 cents to close at $3.25 Monday on the New York Stock Exchange. Weinstein made his ruling after the markets closed.

DOC.HEAD: New Cellular Technology Promises To Boost Capacity
DOC.TEXT: The entrance of a General Motors Corp. subsidiary into the race for the next-generation cellular phone technology will increase an industry fight over which system will prevail, industry analysts say. GM Hughes Electronics has developed technology it says will increase the capacity of cellular phone systems fifteenfold, which would be a boon to overcrowded systems in cities such as New York and Los Angeles. ``If they're successful, it's going to bring the cellular industry to a big stall because people won't know what to do,'' said John Pemberton of the high-tech research firm Gartner Group Inc. ``The standards battle could rage on for two years.'' The Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, the industry's main trade group, already has approved specifications for a digital technology that would replace today's analog cellular phones. But the most-advanced digital phone system envisioned by the trade group would only increase capacity six times - below the tenfold increase the nation's cellular phone operators say they will need to meet expected demand. The trade group announced Monday night that nine large cellular phone equipment makers agreed to a timetable for readying digital phone gear that uses the group's standard. Under it, prototype equipment will be tested by March 31, meaning production should start later next year, the group said. The companies are Motorola Inc., American Telephone & Telegraph Co., Ericsson, Audiovox, Mitsubishi, NovAtel, OKI Telecom, Sony and Uniden. Hughes' digital system, to be formally announced today, would provide much greater capacity than the systems to be tested. It is based on the same technology, called time-division multiple access, which allows several calls to be sent simultaneously over the same channel. But Hughes' system is more advanced. The time-division technique introduces minute pauses into each call; during these pauses, another call in the cellular network is sent. Because the delays are so short and the call is sent in computer language, the pauses are not noticed by the user. But Hughes' system also uses pauses in conversations to send other calls, said Pradeep P. Kaul, executive vice president of Hughes Network Systems Inc., the Hughes subsidiary that developed the system. For example, when a caller pauses in a conversation to listen to the other party, the speaking portion of the signal would be switched off, making it available for another call. As soon as the caller resumes speaking, a speach-recognition device would switch the signal back on. Hughes' system will compete with a technology called code-division multiple access. In it, several calls are sent at once over the same channel, but each is preceded by a special code. The receiving equipment only picks up calls with a particular code. Code-division technology has been developed by a small San Diego company called Qualcomm. AT&T and Motorola, the two largest U.S. makers of cellular telephone equipment, are exploring Qualcomm's technology as well as time-division techniques. Industry analysts say they believe time-division technology will be used, at least initially, to boost the capacity of overtaxed cellular systems in major metropolitan areas. But once the capacity of these time-division systems is reached, the industry will need yet another replacement, said Jason LaMountain, an analyst with the Boston research firm Yankee Group Inc. He said Hughes is one of a number of companies trying to boost time-division technology to greater capacity. At the same time, code-division technology will be vying for the replacement market, he said. Proponents of this technology say it could boost capacity by twenty times over current analog systems. As for the winner, ``I think it's going to be which one works. None of them have been proven in the market,'' LaMountain said. In another cellular development, Motorola said Monday it had devised an enhanced analog system that increases capacity threefold over current systems. It said it would began testing it in January. Hughes says it will use its technology to make the switching equipment used in each ``cell,'' or geographic area, of a cellular phone system, and license the technology to other equipment makers. It also said it would work with GM's Delco Electronics Corp. to develop phones that would be built into the dashboards of cars. In addition, Hughes announced that the French phone-equipment maker Alactel would make the central-office phone switching equipment to be used with Hughes' cellular system.

DOC.HEAD: T. Boone Pickens and Japanese Company At It Again
DOC.TEXT: If the verbal skirmishes between a Japanese auto parts maker and Texas investor T. Boone Pickens were a series of movie sequels they'd by up to number XIV or XV by now. On Monday, Koito Manufacturing Co. called on Pickens to disclose all the details of his arrangement with a Japanese stock speculator to acquire a large stake in the company. Last week, a new Japanese securities law forced Pickens, who has portrayed himself as a David battling the Goliath of Japan's corporate system, to acknowledge that his 26.4 percent stake in Koito was backed - at least in part - by stock speculator Kitaro Watanabe. Koito has used the specter of Watanabe to rebuff Pickens' attempts to secure representation on its board of directors, even though he is the largest single shareholder. The company claims Pickens is merely acting on behalf of Watanabe in another attempt by the Tokyo investor to obtain ``greenmail'' from Koito. Greenmail, a play on the word blackmail, is what a company pays when it buys back its own stock from a potential raider at rates above the going market price. Koito has claimed that before Watanabe sold his stake to Pickens in March 1989, he tried to pursuade carmaker Toyota Motor Corp., Koito's second-largest shareholder, to buy his stock at higher-than-market prices. ``It appears clear from your own statements that the entire transaction was an outright sham,'' Koito's president, Takao Matsuura, wrote Pickens. Pickens has disclosed that he bought 42.4 million shares, or 26.4 percent of Koito, from Watanabe, who loaned him the money after Pickens put up the shares as collateral. The shares are now worth an estimated $1 billion. Pickens also submitted an affidavit stating he will not accept greenmail. ``Now that you have acknowledged your secret arrangement with Mr. Watanabe, I must insist that you disclose the remaining details that your filing omits,'' the Koito president wrote. He wanted to know the conditions of the loan and what interest Pickens' Dallas-based Boone Co. had paid on it. But the new Japanese law does not require Pickens, who has steadfastly denied that he is fronting for Watanabe, to disclose further details about the loan. ``According to our lawyers and the (Japanese) Ministry of Finance, those are the two material agreements that we have to reveal regarding the ownership of the Koito stock,'' said a Pickens spokesman in Washington, Mark Helmke. ``Now comes Koito, saying `You haven't told us what your interest rate is. You haven't told us what your payment schedule is.' None of that's required.'' Helmke added: ``That's the game they play. If the Ministry of Finance wants to require everybody in Japan to disclose that information we would be be happy to comply. They want the Americans to disclose more than what they require of the Japanese.''

DOC.HEAD: RTA to Subsidize Sale of Junk Bonds, Real Estate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Task force hearing scheduled 10 a.m. EST; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Regulators hope to unload hard-to-sell real estate and junk bonds inherited from failed savings and loans by financing 85 percent or more of the purchase price. Real estate agents and builders are applauding the move, a major strategy shift for the Resolution Trust Corp., as a realistic recognition of the credit crunch that is pinching real estate markets. But a congressional critic charged Monday that the new policy is only a costly way of postponing resolution of the S&L mess. ``They're just going to sink into the same quicksand that the S&L operators couldn't pull themselves out of,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., who heads a House task force monitoring the bailout. ``I just think they would be better off to face up to the problem now.'' The RTC Oversight Board is more than doubling the lending limit from the previous $3 billion. Vento's panel planned to review the policy and other aspects of the RTC's performance at a hearing today. In the deteriorating economy, the agency has encountered far more problems than anticipated in selling real estate, junk bonds and other assets inherited from failed S&Ls. Banks in many regions also have grown increasingly reluctant to lend, particularly on commercial real estate, causing what borrowers complain is a shortage of credit. By offering financing, the RTC is, in effect, becoming its own bank. ``The goals of the program are to speed asset sales and increase the value to taxpayers from such sales,'' said oversight board President Peter Monroe. However, Vento said, the government will run the risk of having to repossess financed properties if buyers default. It's better to sell the property outright at whatever price can be obtained, he said. ``The administration, frankly, has been offering one excuse after another as to why they can't do what they said they were going to do,'' Vento said. However, analysts said real estate markets are so slack in areas where the RTC owns property that the agency has little choice. ``Their backs are to the wall,'' said economist Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based research group. ``Ordinarily, if it weren't for the recession, they shouldn't be doing this.'' Kent Colton, executive vice president of the National Association of Home Builders, endorsed the strategy shift as ``a recognition of the credit crunch that has prevented buyers from obtaining private financing.'' ``It will revive real estate markets in the South and Southwest, where many of the properties are located,'' said Harley E. Rouda, president of the National Association of Realtors. Economist Paul M. Horvitz of the University of Houston said the financing policy would work provided the RTC demands enough of a down payment. ``People in Texas tell me it is difficult to get financing on a traditional basis for the acquisition of real estate. In that situation, it makes sense to me for the RTC to be willing to provide financing as long as the buyer puts up some reasonable amount of equity,'' he said. In general, the RTC will require at least a 15 percent down payment, but in some cases may accept less. About half of the $142 billion in assets controlled by the agency will be eligible for financing. Much of it is commercial real estate but some illiquid financial assets, such as junk bonds, are also eligible. Before the agency can lend the government's money to buyers, the oversight board said it must determine that no ready market exists for the asset and then document that providing a loan will help the government get a better price on the sale. The agency hopes to sell the loans it makes, thereby making more money available for financing. The oversight board decided on its new financing policy in private late Friday and announced it after business hours. The five-member panel, headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, controls the policy and purse strings of the bailout agency. The panel includes Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp and two private citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Bureau Calls Wants U.S. to Stand Firm on GATT Deadline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for PM-Farm Scene
DOC.TEXT: Congress needs to stand firm behind a March 1 deadline for an international trade agreement in order to assure that meat and grain producers have better access to world markets, the American Farm Bureau Federation says. ``It is probably imperative that the Congress agree or follows through with the administration's analysis that Congress isn't going to change the fast-track deadline unless there is reason to,'' bureau spokesman Donald Lipton said Monday. He also said President Bush needed to exercise personal diplomacy to break the deadlock in international trade talks, a step the administration said Monday it was plannin to take. President Bush ``undoubtedly will be talking to various leaders about the GATT situation,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, using the acronym for General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the framework agreement for world trade. Lipton, like many farm group representatives, went to Brussels, Belgium, last week to observe the meeting of trade ministers hoping to conclude the so-called Uruguay Round of talks with an agreement on how to conduct trade into the 21st century. However, the delegates never came close to agreement because of a fight between the United States and the 12-nation European Community over farm subsidies. The United States, backed by Australia, Brazil and other major farm exporters, was seeking sharp reductions in subsidies. The EC claimed the U.S. proposal would force more than 2 million of its 10 million farmers off the land. The trade ministers told GATT Director Arthur Dunkel in Brussels to try to get at least low-level discussions started again by late January. Under the fast-track provision of U.S. trade law, the administration has a deadline for submitting an agreement to Congress and Congress has a deadline for ratifying it without any changes. The deadline can be extended legislatively for a two-year period. Lipton said that without the deadline, other industry groups with an interest in the outcome of the trade proposal could lobby to weaken the agricultural provisions. But he also said he was also encouraged by what he saw last week. ``In Brussels, it was remarkable how united the various sectors were,'' he said, referring to U.S. groups with an interest in the other provisions, such as intellectual property, services and investments. Other farm interests agreed with Lipton that the desirability of other provisions could help force an agreement on farm products as well. ``They've got a lot at stake over there,'' said Keith Heard, executive vice president of the National Corn Growers Association. ``I'm guardedly optimistic,'' said Marlyn Jorgensen, a Garrison, Iowa, soybean farmer and board chairman of the American Soybean Association. ``I think there was, in the end, kind of a feeling by most other countries that we needed something to happen.'' If there is no agreement, ``then I think that we do have to turn back to Congress'' and ask that a so-called ``snap-back'' provision under the 1990 Farm Bill be implemented, Jorgensen said. The five-year farm bill, reflecting budget problems, cut farm supports by one-fourth, he noted. The snap-back provision allows Congress to restore supports if there is no trade agreement, but not for two years. He said the United States could increase credit guarantees to the Soviet Union to help growers. Meat producers want the United States to flex some muscle immediately. ``In the interim, I'd like to see the government take some action to show we're intent upon forcing our rights,'' said Michael Kopps, senior vice president for legislative affairs at the American Meat Institute. He said the U.S. Trade Representative could vigorously pursue the industry's complaint about European restrictions on American meat products, including the Oct. 30 ban on pork imports and the announced Dec. 31 ban on beef. The European Community Commission said the bans were due to lack of proper sanitation in the United States. Domestic sugar plant growers and dairy farmers, meanwhile, were not enthusiastic about the U.S.-backed agricultural proposals. Dalton Yancey, a spokesman for sugar cane and sugar beet growers, said he objected to a percentage formula for cutting price supports, because the European guaranteed price is much higher than the U.S. price: 32 cents vs. 18 cents. The guaranteed price is part of the farm bill, and is maintained by restricting imports. Critics say the policy deprives Latin American producing countries of an important source of income and causes consumer prices to be artificially high. Peter Vitaliano of the National Milk Producers Federation said the group opposes any plan to increase imports and called the dispute ``a grain trade issue to a great extent.''

DOC.HEAD: Metzenbaum Sees Insurance Industry in Possible Peril
DOC.TEXT: The life insurance industry, which controls nearly $2 trillion, could suffer the same fate as the savings and loans, jeopardizing the financial security of millions of Americans, a senator contends. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who chairs the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust, said financially shaky insurers are able to conceal their real problems through questionable accounting gimmicks and with little policing from the states. But A.M. Best Co., which operates a well-regarded system of rating insurance companies, says insurers have maintained their secure standing, especially in comparison to other financial industries. ``We ... do not agree that the insurance industry as a whole at this point in time is on the brink of financial crisis analogous to that of the savings and loan industry,'' Michael Albanese, a Best analyst, told the subcommittee Monday. Metzenbaum cited a report by IDS Life Co. of Minneapolis predicting that the loss of consumer confidence following the failure of a prominent insurer ``could have a widespread effect on the industry, with massive cash withdrawals induced by the insolvency of one insurer leading to the insolvency of other, less financially secure companies.'' Albanese said Best ``would not support the dire conclusions which have been reached regarding the potential insolvencies of several large and prominent insurers in the event of unspecified economic scenarios.'' Metzenbaum called the hearing to explore whether the insurance industry and policyholders are jeopardized by insurers' heavy investment in high-risk junk bonds and commercial real estate that, because of a slowing economy, has lost much of its value. Life insurance companies are said to hold about four times as many junk bonds as S&Ls did before scores of thrift institutions collapsed in the late 1980s. Metzenbaum argued that lax state regulation allows insurers to list the value of bonds and real estate as their purchase price, rather than much lower current worth. Thomas H. Borman, Minnesota commerce commissioner, said state regulators must learn from the mistakes of S&L regulators and require insurers to update the valuations of their holdings. ``This is yet another thinly disguised attempt to dupe the public into believing that their security blanket is not in jeopardy,'' Metzenbaum said. ``The insurance industry, and particularly the life insurance industry, has enormous sums invested in these troubled assets.'' Terence Lennon, chief examiner of the New York Insurance Department, questioned the logic of such a move unless an insurer's liabilities - its promise to pay off on policies in the future - also are revalued. Because of the wide variety of policies now available, he said, that would be a mistake. Metzenbaum had asked six life insurance companies to testify at the hearing. They declined, and the senator said their refusal ``sends a loud and clear message - they cannot stand the tough scrutiny that the public demands and deserves.'' The American Council of Life Insurance, which represents most companies, was not allowed to testify but submitted a brief written statement from President Richard S. Schweiker. Because life companies have liabilities that are long-term, they match them with long-term assets - bonds, he said. Insurers list those bonds at book value because changes in market interest rates ``have almost no impact on the ability of the bond issuer to meet interest obligations or repay principal,'' Schweiker wrote. Metzenbaum is exploring whether the federal government should take over some or all of the task of regulating the insurance industry from the states.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Groups Award Lemons to Advertisers
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to include full corporate names and make it air bag sted airbag.
DOC.TEXT: A fast-food kiddie club promises ``fun, non-stop.'' Beer is billed as the beverage of choice on Halloween. And a cigarette maker portrays itself as a patriotic defender of freedom. Those are some of the advertisements an array of consumer, environmental and health groups contended Monday are among the year's ``most misleading, unfair or irresponsible.'' The sixth annual ``Harlan Page Hubbard Lemon Awards'' honor the legacy of the man who tirelessly promoted Lydia Pinkham's Vegetable Compound as a remedy for ailments ranging from fatigue to cancer. Needless to say, the cure-all claim was pure quackery. The Center for Science in the Public Interest called Hubbard ``the first advertising executive to employ deceptive advertising techniques on a national scale'' and said his spirit lives in the commercials of today. The sponsors of the modern-day ads begged to differ. Those who could be found said they stood firmly behind their products and commercials. ``It's been wonderfully successful and lots of fun,'' Burger King Corp. spokesman Cori Zywtow said of the chain's ``Kid's Clubs'' program. Exactly how much fun was the question asked by Action for Children's Television in nominating Burger King for a Hubbard. The ad promises ``fun, non-stop'' and shows groups of children happily engaged in what are presumably club activities. But ACT said they actually receive little more than a membership card and some stickers. Zywtow said the 2.7 million members also get posters, a newsletter and special meals. Does that constitute non-stop fun? ``It has been a terrific program,'' she replied. ``We're very proud of it.'' General Motors Corp. also took issue with its two citations by the Center for Auto Safety and the Safe Energy Communication Council. The safety center said GM misrepresented itself in one ad by claiming that it ``pioneered the air bag.'' It said the company fought government rules to require air bags and now equips fewer models with them than Ford or Chrysler. The energy council denounced an ad touting the Cutlass Supreme as fuel-efficient even though it gets lower mileage than most of GM's other models. Gus Buenz, a spokesman for Oldsmobile, countered that GM had airbags in cars as early as 1974 and has a strong tradition of safety research. He said the Cutlass ad was meant to highlight the car's roominess, price and responsiveness, as well as fuel economy. ``All we're doing is telling people you can get all those things plus 30 mpg'' on the highway, Buenz said. Another double winner was Philip Morris Companies Inc., parent of the cigarette maker. Its alleged lemons: -A Virginia Slims ad that, according to the National Women's Health Network, implies a brand called ``Superslims'' can help women stay thin. -A series of ads celebrating the Bill of Rights. The Coalition on Smoking or Health accused the firm of appropriating one of the country's most important documents ``for its own greedy purposes'' - namely the defeat of government restrictions on tobacco promotion. Philip Morris spokesman Les Zuke said it was ``absurd'' to read a weight pitch in the Superslims ad. He said the commercial ``makes two claims: Superslims emits 70 percent less smoke from the lit end and Superslims is an ultralight cigarette that tastes good.'' The first nominee to a newly established ``Hubbard Hall of Shame'' was a Volvo ad that showed a Volvo surviving as a truck drove over its roof. The car had been specially reinforced during production of the ad - a fact the company says it did not know until after the spot aired. ``It was never Volvo's intention to deceive or mislead the public,'' said spokesman Robert Austin. ``A mistake was made ... We went out and told the public that with our own corrective advertisement.'' Among others receiving laurels for the year's worst ads: -Coors Brewing Co., for Coors Light ads that feature a haunted house and the line that ``it isn't Halloween without the Silver Bullet.'' ``Its appeal to children is chilling,'' said the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence Inc. -Kellogg Co., for saying that protein in Special K cereal can help women maintain healthy muscle tone while dieting. The Iowa attorney general has alleged in federal court that the ads are misleading, said the Center for Science in the Public Interest. Celeste Clark, vice president of nutrition marketing at Kellogg, said Special K has been marketed as a high-protein cereal for 35 years. ``The ad campaign is not meant to indicate that Special K alone can help you lose weight,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Thompson Family To Relinquish Control Of Southland Corp.
DOC.TEXT: The family that developed Southland Corp. from an ice company into the nation's largest operator of convenience stores will relinquish the control they have held for nearly 60 years as the company is restructured. Southland officials said Monday that officials from the Japanese companies that would buy a majority of Southland's stock will dominate the board and management, including Masatoshi Ito as chairman. Ito would replace chairman John P. Thompson, son of the late Joe C. Thompson, the patriarch who developed Southland. Ito is president of Ito-Yokado Group and chairman of 7-Eleven Japan, the two companies that propose paying $430 million to buy 70 percent of Southland. Clark Matthews, Southland's chief financial officer, would become the company's president and chief executive officer, according to the plan filed Monday. He would replace Jere Thompson. Toshifumi Suzuki, Ito-Yokado executive vice president, would become vice chairman of Southland's board. Monday's announcement confirmed speculation about a severely reduced role for the Thompsons that followed Southland's first proposals in March for a restructuring. In an offer revised several times since then, Southland wants to exchange $1.8 billion in expensive loans for less costly notes and sell control of the company to the Japanese companies for the much-needed cash. Southland filed a prepackaged bankruptcy plan in October after gaining approval from the company's major creditors. Southland hopes to emerge from court protection within months. Each of the Thompson brothers - John, Jere and Joe C. - would receive a $960,000 annual salary for five years under terms of the reorganization plan. The retention of Matthews as a top managing officer at Southland ``underscores the confidence of our Japanese partners in the current management of the company,'' Southland spokeswoman Cecilia Norwood said Monday. John and Jere Thompson would remain members of Southland's board as vice chairmen. In that role, they would remain actively involved in strategic planning, Ms. Norwood said. The third brother, Joe C. Thompson, and Matthews also would become company directors. Southland outlined its proposed management team, which depends on confirmation of its restructuring plan by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold Abramson, in documents filed with the court Monday. The new Japanese owners would control 10 seats on Southland's board of 15 to 17 members. The Thompsons directly control three seats, indicating the Japanese approved the appointment of one of the Thompsons or Matthews to the board. A committee that represents the company's bondholders would appoint two other, unnamed board members.

DOC.HEAD: Third-Quarter Trade Deficit Widens to $25.59 Billion
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The deficit in the broadest measure of foreign trade widened sharply to $25.59 billion in the July-September quarter, the worst showing since late last year, the government reported today. The 13.9 percent jump in the deficit was blamed on the fallout from the Persian Gulf crisis, which drove up the price Americans pay for imported oil and also boosted the country's spending on overseas military operations. The Commerce Department said the third quarter deficit in the country's current account trade deficit compared to a $22.49 billion deficit in the second quarter. It was the widest imbalance since a deficit of $26.69 billion in the October-December quarter of last year. The improvement in the country's trade deficit had been the one bright spot in a generally lackluster U.S. economy. Improving export sales had provided more than half of overall growth this year. However, analysts are now worried that a widening trade deficit will be one more drag on an economy many believe is already in a recession. They fear that if the gap between U.S. exports and imports widens significantly it will worsen the severity of the recession. The current account is the country's most important trade statistic because it measures not only trade in merchandise but also trade in services and investment flows between countries. The big deterioration in the third quarter came from a sharply higher merchandise deficit, which climbed 28.9 percent to $29.75 billion, compared to a deficit of $23.10 billion in the second quarter. More than one-half of the increase in imports stemmed from higher petroleum prices following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The balance on investment earnings shifted into a surplus of $2.46 billion, reflecting improved earnings by Americans on their overseas investments. This had been in deficit by $1 billion in the second quarter. The United States also ran a surplus in the services category of $5.82 billion in the third quarter. This reflected a drop of 2.8 percent from the second quarter figure of $5.98 billion. Payments to foreigners on services increased to $27.8 billion, up 7.3 percent from the second quarter. This reflected higher travel and passenger fares paid by Americans to foreign airlines and also higher direct defense spending because of the stationing of U.S. troops in the Middle East. The other component of the current account, unilateral transfer payments, primarily foreign aid payments and government pension payments to Americans living overseas, increased the deficit by $4.11 billion. The current account is the trade statistic that is most closely watched by economists because it shows the amount of borrowing the United States must do each quarter to finance the shortfall between imports of goods, services and investments and exports in those categories. A decade ago, America was the largest creditor nation. It ran surpluses in its current account as the earnings from its overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade. But as Americans handed over billions of dollars to foreigners to pay for imported merchandise, the investment cushion eroded and disappeared altogether in 1985 when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. That means that foreigners now own more in U.S. assets than Americans own overseas, a development which has led some to fear the country is losing control of its economic destiny to foreigners. At the end of 1989, the country's net debtor position was put at $663.7 billion, up a sharp 25 percent from the previous year. Analysts believe that figure will grow by close to another $100 billion this year and will hit $1 trillion before it starts to improve.

DOC.HEAD: Hammer Death: Will Takeover Battle Erupt for Occidental?
With PM-Obit-Hammer, f0022
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with NY stock price in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: As Armand Hammer built Occidental Petroleum Corp. from nearly nothing to the nation's 16th largest industrial corporation, his grip on the company was so tight that critics called it a stranglehold. Today the question is whether his successor, Ray R. Irani, can hold together a company long regarded as a natural takeover target, worth far less as a whole than broken into its separate businesses: oil and gas, chemicals, natural gas pipelines, pork and beef, coal. Occidental stock was up $2.25 at $23 per share in heavy trading this morning on the New York Stock Exchange, after trading up about the same amount in London today. Analysts and investors have watched Occidental with fascination and often suspicion for decades, wondering how long Hammer could last and who would try to replace him. Now, with his death Monday at 92, they will find out. From 1970 to the mid-1980s, Hammer rid himself of at least 10 executives who had believed they were his corporate heir. The joke was that so many people had occupied the Occidental president's office that it should have a revolving door. In 1984, Irani was named president and chief operating officer. In February of this year, Hammer anointed Irani his successor-to-be as Occidental's chairman and chief executive. Among other things, Hammer praised Irani's leadership of Occidental's chemical operations, which grew from a 1983 loss of $38 million on sales of $1.7 billion to 1989 profits of more than $1 billion on $5.2 billion in sales. The move was designed to calm the wild swings in stock price that resulted from the merest rumors of ill health for Hammer, who had a history of heart problems and received a pacemaker in November 1989. It also clearly underlined that Irani was entirely in control of day-to-day operations at Occidental. That point was an important one at a time when Hammer, after seven decades as one of the world's most prominent businessmen, increasingly showed signs of senility, often losing touch with reality, according to associates who spoke on condition of anonymity. In declining to reveal details of those problems, Occidental walked a fine line again with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which requires disclosure of significant facts affecting a publicly held company.

DOC.HEAD: Armand Hammer, Industrialist Who Built Ties to Soviets, Dies
LaserPhotos NY9, NY10, NY16, NY17, LA4, LON9, LaserColor 109
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, ``Armand Hammer...' with one graf to UPDATE with Gorbachev expressing condolences.
DOC.TEXT: Armand Hammer, the communist's son who became an American captain of industry as well-connected in the Kremlin as he was on Wall Street, has died at age 92. Hammer died at his home Monday night after a brief illness, said Frank Ashley, a spokesman for Hammer's Occidental Petroleum Corp. Hammer, a self-made millionaire by the time he graduated from Columbia University medical school at age 23, was also a philanthropist, art collector and crusader for world peace. ``He was absolutely indomitable,'' said his attorney, Arthur Groman. ``He never lost his courage or tenacity. In the last months, he was uncomplaining and optimistic.'' Hammer exhibited a flair for the dramatic until the end, deciding to celebrate his bar mitzvah - which marks a Jewish boy's 13th birthday - at age 92. He died the night before the ceremony. Hammer was born a Jew but his family did not follow religious customs. ``We're going to go ahead with the event,'' said spokesman Howard Bragman. ``He's done extraordinary things for the Jewish people, and since (Tuesday) night is the first night of Hanukkah, we think that a light in the Jewish community like Dr. Hammer who did so much for Jewish freedom should be remembered.'' Hammer - a global businessman who knew world leaders from Vladimir Lenin to George Bush - negotiated deals with communist countries such as China and the Soviet Union to develop resources. For years, he urged American presidents to meet with their Soviet counterparts and encouraged the reduction of nuclear weapons, so the money could be diverted to agriculture and medicine. ``Mr. Hammer was associated with one of the most remarkable pages of our relationship'' with the United States, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today in a condolence message. ``He met with Lenin and was very close in many ways to the Soviet Union, and to Russia.'' Hammer made several fortunes and gave huge sums to his favorite causes, especially cancer research. ``The only reason I make money is so I can give it away,'' he was fond of saying. After the Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Union, he arranged visits by U.S. specialists in bone-marrow transplants, which helped save radiation victims. His empire rested on Los Angeles-based Occidental Petroleum Corp, which he bought for $100,000 in 1957 and turned into one of the nation's largest industrial companies. Ray Irani, the company's president and chief operations officer, succeeds Hammer as chairman. Hammer's death makes the company a potential takeover target. His art collection is displayed at the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Culture, which opened last month. Shareholders sued claiming company money was squandered on the museum. A settlement capped the company's contribution to it at just under $100 million. Hammer was born in 1898 in New York City. His Russian-born father, a doctor, was a founder of the American Communist Party. But Hammer was a staunch capitalist who would say to communists, ``I tell them ... that I don't think their system works. But that doesn't keep us from doing business.'' After World War I, Hammer went to medical school at night and worked to bail out the family's struggling pharmaceutical firm. He turned the business into a million-dollar company, in part because he was able to market tincture of ginger, sometimes used to give an alcoholic kick to ginger ale during Prohibition. After the Bolshevik Revolution, Hammer worked out a deal to trade surplus U.S. grain for Soviet products. Hammer became a Soviet hero for helping ease food shortages in the embattled country. Lenin licensed him as the sole representative of 38 leading American manufacturers. Hammer could not work with Josef Stalin and sold his enterprises to the Soviet government. For the next 25 years, he was an art dealer, a cattle breeder in New Jersey and a whiskey distiller in Kentucky. In 1940, he parlayed a $100,000 investment into $7.5 million by making blended whiskey from potatoes. Hammer bought Occidental as a tax shelter when it was near bankruptcy. Today the company boasts huge oil, natural gas, coal, chemical and agribusiness operations. In 1975, Hammer was charged with making a secret $54,000 donation President Nixon's campaign fund. He pleaded guilty, was put on probation and fined $3,000 - and began campaigning for a pardon, which President Bush gave him last year. Hammer was married three times and is survived by one son, Julian, by his first wife. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Quiet Trading in Anticipation of Schevardnadze Visit
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading was quiet in anticipation of the release later today of the U.S. Agriculture Department's supply and demand report. The market was also anticipating a visit to Washington on Wednesday of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Schevardnadze. There was a belief the USDA will use the occasion to announce the award of U.S. aid or the granting of export credits to the Soviets. ``The question (in the market) is the size of the credits,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``If it is a billion dollars it will be bearish for the market. If it is a couple of billion (dollars) it would be bullish.'' News that China has been targeted with 1.5 million metric tons of export bonus wheat should help wheat prices. DOC.HEAD: Report: GM to Unveil Affirmative Action Dealership Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with announcement.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. plans a 40 percent boost in the number of minority-owned dealerships over the next three years, the company announced today. The automaker plans an additional 76 minority-owned dealerships by December 1993, GM President Lloyd Reuss and Tony March, chairman of the 11-member GM Minority Dealer Advisory Council, said today. The company has 192 black, Hispanic and Asian dealers, making up 2 percent of its approximately 9,600 dealers. ``Increased minority participation in our dealerships is vital to achieving GM's prime objective of the 1990s - satisfying car and truck owners better than any other manufacturer,'' Reuss said in a statement. The automaker has conducted a minority dealer-training program since 1972. But one of GM's leading black dealers said the new agreement went an important step further. ``There is no doubt in my mind about the commitment of Lloyd Reuss and (GM Chairman) Bob Stempel,'' said March, a Buick dealer from Hartford, Conn. ``We are talking about a commitment from the largest corporation in the world.'' ``Some people were pushing the idea'' of a separate target figure for new black dealers, said another council member, Chevrolet dealer Charles Harrell of Flat Rock. ``But we didn't want to get into that kind of trap. We'll get our fair share.'' GM intends to increase the number of minority dealers in cities with relatively large minority populations, according to a GM statement. Those cities include Detroit, where four black-owned GM dealerships folded this year, leaving no black-owned GM franchises in the metropolitan area. At Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., minorities make up 5.7 percent and 2.5 percent, respectively, of dealer ranks.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Approve Merger Creating No. 2 Cellular Firm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with GTE shareholders approving merger; PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `Contel Chairman...
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders for Contel Corp. and GTE Corp. today overwhelmingly approved a $6.2 billion merger that will create the nation's second largest mobile-cellular telephone company. GTE said about 98 percent of shareholders at its meeting in Stamford, Conn., or voting by proxy approved the merger. Atlanta-based Contel said about 97 percent of its shareholders at a meeting in New York or voting by proxy approved the merger. ``The strong vote of confidence by our shareholders reinforces my conviction that this merger is the right move at the right time for all the right reasons,'' GTE Chairman James L. ``Rocky'' Johnson said. The combined company would be second in size to McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's top cellular phone operation, and has been called an ideal match. Remaining regulatory hurdles are expected to delay completion of the merger until the second quarter of 1991. ``It's a logical, natural, normal merger that should benefit both companies,'' said Herschel Schostek, a Silver Springs, Md., telecommunications industry consultant. ``GTE brings capital. Contel brings a nice operational system.'' The deal calls for Contel shareholders to receive 1.27 shares of GTE common stock for each share of Contel common stock. Contel would become a wholly owned subsidiary of GTE, based in Stamford. Contel, which provides a broad range of telecommunications products and services, had more than $3 billion in revenues last year. GTE, the nation's largest independent phone company, had revenues of $17.4 billion. Contel Chairman Charles Wohlstetter called the merger ``a tax-free exchange for shares in a company that will be financially stronger and more competitive and have greatly enhanced marketing and technological resources.'' The merger comes at a time of growth in the cellular phone business. Joel D. Gross, an analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, said subscriber rates industrywide are up 50 percent this year. ``The cellular industry has a tremendous outlook over the next five to 10 years,'' he said. ``It's been growing for some time - it's not like a cyclical business.''

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Dangles $100,000 Carrot Before Brokers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd and 13th grafs pvs to CORRECT attribution to John L. Steffens, sted Daniel P. Tully. SUBS grafs 10-11 pvs to ADD company figure on turnover rate. Pick up 12th graf pvs ``Merrill Lynch executives ...''
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. said it will offer a $100,000 reward to veteran employees under a new program that analysts said was an attempt to keep other firms from robbing workers the company has spent money on to train. Under the program announced Monday, brokers and other financial consultants who remain with the company 10 years and meet other requirements can collect the reward as early as the year 2001, company executives said. ``We want to send a message that there are long-term positive opportunities on Wall Street,'' said John L. Steffens, executive vice president for the brokerage's private client division, during a press conference to announce the program. However, analysts said Merrill Lynch's new reward for loyalty could spur other brokerage firms to follow suit with similar compensation systems in what could turn into a bidding war for high-performance employees. ``I think they'll take up the torch in a modified way that could become competitive,'' said Perrin Long, an analyst who follows the securities industry for Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. For example, a competing company could offer loyal employees $100,000 at the end of nine years instead of 10 years, he said. To be eligible for the $100,000 bonus, Merrill Lynch workers must participate in a new training program designed to raise their skills to a level company executives said will make them more competitive in today's financial services environment. As part of the program, new hires will join an expanded two-year training program where they must successfully complete courses focusing on such subjects as money management, sales, client service and product knowledge. However, Long said he was skeptical about the program's ability to combat lucrative offers from competing firms for high-performance brokers. Merrill Lynch's turnover rate is between 14 percent to 15 percent, according to the company. ``Even though someone's being promised $100,000, maybe at the end of six years somebody else comes along and says we'll give you $100,000-$150,000 up front,'' Long said. Merrill Lynch executives declined to discuss the cost of the program. However, they said that productivity gains would more than cover its price tag. ``If everybody made it (remained at Merrill Lynch) for the next 10 years, it would add several hundred million dollars to Merrill Lynch's bottom line,'' said Steffens. All told, 10,500 domestic workers will be eligible for the reward. Long estimated the two-year training program for new hires would cost Merrill Lynch $40,000-$45,000 per employee, compared with $25,000-$30,000 a worker for the previous program.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Electricity Shares Sprint Higher as Trading Starts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in 2nd graf that package is made up 1,000 shares and CORRECTS its prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock in Britain's 12 newly privatized regional electricity companies sprinted as much as 77.5 percent higher Tuesday as they began trading on London's Stock Exchange. A mixed package of 1,000 of the 12 stocks jumped to 1,595 pounds, or $3,110, shortly after trading commenced at 2:30 p.m. from a partly paid price of 1,000 pounds, or $1,950. The London market's overall volume was a robust 470.8 million shares at mid-afternoon, more than twice the 230.7 million shares traded by midday. Dealers said trading in the new stock was very busy, with millions of shares quickly changing hands. The exchange extended trading for 1{ hours until 6 p.m. Tuesday to handle the heavy volume. Institutional investors were scrambling to get more stock after the government scaled back their allocation because of strong demand from the general public, dealers said. But some small investors were holding on to their stakes to take advantage of the discounts on electricity bills and dividend payments. The 5.18 billion pound, or $10.1 billion, sale of 2.16 billion shares was 10.7 times oversubscribed, with personal investors making 12.75 million applications. The general public is getting about 55 percent of the shares and domestic institutional investors are getting 30 percent, with 15 percent going to foreign investors. The sheer number of applications also prompted the government to reduce most allocations to 100 shares each. The immediate sharp rise in the shares' prices prompted opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock to accuse the Conservative government in the House of Commons of swindling the British public by selling a British asset at what he said was 3 billion pounds, or $5.9 billion, below its true value. Prime Minister John Major rejected the charge, saying the offer provided value to shareholders. The shares were offered at 240 pence, or $4.68, each, payable in three instalments. The first 100 pence, or $1.95, partial payment was due on application.

DOC.HEAD: Heinz Earnings Rise 11.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: H.J. Heinz Co., a food processor and canner, said Tuesday its second-quarter profits increased 11.5 percent because of price increases and a weaker U.S. dollar. Heinz reported earnings of $139.8 million, or 52 cents a share, on sales of $1.6 billion in the quarter ended Oct. 31. That compared with earnings of $125.4 million, or 47 cents a share, on sales of $1.5 billion in the same 1989 period. ``Despite the intense competitive environment in some of our food categories in the U.S.A., we remain confident that we will achieve satisfactory full-year growth and continue to build for future growth in the 1990s,'' said Anthony J.F. O'Reilly, the company's chairman, president and chief executive officer. Profits for the six months ending in October rose 12.3 percent to $283 million, or $1.06 per share, from $251 million, or 95 cents a share, in the same period in 1989. Sales rose to $3.2 billion from $3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: El Al Orders Four Boeing Jets
DOC.TEXT: El Al Israel Airlines has ordered four Boeing jetliners worth about $425 million, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Tuesday. El Al ordered two 747-400s and two 757-200s, and took options on two more 747-400s. The two 757-200s have been on order for some time, but were only announced by the companies Tuesday. One of the planes was delivered in mid-November, Boeing said. The 747-400 jumbo jet can carry 412 passengers 8,400 miles, while the medium-sized 757 can carry 176 to 230 passengers 4,500 miles. For the year, Boeing has announced orders for 502 aircraft, worth $44.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: You May Have Been Overcharged
DOC.TEXT: Don't bank on it, but there's a possibility you might have a sizeable refund coming from your mortgage lender, the result of errors in computing your adjustable rate payments. While nobody knows the full extent of the computing errors, the total is likely to be huge, even in the billions of dollars. Refunding the money could become still another financial problem for already shaky lenders. The first hint of errors came in the summer of 1989, when a former employee of the Federal Savings & Loan Insurance Corp. studied portfolios of failed thrift institutions and found errors in a large percentage of mortgage loans. Seeking to determine the scope of the problem, federal regulators already have asked lending institutions to audit their portfolios. Among these regulators were the Federal Reserve and the Office of Thrift Supervision. Meanwhile, a recent report from the General Accounting Office contains estimates that between 20 percent and 30 percent of all adjustable rate mortgages might have been calculated incorrectly. For the most part, assumptions to date are that the miscalculations were inadvertent rather than an attempt to defraud customers. In fact, it is likely that some errors favor borrowers rather than lenders. Why, then, have they occurred? Information to date suggests the answer lies in the complexity of caculations. Why didn't customers find the errors? For the same reason - complexity - that caused lenders to make them. HSH Associates, which tracks rates at institutions around the country and calls itself the nation's largest publisher of mortgage information, says errors could involve wrong dates, wrong indexes, and just poor arithmetic. Adjustable rate mortgages, or ARMS, are changed on a regular basis by rises or declines in an independent index, such as the ``One-year Treasury Bill'' rate, or the ``Six-month Treasury Bill'' rate or the ``Eleventh District Cost of Funds.'' Most ARMs, says HSH, add a margin or mark-up to the index at each adjustment, which might occur at six months or a year. The resulting sum is then rounded to the nearest one-eighth percent. Some errors are likely to occur at this point, but the possibilities for further errors are myriad. Some adjustments, for example, are limited up and down by caps that are written into the loan contracts. HSH, which has produced a booklet for homeowners wishing to check their ARMs, lists a few of the other possibilities for error: -The servicer, or company to which a borrower sends payments, might select a monthly index value instead of a weekly one. -It might use the wrong date, and thus the wrong index value. -An incorrect margin might be added to the index value. In some cases, the sum might not be rounded to the nearest one-eighth percent. If the calculations are often too much for lenders and their computers, how can a homeowner expect to do better? The task is formidable, to be sure, and some people might automatically send the job to an accountant. But, say the folks at HSH, it can be done by the homeowner with access to a newspaper and, of course, their handly little booklet and worksheet. It is available for $3 from HSH Associates, 1200 Route 23, Butler, N.J. 07405. They'll also calculate it for you if you tell them your current interest rate and send them a copy of your note, rider or disclosure, but it'll cost you $25.

DOC.HEAD: Sagging Sales May End the Era of Transformers Toy Robots
DOC.TEXT: After years of battling for control of the universe, Transformers, those toy robots that can change form, may have met their demise from sagging sales. Hasbro Inc., which made nearly $950 million selling Transformers over the past seven years, is re-evaluating whether domestic demand is strong enough to justify costly promotion, company spokesman Wayne Charness said Tuesday. ``Certainly Transformers had a fantastic run, and we are going to review whether the run continues or whether it goes away,'' he said. Hasbro kept the heroic Autobots and the evil Decepticons going for years by inventing and supplying weapons for both sides of the Transformers battle. It also developed a complicated story line of a futuristic mechanical being that crash-landed on earth in search of fuel and power supplies. In its heyday in 1985, Transformers generated about $333 million for Hasbro, accounting for 27 percent of the company's annual net revenue. This year, the product is expected to garner only about 2.4 percent, or $35 million. Hasbro worldwide net sales should total about $1.46 billion this year, up from about $1.41 billion last year, Gary M. Jacobson, toy industry analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York, told The Providence Journal-Bulletin. Charness said such staples as GI Joe and Cabbage Patch Kids dolls continue to be top sellers, along with new items such as New Kids on the Block dolls and World Wrestling Federation figures. Transformers continue to sell well in other countries, where the toys were introduced more recently, Charness said. A decision on the future of Transformers in this country should be made shortly, he said. ``With any product you'd love to have it last forever and ever,'' he said. ``Our job (is) ... to give it as long a life as it can.'' If Hasbro decides to discontinue U.S. sales of Transformers, it will end one of the toy industry's biggest success stories in years. ``It had a terrific run,'' said Paul H. Valentine, a toy industry analyst at Standard & Poor's Corp. of New York. ``It was one of the major hits of the 1980s.'' Another toy industry analyst, Sean McGowan of Gerard Klauer Mattison & Co. of New York, said: ``The question of Transformers is not, `Why did it die?' but, `Why did it live so long?''' The answer lies, at least in part, in Hasbro's marketing strategy. The Pawtucket-based company constantly updated the line with new figures and vehicles. It offered various models to appeal to different pocketbooks. And there was a Transformers television cartoon show and a movie. Over the years, Hasbro became less aggressive about marketing the figures. ``We certainly continued to support Transformers but not at the level we did when it was the most popular toy in the country,'' Charness said. The line of toy robots first arrived in 1983 when it was unveiled at the annual toy fair in New York City by the Japanese toy company, Takara. While Hasbro worked out a licensing arrangement with Takara, Tonka Corp. of Minnetonka, Minn., introduced a competing line, GoBots, in early 1984. ``Although Transformers appeared five months after GoBots, Hasbro came from behind and outsold GoBots almost 2 to 1,'' according to the book ``Toyland: The High Stakes Game of the Toy Industry.'' Transformers generated about $111.6 million in sales that year. ``I think it really brought a fun new play to toys,'' said Charness. ``The whole transformation theme - it was an exciting one for kids, and I think done well it continues to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Trial Date on Smoking Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A judge set an April 17 trial Tuesday on whether a new state law requires Philip Morris Co. to post no-smoking signs in the gift shop at its tobacco plant. A lawsuit filed by Virginia Group to Alleviate Smoking in Public alleges that the tobacco giant is violating the law that requires no-smoking signs in indoor cashier lines. The maximum penalty is a $25 fine. Lonnie D. Nunley III, an attorney for Philip Morris, told Richmond General District Judge Walter Stout the company would contest the suit. The judge then set the trial date. Robert Moore, a Philip Morris spokesman, has called the lawsuit a frivolous publicity stunt and said the company has no plans to post signs. This is Virginia GASP's second lawsuit against Philip Morris over the alleged violation. The first complaint was dismissed last month on a technicality. Anne Morrow Donley, executive director of Virginia GASP, said her battle with Philip Morris shows the state law that took effect in July is difficult to enforce. ``It's very ridiculous for a person to have to report a violation of the law by going to court time after time,'' she said.
