DOC.TEXT: In a story Dec. 10 on a new training program for Merrill Lynch & Co. employees, The Associated Press erroneously attributed comments to Daniel P. Tully, Merrill Lynch's president and chief operating officer. Actually, it was John L. Steffens, executive vice president for the bokerage's private client division, who said, ``We want to send a message that there are long-term positive opportunities on Wall Street.'' Commenting on the financial impact of the program, he said, ``If everybody made it (remained at Merrill Lynch) for the next 10 years, it would add several hundred million dollars to Merrill Lynch's bottom line.''

DOC.HEAD: GM to Boost Minority Dealers
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is planning to boost the number of dealerships owned by minority group members by 40 percent in three years and find ways to hang on to the 192 it already has, the company said Tuesday. ``Increased minority participation in our dealerships is vital to achieving GM's prime objective of the 1990s, satisfying car and truck owners,'' said a statement by GM President Lloyd Reuss. Currently, about 2 percent of GM's 9,600 dealers are members of minority groups, including blacks, Hispanics and Asians. GM hopes to raise that number to 2.8 percent, or 268 dealerships, by 1993, said the statement by Reuss and Tony March, a Buick dealer from Hartford, Conn., and chairman of the GM Minority Dealer Advisory Council. About 5.7 percent of Ford Motor Co.'s 5,500 dealers are members of minority groups and about 2.5 percent of Chrysler Corp.'s 5,300 dealers are from minority groups. GM has had a dealer training program for minority groups since 1972, but this is the first time a target has been set. The goal was set Friday when Reuss and March signed an agreement. ``There is no doubt in my mind about the commitment of Lloyd Reuss and (GM Chairman) Bob Stempel,'' March said. ``We are talking about a commitment from the largest corporation in the world.'' In addition to adding to the minority dealer ratio, a steering committee of the dealer organizations will look at ways to help dealers from minority groups stay in business. Black-owned, inner-city dealerships are especially vulnerable to economic downturns, such as the one the auto industry currently is experiencing. In 1988, there were 114 black-owned GM dealerships, a number that has shrunk to 83 lately. Four black-owned GM dealerships have folded in metropolitan Detroit in the past year.

DOC.HEAD: Electricity Shares Surge As Much as 66 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Shares in Britain's 12 regional electricity companies surged as much as 66 percent on their first day of trading Tuesday, prompting opponents to accuse the government of selling the industry off too cheaply. Prime Minister John Major rejected the charge, and called the $10 billion privatization the most popular in the government's decade-old program. It's also the biggest and most complex. A package of 1,000 of the 12 stocks jumped to 1,578 pounds, or $3,061, by the close of trading from an opening price of 1,000 pounds, or $1,940. One company's shares, Manweb's, soared to 166 pence, or $3.24, from its opening price of 100 pence, or $1.94. The smallest gain, by two companies, was 42 pence, or 81 cents. Frantic trading in the electricity shares almost trebled the London market's overall volume to 825.5 million shares from 317 million shares Monday. The exchange extended trading for 90 minutes to handle the heavy volume. Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock accused the Conservative government of selling a British asset at what he said was less than half its true value. ``The British people are being subjected to a national scandal and by a great swindle by their own government,'' he said in the House of Commons. ``Any government that inflicts that on its own people is guilty either of infamous incompetence or of great dishonesty, or both.'' Major disputed the charge, saying the offer provided value to shareholders. ``The offer has been a huge success, clearly the most successful ever,'' he said. Pricing a privatization is a tricky business. The government tries to raise as much revenue as it can, while pricing the shares cheaply enough to attract investors without creating a political storm. The latest pricing was complicated by the uncertainty over the Persian Gulf crisis and generally bearish market conditions. Privatization shares generally have spurted on their first day of trading. That's partly because underwriters insist that the shares be priced so that they get an instant 10 percent premium, said John Wilson, an analyst with the London investment firm UBS Phillips and Drew. ``There's no doubt about it, the (electricity shares are) at the slightly high end of expectations,'' Wilson said. ``But I certainly wouldn't say it's been floated off cheaply.'' The gains are not as large as they seem at first glance because they come on stock that is being bought with installment payments, and because dealing costs have to be taken into account. The shares were offered at 240 pence each, or $4.66, payable in three installments. The first 100 pence payment was due on application. There was heightened demand for the shares, however. The sale of 2.16 billion shares was more than 10 times oversubscribed, prompting the government to scale back allocations to institutional investors. Tuesday's rise in prices reflected a scramble among those investors to get more stock, analysts said. At the same time, some small investors were holding on to their stakes to take advantage of the government's enticements of electricity bill vouchers and dividends. That meant demand far exceeded supply, and market makers had to price the shares at levels high enough to entice institutional investors to sell.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Lower in Lackluster Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures closed mostly lower in lackluster trading Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. There was little news to spur trading, as most were consolidating their holdings in anticipation of the release Tuesday of the U.S. Agriculture Department's supply and demand report. Traders also were awaiting Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Schevardnadze's visit to Washington Wednesday, said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. in Chicago. There is a belief the USDA will use the occasion to announce the award of U.S. aid or the granting of export credits to the Soviets. Wheat futures, while lower, received some support from news that China has been targeted with 1.5 million metric tons of export bonus wheat. At the close, wheat was 1{ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.54} a bushel; corn was a { cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.27 a bushel; oats were a { cent lower to a { cent higher with December at $1.10} a bushel; 1 cent lower to 1{ cents higher with January at $5.94} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Pleads Guilty to Illegally Using Advance Magazine Copies
DOC.TEXT: A businessman pleaded guilty to federal charges that he made illegal stock deals based on information from advance copies of Business Week magazine. Stephen R. Rasinski, who entered his plea Monday, faces up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine when he is sentenced April 8 in U.S. District Court. In a complaint filed last month, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Rasinski, 35, traded on information gleaned from Business Week's ``Inside Wall Street'' column. The complaint contended the Newport Beach businessman obtained early copies of Business Week from an employee of Torrance-based R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co., which prints the magazine. Stocks receiving favorable mention in the magazine column would be purchased by Rasinski's broker one day before the magazine was made public, the SEC said. The broker, John Petit of Newport Beach, settled charges by the SEC in November and agreed to repay $195,229. He also pleaded guilty to two counts of insider trading. Shayne A. Walters, a Donnelley salesman, pleaded guilty in New York to perjury and conspiracy to commit securities, wire and mail fraud for supplying Rasinski with advance copies of the magazine. He was awaiting sentencing. Rasinski was the 12th person charged by the SEC with trading on information from advance copies of Business Week. He is the third to plead guilty to criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the London Stock Exchange fell Tuesday in a session extended by 90 minutes to accommodate trading in the 12 newly privatized electricity companies. The session was one of the most hectic in recent memory, dealers said. The electricity shares rose sharply from their opening price of 100 pence. The issue of 2.16 billion shares in Britain's electricity distribution companies had been 10.7 times oversubscribed. At the closing bell, the broad-based Financial Time 100-share index was down 16.7 points, or 0.77 percent, at 2,165.8. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index was down 15.5 points at 1,706.0. The Financial Times 500-share index was down 7.64 at 1,144.87. Volume registered a robust 825.5 million shares, almost three times the 317.0 million shares traded a day ago. The large turnover reflected the vigorous demand for the electricity shares.

DOC.HEAD: Hammer Remembered as Crusader for Peace, Generous Philanthropist
LaserPhotos NY9,10, LA4,7; LaserColor NY109, LA3; Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story slugged Obit-Armand Hammer on Business News Digest; also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Industrialist Armand Hammer was remembered Tuesday as a tireless crusader for international peace who improved the human condition by investing millions in education, medicine and the arts. The flamboyant, globe-trotting chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp., the nation's 16th largest industrial company, died Monday at his home in the Westwood district late Monday following a brief illness. He was 92. The cause of death was not revealed, although associates said privately Hammer had been suffering from kidney problems. He died just one day before a planned celebration for his belated bar mitzvah. Slammed by critics as a self-promoter more concerned with his image than corporate leadership, Hammer nonetheless drew praise from heads of state and leaders in business and education. He met with every Soviet leader. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Hammer helped forge Soviet-American relations. ``Mr. Hammer was associated with one of the most remarkable pages of ur relationship,'' Gorbachev said. ``He met with Lenin and was very close in many ways to the Soviet Union, and to Russia.'' Hammer, whose father helped found the American Communist Party, became a millionaire by age 23 and by most estimates died a billionaire. Hammer bought the then-ailing Occidental for $100,000 in 1957 as a tax shelter, and turned it into an international giant, It 1989 income was $285 million on sales of $20.07 billion. Occidental's core businesses are oil and gas, chemicals, natural gas pipelines, pork and beef, and coal. Ray R. Irani, Occidental's president and chief operating officer, immediately succeeded Hammer as chairman and chief executive. But Hammer's death sparked speculation that Occidental, long beholden to his occasionally whimsical management style, might change its corporate agenda. Warren Shimmerlik, an independent energy analyst, said under Irani's management Occidental was likely to undergo significant restructuring. ``Hammer's style prevented a rationalization that would be beneficial to the company,'' Shimmerlik said, noting Hammer preferred to position Occidental as an income-producing stock rather than a growth company. ``There didn't seem to be any real momentum in the company.'' At times, Hammer's craving for power and publicity threatened to overshadow his achievements in business, philanthropy and the arts. Hammer exhibited a flair for the dramatic until the end of his life, deciding to celebrate his Jewish bar mitzvah manhood rite - normally celebrated at age 13 - at 92. The ceremony, set for Tuesday night, was changed into a memorial service. ``We're going to go ahead with the event,'' event spokesman Howard Bragman said. ``It's really the wish of Dr. Hammer that this event continue because it was important to him.'' Funeral arrangements were pending. Hammer will be entombed in the private Hammer Family mausoleum at Westwood Village Cemetery, just a few hundred yards from Occidental Petroleum headquarters and his new art museum. Hammer was born on May 21, 1898, in New York City. His Russian-born father sent Armand off at age 10 to live with a socialist colleague. After World War I, Hammer went to Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, working at night to bail out the family's struggling pharmaceutical firm. He turned the business into a million-dollar company. While waiting to begin his medical internship, Hammer read about a typhus epidemic in the new Soviet Union. He went to Russia where he quickly learned the Soviets needed food more than doctors. Hammer told Soviet officials, ``I'll bring over ships filled with grain if you will fill them with products I can sell in America.'' During a life of wheeling and dealing he was on a first-name basis with world leaders from Vladimir Lenin to George Bush. He personally negotiated most of Occidental's deals, including a $3 billion oil, gas, fertilizer and hotels pact with the Soviets in 1972 and a $640 million partnership with China in 1984 to develop the world's largest open-pit coal mine. He made several fortunes and donated huge sums to charity. ``The only reason I make money is so I can give it away,'' Hammer was fond of saying. After the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster, he helped American doctors go to the Soviet Union to help with bone-marrow transplants. ``He was able to get a hold of people in Moscow on a weekend and tell them that we were coming to help them,'' said one of the surgeons, Dr. Robert Gale. ``He was a very good friend.'' Hammer flew one time ``Prisoner of Zion'' Ida Nudel from Moscow to Tel Aviv in October 1987 and escorted Ben Charny, who had a tumor in his neck, from the Soviet Union to a Boston hospital in July 1988, said Rick Jacobs, Occidental vice president and Hammer's personal assistant for more than seven years. ``He was trusted by the Soviet, the American and the Israeli leadership,'' Jacobs said. He gave millions of dollars to cancer research, and President Reagan named him chairman of the President's Cancer Panel. Hammer also was an avid art collector. His collection, including works from five centuries of European paintings and a Leonardo da Vinci notebook, is displayed at the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Culture, which opened in November 1990 beside Occidental's headquarters. In 1975, Hammer was indicted by a federal grand jury on charges of making a secret $54,000 donation to the campaign of former President Nixon. He pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges, was fined $3,000 and placed on one year's probation. President Bush pardoned him in 1989 for the Watergate-era crime. Hammer was married three times and is survived by one son, Julian, by his first wife.

DOC.HEAD: Lots of New Names on OPEC Roster
With AM-OPEC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It has been a rough year for OPEC oil ministers. Six of the 13 nations belonging to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have switched ministers in the past year. A seventh still has the same name on the roster but he hasn't been seen at a cartel meeting for quite a while. OPEC veterans cannot remember a year when there ave been so many new faces. The change attracting the most attention occurred in Iraq. Last October, President Saddam Hussein abruptly fired Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, a respected oil minister who had held the job since March 1987. Al-Chalabi was dismissed shortly after a fuel rationing program was imposed in that crisis-ridden country. The rationing program was later cancelled, with the government saying it was put in place by mistake. Al-Chalabi was replaced by Saddam's son-in-law, Hussein Kamel, who also is minister of industry and military industrialization. Kamel did not show up at OPEC's winter meeting. Instead, the delegation was led by Ramzi Salman Abdul Hussain, director of the State Oil Marketing Organization, who was scheduled to take over as OPEC's deputy secretary-general next year. Another veteran dropped from the roster was Mana Saeed Otaiba of the United Arab Emirates, who had been attending OPEC meetings since 1971. Yousef Omeir bin Yousef was named the new oil minister in a Cabinet reshuffle in the oil-rich confederation. Libya also sent a new name. Abdullah Salem al-Badri was head of the delegation instead of Fawzi Shakshuki, that nation's oil minister since October 1984. Kuwait changed ministers last July. Sheikh Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, one of the more colorful OPEC ministers, was replaced by Rasheed Salem al-Ameeri. Al-Sabah, who had been oil minister since February 1978, retained his title as finance minister and popped up at an OPEC meeting in Geneva in late August, the first held after Iraq invaded his country. Nigeria began the cartel's musical chairs last December when it named Rilwanu Lukman, then-OPEC president, as its foreign minister. Jibril Aminu, a physician, was given the job of oil minister. In Gabon, Julien M'Pouho-Epigat was replaced last April by Jean Ping. In Qatar, Abdul Aziz bin Khalifa al-Thani was still listed as the nation's petroleum minister. But his brother, Interior Minister Abdullah bin Khalifa al-Thani, has been seen more at cartel meetings over the past year. Still holding onto their jobs at year's end were ministers in Algeria, Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Ecuador and Iran.

The stock market fell today, with losses among high-tech issues helping to erase Monday's modest gains. Analyst Jack Solomon at Bear Stearns & Co. said high-tech stocks were down on a disappointing report on orders and shipments for computer chips as well as discouraging overviews taken by some computer industry analysts. ``This whole high-tech area has suddenly been punctured, and that puts a damper on the market,'' Solomon said. Other analysts said the market seemed to be showing a technical weakness, because it fell at the same time oil prices and interest rates were dropping. In other recent sessions, that might have pushed stocks higher.

DOC.HEAD: Travelers Forms Partnership With Polish Insurer
DOC.TEXT: The Travelers Corp. announced Tuesday its entry into Eastern Europe by forming a partnership with Poland's oldest and largest insurance company. The partnerhip will provide coverage to subsidiaries of U.S. companies operating in Poland. Under the agreement with Warsaw-based Warta Insurance and Reinsurance Co. Ltd., Travelers and Warta will share the risk for property-casualty coverage provided by Warta in Poland. ``The alliance with Warta reflects the changes that have recently taken place in Poland,'' said Bruce S. MacMillian, president of Travelers International Operations. ``The liberalized environment will draw an increasing number of U.S. multinational companies to the country and Travelers and Warta have a strong mutual commitment to serving their needs.'' Travelers, based in Hartford, operates in 110 countries through a global network of associate companies.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Adopts Curbs on Alcohol, Tobacco Advertising
DOC.TEXT: The French National Assembly adopted strict curbs Tuesday on advertising for tobacco and alcoholic beverages over objections from winegrowers and sports promoters. The Assembly adopted a text worked out by a joint group of Assembly deputies and members of the Senate. The approved text will now go to the upper chamber for consideration. The law forbids all forms of direct or indirect tobacco advertising beginning Jan. 1, 1993 and orders steep hikes in the price of cigarettes. It is less severe on alcohol, taking into account the concerns of senators from winegrowing regions who caused stiffer measures to be rejected in an earlier bill in October. The revised version permits advertising in wine-producing regions, in the written press aimed at adults, and in certain radio broadcasts. Senators on the joint committee expressed confidence the proposal will pass their chamber later this month. Sponsorship by alcoholic beverage or tobacco companies in sports and other events will be strictly forbidden. Health Minister Claude Evin, who has pushed the advertising restrictions for a year, calls such tobacco or alcohol sponsorship ``advertising in disguise.'' The measures irritated Jean-Marie Balestre, president of the International Federation of Auto Sports. The motor racing industry is heavily dependent on tobacco sponsorship. ``There is too much hypocrisy in these measures,'' he declared Monday during an awards ceremony. ``There are other much more dangerous scourges, like drugs.'' Some deputies who voted against the bill Tuesday remarked that the way to cure alcohol or tobacco abuse lay in better education. Others said it would cause unemployment in wine-producing areas. Evin says the law is necessary to bring down consumption of tobacco and alcohol by young French people and has praised the success of anti-tobacco campaigns in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Figure Barred From Securities Business
DOC.TEXT: A key figure in the prosecution of junk bond king Michael Milken agreed Tuesday to be barred from the securities business to settle an action brought by federal regulators. In settling the Securities and Exchange Commission administrative proceeding - without admitting or denying wrongdoing - David A. Solomon agreed to the revocation of his registration as an investment adviser. Late last month, Solomon agreed to pay $7.9 million to settle charges in federal court in New York of insider trading, income tax fraud and other violations involving Milken. Some of the charges against Solomon, a former California money manager, were central to the guilty plea of Milken, the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond department. Milken was sentenced last month to 10 years in prison. Solomon, 46, was granted immunity from criminal prosecution in exchange for providing information against Milken. Solomon also settled SEC civil charges without admitting or denying guilt. Under that settlement, Solomon agreed to return $7.3 million in alleged illegal profits - $588,870 for insider trading and about $6.7 million for other violations. The money is to be placed into two funds to compensate wronged investors. Solomon also must pay $661,674 in civil insider trading penalties. The 46-year-old former head of Solomon Asset Management Inc. was one of Milken's biggest buyers of risky and often lucrative high-yield bonds. The two had a relationship dating to the early 1970s. As part of Tuesday's settlement, Solomon will be barred from associating with any securities broker, dealer investment adviser or investment company.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Gives Up Most of Monday's Gains
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices retreated Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange, erasing most of the gains made in the previous day's trading. On other markets, energy futures fell; grains and soybean futures were mostly lower; livestock and pork futures were mixed; and coffee futures soared. Gold's losses came on reports the German Bundesbank would sell 1 billion marks of gold to help finance reunification. Following the Bundesbank's denial of the report, the market rallied, but fell as energy prices retreated. John Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York, said the call before the start of trading Tuesday was for gold to move higher in follow-through buying from Monday's strong showing. But the rumor of German selling put a damper on that. ``The market jumped on the idea that the Germans were going to sell gold,'' Steel said. ``The story was flimsy. Anyone who knows about gold knows that governments seldom, if ever, sell their gold reserves.'' Also helping to push gold lower was the strength shown by the dollar against foreign currencies. Gold settled $2.10 to $2.30 lower with the contract for delivery in February at $373.60 a troy ounce; silver was 1.5 cents to 1.7 cents lower with December at $4.067 a troy ounce. Energy futures were lower in quiet trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders consolidated their holdings in anticipation of the release of American Petroleum Institute inventory figures. Also sending the market lower was an announcement by Venezuela that it plans to boost crude oil output by 44 percent over the next six years. Concern also existed in the market over what will come out of Wednesday's scheduled Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in Vienna, said Ron Caples, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. Light sweet crude was 49 cents to 64 cents lower with January at $26.41 a barrel; heating oil was 1.08 cents to 3.29 cents lower with January at 77.68 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 94 cent to 1.25 cent lower with January at 66.79 cents a gallon; natural gas was .015 cent to .070 cent lower with July at $2.285 per thousand cubic feet. Grain and soybean futures closed mostly lower in lackluster trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. There was little news to spur trading, as most were consolidating their holdings in anticipation of the release Tuesday of the U.S. Agriculture Department's supply and demand report. Traders also were awaiting Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Schevardnadze's visit to Washington Wednesday, said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. in Chicago. There is a belief the USDA will use the occasion to announce the award of U.S. aid or the granting of export credits to the Soviets. Wheat futures, while lower, received some support from news that China has been targeted with 1.5 million metric tons of export bonus wheat. Wheat was 1{ cents lower to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.54{ a bushel; corn was a { cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.27\ a bushel; oats were a { cent lower to a { cent higher with December at $1.10} a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cent lower to 1{ cents higher with January at $5.94 a bushel. Coffee futures soared on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange. Strong European demand for Central American coffees, coupled with those countries' reluctance to sell, helped boost prices. Also helping to lift prices is labor uncertainty in Colombia. Workers at Barranquilla, Cartagena, Santa Marta and Buenaventura are threatening to strike to protest government plans to privatize ports. Coffee was 1.80 cents to 2.60 cents higher with December at 91 cents a pound. Livestock futures were mixed in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent to .18 cent higher with December at 80.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent lower to .25 cent higher with January at 88.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .05 cent higher with December at 49.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent lower to .18 cent higher with February at 66.65 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises on Plans to Halt its Decline; Gold Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened against major foreign currencies on Tuesday largely on news that the major industrialized nations planned to meet to halt its decline. Gold prices were mostly lower. Foreign exchange dealers were warmed by news that the so-called G-7 group of industrialized nations - the United States, Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - would meet in January to consider the dollar's decline. ``People are presuming with a capital `P' that the outcome will be possibly an attempt to stabilize the dollar,'' said Robert Hatcher, corporate foreign exchange dealer for Barclays Bank PLC. Analysts said the dollar also was supported by a weakening of the German mark after that nation's central bank announced it wasn't planning to raise interest rates on Thursday. Traders had speculated that Bundesbank would tighten its credit policy, which could have buoyed the mark against foreign currencies. The two events combined to bounce the dollar off earlier lows, analysts said. Within two hours Tuesday morning, the dollar jumped in value from 1.4680 German marks to 1.4810. Much of those gains were sustained, with the dollar closing u 1.4784 German marks, compared to 1.4725 late Monday. ``Basically the situation with the dollar was pretty much a complete turn-around from the morning,'' Hatcher said. The dollar gained ground against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 132.40 yen, up from 132.15 yen late Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 131.75 Japanese yen from 130.55 yen at Monday's close, and in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 131.95 yen. The British pound weakened to $1.9380 in New York, compared to $1.9442 at Monday's close, and in London, it fell to $1.9400 from $1.9450 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.2650 Swiss francs, up from 1.2615; 5.0190 French francs, up from 5.0050; 1,114.00 Italian lire, up from 1,112.25; and 1.1606 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1572. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.4790 German marks, up from 1.4708; 2.2665 Swiss francs, up from 1.2610; 5.0230 French francs, up from 4.9980; 1.6683 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6585; 1,110.07 Italian lire, up from 1,109.75; and 1.1591 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1566. Gold prices were mixed. The metal fell in New York, closing at $372.00 a troy ounce, down $2.20 on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $372.00, down $1 from late Monday. In London earlier, gold fell to a late bid price of $370.75 a troy ounce, from $373.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $371.85, from $373.75 bid late Monday. But in Hong Kong early Monday, gold rose $2.91 to close at a bid $375.36. Silver rose on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $4.067 a troy ounce, up 1.7 cents. The metal also rose in London to a late bid price of $4.06 a troy ounce, from $4.05 bid late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: GM Forms Powertrain Division
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. on Tuesday announced formation of a new GM Powertrain Division to coordinate activities of its new Engine Division and the Hydra-matic Division. The move, said GM President Lloyd Reuss, was designed to consolidate major engine and transmission operations into one operation. The GM Engine Division was formed last year to coordinate engine research and development for all GM car and truck divisions. The Powertrain Division will be headed by general manager Richard Donnelly. He joined GM in 1961 and rose through its manufacturing and product planning operations to become general manager of the Engine Division.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Executive Joins Eastern
DOC.TEXT: A veteran pilot and executive for Pan American World Airways has joined Eastern Airlines as its president and chief operating officer, the company said. Robert L. Gould was appointed Monday by Eastern's court-appointed trustee Martin R. Shugrue, also a former Pan Am pilot and executive. ``The arrival of Bob Gould at Eastern Airlines represents a significant step in our reorganization efforts and demonstrates that Eastern is now turning its attention to long-term operational issues rather than short-term survival issues,'' Shugrue said. When Shugrue was appointed by the bankruptcy court to run in Eastern in April, company president Phil Bakes handed in his resignation, and Joseph Leonard resigned last month as chief operating officer. Gould left Pan Am as senior vice president for operations, with responsibility for maintenance and engineering, logistics, inventory management, flight operations, purchasing, system control and environmental affairs. He joined Pan Am as a pilot in 1965 and was elected to head the carrier's pilots union in 1982. He helped structure and implement an employees stock ownership plan and was given a seat on Pan Am's board of directors. Gould joined management in 1986 as senior vice president for airline and strategic planning. Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Oil Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs to UPDATE with American Petroleum Institute weekly figures
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices fell Tuesday in light trading as concerns of overproduction by OPEC nations created some pessimism in the market. Traders said there was little news from the Middle East to influence the market. They said an unconfirmed British broadcast report that Iraq and the United States planned to negotiate initially sent prices lower. Light sweet crude oil for January delivery settled down 49 cents per barrel at $26.41. Later contract months for crude delivery also fell modestly. Crude was down as much as $1.28 a barrel in morning trading before rebounding. Traders attributed much of the gain to buying in order to pay back so-called ``short'' positions on borrowed contracts. Market professionals said traders are reluctant to stake out positions because they do not want to jeopardize reducing profits near the end of the year. Prices were affected in part by a call by Iran's oil minister on Tuesday to cap OPEC production to help bolster prices. ``In view of the situation in the oil markets at the moment, I am worried about the production figure,'' Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh said before a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna. A glut of crude oil would reduce prices on world markets. ``If anything, people are focusing a little bit more on (reports) that production levels are extremely high, considering Iraq and Kuwait (supplies) aren't in there,'' said Christian Gohler, a broker with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``It's making people focus on potentially bearish fundamentals down the road.'' Futures prices for refined petroleum products also fell Tuesday. Home heating oil futures tumbled 3.29 cents to 77.68 cents a gallon on the January contract after rising 1.80 cents to 80.97 cents a gallon Monday. Unleaded gasoline prices settled lower. The contract for delivery in January declined .94 cent a gallon to 66.79 cents after rising 1.26 cents Monday. The January contract for delivery of natural gas, which is not directly affected by fears of war in the Middle East, dropped .70 cent to $2.285 per 1,000 cubic feet after falling .50 cent Monday. After the market closed, the American Petroleum Institute reported that U.S. crude oil inventories fell moderately in the week ended Friday to 332.1 million barrels from 335.5 million barrels the previous week. A year ago, domestic crude oil inventories totaled 343.7 million barrels. Imports of crude oil fell to 4.8 million barrels a day from 4.9 million a week earlier. A year earlier, before imports were affected by the gulf crisis, they were 5.7 million barrels daily. The API also reported that gasoline inventories rose marginally in the most recent week, to 221.7 million barrels from 221.1 million. Petroleum distillates - mainly heating oil and diesel fuel - increased to 133.4 million barrels from 132.9 million barrels a week earlier. A year earlier, inventories were 118.5 million barrels.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Reports $183.2 Million Third-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc., struggling to emerge from Chapter 11 proceedings, reported Tuesday that is third-quarter loss widened from a year earlier. The discount retailer reported a loss of $183.2 million, attributed the poor results to restructuring charges of $129 million and difficulty selling the leases for more than 200 stores it closed under its reorganization plan. The loss, which amounted to $4.97 a share, compared to a restated loss of $1.6 million, or 13 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Ames reported third-quarter sales of $740.2 million, 9.2 percent lower than adjusted 1989 third-quarter sales of $838.3 million. Last year's results did not include sales from the 221 stores Ames closed after it filed for protection from its creditors in April. ``The loss, before the restructuring charge, was much less than anticipated, while sales exceeded our expectations,'' Stephen L. Pistner, Ames chief executive, said in a statement. ``Third-quarter results showed improvement as the stores' merchandise levels began returning to normal and advertising was resumed and intensified.'' A soft real estate market and tight credit resulted in lower than expected sales of leases for many of the stores that Ames closed during the second quarter, the retailer said. Pistner, considered a whiz at turning around ailing retailers, was hired to steer the company away from the brink of financial collapse. Ames filed for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors in April when sales at its 680 stores dropped by 40 percent in a 3{-month period. The company has closed more than 200 stores and consolidated some of its other operations. Pistner said Ames was making progress in stabilizing its finances, noting its seasonal borrowing was repaid ahead of schedule. Ames operates 461 discount department stores in 17 northeastern states. For the first nine months of the fiscal year, Ames reported a loss of $766.7 million, or $20.67 per share, compared to a loss of $29.2 million, or $1.02 per share, in the same period of 1989. The 1990 results include $354 million in restructuring charges. Sales for the period totaled $2.16 billion, compared to $3.39 billion a year earlier. The 1989 figure includes sales from the closed stores.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Industry Says It Wants to Limit Children Smoking; Critics Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Sullivan comment. Picks up 10th graf pvs, She said. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The tobacco industry, which manufactures billions of cigarettes a year, said Tuesday it wants to keep children from lighting up. ``We want to protect children from making decisions that they are not capable of,'' Tobacco Institute vice president Brennan M. Dawson said at a news conference announcing a campaign to keep cigarettes away from anyone under 18. ``If a child never picks up another cigarette it would be fine with the tobacco industry,'' Dawson said. But Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, the Bush administration's crusader against smoking, said the industry's plans ``represent little more than a smoke screen to camouflage their own marketing activities.'' ``The cigarette industry spent $3.3 billion in 1988 to advertise and promote cigarettes, or about $100 per second,'' Sullivan said. ``Much of that advertising reaches young people and lures them into this deadly addiction.'' Dawson said the campaign would support state laws limiting cigarette sales to adults and would put new limitations on billboard and other tobacco advertising and distribute a parent's guide on how to discourage children from smoking. However, she said the guidelines won't prevent cigarette companies from continuing to sponsor sporting events, such as tennis tournaments. Dawson said she didn't know the cost of the program, but said it was `millions of dollars.'' Sullivan said the industry should stop advertising in newspapers and magazines that have a large readership of young people and stop targeting ads to young people, women and minorities. He also said tobacco companies should not sponsor sporting events and stop all free distribution of cigarettes. Fran Du Melle of the American Lung Association, who represented a coalition that includes the American Heart Association and the American Cancer Society, called the program ``just another public relations effort to head off congressional consideration of meaningful and effective legislation to regulate what has proven itself to be an irresponsible industry.'' She said the industry action would not curtail marketing tactics targeted at children. ``Once again, the tobacco industry seeks to mislead the public about its intentions by putting forward a package of reforms which don't go far enough to have a meaningful impact,'' Du Melle said. ``These proposals can't withstand the most minimal scrutiny.'' Another anti-smoking group, Action on Smoking Or Health, said there already are local government efforts under way to curtain sales of cigarettes to minors and that the tobacco industry campaign ``is simply making a virtue of necessity.'' ``I don't think anything the tobacco industry does will ever satisfy our critics,'' Dawson said when asked if the industry was trying to avoid federal legislation. The campaign was kicked off at a news conference that included educators who said they endorsed the effort. The educators also said they were being paid for their appearance. Dawson said the new industry advertising guidelines would forbid cigarette advertising on billboards less than 500 feet from schools or playgrounds. Clothing with cigarette brand names would be made only in large sizes and mailed tobacco promotions would require a statement that the recipient is 21 or older, she said. Asked about paid product placements in popular movies, Dawson said the practice would be stopped. Cigarette companies have paid movie producers to feature their brand name prominently among the props used in films. Dawson said the tobacco lobby would actively support legislation in states that permit cigarette sales to those under age 18. The District of Columbia and 11 states - Delaware, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Missouri, Montana, New Mexico, North Carolina, Vermont, Virginia and Wyoming - that either have no laws regarding sales to minors or permit children as young as 16 to buy the product. She said the effort also would include distributing signs and buttons to retailers about tobacco sales to minors and a series of advertisements in national magazines and newspapers explaining the industry program.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Offers Cheaper Fares to Military Families
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines announced Tuesday it would offer special discounts to people who want to visit relatives in the military who are about to be shipped overseas. TWA said that on trips beginning between Wednesday and Christmas Day, it will waive the advance purchase requirements on its discounted non-refundable domestic fares. To be eligible, passengers must provide the name, rank and serial number of their military relative, as well as the name of their base and the base telephone number. The seats on the available flights are limited, and restrictions will apply, TWA said in a statement. Sample fares would include $504 from New York to San Francisco, or from Los Angeles for Norfolk, Va., TWA said. The discounts are being offered at a time when most holiday travelers have already made their plans, and they could help fill seats that have thus far gone unclaimed.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Soldiers Need Solid Chocolate
DOC.TEXT: Hershey Food Corp. is delivering Hershey chocolate bar to U.S. troops that doesn't become a soft, gooey mess in the Saudi Arabian desert. ``We have signed a contract with the U.S. Army to provide a heat-resistant chocolate bar to the soldiers in Saudi Arabia,'' Hershey spokeswoman Bonnie Glass said Tuesday. The company has already turned over to the Army 144,000 of the Hershey's Desert Bar, and Ms. Glass said they're on their way to their field test in Saudi Arabia. Ms. Glass said the initial contract with Hershey was for a test run of a new product that tastes as good as the old Hershey but is tough enough for desert warfare. The traditional Hershey Bar turns to mush when the prevailing temperature hits 100 degrees, as it does in Saudi Arabia. ``There have been heat-resistant bars in the past, but one of the specifications given out by the Army is that it tastes good, like commercially available chocolate,'' she said. ``Another specification is that it is made with real milk chocolate.'' Ms. Glass declined to discuss the bar's contents or how it's made. The development of candy for military use isn't unprecedented. M&M's, a product of Mars Inc., based in Hackettstown, N.J., were first made for military personnel during World War II. That product's slogan: ``Melts in your mouth, not in your hands.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS number of decliners and gainers, 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: The stock market eased back Tuesday, as losses among high-tech issues helped erase Monday's modest gains. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 10.64 points to 2,586.14. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 9 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 585 up, 999 down and 458 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board totaled 145.33 million shares, up from 138.65 million on Monday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 181.79 million shares. Heading the NYSE's most active list was Occidental Petroleum, which was up 1~ at 22|. The death of chairman Armand Hammer on Monday stirred speculation that Occidental could be a takeover target or that some of its holdings could be sold off. IBP Inc., of which Occidental owns slightly more than 50 percent, was the second most active issue, trading up 2| at 19. Analyst Jack Solomon at Bear Stearns & Co. said high-tech stocks were down on a disappointing report about orders and shipments for computer chips as well as discouraging overviews taken by some computer industry analysts. ``This whole high-tech area has suddenly been punctured, and that puts a damper on the market,'' Solomon said. Other analysts said the market seemed to be showing a technical weakness, because it fell at the same time oil prices and interest rates were dropping. In other recent sessions, that might well have pushed stocks higher. Among high-tech NYSE issues, Conner Peripherals was down 1| at 25\ and IBM was down { at 112~. Texas Instruments was able to avoid the downturn, rising { to 34} in active trading. In over-the-counter trading, Apple Computer was down 1} at 40, Intel was down 2 at 35} and Quantum was down 1{ 20. Adaptec fell 5[ to 9~. Among other active NYSE issues, General Motors was down 1[ at 35|, Wal Mart was down } at 30\, Upjohn was up 1{ at 40| and General Electric was down \ at 56}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $20.97 billion, or .68 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.16 to 178.42. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.90 to 381.98, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 2.45 t0 326.44. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 3.48 to 367.99. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 306.11, down .50.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Votes to Tighten Rules on Mortgage Capital
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. voted Tuesday to tighten rules that affect banks and savings institutions devoting a large part of their business to collecting mortgage payments. The board of the agency voted 4-0 to allow no more than 50 percent of an institution's capital to be made up of the collection contracts, known as mortgage-servicing rights. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates nationally-chartered banks, already has an even stricter limit, 25 percent. But state-chartered banks and S&Ls had no limit. The S&L bailout law enacted in August 1989 required regulators to come up with a rule on the mortgage-servicing rights. They had been debating it since February. The issue was whether the value of the servicing contracts was too risky to count as capital, which represents the owner's investment in a financial institution and acts as a loss-absorbing buffer, protecting government deposit insurance funds. Mortgage-servicing rights are bought and sold among financial institutions. After purchasing the right, institutions can then earn a steady stream of fees for collecting monthly payments. They forward the payments to the actual owners of the mortgages, often a secondary mortgage company such as Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae. However, there is a risk. If interest rates drop and homeowners refinance their loans, the old mortgages, and the value of the right to service them, disappear.

DOC.HEAD: Portugal Privatizes Bank
DOC.TEXT: The government advanced its ambitious privatization program Tuesday by launching the sale of Portugal's leading commercial bank, Banco Portugues do Atlantico. The government made $382 million from the sale of 33 percent of the bank's capital, according to results from the Oporto bourse. BPA President Joao Oliveira said the sale met expectations, given the shaky international market. Figures from the bourse indicated the sale was 20 percent oversubscribed. Foreign interest was slight. International investors were likely to wait for the later stages of the three-phase privatization, said reports in the Lisbon financial press. The second stage is scheduled for late 1991. Since the first complete privatization in June of the Unicer beermaker, five state firms have been sold successfully. November's sale of the Centralcer brewery was 35 percent undersubscribed.

DOC.HEAD: Times Mirror Says Weak Ad Market Likely to Persist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 new grafs after 8th graf pvs, He did not ... to include McClatchy comments. Picks up 9th graf pvs, On Monday ... Adds 5 new grafs with more McClatchy detail.
DOC.TEXT: Media giant Times Mirror Inc. said Tuesday it plans to boost advertising rates and reduce capital spending next year as it adjusts to the most severe advertising slump in more than a decade. The diversified media company, which publishes the Los Angeles Times and seven East Coast newspapers, is also trying to cut costs with hiring freezes or layoffs in some divisions, foregoing a dividend increase for the first time since 1983 and swearing off major acquisitions. Chairman and Chief Executive Robert F. Erburu said the ad slump that has spread from the Northeast to the West Coast has deteriorated further in the fourth quarter and is expected to last into the new year. But he said the main reason for the ad slowdown has been a cyclical decline in the economy. He said the steps Times Mirror has taken to cut costs will enable it to rebound when the economy improves. In addition to its newspaper holdings, Los Angeles-based Times Mirror owns four network-affiliated television stations, publishes magazines and books and has interests in cable television systems. Erburu told the annual PaineWebber media outlook conference that the company's businesses that are not dependent on advertising such as professional infrmation, book publishing and cable operations are showing healthy growth. But he said the company's overall performance ``likely will continue to be weakened'' by the impact of the ad slump on the company's other businesses. He did not provide specific earnings estimates, and a spokeswoman said the company traditionally does not make such forecasts. Another California-based media company, McClatchy Newspapers Inc., said its operating results this year should about match last year and may improve next year. Erwin Potts, president and chief executive, said the company is better off than some other media companies because its 19 newspapers are located in cities that have withstood the economic slump such as Sacramento and Modesto, Calif. ``To one degree or another, we are all singing the blues. But I'm not going to join that chorus,'' he said. On Monday, media spending forecaster Robert Coen of the ad agency McCann-Erickson said U.S. ad spending would be up 4.9 percent this year, its slowest advance since 1975, and would rise only 4.6 percent in 1991. The slowdown, Coen said, is having its most pronounced effect on newspapers that are seeing big declines in classified advertising and only slow growth in spending by local retail advertisers. David Laventhol, chief operating officer at Times Mirror and publisher and chief executive at the Los Angeles Times, said the Times plans to boost its ad rates by 7 percent to 9 percent in January. Rates at the East Coast newspapers, which include Newsday, New York Newsday and the Baltimore Sun, will rise by 6 percent to 8 percent next year, he said. Laventhol said New York Newsday has seen circulation rise since the strike Oct. 25 at the Daily News in New York. The Daily News has continued to publish but has had difficulty distributing the paper. New York Newsday's circulation is up by about 110,000 daily to 335,000 and by 225,000 on Sunday to 380,000, Laventhol said. The combined Sunday circulation of New York Newsday and Newsday on Long Island surpassed 1 million this past Sunday for the first time, he said. Erburu said ad rates at Times Mirror magazines would be increased 3 percent to 9 percent next year. Its titles include Field & Stream, Popular Science and Home Mechanix. Times Mirror is reducing its capital spending to under $350 million in 1990 and to under $300 million in 1991 compared with $420 million in 1989, he said. He said he doesn't expect ``any significant expenditure in the acquisition area'' next year. Erburu also noted that the company recently announced it was holding its dividend at $1.08 a share for 1991, the first year since 1983 that it has not raised the payout. James P. Smith, vice president of finance and treasurer at Sacramento-based McClatchy, said he was comfortable with analysts' estimates of 1990 earnings of 88 cents to 95 cents a share, down from $1.19 a share in 1989. Potts said 1990 operating results should be about even with 1989 when extraordinary items such as the debt incurred in buying three newspapers in South Carolina and investment in a new newsprint mill company are excluded. He said McClatchy will ``do a little better'' in 1991, mainly because the classified advertising revenues are showing strength in its markets while other newspaper groups are showing sharp declines. Smith said revenues should grow 7 percent to 8 percent while operating expenses including an expected newsprint price hike and labor costs will go up by 7 percent to 9 percent. But non-operating expenses should be down 25 percent to 35 percent, he said. Potts said the company is not seeking any acquisitions although it has been approached by would-be sellers. He described the company's strategy on acquisitions as ``opportunistic,'' however.

DOC.HEAD: Equitable, Facing Troubled Investments, to Convert to Stockholder Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with additional analyst comment, quotes from Equitable's chairman, details and background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Equitable, the nation's third-largest life insurer, said Tuesday it will convert from a mutual company to one owned by stockholders so that it can more easily bolster its troubled finances. The Equitable, with more than $135 billion in assets, would become the largest insurer to take such a step, the company said. By converting from a mutual company owned by its policyholders to a stockholder company, the Equitable will be able to raise funds by selling shares to investors. James Guenther, an insurance industry analyst at the Chicago investment firm Duff & Phelps, said that as a mutual company, the Equitable's options for raising additional funds are limited to selling forms of debt instruments such as bonds. ``You can't raise equity capital (through selling shares), which regulators want to see,'' he said. ``Debt is debt. It's something that has to be paid back.'' The Equitable suffers from declining values in its real estate investments, losses in its large portfolio of high-risk junk bonds and problems with its mortgage loans, analysts said. Late last month, rumors swept the financial markets that the Equitable had missed a payment on its bonds and was near insolvency. The company denied the rumors. ``I don't think it's a solvency question,'' said Michael Frinquelli, an insurance industry analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. ``But clearly they would like to have more capital if for no other reason than to enable them to grow faster.'' He said the Equitable's ability to write additional insurance policies is limited by the size of its capital. Standard & Poor's Corp., a major credit-rating agency, predicted the insurance company will take large write-offs for its troubled investments, which ``may cause a significant loss for the year and reduce the company's capital.'' S&P added that the Equitable's greater investment in junk bonds than other life insurers and its large mortgage loan portfolio ``indicates a potential for additional future investment-related losses, given the current outlook in the economy in general and investment markets in particular.'' S&P said the Equitable is ``already more thinly capitalized than its peers.'' The ratings agency lowered by one notch its ratings on the Equitable's ability to pay policyholder claims. S&P said Equitable's announcement that it will convert to a stockholder company ``indicates that the company recognizes its need to seek significant external capital.'' The Equitable said the conversion to a stockholder company could take up to 18 months. Most of its 3 million policyholders would receive payments in the form of cash or stock in the Equitable, the insurer said, adding it was too soon to say how large the payouts would be. ``These shares will become marketable and in some cases will represent important additional value to these shareholders,'' said Richard H. Jenrette, the Equitable's chairman and chief executive officer. The conversion is allowed under a 1988 New York state law that is similar to other demutualization laws enacted in others states in recent years. In an interview, Jenrette said the principal reason for demutualizing is to give the company more flexibility in raising capital. But he denied that the Equitable was in trouble. ``The company is not in any jeopardy. We are in strong financial shape,'' he said. Another reason for demutualization, he said, is that it would give the company more flexibility as the financial services industry is deregulated. As a mutual company, the Equitable cannot participate in transactions with shareholder-owned companies. Due to the length of the conversion process, he said the company may seek long-term private investors who in the meantime would purchase notes that could be converted into stock when the conversion is completed. The Equitable already has been in contact with several potential investors, Jenrette said, declining to identify them. Frinquelli, the Salomon analyst, speculated that Japanese or European companies may be interested in taking a stake in the Equitable to gain a foothold in the U.S. insurance market. Jenrette said foreign investors were among those he has contacted. The demutualization must be approved by state regulators and certain classes of policyholders. The Equitable started as a stock company in 1859. It was converted to a mutual company in 1918 under a plan devised by J.P. Morgan & Co. Among its divisions is the stock brokerage Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., which was co-founded by Jenrette. The Equitable bought the brokerage in 1985. The last insurance company of any size to demutualize was Union Mutual of Portland, Maine, which converted to a stockholder company in 1986 and now is called Unum Corp., Frinquelli said. Frinquelli added that if the Equitable conversion is successful, it could be the start of a trend.

DOC.HEAD: Splitsville for Trumps; Judge Cites The Donald's `Cruel' Treatment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `In granting ...' to CLARIFY judge's comment. Picks up 14th graf, `Trump has ...'. Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: A tearful Ivana Trump was divorced Tuesday from her millionaire husband, Donald, whose ``cruel and inhuman treatment'' was cited for the end of their 12-year marriage. But the dissolution of the marriage left unresolved exactly who will get what from the troubled Trump empire and whether the couple's marital agreement giving The Donald the lion's share will hold. ``There are two parts to any marriage: One, `Are we married?' And two, `Do I owe you any money?' Today's we've cleared the way for the real issue: division of property,'' said Trump's lawyer, Jay Goldberg. Mrs. Trump, assisted by attorney Michael Kennedy, left the courthouse in tears after the divorce was approved by state Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob. While Mrs. Trump said through her attorney she would have no further comment on the matter, her ex-husband issued a statement of good will. ``I wish Ivana the best. I have no doubt that she will do very well in the years to come,'' said Trump. But whether Mrs. Trump will do it with a reported $25 million pre-nuptial agreement or with much more remains to be seen. The judge said all other money matters such as child support, equitable distribution of property and the validity of any pre- and post-marital agreement will be decided at an April 11 hearing, unless they are otherwise resolved. The property includes their Connecticut estate, their condominium at the Trump Tower here and their Mar-A-Lago estate in Florida. In court papers filed earlier this year, Mrs. Trump asked for half Trump's estimated $5 billion. Since then, analysts say Trump's fortune has fallen below $1 billion. Last month, Trump and his creditors agreed to a restructing of $675 million in debt held by the investors in Trump's Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, N.J. Under the agreement, the casino will briefly come under protection of federal bankruptcy court. He also faces an $18.4 million bond payment due Saturday on another casino, the Trump Castle. It is not known if he will be able to make the payment. Mrs. Trump argued in court papers that the couple's updated marital agreement, signed in December 1987, was drawn up while her husband was already committing adultery and intended to leave her. In granting the divorce, Gangel-Jacob said Trump's ``cruel and inhuman treatment'' made it improper for the couple to remain married. The judge did not elaborate. Trump has been romantically linked with aspiring actress and model Marla Maples. ``Marla is out of town on business. She won't be having any comment,'' said her spokesman, Chuck Jones. The Trumps have three children, who have been staying with Mrs. Trump since the couple's split became public in February.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Settlement in Mesa Takeover Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge approved a $6.7 million settlement between T. Boone Pickens' Mesa Limited Partnership, Phillips Petroleum Co. and Phillips shareholders. Mesa, Phillips and other defendants agreed to pay the amount to settle the suit brought by shareholders unhappy with how Phillips headed off Pickens' 1984 takeover bid. U.S. District Judge Murray M. Schwartz approved the settlement in Wilmington, Del., on Monday and dismissed the case with prejudice, which means it cannot be brought up again. Mesa will pay about 80 percent of the amount. The settlement stipulates that the defendants make the payment without conceding guilt or wrongdoing. In December 1984, Mesa offered $60 a share in cash for up to 23 million of Phillips' 154.6 million outstanding common shares. Mesa was considering further shareholder enticements when it dropped the bid in an agreement with Phillips, which is based in Bartlesville, Okla. Under the agreement, Mesa said it would sell back its 8.9 million shares of Phillips stock to the company for $53 a share in cash, giving Mesa a pre-tax profit of $89 million. Such a circumstance is sometimes considered ``greenmail,'' in which a party threatens a takeover, but profits by forcing the company to buy back its stock at a premium. Holders of Phillips shares between Dec. 5 and Dec. 21, 1984, formed the class of plaintiffs in the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. Announces Restructuring, Staff Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the world's largest auction house, announced plans Tuesday to restructure its European and Asian operations and trim its staff by 6 percent. Sotheby's also said it would focus more on higher quality, more expensive artworks. The restructuring stemmed from a strategic review of European and Asian operations last year, said Diana Phillips, a spokeswoman for the auction house in London. It is also symptomatic of a slumping art market in certain areas, especially Impressionist and contemporary art, said Tim Llewellyn, managing director of Sotheby's International. The staff reduction will lead to 80 to 100 layoffs by the end of next year, Phillips said. The auction house will attempt to find employment for them, she said. Phillips said Sotheby's will be closing regional sales rooms in Chester and Sussex, England, and in Florence, Italy. They will be replaced by a major new auction center near London. ``It's a move by Sotheby's that will produce the best possibility for growth and development in this decade,'' Phillips said.

DOC.HEAD: MNC Might Sell Credit-Card Subsidiary To Public
DOC.TEXT: MNC Financial Inc., the parent of Maryland National Bank, said it might spin off its giant credit-card subsidiary, MBNA America, as a publicly traded company if it cannot find a buyer for it. Such an offering could bring MNC as much as $1.13 billion, according to the estimated price of $25 a share that was part of the company's filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday. However, the stock price could change before the actual offering. The filing was intended ``to expand MNC's options with respect to the disposition of MBNA America,'' the company said in a statement. ``The offering will not proceed if MNC Financial reaches an agreement for the sale of MBNA America.'' In the SEC filing, MNC proposed an initial public offering of 45 million shares in MBNA Corp., a company created to take over the operations of MBNA America. MNC announced Oct. 25 it wanted to sell its profitable credit-card division as a way of improving its sagging capital condition. MBNA America, with $6.2 billion in credit-card receivables, is considered one of the top credit-card operations in the country. MNC made the announcement as it reported a third-quarter loss of $173 million, or $2.05 a share, as the result of the bank holding company putting $350 million into its reserves for possible loan losses. The credit-card subsidiary, based in Newark, Del., has carved out a high-income clientele by primarily offering cards to professional, fraternal, educational and special interest associations. MNC Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Alfred Lerner said in October that the company hoped to sell MBNA by the end of the year. However, other banks that might be interested in buying it also are strapped for cash and some are selling their credit-card operations to raise capital.

DOC.HEAD: Quasar Ordered To Pay $2.5 Million in Discrimination Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ordered Quasar Co. to pay nearly $2.5 million to three former employees who charged discrimination on the basis of age and nationality, officials said Tuesday. The Japanese-owned consumer electronics company also must pay court costs and attorney fees, making the total judgment greater than $3 million, said attorney Norman Berger, who represents the plaintiffs. The exact total of those fees was not available late Tuesday. Quasar was found guilty of violating the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, according to Berger. ``This is the first case we're aware of that, after a trial, a Japanese company has been found guilty of this type of discrimination,'' Berger said. The plaintiffs, John Fortino, Carl Meyers and F. William Schulz, were fired from their management positions during a 1986 restructuring in which Quasar's work force was cut in half, Berger said. Quasar officials said they were disappointed in the case's outcome. ``We are fully confident of the merits of our position and believe the court has made substantial errors in both law and in fact,'' said Quasar spokesman John Monaco, reading a statement. ``Of course, we intend to appeal the decision and firmly believe that ultimately our position in this case will be upheld.'' Before the company's reorganization, Quasar had 89 managerial employees. After the restructuring, the management staff was cut to 23, Berger said. Of that total, 14 were Americans and nine were Japanese, he said. ``The evidence showed that Quasar had full knowledge of the laws which prohibit discrimination, and yet it tried to circumvent these laws,'' Berger said. ``The court found that Quasar would not have fired any of our clients but for their national origin.'' In a 1988 ruling, a jury awarded $1.9 million to the plaintiffs in settlement of the age discrimination lawsuit. All three were over 50 at the time of their dismissal. The three were told that their jobs were being eliminated, but their functions were reassigned to younger people, Berger said. U.S. District Judge James Alesia upheld the jury's 1988 decision in post-trial motions and assessed additional fines in the nationality discrimination case Friday. Quasar, based in suburban Elk Grove Village, handles sales and distribution of consumer electronics and employees about 50 people. The company is a division of the Japanese-owned Matsushita Electric Corp. of America.

DOC.HEAD: Investor Backs Out of Biggest Philippine Project Since Aquino Took Over
DOC.TEXT: A major Taiwanese investor has withdrawn from a $500 million petrochemical project that would have been the largest single foreign investment in the Philippines since President Corazon Aquino took office in 1986. The group said it pulled out of the project, which has been mired in political controversy, because of political unrest in the island nation. Butch Pajarillo, spokesman of the Department of Trade and Industry, said Wednesday that the investor, USI Far East, has written Trade Secretary Jose Concepcion notifying him of the firm's pullout. Concepcion's office received word of the pullout in a letter from Anthony Chong, chairman of the Taiwanese firm, on Monday. In Taipei, USI Far East spokesman Lin Yun-teng confirmed the company has decided to withdraw. ``We regret that we have to pull out the investment because of political reasons. The petrochemical project is good for the industry and the Philippine people,'' Lin said. He said fighting between different political factions in the Philippines led to the decision. Concepcion strongly supported the project, saying it was crucial in building a petrochemical industry in a country struggling to cope with energy shortages. But critics charged Concepcion and others had been too generous in its financing arrangements. The project became a major political controversy, underscoring differences on investment policy within the Aquino government. Supporters of the project said opposition would discourage foreign investment in the Philippines, whose economy is hobbled by a $28 billion foreign debt, hard currency shortages and mounting inflation.
